subject: BEST
title: Foundations in Bioproducts and the Bioeconomy
description: Introduction to the production, use, and attributes of renewable products and energy derived from biobased materials. Sustainability paradigms related to the bioeconomy; potential environmental and socio-political impacts associated with biobased technologies and transitions to sustainable economies. [3-0-0]

subject: BEST
title: Plants, Carbon, and Environment
description: Introduction to plant biology, with special emphasis on growth and development, highlighting the biological mechanisms of radiation energy capture, and water and nutrient acquisition in the production of plant biomass. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 112 and BIOL _V 121
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 112 and BIOL _V 121

subject: BEST
title: Alternative Energy Systems
description: Introduction to safe, clean, and sustainable supplies of energy. Economic, social, environmental, and policy issues raised by current systems of energy use and production are examined. [3-0-0]

subject: BEST
title: Ecology of Managed Ecosystems
description: Provides a foundation in managed ecosystems and community ecology. Includes material on forest ecology and agricultural ecosystems as managed environments. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: BEST 201 and one of BIOL 112, BIOL 121.
prerequisite_raw: BEST 201 and one of BIOL 112, BIOL 121.

subject: BEST
title: Biobased Polymers and Bioproducts
description: Study of occurrence, synthesis, derivatization, physical properties, processing, and application of major bio-based polymers from biomass. Manufacturing processes and uses of biobased products are examined. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CHEM 203, CHEM 233.
prerequisite_raw: One of CHEM 203, CHEM 233.

subject: BEST
title: Bioenergy
description: Interdisciplinary approach to bioenergy. The technology of the systems involved, the social and environmental implications of biomass use for energy systems. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BEST 202.
prerequisite_raw: BEST 202.

subject: BEST
title: Laboratory in Bioeconomy Technology (I)
description: Laboratory modules for bioeconomy technologies; plant breeding, deconstruction, fermentation, and applied biotechnology. [1-3-0] Prerequisite: BEST 200 and BEST 201 .
prerequisite_raw: BEST 200 and BEST 201 .

subject: BEST
title: Applied Biotechnology for Bioproducts
description: Use of microbiology and enzymology for processing and enhancing value of forest and agro-based bioproducts; saccharification of biomass, fermentation, and product upgrading with biocatalysts. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BEST 300.
prerequisite_raw: BEST 300.

subject: BEST
title: Laboratory in Bioeconomy Technology (II)
description: Laboratory modules for bioeconomy technologies; bioenergy and bioproducts. [1-3-0] Prerequisite: BEST 300 and BEST 302.
prerequisite_raw: BEST 300 and BEST 302.

subject: BEST
title: Land Use Management and Planning
description: Global overview of land use management and planning, with a focus on principles and practice. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: BEST 203.
prerequisite_raw: BEST 203.

subject: BEST
title: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Forest Bioeconomy Sciences and Technology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BEST
title: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Forest Bioeconomy Sciences and Technology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BEST
title: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Forest Bioeconomy Sciences and Technology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BEST
title: Biomimicry and Biocomposites
description: Introduction to principles of self-assembly, hierarchical structures, biocomposites, and unique adaptive structures. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BEST 300.
prerequisite_raw: BEST 300.

subject: BEST
title: Carbon and Energy Economics
description: Understanding key issues for carbon management, protocols for carbon accounting and methodologies for emissions inventories and carbon costing. Economics and business response to climate change are examined. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of ECON 101, FRST 101.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON 101, FRST 101.

subject: BEST
title: Industrial Ecology
description: Concepts in sustainability around technology and material use; relevance of biological ecology to industrial ecology; life cycle analysis: components and applications; and approaches to design. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: BEST 200.
prerequisite_raw: BEST 200.

subject: BEST
title: Integrated Strategies for Bioproduct Innovation
description: Project-based course on development of bioeconomy products; demonstration of out-of-box thinking, service learning and teamwork. Restricted to students in the Forest Bioeconomy Sciences and Technology program. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: Fourth year standing in Forest Bioeconomy Sciences and Technology.
prerequisite_raw: Fourth year standing in Forest Bioeconomy Sciences and Technology.

subject: BEST
title: Synthetic Biology for Bioproducts and Bioeconomy
description: Principles of synthetic biology, DesignBuild-Test-Learn (DBTL) cycle for bioproduct development, enzyme engineering, strain engineering for bioproducts, ethical framework, and social implications [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BEST 302 and BEST 303
prerequisite_raw: BEST 302 and BEST 303

subject: BEST
title: Co-operative Work Placement
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Forest Bioeconomy Sciences and Technology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BEST
title: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Forest Bioeconomy Sciences and Technology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BEST
title: Co-operative Work Placement V
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Forest Bioeconomy Sciences and Technology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BEST
title: Advanced Life Cycle Assessment
description: Concepts and applications of Life Cycle Assessment (LCA), LCA methodologies, international standards and frameworks. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: Introductory Medical Biochemistry
description: Introduction to proteins and enzymes, carbohydrate metabolism, and glucose homeostasis. The course emphasis is on human biochemistry and it is designed for students going into health science fields. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203 or BIOL 201. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233.
prerequisite_raw: One of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233.
exclusion_raw: Introduction to proteins and enzymes, carbohydrate metabolism, and glucose homeostasis. The course emphasis is on human biochemistry and it is designed for students going into health science fields. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203 or BIOL 201. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233.

subject: BIOC
title: Fundamentals of Biochemistry
description: Amino acids and proteins. Enzymes and enzymology. Human metabolic pathways. Structure, function and metabolism of carbohydrates including glycogen storage and gluconeogenesis. Restricted to students in Biochemistry specializations. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203 or BIOL 201. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223. Corequisite: CHEM 213.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223. Corequisite: CHEM 213.
corequisite_raw: CHEM 213.
exclusion_raw: Amino acids and proteins. Enzymes and enzymology. Human metabolic pathways. Structure, function and metabolism of carbohydrates including glycogen storage and gluconeogenesis. Restricted to students in Biochemistry specializations. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203 or BIOL 201. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223. Corequisite: CHEM 213.

subject: BIOC
title: Biochemistry Laboratory
description: Techniques by which the chemical and physical properties of fundamental components of the cell are studied. [0-3-1] Corequisite: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303.
corequisite_raw: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303.

subject: BIOC
title: General Biochemistry
description: Metabolic reactions of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry of replication, transcription and translation. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 302 or BIOC 303. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233. Equivalency: BIOC 303
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233. Equivalency: BIOC 303
exclusion_raw: Metabolic reactions of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry of replication, transcription and translation. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 302 or BIOC 303. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233. Equivalency: BIOC 303

subject: BIOC
title: Molecular Biochemistry
description: Structure, function and metabolism of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, translation and gene regulation. For students in Biochemistry and Honours programs in other life sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 302 or BIOC 303. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOC 203, BIOC 202, BIOL 201 and either (a) CHEM 213 or (b) CHEM 233.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOC 203, BIOC 202, BIOL 201 and either (a) CHEM 213 or (b) CHEM 233.
exclusion_raw: Structure, function and metabolism of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, translation and gene regulation. For students in Biochemistry and Honours programs in other life sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 302 or BIOC 303. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOC 203, BIOC 202, BIOL 201 and either (a) CHEM 213 or (b) CHEM 233.

subject: BIOC
title: Contemporary Biochemical Research
description: Exploration of the breadth and importance of biochemical research to present day challenges in medicine and biotechnology. Detailed experimental research case studies of novel biochemical methods used to address pressing and ongoing biochemical issues. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: CHEM 213. Corequisite: BIOC 303.
prerequisite_raw: CHEM 213. Corequisite: BIOC 303.
corequisite_raw: BIOC 303.

subject: BIOC
title: Quantitative Methods in Biochemistry
description: Quantitative and computational methods of biological information transfer. Methods; data analysis approaches and theories involved in bioinformatics; computational biology and high-throughput data. [3-0-0] Prerequisites: a) BIOC 203 and a corequisite of BIOC 303 or b) One of BIOC 202 or BIOL 201 with a grade of 76% or higher and a corequisite of BIOC 302.

subject: BIOC
title: Internship Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic laboratory for three or four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology. Prerequisite: Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry major or honours program is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry major or honours program is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: Internship Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology. Prerequisite: BIOC398 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: BIOC398 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: Proteins: Structure and Function
description: Structural components of proteins, classification by primary, secondary and tertiary structure, protein chemistry and purification, peptide and protein synthesis by chemical means and three-dimensional structure determination using X-ray diffraction and NMR. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.

subject: BIOC
title: Enzymology
description: Kinetic analysis, catalytic mechanisms, transition state stabilization and regulation of activity, strategies for active site characterization and case studies of well-documented enzyme systems. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 403, CHEM 413 or CHEM 569. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOC402 A minimum standing of 65% is recommended.
prerequisite_raw: BIOC402 A minimum standing of 65% is recommended.
exclusion_raw: Kinetic analysis, catalytic mechanisms, transition state stabilization and regulation of activity, strategies for active site characterization and case studies of well-documented enzyme systems. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 403, CHEM 413 or CHEM 569. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOC402 A minimum standing of 65% is recommended.

subject: BIOC
title: Biochemical Methods
description: Theory and application of classical and emerging technologies in biochemical research. Emphasis on using primary literature and oral presentation skills. Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry or others with permission of the instructor. [1-0; 2-0]

subject: BIOC
title: Nucleic Acids-Structure and Function
description: Chemical, physical and biological properties of nucleic acids and their role in replication, transcription, translation and regulation of expression of genetic material. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 410 or BIOC 510. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOC 303, BIOL 335 or (b) BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of BIOC 303, BIOL 335 or (b) BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.
exclusion_raw: Chemical, physical and biological properties of nucleic acids and their role in replication, transcription, translation and regulation of expression of genetic material. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 410 or BIOC 510. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOC 303, BIOL 335 or (b) BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.

subject: BIOC
title: Advanced Biochemical Techniques
description: Multi-week experiments in areas of contemporary biochemistry research using classical and modern techniques. Emphasis on experimental design, technique, critical analysis of data, and scientific communication skills. Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry and others with permission of the instructor. [0-6-0] Corequisite: One of BIOC 404, FSCT 480.
corequisite_raw: One of BIOC 404, FSCT 480.

subject: BIOC
title: Recombinant DNA Techniques
description: Multi-week experiments involving contemporary nucleic acid research, cloning and recombinant protein engineering. Emphasis is on experimental design, critical analysis of data and scientific communication skills. Restricted to Major students in Biochemistry. [0-6-0] Prerequisite: All of BIOC 301, BIOC 410.
prerequisite_raw: All of BIOC 301, BIOC 410.

subject: BIOC
title: Advanced Topics in Protein Biochemistry
description: Advanced topics in protein structure and function. [3-0-0] Prerequisites: BIOC 402

subject: BIOC
title: Concepts in Molecular Biology
description: Developing areas of molecular biology, focusing on experimental design and data analysis. Signal transduction, the use of model eukaryotes, and the regulation of gene expression. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

subject: BIOC
title: Membrane Biochemistry
description: Biochemistry of membranes and membrane proteins, membrane fusion, electrical signaling, and the involvement of membrane proteins in disease and drug development. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

subject: BIOC
title: Advanced Techniques in Biochemistry
description: Theoretical basis and practical applications of a selection of advanced techniques currently used in biochemical research. Topics will vary. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

subject: BIOC
title: Biochemistry & Society: Current Issues
description: Biochemical basis of select global challenges. Critical evaluation of primary literature to form evidence-based opinions and communicating biochemistry as it relates to several controversial societal issues. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303.

subject: BIOC
title: Student Directed Seminars
description: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. Not given every year. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing. Corequisite: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing. Corequisite: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303.
corequisite_raw: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303.

subject: BIOC
title: Internship Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology. Prerequisite: BIOC399 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: BIOC399 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: Internship Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology. Prerequisite: BIOC498 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: BIOC498 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: Membrane Structure and Function
description: The physical properties and functional roles of lipids in membranes, liposomes, membrane permiability; membrane function; structure, biosynthesis and cell sorting of membrane proteins; and the structure-function relationships of channels, transporters and receptors. Given in alternate years. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: Nucleic Acids: Structure and Function
description: Structure and function of nucleic acids and their role in replication, transcription, translation and expression of genetic information. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 410 or BIOC 510. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Structure and function of nucleic acids and their role in replication, transcription, translation and expression of genetic information. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 410 or BIOC 510. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: Biochemical Aspects of Cellular Regulation
description: A lecture and discussion course on the molecular basis of cellular regulation with special emphasis on mammalian cells. Mechanisms involved in the responses of cells to adrenergic, steroid and peptide hormones and growth factors. Regulation of the concentration and specific activity of key enzymes, transport systems and structural proteins. Given in alternate years. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: Advanced Topics in Protein Chemistry
description: Topics will include contemporary theoretical and experimental investigation of protein structure-function relationships. Topics will vary. Given in alternate years. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: Seminar in Biochemistry
description: Attendance is required of all graduate students in Biochemistry. Normally students will make a presentation once per year on a topic approved by their research advisor or committee or on the results of their research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: M.Sc. Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: Advanced Topics in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
description: Discussions based on topics in the current literature. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOC
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOF
title: Special Topics in Bioinformatics
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOF
title: Problem-Based Learning In Bioinformatics
description: Develops the student's ability to exchange ideas in small groups focused on real but simplified problems in bioinformatics. Problems are carefully selected to cover all aspects of Bioinformatics research. Required of students in the Bioinformatics graduate program. Students not registered in the Bioinformatics graduate program must get permission to register in this course. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOF
title: M.Sc. Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOF
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Modern Biology
description: Concepts fundamental to biological issues, such as the genetic basis of biological variation, evolution, infectious diseases, causes of cancer, population growth, and human effects on ecosystems. Not open to students who have credit for Biology 12 (including AP, IB). [3-0-0]

subject: BIOL
title: Biology of the Cell
description: The principles of cellular and molecular biology using bacterial and eukaryotic examples. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.
prerequisite_raw: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

subject: BIOL
title: Genetics, Evolution and Ecology
description: Principles of storage and transmission of genetic variation; origin and evolution of species and their ecological interactions. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 121 or BIOL 344. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.
exclusion_raw: Principles of storage and transmission of genetic variation; origin and evolution of species and their ecological interactions. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 121 or BIOL 344. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

subject: BIOL
title: Laboratory Investigations in Life Science
description: Guided experimental investigations of biological questions. [1-2-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

subject: BIOL
title: Human Biology: Anatomy and Physiology
description: The principles of biology with particular reference to the human body (anatomy and physiology). Laboratories include selected experiments on organ physiology and general anatomy. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-3-0; 3-3-0] Prerequisite: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Human Biology: Physiology and Introductory Anatomy
description: The principles of biology with particular reference to the human body (anatomy and physiology). (physiology and introductory anatomy). Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-0-0; 3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.
prerequisite_raw: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

subject: BIOL
title: Thinking Like a Life Scientist
description: Science as a process, the skills of scientists, and the exploration of a current biological challenge with a practicing UBC scientist. [2-0-1] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

subject: BIOL
title: Fundamentals of Cell Biology
description: Structure and function of plant and animal cells; membrane models, cytoplasmic organelles, biological information from gene to protein, the endomembrane system, secretion, intracellular digestion, endocytosis, transport processes, cytoskeleton and cell motility. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 112 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 130; or (b) SCIE 001. or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year BIOL and 6 credits of first-year CHEM or (d) one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121 and a corequisite of one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) BIOL 112 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 130; or (b) SCIE 001. or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year BIOL and 6 credits of first-year CHEM or (d) one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121 and a corequisite of one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223.

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Biochemistry
description: Biological molecules, protein structure and enzyme action, energy transfer, central metabolic pathways and their regulation. Examples drawn from plants, animals and microorganisms. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, or BIOC 203. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 233, CHEM 260. ; or BIOL 200 and a corequisite of CHEM 213; or a corequisite of either CHEM 313 or CHEM 330.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 233, CHEM 260. ; or BIOL 200 and a corequisite of CHEM 213; or a corequisite of either CHEM 313 or CHEM 330.
exclusion_raw: Biological molecules, protein structure and enzyme action, energy transfer, central metabolic pathways and their regulation. Examples drawn from plants, animals and microorganisms. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, or BIOC 203. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 233, CHEM 260. ; or BIOL 200 and a corequisite of CHEM 213; or a corequisite of either CHEM 313 or CHEM 330.

subject: BIOL
title: Eukaryotic Microbiology
description: Introduction to the origin and diversity of protists (protozoa and algae) at both cellular and genomic levels, including the role of endosymbiosis in evolution. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. Or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. Or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

subject: BIOL
title: Vertebrate Structure and Function
description: Introduction to the vertebrate phyla and their evolution; a comparative study of vertebrate structure and function, with dissection of representative forms. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. Or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. Or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

subject: BIOL
title: Comparative Invertebrate Zoology
description: An introduction to the unity, diversity and evolutionary history of invertebrates. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. Or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. Or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

subject: BIOL
title: Biodiversity of Algae, Fungi and Bryophytes
description: Diversity, ecology, cell biology and evolutionary origins of multicellular eukaryotes, illustrated through mosses and liverworts; fungi and slime molds; and fresh water and marine algae. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. Or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. Or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

subject: BIOL
title: Vascular Plants
description: A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function and ecology. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology. Equivalency: APBI 210
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology. Equivalency: APBI 210

subject: BIOL
title: Fundamentals of Ecology
description: Dynamics of plant and animal populations, structure of ecological communities and functioning of ecosystems. Interpretation of research results and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [3-3*-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001 or 8 transfer credits of first-year BIOL.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001 or 8 transfer credits of first-year BIOL.

subject: BIOL
title: Genetics for Life
description: How genetic differences determine individual characteristics, and how they are inherited, analyzed, and modified. Emphasis on genetic diversity, human ancestry, personal genomics, and cancer genetics. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001. ; or (c) a corequisite of one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001. ; or (c) a corequisite of one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121.

subject: BIOL
title: Fundamentals of Genetics
description: Genotype and phenotype, mechanisms of inheritance, genetic analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [3-0-2] Prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001 ; (c) a corequisite of one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121; or (d) 8 transfer credits of first-year BIOL.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001 ; (c) a corequisite of one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121; or (d) 8 transfer credits of first-year BIOL.

subject: BIOL
title: Fundamentals of Physiology
description: Principles of cellular and organismal physiology illustrated with examples from unicellular organisms, plants and animals, focusing on transport processes, water balance, nutrient acquisition and communication. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001. or (c) 8 transfer credits of 1st year BIOL and 6 credits of 1st year chemistry.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001. or (c) 8 transfer credits of 1st year BIOL and 6 credits of 1st year chemistry.

subject: BIOL
title: Fundamentals of Biostatistics
description: Statistical procedures for biological research; estimation, hypothesis testing, goodness of fit, analysis of variance and regression; use of computers for statistical analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

subject: BIOL
title: Biomathematics
description: Introduction to uses of mathematics in the biological sciences; experimental design and modelling of biological processes. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . Recommended co-requisites: one of BIOL 300, STAT 200. [3-0-2]

subject: BIOL
title: Biodiversity, Human & Planetary Health
description: Effects of biodiversity on human health, from human microbiome to ecosystem. Strategies for protecting, restoring and managing for biodiversity, human and planetary health. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 121, GEOS 207, SCIE 001 and third-year class standing.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 121, GEOS 207, SCIE 001 and third-year class standing.

subject: BIOL
title: Green Planet: Biology and History of Plants that Changed Civilizations
description: Biological, cultural, and societal significance of staple crops selected as foods, medicines or raw materials by different societies, and their pivotal role in the rise and fall of past and present civilizations. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: 3rd-year class standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: 3rd-year class standing or higher.

subject: BIOL
title: Advanced Ecology
description: Ecology of populations, communities and ecosystems. Tests of ecological theory with experiments and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [3-3*-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 230.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 230.

subject: BIOL
title: Natural History Collections and Biodiversity Science
description: An introduction to biodiversity and specimen-based science, including theory and best practices for creating, curating and preserving natural history collections, working ethically with collections, and the historical, contemporary and future role of these collections to science and society. [2-3-0] Pre-requisites: A minimum of 3rd-year class standing or higher.

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Animal Behaviour
description: Animal behavior from an ecological and evolutionary perspective; the methods used to study behaviour and test its adaptive significance. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001; and 3rd-year class standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001; and 3rd-year class standing or higher.

subject: BIOL
title: Experimental Methods in Animal Behaviour
description: Designing, conducting, and analyzing studies of animal behaviour, with an emphasis on field-based methods. Students conduct capstone research projects. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [1-4-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 300, STAT 200. Corequisite: BIOL 310.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 300, STAT 200. Corequisite: BIOL 310.
corequisite_raw: BIOL 310.

subject: BIOL
title: Elements of Biodiversity
description: The units of biodiversity, from genes to ecosystems, how they are structured in space, and their importance to human well-being and ecosystem health. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APBI 260, BIOL 230, FRST 201, GEOB 207, GEOS 207. Equivalency: CONS 314
prerequisite_raw: One of APBI 260, BIOL 230, FRST 201, GEOB 207, GEOS 207. Equivalency: CONS 314

subject: BIOL
title: Weed Science
description: Importance, identification, dissemination and biology of weeds; preventative, cultural, biological and chemical methods of control. [3-2-0] Equivalency: APBI328

subject: BIOL
title: Survey of Algae
description: A survey of the algae, considering their morphology, life history, classification, and ecology. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.

subject: BIOL
title: Morphology and Evolution of Bryophytes
description: A study of evolution, taxonomy and morphology of mosses, liverworts and hornworts with emphasis on living plants in their environment. [2-4-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.

subject: BIOL
title: Structure and Evolution of Ferns and Fern-allies
description: Anatomy, morphology and relationships of the ferns and fern-allies, with assessment of both fossil and extant taxa. [2-4-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.

subject: BIOL
title: Structure and Reproduction of Fungi
description: The evolutionary diversity of the fungi as shown by their morphology and reproductive biology. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Seed Plant Taxonomy
description: Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001. Equivalency: APBI_V 324
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001. Equivalency: APBI_V 324

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Animal Mechanics and Locomotion
description: Comparative aspects of the functional design of skeletal systems and the mechanics of swimming, flying and terrestrial locomotion, with particular reference to the vertebrates. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.

subject: BIOL
title: Experimental Biology of Invertebrates
description: Behaviour and ecology of invertebrates as revealed by hands-on experiments in the laboratory and field. Marine emphasis. [1-4-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 205. Corequisite: Either (a) STAT 200 or (b) BIOL 300.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 205. Corequisite: Either (a) STAT 200 or (b) BIOL 300.
corequisite_raw: Either (a) STAT 200 or (b) BIOL 300.

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Entomology
description: A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology, life-histories and insect-plant relations. Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001. Equivalency: APBI_V 327
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001. Equivalency: APBI_V 327

subject: BIOL
title: Ecology and Evolution of Parasites
description: Morphology, life histories, ecology and evolution of parasites (and infectious agents more broadly) infecting humans and animals. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001

subject: BIOL
title: Cell Receptor Signaling, Communication and Regulation
description: How cells react to external signals, and how these responses are regulated. Experimental approaches and common themes will be examined using a variety of cell receptors as models. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 200. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 200. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Developmental Biology (Lecture)
description: Animal development and its underlying causal principles; introductory embryology. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 201 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) BIOL 201 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.

subject: BIOL
title: Developmental Biology
description: Animal development and its underlying causal principles; introductory embryology. [3-5-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 201 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) BIOL 201 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.

subject: BIOL
title: Protistology
description: Cell biology, ecology, and evolution of protists; origins of multicellularity; the role of protists in micropaleontology, parasitology, and oceanography. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 200
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 200

subject: BIOL
title: Molecular Genetics
description: Isolation and identification of genes, analysis of gene structure; gene expression and its regulation in prokaryotes and in eukaryotes; developmental genetics. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234, MICB 322, FRST 302.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234, MICB 322, FRST 302.

subject: BIOL
title: Fundamentals of Evolutionary Biology
description: Natural selection; population genetics, quantitative genetics and systematics; classical and molecular approaches to the study of evolution. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.

subject: BIOL
title: Introductory Genetics Laboratory
description: A laboratory course demonstrating the fundamental principles of inheritance: Mendel's Laws, sex-linkage, mapping, mutagenesis, chromosome structure, developmental biology, biochemical and population genetics. [1-4-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 200. Corequisite: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 200. Corequisite: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.
corequisite_raw: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.

subject: BIOL
title: Introduction to Genomics
description: An introduction to genome biology and applications of genomics. [3-0-1.5] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 234, BIOL 233, FRST 302.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 234, BIOL 233, FRST 302.

subject: BIOL
title: Introductory Cell Biology Laboratory
description: Designing and conducting cell biology experiments using unicellular eukaryotes or prokaryotes with emphasis on techniques in microscopy and cell biology. [1-6-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 200 and 3rd-year class standing or higher in Science and one of (a) BIOL_V 180 (or BIOL_V 140), or (b) SCIE_V 001, or (c) 3rd-year class standing in Combined Honours Biophysics.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 200 and 3rd-year class standing or higher in Science and one of (a) BIOL_V 180 (or BIOL_V 140), or (b) SCIE_V 001, or (c) 3rd-year class standing in Combined Honours Biophysics.

subject: BIOL
title: Introductory Molecular Biology Laboratory
description: Designing and conducting molecular biology experiments using bioinformatics recombinant DNA techniques. [1-5-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 200 and 3rd-year class standing or higher in Science.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 200 and 3rd-year class standing or higher in Science.

subject: BIOL
title: Integrative Biology Laboratory
description: Field-based and laboratory-based investigation of organisms. [1-3-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing or higher in Combined Major in Science, and one of (a) BIOL 121 and BIOL 180 (or BIOL 140), or (b) SCIE 001, or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing or higher in Combined Major in Science, and one of (a) BIOL 121 and BIOL 180 (or BIOL 140), or (b) SCIE 001, or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

subject: BIOL
title: Plants and Peoples
description: The interactions of plants and human societies: the role of people in the origin, evolution and dispersal of food, drug and economic plants, and the influences of plants on human societies. Suitable for upper-level Arts students. [2-2-1]

subject: BIOL
title: Human Heredity and Evolution
description: Relates genetic and evolutionary concepts to humans. Primarily for upper-level students in the Faculty of Arts. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 121 or BIOL 344. Not open to students in the Life Sciences. [3-0-2]
exclusion_raw: Relates genetic and evolutionary concepts to humans. Primarily for upper-level students in the Faculty of Arts. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 121 or BIOL 344. Not open to students in the Life Sciences. [3-0-2]

subject: BIOL
title: Human Ecology
description: Basics of ecology are introduced, focussing on observations of the natural world. Assignments, including a group project, consider connections between research, awareness and practical uses of ecology. Not for credit in the Life Sciences. [3-0-2]

subject: BIOL
title: Microbes and Society
description: An elementary course in molecular biology primarily for Arts students. The historical development of recent discoveries in molecular biology with emphasis on bacteria and viruses and their interaction with humans. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) Not for credit in Life Sciences. [3-0-0]

subject: BIOL
title: Principles and Methodology in Biological Research
description: Contemporary research in the Botany and Zoology Departments; history and methodology of scientific discovery; seminars on current problems. Restricted to Honours students in Biology. Not to be taken concurrently with BIOL 449. [2-3-0]

subject: BIOL
title: Biology of Cannabis
description: Biological aspects of cannabis, including structure and function, photosynthesis, plant growth, specialized metabolites, neuroscience and the human endocannabinoid system, and applications for human use in medicine, consumer products and textiles. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: 3rd-year class standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: 3rd-year class standing or higher.

subject: BIOL
title: Darwinian Medicine
description: Using the Darwinian theory of natural selection to explore explanations of infectious diseases, allergies, cancer, mental illness, and other human diseases. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/faculty-sc… [2-0-2] Prerequisite: Third-year standing. Equivalency: ISCI 350
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing. Equivalency: ISCI 350

subject: BIOL
title: Plant Physiology I
description: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. Restricted to Majors and Honours students in Biology. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 130; or (b) SCIE 001. CHEM 233 is recommended. Equivalency: APBI351, FRST311
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 130; or (b) SCIE 001. CHEM 233 is recommended. Equivalency: APBI351, FRST311

subject: BIOL
title: Plant Physiology II: Plant Development
description: Introduction to the processes involved in growth and development: cell division, tissue culture, meristems, differentiation, and the action of major growth regulators, and photomorphogenesis. Emphasis on experimental approaches. [2-3-1] Prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234; or (b) FRST 302. CHEM 233 is recommended.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234; or (b) FRST 302. CHEM 233 is recommended.

subject: BIOL
title: Neural and Muscular Physiology
description: Excitable membranes, neural signaling and transmission; transduction and coding of sensory information; muscle contraction. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 200.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 200.

subject: BIOL
title: Cellular Dynamics
description: The cytoskeleton, cell dynamics, and regulation of cellular activities. Preference will be given to Majors or Honours students in Biology and Combined Honours Biophysics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of APBI 312, APBI 351, BIOL 260, BIOL 351, BIOL 352, BIOL 361, FRST 311.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 200 and one of APBI 312, APBI 351, BIOL 260, BIOL 351, BIOL 352, BIOL 361, FRST 311.

subject: BIOL
title: Laboratory in Animal Physiology
description: Experimental studies in animal physiology. Restricted to Majors and Honours students in Biology, Nutritional Sciences and Combined Honours Biophysics. Recommended corequisites: one of BIOL_V 361, BIOL_V 370, BIOL_V 371. [1-3-1] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 204 or BIOL_V 260.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 204 or BIOL_V 260.

subject: BIOL
title: Comparative Cardiovascular, Respiratory and Osmoregulatory Physiology
description: Cardiovascular, respiratory, and osmoregulatory physiology. Preference will be given to students who are in Biology, Nutritional Sciences, and Combined Honours Biophysics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361. Equivalency: APBI 311
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361. Equivalency: APBI 311

subject: BIOL
title: Principles of Muscle Physiology and Energetics
description: Introduction to the structure and function of the muscular system, metabolism and energetics from a comparative perspective across vertebrates and invertebrates. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203.

subject: BIOL
title: Principles of Neurobiology I
description: Introduction to the structure and function of the nervous system, excitable membranes, and synaptic signaling using representative vertebrate and invertebrate species. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 260, NSCI 200, PSYC 270, PSYC 271, PSYC 304, CAPS 301.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 260, NSCI 200, PSYC 270, PSYC 271, PSYC 304, CAPS 301.

subject: BIOL
title: Principles of Neurobiology II
description: Examination of the neural systems underlying sensation, action, and complex behaviours using representative vertebrate and invertebrate species. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 371.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 371.

subject: BIOL
title: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Work experience in an industrial setting, taken during Winter Session (Term 2) of third-year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third-year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology. Prerequisite: BIOL_V 398 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 398 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Theory of Evolutionary Dynamics
description: Evolution as a dynamical system based on ecological interactions. Adaptive dynamics and evolutionary game theory. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 401 or BIOL 560. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 301 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 301 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Evolution as a dynamical system based on ecological interactions. Adaptive dynamics and evolutionary game theory. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 401 or BIOL 560. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 301 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Aquatic Ecology
description: Theoretical and applied limnology; ecology of inland water organisms in relation to physical, chemical and biological factors. One weekend field trip required. [2-4-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.

subject: BIOL
title: Microbial Ecology
description: Theoretical and applied ecology of microbes. Focus on microbial symbionts of animals, plants and seaweeds. Research project development through critical analysis of microbial ecological literature and computational analysis of ecological data. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL_V 121, SCIE_V 001, BIOL_V 230 and one of BIOL_V 300, FRST_V 231, STAT_V 200. 4th-year class standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL_V 121, SCIE_V 001, BIOL_V 230 and one of BIOL_V 300, FRST_V 231, STAT_V 200. 4th-year class standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Ecological Methodology
description: Design, execution, and analysis of ecological surveys and experiments. Practical field methods for estimating population metrics and describing community structure. Computer techniques for the statistical analysis of ecological data. [2-4-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.

subject: BIOL
title: Plant Ecology I
description: Plant community ecology including a consideration of the major approaches to sampling, analyzing and interpreting vegetation patterns. Instruction given in field work and computer analysis of field data. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 230. BIOL 324 is recommended.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 230. BIOL 324 is recommended.

subject: BIOL
title: Principles of Applied Ecology
description: Principles of animal and community ecology applicable to the management of animal resources; application of statistical and computer techniques for measuring, analyzing, modelling, and simulating resource systems; problems of multiple resource use. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 300
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 300

subject: BIOL
title: Field Course in Ecology
description: A two-week intensive course in field methods used in ecology. Fieldwork for this course is normally in the summer. A fee will be assessed for living and traveling expenses. Pre-registration required. Prerequisite: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200. BIOL 306 is recommended.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200. BIOL 306 is recommended.

subject: BIOL
title: Current Topics in Animal Behaviour
description: Lectures and seminar discussions on selected topics in animal behaviour. [2-0-2] Prerequisite: BIOL 310
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 310

subject: BIOL
title: Insect Ecology
description: Behavioural, population and community ecology of insects. Interactions between insects and plants and the application of the principles of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 205, BIOL 327, APBI 327. Equivalency: APBI 427
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 205, BIOL 327, APBI 327. Equivalency: APBI 427

subject: BIOL
title: Plant Biogeography
description: Description and interpretation of present and past floristic vegetational patterns; integration of evolutionary, ecological, and plant biogeographical concepts. Terrestrial and aquatic plants are considered. Restricted to students of third and fourth years. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.

subject: BIOL
title: Zoogeography
description: The role of physical, ecological, and evolutionary processes in determining the geographic distribution of animals including humans, with implications for speciation and conservation. Restricted to students in third and fourth year. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.

subject: BIOL
title: Evolutionary Processes in Plants
description: Experimental and comparative analysis of evolutionary processes, speciation, and phylogenetic patterns in plants. [2-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 336.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 336.

subject: BIOL
title: Principles of Conservation Biology
description: Ecological basis of conserving biological diversity and ecosystem services; application of ecological theory to global and local conservation problems in the context of economic, legal, political, and social perspectives. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [2-0-2] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 230, FRST 201.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 230, FRST 201.

subject: BIOL
title: Phylogenetic Biology
description: Biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective. The evolutionary (phylogenetic) tree of genetic descent that links all organisms: its reconstruction, interpretation, and implications for fields from ecology to molecular biology. [2-0-2] Prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234. BIOL 336 is recommended
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234. BIOL 336 is recommended

subject: BIOL
title: Evolutionary Ecology
description: Ecological adaptation and evolutionary processes in contemporary populations; natural selection, variation, optimization, foraging theory, coevolution, arms races; life history theory, evolution of sex, sexual selection, evolution in managed populations. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 336 and BIOL 230.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 336 and BIOL 230.

subject: BIOL
title: Ocean Conservation and Sustainability
description: An interdisciplinary conservation course with a solutions-oriented approach to marine issues, drawing from natural sciences, social sciences, business, law, and communication. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Fourth-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Plant-Microbe Interactions
description: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOL 201, BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 260. Equivalency: APBI 426
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 200 and one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOL 201, BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 260. Equivalency: APBI 426

subject: BIOL
title: Plant Stress Ecophysiology
description: Molecular mechanisms of plant responses to extreme environments. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 351. BIOL 406 or 407 are recommended.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 351. BIOL 406 or 407 are recommended.

subject: BIOL
title: Tropical Ecology and Conservation
description: Ecology, function, history and conservation of tropical systems. Focus on ecological and evolutionary principles using tropical landscapes as a geographic template. Assessment of factors that make tropical systems vulnerable to degradation. Research project development using analysis of tropical ecology literature. [2-0-2] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001 and one of BIOL_V 230, FRST_V 201, GEOS_V 207, GEOB_V 207.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001 and one of BIOL_V 230, FRST_V 201, GEOS_V 207, GEOB_V 207.

subject: BIOL
title: Biomechanics
description: An analytical approach to the study of skeletal mechanics and animal locomotion. Selected topics in the structure and properties of biological materials, the functional design of skeletons for locomotion, and the fluid mechanics of swimming and flight. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 325
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 325

subject: BIOL
title: Mammalogy
description: Natural history, behavioral ecology and conservation of terrestrial mammals. The laboratory includes classification, life histories, and ecology, with particular attention to species from British Columbia. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 204
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 204

subject: BIOL
title: Ornithology and Herpetology
description: Ecology, evolution, behavior, and conservation of birds, amphibians, and reptiles. Laboratories and field projects will focus on identification, systematics, and natural history, with particular attention to species from British Columbia. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 121 or SCIE_V 001.

subject: BIOL
title: Evolutionary Morphology of Marine Invertebrates
description: Comparative analysis of marine invertebrate morphology from a macroevolutionary perspective. Origin and evolution of reoccurring adaptations in meiofaunal, benthic, pelagic, and deep-sea invertebrates, including their larval stages. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 205 and 3rd-year class standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 205 and 3rd-year class standing or higher.

subject: BIOL
title: Genome Evolution
description: Integration of molecular genetics and genomics with evolutionary biology. Emphasis on the evolutionary dynamics of genomes and the evolutionary implications of recent discoveries in molecular genetics and genomics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 335, BIOL 336, BIOL 338.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 335, BIOL 336, BIOL 338.

subject: BIOL
title: Evolutionary Cell Biology
description: Ultrastructure, biogenesis, and evolution of eukaryotic cells and cell organelles, including their macromolecular basis. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL200 And fourth-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL200 And fourth-year standing.

subject: BIOL
title: Research Strategies and Techniques in Cell Biology
description: Major physiological mechanisms that define eukaryotic cells, explored through student visits to UBC research laboratories and discussion of recent scientific literature, with emphasis on the techniques and strategies that enable researchers to test hypotheses and advance new concepts. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL_V 200 and one of BIOL_V 233, BIOL_V 234 and 4th-year class standing.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 200 and one of BIOL_V 233, BIOL_V 234 and 4th-year class standing.

subject: BIOL
title: Plant Genetics
description: Emphasis on molecular aspects. Systems and techniques for genetic analysis in plants; isolation and regulation of plant genes; genetic dissection of plant-specific processes; transposable elements; gene transfer in plants; cytoplasmic inheritance; genetic engineering. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 335
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 335

subject: BIOL
title: Population Genetics
description: Theoretical and experimental aspects of population and quantitative genetics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-0-2] Prerequisite: BIOL 336 and either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234; or (b) FRST 302.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 336 and either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234; or (b) FRST 302.

subject: BIOL
title: Integrated Functional Genomics
description: Global transcript, protein, and metabolite profiling technologies and their integration; applications focus on plant functions and plant interactions with pathogens and pests. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 335, BIOL 338. Equivalency: FNH 436
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 335, BIOL 338. Equivalency: FNH 436

subject: BIOL
title: Laboratory in Animal Cell Molecular Biology
description: The use of recombinant DNA techniques to explore problems in animal developmental biology. [2-4-0] Prerequisite: All of BIOL 331, BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203.
prerequisite_raw: All of BIOL 331, BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203.

subject: BIOL
title: Zoological Physics
description: Animal systems viewed from a physicist's perspective. Topics include sensory systems, energy budgets, locomotion, internal flows, physical advantages of grouping. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. BIOL 325 is recommended. Equivalency: PHYS 438
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. BIOL 325 is recommended. Equivalency: PHYS 438

subject: BIOL
title: Advanced Microscopy Techniques
description: Microscopy techniques used in biological research. Principles, applications and hands-on training of optical and electron microscopy. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [2-4-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 200. Corequisite: One of BIOL 448, BIOL 449. and Fourth-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 200. Corequisite: One of BIOL 448, BIOL 449. and Fourth-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: One of BIOL 448, BIOL 449. and Fourth-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Plant Genomics
description: Concepts, principles, applications, and recent discoveries in genome structure, genetics, and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants. [3-0-0] Corequisite: One of BIOL 335, BIOL 338. Equivalency: APBI 440
corequisite_raw: One of BIOL 335, BIOL 338. Equivalency: APBI 440

subject: BIOL
title: Advanced Topics in Cell Biology
description: Analysis of cellular organelles and the intracellular traffic between them, concentrating on mammalian cell systems. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 340, BIOL 341 and one of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 370, BIOL 371.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 340, BIOL 341 and one of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 370, BIOL 371.

subject: BIOL
title: Darwin's Fishes
description: A series of computer-assisted lectures using ichthyology and the work of Charles Darwin to illustrate basic principles of biology, and their practical implementation, i.e., how biologists select research programs, generate and test hypotheses, and present their case to peers and the public. [2-0-2] Prerequisite: 3rd-year class standing or higher in Science is required.
prerequisite_raw: 3rd-year class standing or higher in Science is required.

subject: BIOL
title: History and Philosophy of Biology
description: The nature of science, this history of evolutionary and molecular biology, philosophical questions about scientific methods and fundamental conclusions of biology. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: 4th-year class standing in any degree program.
prerequisite_raw: 4th-year class standing in any degree program.

subject: BIOL
title: Principles and Methodology in Biological Research
description: Seminars, debates, workshops and tutorials designed to produce competence in specific areas of Biology. Restricted to Honours students in Biology. [2-3-0] Corequisite: BIOL 449
corequisite_raw: BIOL 449

subject: BIOL
title: Directed Biological Research
description: A course designed to allow students to undertake a research project in selected fields. Open only to Honours students in Biology, with permission of the supervisor. Presentation of a thesis and an oral examination are required. Corequisite: BIOL 447
corequisite_raw: BIOL 447

subject: BIOL
title: Molecular Adaptation of Animals to the Environment
description: Physiological, biochemical, and molecular strategies of adaptation of animals to environmental challenges. The evolution of genetic and biochemical systems, and their impact on animal structure and function. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APBI 311, BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364, BIOL 370, BIOL 371 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203. BIOL 457 is recommended.
prerequisite_raw: One of APBI 311, BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364, BIOL 370, BIOL 371 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203. BIOL 457 is recommended.

subject: BIOL
title: Comparative Neurobiology
description: Advanced investigations of the evolution of animal nervous systems, integrating studies of diverse species to understand fundamental neurobiology. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 371, BIOL 372, CAPS 301, PSYC 304, PSYC 367, PSYC 370.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 371, BIOL 372, CAPS 301, PSYC 304, PSYC 367, PSYC 370.

subject: BIOL
title: Insect Physiology
description: Physiological adaptations used by insects, including adaptations used to survive in extreme environments. Homeostatic mechanisms, neurophysiology, and experimental techniques. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 204, BIOL 205, BIOL 327, APBI 327 and one of BIOL 361, BIOL 364, BIOL 370, BIOL 371, APBI 311.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 204, BIOL 205, BIOL 327, APBI 327 and one of BIOL 361, BIOL 364, BIOL 370, BIOL 371, APBI 311.

subject: BIOL
title: Comparative Animal Physiology
description: Selected topics in physiology emphasizing comparisons between diverse phylogenetic groups of animals. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APBI 311, BIOL 362, BIOL 364.
prerequisite_raw: One of APBI 311, BIOL 362, BIOL 364.

subject: BIOL
title: Comparative Neurobiology
description: Current approaches in neurobiology, from the cellular to the behavioural level, are examined using representatives of vertebrate and invertebrate nervous systems. [3-0-2*] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364, CAPS 301, PSYC 360.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364, CAPS 301, PSYC 360.

subject: BIOL
title: Comparative and Molecular Endocrinology
description: A comparative study of vertebrate and invertebrate endocrinology. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APBI 311, BIOL 364.
prerequisite_raw: One of APBI 311, BIOL 364.

subject: BIOL
title: Comparative Environmental Physiology
description: A survey of physiological adaptions of animals to different environments. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APBI 311, BIOL 364.
prerequisite_raw: One of APBI 311, BIOL 364.

subject: BIOL
title: Developmental Neurobiology
description: Cellular, molecular and physiological aspects of nervous system development with applications to understanding adult nervous system function and neurological disorders. [3-0-0]

subject: BIOL
title: Neurobiology of Sensory and Motor Systems
description: Analysis of the mechanisms of sensory processing and motor orchestration using vertebrate and invertebrate model systems. Neural circuit structure, specialization, information coding, integration, and behaviour. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 372, CAPS 301, PSYC 304, PSYC 367, PSYC 370.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 372, CAPS 301, PSYC 304, PSYC 367, PSYC 370.

subject: BIOL
title: Neurobiology of Vision
description: Advanced investigation of animal vision; critical analysis of recent literature and research project development in visual neurobiology. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 372, CAPS 301, PSYC 304, PSYC 367, PSYC 370.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 372, CAPS 301, PSYC 304, PSYC 367, PSYC 370.

subject: BIOL
title: Ecological Plant Biochemistry
description: The structure, biosynthesis, distribution and biological function of secondary plant metabolites. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: All of BIOL_V 200, BIOL_V 201, BIOL_V 209 or BIOL_V 210 is recommended. Equivalency: FRST_V 413.
prerequisite_raw: All of BIOL_V 200, BIOL_V 201, BIOL_V 209 or BIOL_V 210 is recommended. Equivalency: FRST_V 413.

subject: BIOL
title: Gene Regulation in Development
description: Control of gene expression in development; the genetic and physiological basis of epigenetic determination; inductive interactions. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203; or (b) BIOT 380.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203; or (b) BIOT 380.

subject: BIOL
title: Animal Developmental Genetics
description: Role of genes in embryonic development. Emphasis on tissue specific expression patterns and the role of genetic networks in establishing cell types. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 463
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 463

subject: BIOL
title: Diversity and Evolution of Fishes
description: Introduction to fish diversity, with a focus on their phylogenetic interrelationships and the evolutionary, ecological, and biogeographic processes involved in generating patterns of fish biodiversity. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 204
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 204

subject: BIOL
title: Applied Biology of Fishes
description: Physiological ecology and exploitation biology of teleost fishes; computer-based analysis and modeling of fish populations. Prerequisite: BIOL 465
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 465

subject: BIOL
title: Student Directed Seminars
description: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. Normally not suitable as a specific BIOL program elective. [3-0] Prerequisite: 3rd-year class standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: 3rd-year class standing or higher.

subject: BIOL
title: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth-year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth-year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology. Prerequisite: One of BIOL_V 399, BIOL_V 498. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL_V 399, BIOL_V 498. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Quantitative Methods in Ecology and Evolution
description: Prerequisite: BIOL 300 or equivalent and graduate student standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 300 or equivalent and graduate student standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Microbial Ecology
description: Theoretical and applied ecology of microbes. Focus on microbial symbionts of animals, plants and seaweeds. Critical analysis of microbial ecological literature and computational analysis of ecological data. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [2-3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Population and Quantitative Genetics
description: Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Applied Population Genetics
description: Equivalency: FRST510 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: The Biology of the Cell
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Plant Genetics
description: Emphasis on molecular aspects. Systems and techniques for genetic analysis in plants; isolation and regulation of plant genes; genetic dissection of plant-specific processes; transposable elements; gene transfer in plants; cytoplasmic inheritance; genetic engineering. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 335. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 335. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Teaching and Learning in the Life Sciences
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Topics in Biotechnology
description: Research reviews, class discussions, and presentations about current research in the diverse areas of biotechnology. Topics include the research interests of members of the UBC Biotechnology Laboratory. [1.5-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Advanced Microscopy Techniques
description: Microscopy techniques used in biological research. Principles, applications and hands-on training of optical and electron microscopy. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [2-4-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: BIOL
title: Theory of Adaptive Dynamics and Evolutionary Games
description: Consult the credit exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Academic Calendar: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 560 or BIOL 401. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: An introductory course in the mathematical treatment of population biology as well as a course in integral calculus. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: An introductory course in the mathematical treatment of population biology as well as a course in integral calculus. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Consult the credit exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Academic Calendar: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 560 or BIOL 401. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: An introductory course in the mathematical treatment of population biology as well as a course in integral calculus. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
