subject: COMR
title: Introduction to Business
description: An overview of all functional areas of business. Students will be introduced to the computer and internet tools commonly used in business. For non-Commerce students only. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 100 or COMM 100. Equivalency: COMM 100
exclusion_raw: An overview of all functional areas of business. Students will be introduced to the computer and internet tools commonly used in business. For non-Commerce students only. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 100 or COMM 100. Equivalency: COMM 100

subject: COMR
title: Entrepreneurship
description: Entrepreneurial essentials from creating viable opportunities through building a founding team, strategic planning, going to market, fleshing out an organization and planning the future of the business. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 280 or COMM 280. Equivalency: COMM280 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Entrepreneurial essentials from creating viable opportunities through building a founding team, strategic planning, going to market, fleshing out an organization and planning the future of the business. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 280 or COMM 280. Equivalency: COMM280 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Principles of Organizational Behaviour
description: An introductory examination of work organizations and the behaviour of individuals within them. Phenomena to be studied include organizational structure, environments, group processes, motivation and leadership (for non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 192, COMM 292, COMM 321, or COMM 329. Equivalency: COMM 329 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Economics of Entrepreneurship and Innovation
description: Fundamental economic issues faced by entrepreneurs who want to commercialize innovations within start-ups and established firms. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 382 or COMM 382. Prerequisite: One of ECON 101, ECON 310. Corequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM382 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON 101, ECON 310. Corequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM382 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM382 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Fundamental economic issues faced by entrepreneurs who want to commercialize innovations within start-ups and established firms. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 382 or COMM 382. Prerequisite: One of ECON 101, ECON 310. Corequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM382 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Entrepreneurial Finance and Private Equity
description: Financial issues encountered by entrepreneurs and those active on the investing side of entrepreneurship, such as working for banks, venture capital firms, or corporate venture organizations, or anyone interacting with entrepreneurs and private equity investors. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 387, COEC 387, or COMM 387. Corequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COEC387, COMM387 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COEC387, COMM387 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Financial issues encountered by entrepreneurs and those active on the investing side of entrepreneurship, such as working for banks, venture capital firms, or corporate venture organizations, or anyone interacting with entrepreneurs and private equity investors. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 387, COEC 387, or COMM 387. Corequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COEC387, COMM387 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Design Methods for Business Innovation
description: Studio-based experience in thinking strategies and design processes applied to business innovation in the private, public, and social sectors. Emphasis on problem solving, co-creation, and innovation for external clients in a collaborative environment. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 388 or COMM 388. Prerequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM388 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM388 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Studio-based experience in thinking strategies and design processes applied to business innovation in the private, public, and social sectors. Emphasis on problem solving, co-creation, and innovation for external clients in a collaborative environment. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 388 or COMM 388. Prerequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM388 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Creativity in Business
description: The role and importance of creativity in developing successful business solutions. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 389 or COMM 389. Prerequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM389 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM389 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The role and importance of creativity in developing successful business solutions. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 389 or COMM 389. Prerequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM389 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Introduction to Business Processes and Operations
description: The design and management of systems that efficiently and effectively supply products and services to the end-user. The concepts apply to a variety of settings such as manufacturing, logistics, healthcare, and others (For non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 204 or COMM 398. Equivalency: COMM 398 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Fundamentals of Financial Accounting
description: Financial accounting for business organizations; principles and problems of accounting measurements; forms of business organizations; financing of businesses. (For non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM_V 293, COMM_V 320, or COMM_V 457. Equivalency: COMM_V 457 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Fundamentals of Managerial Accounting
description: Use of accounting data in decision making by businesses; financial statement analysis; cash flows; cost behaviour patterns; methods of accounting for costs. (For non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM_V 294 or COMM_V 458. Prerequisite: One of COMM_V 293, COMM_V 457, COMR_V 457. Equivalency: COMM_V 458 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of COMM_V 293, COMM_V 457, COMR_V 457. Equivalency: COMM_V 458 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Marketing Management
description: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services. (For non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 296, COMM 420, or COMM 465. Corequisite: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310. Equivalency: COMM 465 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310. Equivalency: COMM 465 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Business Finance
description: Introduction to managerial finance, including the role and functioning of financial markets, procurement of funds and financing strategies, dividend policy, capital budgeting and financial analysis and planning. (For non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 298, COMM 421, or COMM 473. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310; and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184. Corequisite: One of COMM 293, COMM 457, COMR 457. Equivalency: COMM 473 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310; and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184. Corequisite: One of COMM 293, COMM 457, COMR 457. Equivalency: COMM 473 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: One of COMM 293, COMM 457, COMR 457. Equivalency: COMM 473 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: New Product Development
description: How new products are developed and the factors that influence success and failure throughout the various stages of development. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 482 or COMM 482. Prerequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM 482 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM 482 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: How new products are developed and the factors that influence success and failure throughout the various stages of development. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 482 or COMM 482. Prerequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Equivalency: COMM 482 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Social Entrepreneurship
description: An applied course that examines the innovative, growing, and rapidly evolving field of social entrepreneurship, which tackles social and environmental challenges through business perspectives and methods. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 485 or COMM 485. Equivalency: COMM 485 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: An applied course that examines the innovative, growing, and rapidly evolving field of social entrepreneurship, which tackles social and environmental challenges through business perspectives and methods. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 485 or COMM 485. Equivalency: COMM 485 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: Strategic Management in Business
description: A conceptual and practical introduction to the major areas of business strategy with an integrative perspective on managing a business. Includes the analysis of a business and its environment, the development and evaluation of strategic alternatives, and implementation of change (For non-Commerce students only in fourth year). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 491 or COMM 493. Prerequisite: One of COMM 293, COMM 457, COMR 457 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (c) ECON 100 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310. Corequisite: One of COMM 329, COMR 329 and one of COMM 465, COMR 465 and one of COMM 473, COMR 473. Equivalency: COMM493 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of COMM 293, COMM 457, COMR 457 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (c) ECON 100 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310. Corequisite: One of COMM 329, COMR 329 and one of COMM 465, COMR 465 and one of COMM 473, COMR 473. Equivalency: COMM493 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: One of COMM 329, COMR 329 and one of COMM 465, COMR 465 and one of COMM 473, COMR 473. Equivalency: COMM493 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: COMR
title: New Enterprise Development
description: The particular problems and experiences encountered in starting, developing, and managing new enterprises. The course includes lectures, guest speakers, and case studies. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 497, COMM 466, COMM 497, COEC 497, APSC 486, or APSC 496E. Prerequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Corequisite: One of COMM 382, COMR 382 and one of COMM 387, COMR 387. Equivalency: COEC497, COMM497 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Corequisite: One of COMM 382, COMR 382 and one of COMM 387, COMR 387. Equivalency: COEC497, COMM497 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: One of COMM 382, COMR 382 and one of COMM 387, COMR 387. Equivalency: COEC497, COMM497 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The particular problems and experiences encountered in starting, developing, and managing new enterprises. The course includes lectures, guest speakers, and case studies. Credit will be granted for only one of COMR 497, COMM 466, COMM 497, COEC 497, APSC 486, or APSC 496E. Prerequisite: One of COMM 280, COMR 280. Corequisite: One of COMM 382, COMR 382 and one of COMM 387, COMR 387. Equivalency: COEC497, COMM497 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CONS
title: Introduction to Conservation
description: Seminars on current natural resources conservation and forest sciences topics. [3-0-0]

subject: CONS
title: Observing the Earth from Space
description: Exploration of innovative Earth observation and other geospatial technologies and how they allow us to better understand the changing Earth. [3-0-0]

subject: CONS
title: Foundations of Conservation
description: Conceptual foundations of conservation; means of conserving nature and natural resources. [3-0-0]

subject: CONS
title: Visualizing Climate Change
description: Introduction to climate change through the lens of local landscapes and future scenarios, using visual media to communicate the underlying science & psychology, and engage communities in local climate change solutions.

subject: CONS
title: Issues in Genomics and the Environment
description: Introductory genomics in the context of genetics and epigenetics; current and topical issues, including genetic determinism, environmental DNA, revival of extinct species, and applications of genomics to improve our life and environment including adaptation to climate change. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 11, BIOL 12.

subject: CONS
title: Ecology in a Changing Climate
description: Impact of climate change on ecological systems. Builds framework for understanding past and future changes following fundamental organizing units of ecology - individuals, populations, species, communities, and ecosystems. Prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, GEOS 207.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 121, GEOS 207.

subject: CONS
title: Elements of Biodiversity
description: The units of biodiversity, from genes to ecosystems, how they are structured in space, and their importance to human well-being and ecosystem health. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APBI_V 260, BIOL_V 230, FRST_V 201, NRES_V 201, GEOS_V 207. Equivalency: BIOL_V 314
prerequisite_raw: One of APBI_V 260, BIOL_V 230, FRST_V 201, NRES_V 201, GEOS_V 207. Equivalency: BIOL_V 314

subject: CONS
title: Conservation Science and Sustainability
description: Fundamental concepts in conservation science. Different philosophies, perspectives, and disciplines used in setting priorities for managing biodiversity at all scales. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, GEOS 102, GEOS 103. Second-year standing required.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 121, GEOS 102, GEOS 103. Second-year standing required.

subject: CONS
title: Indigenous Forestry
description: Principles, issues and ethics germane to working with or for Indigenous Nations or communities, including Indigenous rights and title, relational values and natural resources governance. [3-0-0]

subject: CONS
title: Belowground Ecosystems
description: Current concepts, methods, and applications of belowground ecology with emphasis on biotic interactions in soil; to understand the roles that aboveground and belowground communities play in regulating the structure and function of terrestrial ecosystems and their responses to global change. [3-0-0] Credit will be granted for only one of CONS 412, APBI 412, or FRST 512. Prerequisite: Fourth year standing in the Faculty of Forestry or a Bachelor of Science Program awarded by any Faculty. Equivalency: APBI 412
prerequisite_raw: Fourth year standing in the Faculty of Forestry or a Bachelor of Science Program awarded by any Faculty. Equivalency: APBI 412
exclusion_raw: Current concepts, methods, and applications of belowground ecology with emphasis on biotic interactions in soil; to understand the roles that aboveground and belowground communities play in regulating the structure and function of terrestrial ecosystems and their responses to global change. [3-0-0] Credit will be granted for only one of CONS 412, APBI 412, or FRST 512. Prerequisite: Fourth year standing in the Faculty of Forestry or a Bachelor of Science Program awarded by any Faculty. Equivalency: APBI 412

subject: CONS
title: Land, Trees, and Property Institutions
description: Exploration of the forces that gave rise to the global variety of systems of property for trees and forestlands; evolution in the governance of property. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing.

subject: CONS
title: Sustainable Energy: Policy and Governance
description: Energy as a global policy problem; current energy challenges; energy systems and energy analysis; the politics and policy of energy alternatives. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third- or fourth-year standing; 100-level MATH course.
prerequisite_raw: Third- or fourth-year standing; 100-level MATH course.

subject: CONS
title: Conservation Decision-Making and Policy
description: An introduction to policy and decision making for conserving biodiversity in an uncertain world using a combination of ecological data and decision science. [3-1-0] Prerequisite: [CONS200]
prerequisite_raw: [CONS200]

subject: CONS
title: Integrated Field School
description: Field methods, research and analysis, community-oriented projects, and the interactions between biological and social aspects of conservation research. Students may not take any other courses in conjunction with CONS 451. Restricted to B.Sc. in Natural Resources Conservation students in the fourth year of the Science and Management Major or B.Sc. in Natural Resources students in the fourth year of the Science and Management Specialization of the Conservation Major. [10-10-10] Prerequisite: All of CONS 330, CONS 340, CONS 440, CONS 481, FRST 385, FRST 386, FRST 395. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of CONS 330, CONS 340, CONS 440, CONS 481, FRST 385, FRST 386, FRST 395. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CONS
title: Global Perspectives Capstone
description: Examination of global resources and sustainability via scenario evaluation, modelling, and prescription. Students must have already completed their International/Cultural Experience. [3-0-9] Prerequisite: CONS 330 and one of NRES 231, FRST 231, BIOL 300 and one of NRES 241, CONS 340, NRES 340, GEOS 270. and fourth-year standing in the Global Perspectives Specialization of the Conservation Major. Corequisite: One of NRES 341, FRST 443, NRES 443. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: CONS 330 and one of NRES 231, FRST 231, BIOL 300 and one of NRES 241, CONS 340, NRES 340, GEOS 270. and fourth-year standing in the Global Perspectives Specialization of the Conservation Major. Corequisite: One of NRES 341, FRST 443, NRES 443. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: One of NRES 341, FRST 443, NRES 443. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CONS
title: International Conservation and Forest Ecosystem Management Field School
description: International, experiential learning in conservation and forest ecosystem management. A 300-level ecology course such as CONS 330 is strongly recommended as a prerequisite. Fee will be assessed for living and traveling expenses. Pre-registration is required. Prerequisite: One of FRST 231, NRES 231, BIOL 300 and one of FRST 210, NRES 210 and one of FRST 211, NRES 211. Or 6 credits of ecology-based courses (e.g. BIOL 230, BIOL 306, APBI 260, APBI 360). Third-year standing and permission of the instructor are required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 231, NRES 231, BIOL 300 and one of FRST 210, NRES 210 and one of FRST 211, NRES 211. Or 6 credits of ecology-based courses (e.g. BIOL 230, BIOL 306, APBI 260, APBI 360). Third-year standing and permission of the instructor are required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CONS
title: Communities, Wildlife, and Conservation in Post-Apartheid South Africa
description: Immersive, international field course on evolving landscapes of community conservation in post-apartheid South Africa and social-ecological issues facing 2 million residents on the edge of Kruger National Park. Fee will be assessed for living and traveling expenses. Pre-registration is required. Prerequisite: Third-year standing and permission of the instructor are required.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing and permission of the instructor are required.

subject: CONS
title: Conservation Planning in Practice
description: Theory, tools and practical skills needed to conduct conservation planning at the community level. Addresses issues of developing and implementing plans in the context of sustainability goals, political realities and diverse public opinion. [2-2-0]

subject: CONS
title: Fish Conservation and Management
description: Principles of fish biology, population and community ecology necessary to understand conservation and management; overview of current issues, tactics and institutions involved with fisheries conservation and management. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: FRST 386.
prerequisite_raw: FRST 386.

subject: CONS
title: Contemporary Forestry and Conservation in China (UBC Global Seminar Series)
description: This is a one-month UBC Global Seminar program in China allows students to learn forestry and conservation in Asia through lectures and field trips to nature reserves, plantations, wood industry firms and national parks in China. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing.

subject: CONS
title: Recreation and Tourism Planning
description: Principles and methods for planning urban and rural recreation and related tourism resources including analyzing recreation resources, applying policies and standards, developing park/recreation area management plans, and understanding benefits to human and community wellbeing and biodiversity. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing.

subject: CONS
title: Human Wildlife Conflict
description: Evaluation of the impacts of human wildlife conflicts on wildlife populations; application of innovative methods to reduce human wildlife conflicts. [2-0-1] Prerequisite: Third-year standing or higher. BIOL 230 or FRST 395 and APBI 315 or APBI 416 recommended. Equivalency: APBI495
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing or higher. BIOL 230 or FRST 395 and APBI 315 or APBI 416 recommended. Equivalency: APBI495

subject: CONS
title: Primate Conservation in the Anthropocene
description: Modern-day threats facing primates and the wide range of conservation strategies being implemented globally to protect them. Prerequisite: Third year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third year standing.

subject: CONS
title: Thesis or Special Project
description: An independent study or research project of a subject of special interest to the student under the supervision of a staff member.

subject: CONS
title: Seminar in Biological Conservation
description: Topics in conservation biology with application to current issues and particular reference to (but not limited to) forested ecosystems. [2-0-1] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CONS
title: Topics in Conservation Genetics
description: The genetics of small populations, inbreeding, extinction risks due to genetic versus demography factors, adaptation and climate change, and methods for assessing genetic diversity for conservation planning. Equivalency: ZOOL524 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CONS
title: Ecological Restoration
description: Global overview of ecological restoration, examining perspectives and practices in diverse ecosystems worldwide. Causes of degradation, motivations for restoration (including cultural underpinnings), restoration objectives (biodiversity, ecosystem function, ecosystem services), restoration practices (and their evolution over time), challenges and lessons learnt. Credit will be granted for only one of CONS 505 or UFOR 403. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Global overview of ecological restoration, examining perspectives and practices in diverse ecosystems worldwide. Causes of degradation, motivations for restoration (including cultural underpinnings), restoration objectives (biodiversity, ecosystem function, ecosystem services), restoration practices (and their evolution over time), challenges and lessons learnt. Credit will be granted for only one of CONS 505 or UFOR 403. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CONS
title: Forest Conservation in Asia: Challenges and Opportunities
description: Key forest conservation issues in Asia, regional strategies, programs, and practices for restoration of critical landscapes, rehabilitation of terrestrial ecosystems and conservation of flagship species. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CONS
title: Science and Expertise in Global Environmental Governance
description: Structures of global environmental governance, how science and expertise shape the evaluation and incorporation (or not) of diverse forms of knowledge into decisions, failings of global environmental regimes and what can be done to support transformative change. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CONS
title: Conservation Policy
description: Examination of international and Canadian conservation agreements and policies as instruments of distributive justice. Application of contemporary theories of justice to conservation policy issues. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CONS
title: Social Science Research Methods and Design for Natural Resource Management
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Computing Systems I
description: Boolean algebra; combinational and sequential circuits; organization and operation of microcomputers, memory addressing modes, representation of information, instruction sets, machine and assembly language programming, systems programs, I/O structures, I/O interfacing and I/O programming, introduction to digital system design using microcomputers. Credit will be granted for only one of CPEN 211, CPEN 312, EECE 256, EECE 259 or EECE 355. [4-2-2*] Prerequisite: APSC 160. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: APSC 160. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Boolean algebra; combinational and sequential circuits; organization and operation of microcomputers, memory addressing modes, representation of information, instruction sets, machine and assembly language programming, systems programs, I/O structures, I/O interfacing and I/O programming, introduction to digital system design using microcomputers. Credit will be granted for only one of CPEN 211, CPEN 312, EECE 256, EECE 259 or EECE 355. [4-2-2*] Prerequisite: APSC 160. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Computing Systems II
description: Abstractions at the hardware-software interface and their low-level implementation. Procedure invocation, dynamic dispatch, and related exploits; library linkage, virtual memory, heap management, garbage collection, and caches; interrupts, signals, and processes; threads, locks, and cache coherence; files, devices, and network topology. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: CPEN 211 and one of CPEN 221, CPEN 223, CPSC 259. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: CPEN 211 and one of CPEN 221, CPEN 223, CPSC 259. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Software Design for Engineers I
description: Introduction to robust software design: static typing, procedural specifications, unit testing, black-box & white-box tests, user- defined data types (representations, invariants, abstraction functions), data abstractions, communicating design (e.g., UML). [3-2-0] Prerequisite: APSC 160. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: APSC 160. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Technical Communication
description: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, BMEG 201 or APSC 201. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, BMEG 201 or APSC 201. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Computer Engineering Design Studio I
description: Design projects involving hardware (electronic devices and circuits, microcomputers) and software. [2-6-0] Prerequisite: CPEN 211. Corequisite: ELEC 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: CPEN 211. Corequisite: ELEC 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: ELEC 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Digital Systems Design
description: Advanced combinational and sequential electronic system design. Hardware specification, modelling, and simulation using hardware description languages (HDLs) and CAD tools. Design with programmable logic including FPGA's. Applications include complex state machines, microcontrollers, arithmetic circuits, and interface units. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: One of CPEN 211, CPEN 312. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPEN 211, CPEN 312. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Digital Systems and Microcomputers
description: Data representation in digital computers; boolean algebra; the design and optimization and implementation of combinatorial and sequential circuits; modern digital circuit technologies; memory and programmable logic devices; organization and operation of microcomputers; data/address bus organization; input-output interfacing. Credit will be granted for only one of CPEN 312, CPEN 211. [3-2*-0] Prerequisite: One of ELEC 201, ELEC 204, ELEC 203, MECH 221. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of ELEC 201, ELEC 204, ELEC 203, MECH 221. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Data representation in digital computers; boolean algebra; the design and optimization and implementation of combinatorial and sequential circuits; modern digital circuit technologies; memory and programmable logic devices; organization and operation of microcomputers; data/address bus organization; input-output interfacing. Credit will be granted for only one of CPEN 312, CPEN 211. [3-2*-0] Prerequisite: One of ELEC 201, ELEC 204, ELEC 203, MECH 221. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Software Construction II
description: Contemporary concepts and techniques for developing interactive software applications: client-server architectures; session-oriented systems; security and scalability; models of application deployment.  [3-2-0] Prerequisite: All of CPEN 221, CPSC 221. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of CPEN 221, CPSC 221. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Software Engineering
description: Engineering practices for the development of non-trivial software-intensive systems including requirements specification, software architecture, implementation, verification, and maintenance. Iterative development. Recognized standards, guidelines, and models. Credit will only be granted for only one of CPSC 310, CPEN 321. [3-2-0] Corequisite: CPEN 322. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: CPEN 322. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Operating Systems
description: Operating systems, their design and their implementation. Process concurrency, synchronization, communication and scheduling. Device drivers, memory management, virtual memory, file systems, networking and security. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: CPEN 212 and CPEN 221. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: CPEN 212 and CPEN 221. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Machine Learning with Engineering Applications
description: Foundations and concepts of data science and machine learning with applications to engineering problems. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: One of MATH_V 152, MATH_V 221 and one of MATH_V 318, MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302, STAT_V 321, ELEC_V 321 and one of CPEN_V 221, CPEN_V 223, CPSC_V 259. Credit cannot be obtained for both CPEN_V 355 and CPSC_V 340. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH_V 152, MATH_V 221 and one of MATH_V 318, MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302, STAT_V 321, ELEC_V 321 and one of CPEN_V 221, CPEN_V 223, CPSC_V 259. Credit cannot be obtained for both CPEN_V 355 and CPSC_V 340. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Computer Engineering Design Studio II
description: Design and implementation of a hardware platform and software design and implementation at the operating system and application layers. Project management skills. Effective presentations. Going-forward, credit will be given for only one of CPEN291, CPEN391. [2-6-0] Prerequisite: All of CPEN 212, CPSC 221, ELEC 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of CPEN 212, CPSC 221, ELEC 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Computer Architecture
description: Modern processors, GPUs, and memory hierarchies; quantitative principles and instruction set design; pipelining, superscalar issue, out-of-order execution, branch prediction and speculation; memory hierarchies, caches, virtual addressing, prefetching, coherence, and consistency; multicores, VLIW, on-chip networks, and other advanced architectures. Credit will be granted for only one of CPSC 313, CPEN 411.  [3-0-2] Prerequisite: One of CPEN 212, CPEN 311, CPEN 312. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPEN 212, CPEN 311, CPEN 312. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Modern processors, GPUs, and memory hierarchies; quantitative principles and instruction set design; pipelining, superscalar issue, out-of-order execution, branch prediction and speculation; memory hierarchies, caches, virtual addressing, prefetching, coherence, and consistency; multicores, VLIW, on-chip networks, and other advanced architectures. Credit will be granted for only one of CPSC 313, CPEN 411.  [3-0-2] Prerequisite: One of CPEN 212, CPEN 311, CPEN 312. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Microcomputer Systems Design
description: Microprocessor and system buses; advanced I/O methods; priority interrupts; event/exception handling; serial I/O; computer networking; memory system design; interaction of hardware and software, microprocessor comparison, testability issues, safety critical systems. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: CPEN 311 and one of CPEN 211, CPEN 312. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: CPEN 311 and one of CPEN 211, CPEN 312. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Gate-Model Quantum Computing
description: A software-based introduction to gate model quantum computing algorithms. Basic elements of quantum computation; analysis and software implementation of Grover’s algorithm, Shor’s algorithm, quantum compilation, variational algorithms, Hamiltonian simulation, noise characterization. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of CPEN_V 221, CPEN_V 223, CPSC_V 259, CPSC_V 221, PHYS_V 210, and one of MATH_V 152, MATH_V 221, MATH_V 223. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPEN_V 221, CPEN_V 223, CPSC_V 259, CPSC_V 221, PHYS_V 210, and one of MATH_V 152, MATH_V 221, MATH_V 223. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Software Project Management
description: Advanced project planning, cost estimation and scheduling. Project management tools. Factors influencing productivity and success. Productivity metrics. Analysis of options and risk. Tools. Case studies. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: One of CPEN 321, CPSC 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPEN 321, CPSC 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Software Testing and Analysis
description: Different levels of testing including unit, integration, system, performance and regression levels. Requirements flowdown. Problem tracking. Coverage criteria. Static methods. Tools support. Specialized techniques. Assessment of correctness, reliability, safety. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of CPEN 221, CPEN 321, CPSC 210, CPSC 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPEN 221, CPEN 321, CPSC 210, CPSC 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Software Architecture
description: Software architecture as a bridge from requirements to implementation. Architectural description and patterns. Iterative development. Use of commercial off-the-shelf products. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of CPEN 221, CPEN 321, CPSC 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPEN 221, CPEN 321, CPSC 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Design of Distributed Software Applications
description: Communications, processes, naming, synchronization, consistency and replication, fault tolerance, middleware, and security technologies for distributed applications. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of CPEN 331, CPSC 313 and one of CPEN 221, CPSC 210. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPEN 331, CPSC 313 and one of CPEN 221, CPSC 210. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Real-time System Design
description: Multi-tasking; interrupt-driven systems; task scheduling; schedulability analysis; inter-process communication and synchronization; resource management; performance measurement; hardware/software integration; hardware/software tradeoffs; system reliability. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: One of CPEN 333, CPEN 331, CPSC 313. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPEN 333, CPEN 331, CPSC 313. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Human Computer Interfaces in Engineering Design
description: Practical issues for interfaces for modern software. Task analysis, user modelling, usability engineering, representations, metaphors, prototyping tools. Applications: interactive multimedia systems, engineering, scientific visualization, engineering design. [3-1-2*] Prerequisite: CPSC 221 and one of CPEN 221, CPSC 210, CPEN 333. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 221 and one of CPEN 221, CPSC 210, CPEN 333. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Introduction to Cybersecurity
description: Security risks, threats, and vulnerabilities from technical perspectives; cryptography; software and web security; access control, assurance, accountability; usable privacy and security; engineering of secure systems; cryptocurrencies. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of CPEN 333, CPEN 331, CPSC 313. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPEN 333, CPEN 331, CPSC 313. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Deep Learning
description: Fundamentals of deep learning, including architectures (e.g., MLPs, CNNs, RNNs, Transformers, and GNNs) and learning algorithms under different paradigms (supervised / unsupervised / reinforcement learning). Emphasis on design principles and motivating applications. Recommended pre-requisite: CPEN_V 355 or CPSC_V 340. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: One of MATH_V 152, MATH_V 221 and one of MATH_V 318, MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302, STAT_V 321, ELEC_V 321 and one of CPEN_V 221, CPEN_V 223, CPSC_V 259. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH_V 152, MATH_V 221 and one of MATH_V 318, MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302, STAT_V 321, ELEC_V 321 and one of CPEN_V 221, CPEN_V 223, CPSC_V 259. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
description: Time-money relationships; economic analysis of alternatives including the effects of interest rates, inflation, depreciation, taxation and uncertainty; cost estimation and budgeting; financial analysis of engineering operations. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Architecture for Learning Systems
description: Credit will only be given for one of CPEN 502 or EECE 592. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Advanced Computer Architecture
description: Credit will only be given for one of CPEN 511 or EECE 527. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Parallel and Reconfigurable Computing
description: Credit will only be given for one of CPEN 512 or EECE 528. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: CAD Algorithms for Integrated Circuits
description: Credit will only be given for one of CPEN 513 or EECE 583 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Quantum Information and Computation
description: [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Topics in Software Engineering
description: Credit will only be given for one of CPEN 521 or EECE 511. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Software Verification and Testing
description: Credit will only be given for one of CPEN 522 or EECE 514. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Software Project Management
description: Credit will only be given for one of CPEN 523 or EECE 543 or CPEN 421. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Principles of Mobile Application Development and Analysis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Error Resilient Computing Systems
description: Credit will only be given for one of CPEN 533 or EECE 513. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Trade-offs in Designing Computer Systems
description: [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Human Interface Technologies
description: Credit will only be given for one of CPEN 541 or EECE 518. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPEN
title: Cybersecurity
description: Credit will only be given for one of CPEN 542 or EECE 512. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPSC
title: Computational Thinking
description: Meaning and impact of computational thinking. Solving problems using computational thinking, testing, debugging. How computers work. No prior computing experience required. Not for students with existing credit for or exemption from CPSC 107, CPSC 110 or APSC 160. [3-1-0]

subject: CPSC
title: Introduction to Systematic Program Design
description: Computation as a tool for systematic problem solving in non-computer-science disciplines. Introductory programming skills. Not for credit for students who have credit for, or exemption from, or are concurrently taking CPSC 110 or APSC 160. No programming experience expected. [3-0-1]

subject: CPSC
title: Systematic Program Design
description: Fundamental computation and program structures. Continuing systematic program design from CPSC 103. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: CPSC 103.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 103.

subject: CPSC
title: Computation, Programs, and Programming
description: Fundamental program and computation structures. Introductory programming skills. Computation as a tool for information processing, simulation and modelling, and interacting with the world. [3-3-0]

subject: CPSC
title: Models of Computation
description: Physical and mathematical structures of computation. Boolean algebra and combinations logic circuits; proof techniques; functions and sequential circuits; sets and relations; finite state machines; sequential instruction execution. [3-2-1] Prerequisite: Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12. Corequisite: One of CPSC 107, CPSC 110.
prerequisite_raw: Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12. Corequisite: One of CPSC 107, CPSC 110.
corequisite_raw: One of CPSC 107, CPSC 110.

subject: CPSC
title: Programming, Problem Solving, and Algorithms
description: Analysis of increasingly complex algorithmic problems, using a modern programming language and a variety of approaches. Problem decomposition and abstraction guide explorations of topics from applied algorithms, for example Voronoi Diagrams, Markov Chains, Bin Packing, and Graph Search. Not for students with credit for, or currently enrolled in, CPSC 210 or CPEN 221. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, APSC 160, EOSC 211, MATH 210, PHYS 210, COMM 337.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, APSC 160, EOSC 211, MATH 210, PHYS 210, COMM 337.

subject: CPSC
title: Software Construction
description: Design, development, and analysis of robust software components. Topics such as software design, computational models, data structures, debugging, and testing. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 107, CPSC 110.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 107, CPSC 110.

subject: CPSC
title: Introduction to Computer Systems
description: Software architecture, operating systems, and I/O architectures. Relationships between application software, operating systems, and computing hardware; critical sections, deadlock avoidance, and performance; principles and operation of disks and networks. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: All of CPSC 121, CPSC 210.
prerequisite_raw: All of CPSC 121, CPSC 210.

subject: CPSC
title: Basic Algorithms and Data Structures
description: Design and analysis of basic algorithms and data structures; algorithm analysis methods, searching and sorting algorithms, basic data structures, graphs and concurrency. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 210, CPEN 221 and either (a) one of CPSC 121, MATH 220 or (b) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 226.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 210, CPEN 221 and either (a) one of CPSC 121, MATH 220 or (b) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 226.

subject: CPSC
title: Data Structures and Algorithms for Electrical Engineers
description: Advanced procedural programming. Fundamental algorithms for sorting and searching. Data structures including lists, trees, and hash tables. Introduction to scripting languages and file input/output. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: APSC 160.
prerequisite_raw: APSC 160.

subject: CPSC
title: Basics of Computer Systems
description: Software architecture, operating systems, and I/O architectures. Relationships between application software, operating systems, and computing hardware; critical sections, deadlock avoidance, and performance; principles and operation of disks and networks. [3-2-1] Prerequisite: One of EECE 259, CPEN 211 and one of EECE 210, CPEN 221.
prerequisite_raw: One of EECE 259, CPEN 211 and one of EECE 210, CPEN 221.

subject: CPSC
title: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during Winter Session of second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPSC
title: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education. Prerequisite: [CPSC298] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [CPSC298] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPSC
title: Numerical Computation for Algebraic Problems
description: Numerical techniques for basic mathematical processes involving no discretization, and their analysis. Solution of linear systems, including analysis of round-off errors; norms and condition number; introduction to iterative techniques in linear algebra, including eigenvalue problems; solution to nonlinear equations. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, CPEN 221, EOSC 211, PHYS 210 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, CPEN 221, EOSC 211, PHYS 210 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

subject: CPSC
title: Numerical Approximation and Discretization
description: Numerical techniques for basic mathematical processes involving discretization, and their analysis. Interpolation and approximation, including splines and least squares data fitting; numerical differentiation and integration; introduction to numerical initial value ordinary differential equations. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, CPEN 221, EOSC 211, PHYS 210 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, CPEN 221, EOSC 211, PHYS 210 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

subject: CPSC
title: Introduction to Relational Databases
description: Overview of database systems, ER models, logical database design and normalization, formal relational query languages, SQL and other commercial languages, data warehouses, special topics. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: CPSC_V 221 or DSCI_V 221.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC_V 221 or DSCI_V 221.

subject: CPSC
title: Introduction to Software Engineering
description: Specification, design, validation, evolution and construction of modern software systems, within the context of socially and professionally relevant domains such as ethics, intellectual property, and information security. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: All of CPSC 213, CPSC 221.
prerequisite_raw: All of CPSC 213, CPSC 221.

subject: CPSC
title: Definition of Programming Languages
description: Comparative study of advanced programming language features. Statement types, data types, variable binding, parameter passing mechanisms. Methods for syntactic and semantic description of programming languages. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: CPSC 210.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 210.

subject: CPSC
title: Functional and Logic Programming
description: Principles of symbolic computing, using languages based upon first-order logic and the lambda calculus. Algorithms for implementing such languages. Applications to artificial intelligence and knowledge representation. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 210, CPEN 221.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 210, CPEN 221.

subject: CPSC
title: Computer Hardware and Operating Systems
description: Instruction sets, pipelining, code optimization, caching, virtual memory management, dynamically linked libraries, exception processing, execution time of programs. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: CPSC_V 213 and either CPSC_V 221 or DSCI_V 221.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC_V 213 and either CPSC_V 221 or DSCI_V 221.

subject: CPSC
title: Computer Graphics
description: Human vision and colour; geometric transformations; algorithms for 2-D and 3-D graphics; hardware and system architectures; shading and lighting; animation. [3-1-0] Prerequisite: CPSC 221 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 221 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

subject: CPSC
title: Introduction to Computer Networking
description: Computer networking, basic communication protocols, network infrastructure and routing. Common application-level protocols and principles associated with developing distributed applications. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: CPSC_V 213 and either CPSC_V 221 or DSCI_V 221.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC_V 213 and either CPSC_V 221 or DSCI_V 221.

subject: CPSC
title: Software Engineering Project
description: The design, implementation, and test of a large software system, using a team approach. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: CPSC 310.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 310.

subject: CPSC
title: Intermediate Algorithm Design and Analysis
description: Systematic study of basic concepts and techniques in the design and analysis of algorithms, illustrated from various problem areas. Topics include: models of computation; choice of data structures; graph-theoretic, algebraic, and text processing algorithms. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: All of (a) CPSC_V 221 or DSCI_V 221, (b) at least 3 credits from COMM_V 291, BIOL_V 300, MATH or STAT at 200 level or above.
prerequisite_raw: All of (a) CPSC_V 221 or DSCI_V 221, (b) at least 3 credits from COMM_V 291, BIOL_V 300, MATH or STAT at 200 level or above.

subject: CPSC
title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
description: Problem-solving and planning; state/action models and graph searching. Natural language understanding Computational vision. Applications of artificial intelligence. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: CPSC 221.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 221.

subject: CPSC
title: Applied Machine Learning
description: Application of machine learning tools, with an emphasis on solving practical problems. Data cleaning, feature extraction, supervised and unsupervised machine learning, reproducible workflows, and communicating results. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of CPSC_V 203, CPSC_V 210, CPEN_V 221, DSCI_V 221 or (b) MATH_V 210 and one of CPSC_V 107, CPSC_V 110.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) one of CPSC_V 203, CPSC_V 210, CPEN_V 221, DSCI_V 221 or (b) MATH_V 210 and one of CPSC_V 107, CPSC_V 110.

subject: CPSC
title: Machine Learning and Data Mining
description: Models of algorithms for dimensionality reduction, nonlinear regression, classification, clustering and unsupervised learning; applications to computer graphics, computer games, bio-informatics, information retrieval, e-commerce, databases, computer vision and artificial intelligence. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: All of (a) one of CPSC_V 221, DSCI_V 221 (b) one of MATH_V 152, MATH_V 221, MATH_V 223 (c) one of MATH_V 200, MATH_V 217, MATH_V 226, MATH_V 253, MATH_V 254 (d) one of STAT_V 241, STAT_V 251, ECON_V 325, ECON_V 327, MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302, MATH_V 318.
prerequisite_raw: All of (a) one of CPSC_V 221, DSCI_V 221 (b) one of MATH_V 152, MATH_V 221, MATH_V 223 (c) one of MATH_V 200, MATH_V 217, MATH_V 226, MATH_V 253, MATH_V 254 (d) one of STAT_V 241, STAT_V 251, ECON_V 325, ECON_V 327, MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302, MATH_V 318.

subject: CPSC
title: Introduction to Human Computer Interaction Methods
description: Basic tools and techniques, teaching a systematic approach to interface design, task analysis, analytic and empirical evaluation methods. [2-2-2] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 210, CPEN 221.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 210, CPEN 221.

subject: CPSC
title: Honours Research Seminar
description: Students will attend a series of research seminars presented by faculty members, produce a thesis proposal, and choose their honours thesis supervisor. Available to Honours students. Majors students with satisfactory standing may also be permitted to enrol. [1-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPSC
title: Databases in Data Science
description: Overview of relational and non-relational database systems, role and usage of a database when querying data, data modelling, query languages, and query optimization. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of CPSC_V 203, CPSC_V 210, CPEN_V 221, DSCI_V 221.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC_V 203, CPSC_V 210, CPEN_V 221, DSCI_V 221.

subject: CPSC
title: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPSC
title: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPSC
title: Numerical Linear Algebra
description: Investigation of the practical techniques of computational linear algebra. Orthogonal transformations and their application to the solution of linear equations, the eigenproblem, and linear least squares. Complete solution of the symmetric eigenproblem, including bisection and the QR method. Refinements of these techniques for sparse matrices. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 302, CPSC 303, MATH 307.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 302, CPSC 303, MATH 307.

subject: CPSC
title: Advanced Relational Databases
description: Physical database design, indexing, external mergesort, relational query processing and optimization, transaction processing, concurrency control, crash recovery, special topics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: CPSC 304 and one of CPSC 213, CPSC 261, CPEN 212.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 304 and one of CPSC 213, CPSC 261, CPEN 212.

subject: CPSC
title: Computational Optimization
description: Formulation and analysis of algorithms for continuous and discrete optimization problems; linear, nonlinear, network, dynamic, and integer optimization; large-scale problems; software packages and their implementation; duality theory and sensitivity. [3-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 302, CPSC 303, MATH 307.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 302, CPSC 303, MATH 307.

subject: CPSC
title: Advanced Software Engineering
description: Specification, design, construction and validation of multi-version software systems. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) CPSC 310 or (b) all of CPEN 321, CPEN 331.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) CPSC 310 or (b) all of CPEN 321, CPEN 331.

subject: CPSC
title: Introduction to Compiler Construction
description: A practical introduction to lexical analysis, syntactic analysis, type-checking, code generation and optimization. This will be used to design and implement a compiler for a small language. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: All of CPSC 213, CPSC 221, CPSC 311.
prerequisite_raw: All of CPSC 213, CPSC 221, CPSC 311.

subject: CPSC
title: Advanced Operating Systems
description: Process synchronization and communication schemes, including message-passing and concepts of monitor and serializer. Virtual memory systems management and the problem of information sharing in such systems. The working set principle. Traps and interrupt handling. Elementary queuing theory and its application such as process scheduling, system balancing and load control. File systems and operating system design methodologies. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 313, CPEN 331.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 313, CPEN 331.

subject: CPSC
title: Distributed Systems
description: Concepts and design of distributed systems. Communication architecture and models for interprocess communication. Process migration, naming, distributed file systems, fault tolerance, and concurrency control. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 313, CPEN 331 and one of CPSC 317, ELEC 331.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 313, CPEN 331 and one of CPSC 317, ELEC 331.

subject: CPSC
title: Computer Networking
description: Network protocols and architecture including internetworking, the Internet, layered communication protocols, routing, flow and congestion control, network performance, wired and wireless data communication. [3-0] Prerequisite: All of CPSC 313, CPSC 317 and one of STAT 200, STAT 201, STAT 241, STAT 251.
prerequisite_raw: All of CPSC 313, CPSC 317 and one of STAT 200, STAT 201, STAT 241, STAT 251.

subject: CPSC
title: Parallel Computation
description: Algorithms, architectures, and programming paradigms for parallel computation. Shared memory, message passing, and data parallel architectures and programming models. Parallel algorithms including reduce, scan, and sorting networks. Reasoning about the correctness of parallel programs. Performance analysis and measurement for parallel programs. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: CPSC 320 and one of CPSC 261, CPSC 313, CPEN 212, CPEN 411.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 320 and one of CPSC 261, CPSC 313, CPEN 212, CPEN 411.

subject: CPSC
title: Advanced Algorithms Design and Analysis
description: The study of advanced topics in the design and analysis of algorithms and associated data structures. Topics include algorithms for graph-theoretic; algebraic and geometric problems; algorithms on nonsequential models; complexity issues; approximation algorithms. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: [CPSC320]
prerequisite_raw: [CPSC320]

subject: CPSC
title: Introduction to Theory of Computing
description: Characterizations of computability (using machines, languages and functions). Universality, equivalence and Church's thesis. Unsolvable problems. Restricted models of computation. Finite automata, grammars and formal languages. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 320 or MATH 220 or MATH 226.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 320 or MATH 220 or MATH 226.

subject: CPSC
title: Intelligent Systems
description: Principles and techniques underlying the design, implementation and evaluation of intelligent computational systems. Applications of artificial intelligence to natural language understanding, image understanding and computer-based expert and advisor systems. Advanced symbolic programming methodology. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: CPSC 322.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 322.

subject: CPSC
title: Geometric Modelling
description: Digital representation of curves and surfaces, including splines, subdivision surfaces and meshes. Principles, algorithms and mathematical foundations for geometry representation in computer graphics, computer vision, fabrication, CAD/CAM, and medical imaging. Algorithms for acquisition, creation, representation, and processing of 3D shapes. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253.

subject: CPSC
title: Computer Vision
description: Introduction to the processing and interpretation of images. Image sensing, sampling, and filtering. Algorithms for colour analysis, texture description, stereo imaging, motion interpretation, 3D shape recovery, and recognition. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: All of CPSC 221, MATH 200, MATH 221.
prerequisite_raw: All of CPSC 221, MATH 200, MATH 221.

subject: CPSC
title: Computer Animation
description: Motion in computer graphics for characters and their environments. Keyframing, inverse kinematics, particle systems, rigid body dynamics, contact and collision, controller-based active motion, motion capture. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: CPSC 314.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 314.

subject: CPSC
title: Video Game Programming
description: Video game programming techniques and technologies, including rendering, animation, interaction, game AI, real-time software development for games; start-to-finish simple video-game design and implementation. [1.5–1.5-1] Prerequisites: CPSC_V 314 and one of MATH_V 200, MATH_V 217, MATH_V 226, MATH_V 253 and one of MATH_V 152, MATH_V 221, MATH_V 223.

subject: CPSC
title: Computers and Society
description: Impact of computer technology on society; historical perspectives; social and economic consequences of large-scale information processing systems and automatic control; legal and ethical problems in computer applications. Computers and the individual: machine versus human capabilities, fact and fancy; problematic interface between man and machine. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: 3 credits of Computer Science and at least third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: 3 credits of Computer Science and at least third-year standing.

subject: CPSC
title: Advanced Machine Learning
description: Advanced machine learning techniques focusing on probabilistic models. Deep learning and differentiable programming, exponential families and Bayesian inference, probabilistic graphical models and other generative models, Monte Carlo and variational inference methods. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: All of CPSC 320, CPSC 340.
prerequisite_raw: All of CPSC 320, CPSC 340.

subject: CPSC
title: Advanced Methods for Human Computer Interaction
description: Design and evaluation methodologies and theories; formal models of the user including visual, motor, and information processing; advanced evaluation methods including laboratory experiments and field studies; HCI research frontiers. [2-2-2] Prerequisite: CPSC 344 and one of STAT 200, STAT 201, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, GEOG 374, KIN 206, KIN 371, POLI 380, PSYC 218, PSYC 278, PSYC 366, SOCI 328.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 344 and one of STAT 200, STAT 201, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, GEOG 374, KIN 206, KIN 371, POLI 380, PSYC 218, PSYC 278, PSYC 366, SOCI 328.

subject: CPSC
title: Algorithms in Bioinformatics
description: Sequence alignment, phylogenetic tree reconstruction, prediction of RNA and protein structure, gene finding and sequence annotation, gene expression, and biomolecular computing. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: CPSC 320. and either BMEG 250 or six credits of BIOL beyond BIOL 111.
prerequisite_raw: CPSC 320. and either BMEG 250 or six credits of BIOL beyond BIOL 111.

subject: CPSC
title: Introduction to Visualization
description: Design and implementation of static and interactive visualizations. Selection of appropriate visualization methods for given combinations of data type and intended analysis task. Assessment of visual representations according to design and perceptual principles. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 310, CPEN 321.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 310, CPEN 321.

subject: CPSC
title: Honours Thesis
description: Under supervision of a faculty member, students investigate a research topic and prepare a thesis. Prerequisite: [CPSC349]
prerequisite_raw: [CPSC349]

subject: CPSC
title: Applied Industry Practices
description: Hands-on project, mentored by industry experts, integrating skills relevant to early career in the computing industry: technical skills, communication, teamwork, networking and portfolio building. [2.5-2-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 310, CPEN 321.
prerequisite_raw: One of CPSC 310, CPEN 321.

subject: CPSC
title: Student Directed Seminars
description: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. [3-0-0]

subject: CPSC
title: Interactive Digital Media Practicum
description: Design and implementation of interactive digital media systems using modern processes and tools. Projects provided by external clients or vetted entrepreneurial pitches are developed by interdisciplinary teams composed of one CPSC 491 student and multiple Master of Digital Media students. Prerequisite: All of CPSC 221, CPSC 310, CPSC 344. and Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of CPSC 221, CPSC 310, CPSC 344. and Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: CPSC
title: Co-operative Work Placement V
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
