description: Application of chemical, biological, and environmental science; engineering concepts; sustainable development and health and safety considerations; engineering economics; and life cycle analysis. Conceptual and detailed design for a multi-scale and complex environment health and protection problem. [2-0-4; 2-0-4] Prerequisite: ENVE 301. and Fourth-year standing in ENVL. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: ENVE 301. and Fourth-year standing in ENVL. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: ENVR
title: Exploring Environmental Science
description: Introduction to topics in Earth Science, Ecology, Human Health and Energy from an Environmental Science perspective. [3-0-0]

subject: ENVR
title: Introduction to Environmental Science
description: Seminars and field trips introducing the major global, regional, and local environmental issues facing human societies. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Open to all students with second-year, or higher, standing.
prerequisite_raw: Open to all students with second-year, or higher, standing.

subject: ENVR
title: Climate Action Lab 1
description: Community-engaged climate action projects; skill building for climate action. Pass/Fail [0-2-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: ENVR
title: Environmental Science in Practice I
description: Community building, land connections and academic and career planning in environmental science. [1.5-0-0]

subject: ENVR
title: Environmental Problem Solving
description: Practical and theoretical approaches to tackling complex environmental challenges with emphasis on critical thinking to analyze real-world issues. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MATH_V 101. Corequisite: One of STAT_V 200, 201, BIOL_V 300.
prerequisite_raw: MATH_V 101. Corequisite: One of STAT_V 200, 201, BIOL_V 300.
corequisite_raw: One of STAT_V 200, 201, BIOL_V 300.

subject: ENVR
title: Introduction to Research in Environmental Science
description: Environmental research. Students investigate research methodologies and reporting in a range of scientific disciplines and fields. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Open to all students with third-year, or higher, standing in the Faculty of Science.
prerequisite_raw: Open to all students with third-year, or higher, standing in the Faculty of Science.

subject: ENVR
title: Climate Action Lab 2
description: Community-engaged climate action projects; skill building for climate action. Pass/Fail [0-2-0] Prerequisite: ENVR 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: ENVR 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: ENVR
title: Climate Action Lab 1 and 2
description: Community-engaged climate action projects; skill building for climate action. Pass/Fail [0-3-0] Prerequisite: 3rd year class standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: 3rd year class standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: ENVR
title: Environmental Science in Practice II
description: Mentoring, incorporating feedback, strengthening land connections and academic and career planning in environmental science. [1.5-0-0] Prerequisite: ENVR_V 205.
prerequisite_raw: ENVR_V 205.

subject: ENVR
title: Applied Environmental Ethics
description: The complexities of socio-ecological issues facing practitioners of environmental sciences including ethics and social equity. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: 3rd-year class standing.
prerequisite_raw: 3rd-year class standing.

subject: ENVR
title: Community Project in Environmental Science
description: Instructor-guided collaboration between student teams and community partners on community-based environmental science projects. Teams articulate project questions and goals, devise methods, conduct research and communicate results. Credit will be given for only one of ENVR 400 or ENVR 449. [3-0-0; 3-0-0] Prerequisite: ENVR 300.
prerequisite_raw: ENVR 300.

subject: ENVR
title: Climate Action Lab 3
description: Community-engaged climate action projects; skill building for climate action. Pass/Fail [0-2-0] Prerequisite: One of ENVR 301, ENVR 302. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of ENVR 301, ENVR 302. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: ENVR
title: Climate Studies and Action Capstone
description: Instructor-guided collaboration between student teams and community partners on climate action projects. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: ENVR 401.
prerequisite_raw: ENVR 401.

subject: ENVR
title: Energy, Environment, and Society
description: The role of energy in human societies throughout history and the environmental and social implications of energy use. Coverage of both the science and policy of energy use. Energy supply and demand, energy transitions, analytical tools, impacts, and alternatives. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in B.Sc., B.A.Sc. or related programs.
prerequisite_raw: Fourth-year standing in B.Sc., B.A.Sc. or related programs.

subject: ENVR
title: Ecohydrology of Watersheds and Water Systems
description: Analysis of water resources from a water-in-ecosystem perspective. Application to natural, managed, and urban systems, considering ecological interactions with hydrological processes. Exploration of biogeochemical processes related to water quality, and human impacts on water resources. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third or fourth-year standing in Science, Applied Science, Land and Food Systems, or Forestry.
prerequisite_raw: Third or fourth-year standing in Science, Applied Science, Land and Food Systems, or Forestry.

subject: ENVR
title: Ecological Dimensions of Sustainability
description: Current issues. Application to agricultural, energy, and resource systems in terrestrial and aquatic contexts. Analysis of complex problems; incorporation of science into novel interdisciplinary solutions. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Class standing 3, and either (1) one of ENVR 300, BIOL 230, FRST 201 or (2) other demonstrated ecology background.
prerequisite_raw: Class standing 3, and either (1) one of ENVR 300, BIOL 230, FRST 201 or (2) other demonstrated ecology background.

subject: ENVR
title: Analytical Methods in Sustainability Science
description: Sustainability analysis through a series of case studies. Example approaches include cost-benefit analysis, trade-offs analysis, and life-cycle analysis. Active learning in a computer lab using real-world data. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: One of ENVR 200, ASIC 220, SCIE 220, GEOG 211. Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: One of ENVR 200, ASIC 220, SCIE 220, GEOG 211. Third-year standing.

subject: ENVR
title: Environmental Science Honours Thesis
description: [3-0-0] Prerequisite: [ENVR300] and fourth-year standing in the B.Sc. Environmental Sciences honours program.
prerequisite_raw: [ENVR300] and fourth-year standing in the B.Sc. Environmental Sciences honours program.

subject: ENVR
title: Environmental Policy and Law
description: The creation, implementation and enforcement of environmental laws and policies at the international, national, and sub-national levels. Examination and critique of laws, principles, and policies dealing with issues such as climate change, pollution, and biological diversity. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: 4th-year class standing.
prerequisite_raw: 4th-year class standing.

subject: ENVR
title: Student Directed Seminars in Environmental Sciences
description: Self-directed, collaborative studies in environmental sciences, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. Prerequisite: Prerequisite: Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Prerequisite: Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: The Solid Earth: A Dynamic Planet
description: Earth's origin, composition, structure, and natural resources. Plate tectonics as the driving force for volcanism, mountain building, and earthquakes. Imaging Earth's interior. Environmental geoscience and sustainability. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list for the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) [3-0-0]

subject: EOSC
title: Laboratory Exploration of Planet Earth
description: An examination of the processes that shape and change the planet earth. This laboratory course is an appropriate complement to EOSC 110, EOSC 112, EOSC 114, EOSC 116 but can also be taken independently. [0-3-0]

subject: EOSC
title: The Climate System
description: Introduction to Earth's climate system: radiation balance, greenhouse effect, atmosphere and ocean circulation, plate tectonics, biosphere interactions, and the carbon cycle. Applications to understand the causes of climate change, from long-term climate evolution to modern human-induced climate change. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list, within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.) [3-0-0]

subject: EOSC
title: The Catastrophic Earth: Natural Disasters
description: Introduction to causes and physical characteristics of disasters such as volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, tsunamis, hurricanes, storm surge, thunderstorms, tornadoes, landslides, wind waves, meteor impacts, mass extinctions. [3-0-0]

subject: EOSC
title: Mesozoic Earth: Time of the Dinosaurs.
description: Earth's tectonics, climate, and oceans during the time of the dinosaurs. Reading the fossil record of Earth from its earliest origins up to and including the Mesozoic, 250 - 65 million years ago. [3-0-0]

subject: EOSC
title: Earth's Treasures: Gold and Gems
description: Origin, properties, valuation, prospecting and geology of gold, platinum, silver, diamonds, rubies, emeralds, and other precious metals and gems. [3-0-0]

subject: EOSC
title: Earth Science for Engineers
description: Focus on the interaction between society and the geologic environment. Locating, assessing and developing natural resources; understanding and preparing for natural hazards, design of structures and waste disposal sites. [3-2-0] Corequisite: One of CIVL 215, MINE 200.
corequisite_raw: One of CIVL 215, MINE 200.

subject: EOSC
title: Computer Methods in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences
description: Mathematical computer-based problem solving in the physical, chemical, and biological sciences. Problems drawn from studies of the earth, the oceans and the atmosphere. Credit will be granted for only one of APSC 160 or EOSC 211. [2-0-2] Prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
exclusion_raw: Mathematical computer-based problem solving in the physical, chemical, and biological sciences. Problems drawn from studies of the earth, the oceans and the atmosphere. Credit will be granted for only one of APSC 160 or EOSC 211. [2-0-2] Prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

subject: EOSC
title: Topics in the Earth and Planetary Sciences.
description: Cutting edge problems in earth, ocean, atmospheric and planetary sciences. Topics will be introduced through discussions of the current literature. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Second-year standing in science or engineering.
prerequisite_raw: Second-year standing in science or engineering.

subject: EOSC
title: Computational Methods in Geological Engineering
description: Combining basic physical principles with their mathematical description and generating computational models that describe them. Introduction to basic building blocks in modelling, simulation and parameter estimation. [3-1-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of APSC 160, CPSC 103, CPSC 110, EOSC 211.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 200, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of APSC 160, CPSC 103, CPSC 110, EOSC 211.

subject: EOSC
title: Introductory Mineralogy
description: Introduction to crystallography, physical and chemical properties of minerals. Recognition and identification of common minerals. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [2-3-0] Prerequisite: One of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: One of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, SCIE 001.

subject: EOSC
title: Introductory Petrology
description: Optical mineralogy and the classification and genesis of igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: [EOSC220]
prerequisite_raw: [EOSC220]

subject: EOSC
title: Geological Time and Stratigraphy
description: Measuring geological time and understanding Earth history using stratigraphic principles, paleontology and radioactive decay. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [2-2-0] Prerequisite: Second-year standing in Science. One of EOSC 1**, EOSC 210, GEOB 103 is recommended.
prerequisite_raw: Second-year standing in Science. One of EOSC 1**, EOSC 210, GEOB 103 is recommended.

subject: EOSC
title: Field Techniques
description: Introduction to the techniques of geological mapping and the interpretation of field data. Includes three one-day field trips on weekends plus a seven-day field school after Spring examinations. A fee is to be paid by January 31. [2-2-0] Corequisite: EOSC 221.
corequisite_raw: EOSC 221.

subject: EOSC
title: Site Investigation
description: Theory and practice of site investigation for geological engineers, including background studies, field work, remote sensing, development of ground models, importance of geological variability and uncertainty. Impacts on design, project risk and decision making. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: EOSC 210. Corequisite: CIVL 210.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 210. Corequisite: CIVL 210.
corequisite_raw: CIVL 210.

subject: EOSC
title: Fields and Fluxes
description: Application of classical theory of scalar and vector fields to geophysical sciences. Conductive, convective and radiative energy flux, gravitation, electrostatics, and magnetostatics. Gauss' and Stokes' theorems. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157. Corequisite: [MATH200] One of PHYS 108, 118, 158 is recommended.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157. Corequisite: [MATH200] One of PHYS 108, 118, 158 is recommended.
corequisite_raw: [MATH200] One of PHYS 108, 118, 158 is recommended.

subject: EOSC
title: Earthquakes
description: Characteristics, types, plate tectonics, faults, earth stresses and strains, seismic waves, magnitude scales, instrumentation, hazard mapping, prediction, and forecasting. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157; or (b) SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157; or (b) SCIE 001.

subject: EOSC
title: Marine Ecosystems
description: Introduction to diversity of marine habitats and ecosystems; hydrothermal vent, intertidal, coral reef, estuarine, deep sea, and polar ecosystems; impacts of ecosystem change; evolution of ocean plankton; invasive species; climate change; pollution. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of SCIE 001, CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, CHEM 154.
prerequisite_raw: One of SCIE 001, CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, CHEM 154.

subject: EOSC
title: The Earth and the Solar System
description: The Earth as a planet: its composition, internal dynamics, and surface evolution. Rotation, magnetic field, plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanoes. The ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere as components of a varying geo-environment. Not for credit for students in specializations administered by the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences. ( https://www.eoas.ubc.ca/undergrad/degrees ). No background in science or mathematics is required. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-0-0] Prerequisite: 2nd-year class standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: 2nd-year class standing or higher.

subject: EOSC
title: The Earth and its Resources
description: An introduction to the Earth with emphasis on its industrial and aesthetic resources. Rocks, minerals, gold, diamonds, sediments, fossils, oil and gas, canyons, and volcanoes and the processes that create them. Not for credit for students in specializations administered by the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences. ( https://www.eoas.ubc.ca/undergrad/degrees ). No background in science or mathematics is required. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Class standing 2.
prerequisite_raw: Class standing 2.

subject: EOSC
title: The Ocean Environment
description: An introduction to the oceans and the processes that have shaped them, their composition and movement, waves, tides, beaches, interactions with the atmosphere and human exploitation of the non-living resources. Not for credit for students in specializations administered by the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences. ( https://www.eoas.ubc.ca/undergrad/degrees ). No background in science or mathematics is required. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Class standing 2.
prerequisite_raw: Class standing 2.

subject: EOSC
title: The Ocean Ecosystem
description: An introduction to life in the oceans, its variety and evolution; primary producers and their links to the environment, zooplankton, marine communities, living marine resources and their role in today's world. Not for credit for students in specializations administered by the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences. ( https://www.eoas.ubc.ca/undergrad/degrees ). No background in science or mathematics is required. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Class standing 2.
prerequisite_raw: Class standing 2.

subject: EOSC
title: Sedimentology
description: Origin, diagenesis and geochemistry of sediments and sedimentary rocks. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: EOSC 221 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 221 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.

subject: EOSC
title: Igneous Petrology
description: The origin and formation of igneous rocks. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: EOSC 221.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 221.

subject: EOSC
title: Metamorphic Petrology
description: Deciphering lithospheric processes as recorded by the mineralogy, chemistry and textures of metamorphosed rocks. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: EOSC 221.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 221.

subject: EOSC
title: Structural Geology I
description: Analysis and interpretation of natural deformation. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: All of EOSC 221, EOSC 223 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.
prerequisite_raw: All of EOSC 221, EOSC 223 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.

subject: EOSC
title: Principles of Physical Hydrogeology
description: Theories of storage and movement of water within groundwater systems; Groundwater-surface water interaction; Role of groundwater systems in watershed management and regulating the environmental impacts of global change; Groundwater sustainability; Impacts of climate & land use changes on groundwater resources [3-0-1] Prerequisite: (a) 3rd year standing in Science, Land and Food Systems, or Forestry; and (b) One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: (a) 3rd year standing in Science, Land and Food Systems, or Forestry; and (b) One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Earth and Life Through Time
description: The fossil record of adaptation and extinction emphasizing the interaction of biological and geological processes. Not for credit in Geological Sciences and Geophysics specializations. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Biology 100-level and 3rd-year class standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: Biology 100-level and 3rd-year class standing or higher.

subject: EOSC
title: Geochemical Thermodynamics
description: Application of chemical thermodynamics to problem solving in the earth sciences. Geochemical tools are developed for: low-T aqueous geochemistry, high-T, high-P processes in the lithosphere, ore-deposit formation, and for prediction of geochemical reaction rates in all environments. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: EOSC220 Corequisite: CHEM 205.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC220 Corequisite: CHEM 205.
corequisite_raw: CHEM 205.

subject: EOSC
title: Field Geology
description: Recording and processing geological data in the field. Held within the three weeks following April examinations after third year. A special fee is to be paid by January 31. Prerequisite: All of EOSC_V 323, EOSC_V 330 and one of EOSC_V 321, EOSC_V 322.
prerequisite_raw: All of EOSC_V 323, EOSC_V 330 and one of EOSC_V 321, EOSC_V 322.

subject: EOSC
title: Quantitative Groundwater Hydrology
description: Introduction to theory of groundwater flow; flow nets; regional groundwater resource evaluation; well hydraulics; role of groundwater in geologic processes, case studies. [2-3*-3*] Prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

subject: EOSC
title: Principles of Geomorphology
description: Landform development; morphological and historical analysis of landforms; applications in engineering and resource development. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of GEOB 103, EOSC 110, EOSC 210.
prerequisite_raw: One of GEOB 103, EOSC 110, EOSC 210.

subject: EOSC
title: Introduction to Mineral Deposits
description: Introduction to economic geology and models related to mineral exploration. Study includes typical deposit types and their plate tectonic setting. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: EOSC 221.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 221.

subject: EOSC
title: Tectonic Evolution of North America
description: An overview of the geology and tectonic evolution of North America; comparisons and contrasts between Precambrian rocks of the North American craton and Phanerozoic belts of the Cordilleran, Appalachian, Ouachita and Innuitian orogens; interrelations between sedimentation, deformation, metamorphism and magmatism in a plate tectonic context. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: [EOSC323] or permission of the instructor.
prerequisite_raw: [EOSC323] or permission of the instructor.

subject: EOSC
title: Elemental and Isotopic Geochemistry
description: Analytical methods in geochemistry, major and trace element geochemistry, radiogenic isotopes, geochemistry of seawater, the mantle, basalts, subduction zones, sedimentary rocks, continental crust. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: EOSC 221.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 221.

subject: EOSC
title: Climate Change: Causes and Solutions
description: Mechanisms and processes of past and future global climate change. Climate models and projected impacts. Climate solutions including carbon sequestration, adaptation and geoengineering. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

subject: EOSC
title: Climate Change: Evidence and Impacts
description: Climate science fundamentals: Energy balance, ocean and atmospheric circulation. Future climate scenarios. Processes driving spatial and temporal climate variability. Analysis of observations and climate projection data to evaluate the anthropogenic impact on climate. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: 3rd year class standing
prerequisite_raw: 3rd year class standing

subject: EOSC
title: Environmental, Geotechnical, and Exploration Geophysics I
description: Principles of geophysical survey design, data acquisition, processing and interpretation with emphasis on near-surface problems. Magnetic, seismic reflection/refraction, electromagnetic and ground penetrating radar surveys. Case history analysis of environmental and geotechnical problems. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH_V 200, MATH_V 253 and third-year standing or higher in Science or Applied Science.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH_V 200, MATH_V 253 and third-year standing or higher in Science or Applied Science.

subject: EOSC
title: Geophysical Continuum Dynamics
description: Introduction to tensor calculus and continuum mechanics. Stress, strain and strain-rate tensors. Mass, momentum and energy balance. Applications to problems of geophysical heat transport, elasticity and fluid dynamics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of EOSC 250, MATH 317.
prerequisite_raw: One of EOSC 250, MATH 317.

subject: EOSC
title: Seismology
description: Hooke's law for isotropic continua, elastic wave equation, reflection and refraction methods for imaging the Earth's internal structure, plane waves in an infinite medium and interaction with boundaries, body wave seismology, inversion of travel-time curves, generalized ray theory, crustal seismology, surface waves and earthquake source studies. [3-3*] Prerequisite: [EOSC352]
prerequisite_raw: [EOSC352]

subject: EOSC
title: Analysis of Time Series and Inverse Theory for Earth Scientists
description: Continuous and discrete Fourier transforms, correlation and convolution, spectral estimates, optimum least-squares filters, deconvolution and prediction, frequency-wave number filtering. A practical course on computer techniques applied to the analysis of a wide range of geophysical phenomena. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157.

subject: EOSC
title: The Planets
description: Diversity among the planets and moons of the solar system; integrating concepts across scientific disciplines, including geology, geophysics, and atmospheric science to understand how planets evolve. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121; and one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, CHEM 154 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121; and one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, CHEM 154 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

subject: EOSC
title: Introductory Oceanography: Circulation and Plankton
description: Physical and chemical processes and their controls on the distribution of plankton in the ocean. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

subject: EOSC
title: Introductory Oceanography: Climate and Ecosystems
description: Physical, chemical, and biological processes in the ocean and their interaction with climate and marine food-webs. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: EOSC 372.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 372.

subject: EOSC
title: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in Winter Session (Term 1) in third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Geoscientific Data Analysis and Empirical Modelling
description: Application of data analysis and empirical modelling strategies for conducting a data-oriented research in geosciences; from setting research questions and hypothesis to delivering and interpreting results. Examples are drawn from across the Earth, ocean, atmospheric and planetary sciences. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of STAT 200, BIOL 300 and one of MATH 200, MATH 221, EOSC 250 and one of EOSC 211, CPSC 203, CPSC 210.
prerequisite_raw: One of STAT 200, BIOL 300 and one of MATH 200, MATH 221, EOSC 250 and one of EOSC 211, CPSC 203, CPSC 210.

subject: EOSC
title: Volcanology
description: Field and lab-based studies in volcanology concentrating on physical and chemical aspects of volcanic processes. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: All of EOSC_V 220, EOSC_V 221.
prerequisite_raw: All of EOSC_V 220, EOSC_V 221.

subject: EOSC
title: Advanced Sedimentology
description: Description and interpretation of ancient and modern sediments, with emphasis on the origin, composition, textures, structures, diagenesis and chemistry of biogenic sediments. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: [EOSC320] or permission of instructor.
prerequisite_raw: [EOSC320] or permission of instructor.

subject: EOSC
title: Structural Geology II
description: Studies of natural deformation using advanced techniques. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: [EOSC323]
prerequisite_raw: [EOSC323]

subject: EOSC
title: Advanced Mineral Deposits
description: Advanced concepts in the processes that lead to the formation of mineral deposits. Introduction to the study of ore minerals using reflected light microscopy. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: EOSC 331.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 331.

subject: EOSC
title: Paleontology
description: Paleobiogeography in the context of plate tectonics. Mass extinction events. Fossilization and biases in the fossil record. Species concepts in paleontology. Biostratigraphy. Paleontological evidence for early life; the colonization of oceanic and terrestrial environments and; the evolution of the primates. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: EOSC 222.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 222.

subject: EOSC
title: Fundamentals of Geomicrobiology
description: Foundational knowledge of the interactions between microorganisms and Earth's surface chemistry. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 121, CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, EOSC 110, EOSC 112. Third year standing in Science. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 121, CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 141, EOSC 110, EOSC 112. Third year standing in Science. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Field Techniques in Groundwater Hydrology
description: Hydraulic head measurements, water-quality sampling, pump and slug testing, infiltration measurements, profiling techniques. Held over five days after spring term at the Richmond groundwater hydrology field-school site. Enrolment limitations. Prerequisite: One of EOSC 325, EOSC 329.
prerequisite_raw: One of EOSC 325, EOSC 329.

subject: EOSC
title: Groundwater Contamination
description: Contaminant transport processes in groundwater flow systems; aqueous and multiphase transport; mathematical models describing migration and chemical evolution of contaminant plumes; case studies. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: One of EOSC 325, EOSC 329.
prerequisite_raw: One of EOSC 325, EOSC 329.

subject: EOSC
title: Aqueous Geochemistry
description: Quantitative approaches to practical aqueous geochemistry problems. Equilibrium thermodynamics, kinetics, complexation, oxidation reduction, cation exchange, sorption and partitioning of organics. Case Studies. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHEM 154, SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of EOSC 325, EOSC 329.
prerequisite_raw: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHEM 154, SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of EOSC 325, EOSC 329.
corequisite_raw: One of EOSC 325, EOSC 329.

subject: EOSC
title: Groundwater Remediation
description: Methods for containment and remediation of subsurface contaminants; including groundwater control, groundwater extraction, and in situ treatment. Experience with common design approaches. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: [EOSC429]
prerequisite_raw: [EOSC429]

subject: EOSC
title: Fossil Fuels
description: Origin, geochemistry and distribution of petroleum and coal in the stratigraphic record. Sedimentation of organic matter, organic diagenesis, migration and accumulation of hydrocarbons. Principles of exploration and development. Techniques for measurement of organic maturation and source rock analyses. [2-2-0] Corequisite: EOSC 320.
corequisite_raw: EOSC 320.

subject: EOSC
title: Geological Engineering Practice I - Rock Engineering
description: Application of rock mechanics, hydrogeology, and engineering design tools in realistically complex geological environments. Influence and treatment of geological uncertainty, and use of field data, geotechnical monitoring, and numerical analyses for tunnelling, mining and rock slope engineering projects. Case histories. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: All of EOSC 329, CIVL 210, MINE 303.
prerequisite_raw: All of EOSC 329, CIVL 210, MINE 303.

subject: EOSC
title: Geological Engineering Practice II - Soil Engineering
description: Application of geomorphology, hydrogeology, and soil mechanics to geotechnical design. Influence and treatment of geological uncertainty in geotechnical hazard and risk assessments; multi-disciplinary approaches to geotechnical engineering problems in realistically complex geological environments. Case histories. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: All of EOSC 329, EOSC 330, CIVL 210.
prerequisite_raw: All of EOSC 329, EOSC 330, CIVL 210.

subject: EOSC
title: Physical Climate Modelling
description: Understanding climate models from 1D energy balance to fully coupled atmosphere-ocean general circulation models. Physics and thermodynamics of radiative balance and clouds. Spatial and temporal climate variability. Run simple climate models and analyze data from complex models. [3-0-0] Prerequisites: 3rd year class standing, and one of EOSC 211, EOSC 213, CPSC 203, CPSC 210, and MATH 200, and one of EOSC 112, ATSC 201, EOSC 340, EOSC 345, GEOS 102,GEOG 312, PHYS 333.

subject: EOSC
title: Climate Measurement and Analysis
description: Local climate time series collection and analysis. Retrieval and analysis of online climate data and model output. [0-3-0] Prerequisite: One of EOSC 340, EOSC 345 and one of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, EOSC 211, MATH 210, PHYS 210 and one of STAT 200, STAT 201, STAT 251, BIOL 300.
prerequisite_raw: One of EOSC 340, EOSC 345 and one of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, EOSC 211, MATH 210, PHYS 210 and one of STAT 200, STAT 201, STAT 251, BIOL 300.

subject: EOSC
title: Engineering Design Project
description: Geological engineering design project from scope definition to final design. Based on a problem from industry. [2*-3-0, 2*-3-0] Prerequisite: All of EOSC 323, EOSC 330, CIVL 316. Corequisite: All of EOSC 433, CIVL 410.
prerequisite_raw: All of EOSC 323, EOSC 330, CIVL 316. Corequisite: All of EOSC 433, CIVL 410.
corequisite_raw: All of EOSC 433, CIVL 410.

subject: EOSC
title: Thesis
description: For B.A.Sc. Topic to be approved by the Department. [0-3-0]

subject: EOSC
title: Thesis
description: Original research work under the direction of a faculty member. Required of all honours students. Open to major students with a satisfactory standing, appropriate background courses and permission of the course instructor and the directing faculty member.

subject: EOSC
title: Interior Structure of Earth and Planets
description: Theory, application and quantitative interpretation of potential field methods for use in exploring the interior structure of Earth and planets. Topics drawn from problems in geophysical exploration, geodesy, geodynamics, geomagnetism, planetary magnetic fields, heat flow and fluid flow. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 312, MATH 316, MATH 257 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 312, MATH 316, MATH 257 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, SCIE 001.

subject: EOSC
title: Physics of the Earth and Other Planets
description: Identification and quantitative analysis of diverse physical problems in the earth, ocean, atmospheric, and planetary sciences. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS_V 312, MATH_V 316, MATH_V 257.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS_V 312, MATH_V 316, MATH_V 257.

subject: EOSC
title: Applied Geophysics
description: Using geophysics to characterize the Earth's subsurface for resource exploration, engineering, or environmental applications. Data acquisition, processing, and interpretation of geophysical surveys. Inversion examples drawn from potential (electrical, magnetic, gravity) or wave field (seismic, ground penetrating radar) surveys. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223, and one of EOSC 211, CPSC 203, CPSC 210, and one of MATH 316, PHYS 312, EOSC 350, EOSC 352.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223, and one of EOSC 211, CPSC 203, CPSC 210, and one of MATH 316, PHYS 312, EOSC 350, EOSC 352.

subject: EOSC
title: Biological Oceanography
description: A quantitative examination of processes regulating the abundance, distribution and production of phytoplankton, zooplankton, microbes and fish. Controls of primary and secondary production, ecosystem dynamics and foodwebs. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of EOSC 372, EOSC 373.
prerequisite_raw: One of EOSC 372, EOSC 373.

subject: EOSC
title: Waves, Currents and Ocean Mixing
description: Use of observations, theory and model results to solve physical oceanographic problems including applications to transport and mixing of pollutants or nutrients. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: EOSC 211 and one of ATSC 201, EOSC 372, GEOB 200 and one of SCIE 001, PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 211 and one of ATSC 201, EOSC 372, GEOB 200 and one of SCIE 001, PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157.

subject: EOSC
title: Chemical Oceanography and Marine Geochemistry
description: Controls on chemical composition and elemental distributions in seawater and marine sediments (including nutrient elements, dissolved gases, the carbonate system, marine organic matter, and trace metals); solution chemistry of seawater; isotopic tracers of rates and dates in marine systems; geochemical balance in the oceans. [3-0-2*] Prerequisite: EOSC 373.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 373.

subject: EOSC
title: Methods in Oceanography
description: Methods of data acquisition, study and analysis required in solving oceanographic problems. Includes a field school held during the mid-term break. A fee is to be paid by January 31. Open to third- and fourth-year students in Oceanography, or with permission of the Department Head. [0-3-0] Prerequisite: One of EOSC 372, EOSC 373.
prerequisite_raw: One of EOSC 372, EOSC 373.

subject: EOSC
title: Marine Pollution
description: An interdisciplinary study of pollution, with examples drawn from coastal and oceanic environments, including areas of local interest. Intended for third and fourth-year students with a background in the sciences. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing in Science.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing in Science.

subject: EOSC
title: Marine Microbiology
description: Advanced biology, ecology and diversity of marine microbes. Emphasis on the roles of bacteria and viruses in marine foodwebs and geochemical cycles. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: A minimum of 6 credits of third-year level life science courses.
prerequisite_raw: A minimum of 6 credits of third-year level life science courses.

subject: EOSC
title: Introduction to Fisheries Science
description: An introduction to the ecology and management of freshwater and marine fisheries. Topics include: population dynamics, species interactions, communities, environmental influences, stock assessment, economics and sociology of fisheries. Laboratories will consist of numerical analyses and simulations. [2-0-3]

subject: EOSC
title: Student Directed Seminars in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences
description: Self-directed, collaborative studies in earth, ocean and atmospheric sciences, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. Prerequisite: Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university of government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Data Analysis in Atmospheric, Earth and Ocean Sciences
description: [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Numerical Techniques for Ocean, Atmosphere and Earth Scientists
description: This course is Web-based. Credit will not be granted for both ATSC 409 and ATSC 506/EOSC 511. Equivalency: ATSC506 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Advanced Geophysical Fluid Dynamics
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Imaging and estimation with wavelets
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Introduction to Geological Fluid Mechanics
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Graduate Seminar Course
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Teaching and Learning in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Science Communication and Outreach in Museum and Other Informal Learning Settings
description: Theory and best practices for effective science communication in informal learning environments; common obstacles in communicating science to children and adults; design and rhetorical theory in the context of outreach development and communication; presentation of scientific phenomena to the public. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Advanced Mineralogy
description: Crystal structure, chemistry, origin and paragenesis of major rock-forming and ore minerals. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Microbeam and Diffraction Methods for the Characterization of Minerals and Materials
description: [2-3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Methods and Modelling in Petrology and Geochemistry
description: [3-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Isotope Geology
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Problems in Paleontology
description: Seminar. Given in alternate years. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Magmatic Ore Deposits
description: Magmatic ore deposits and associated ore-forming systems with a focus on the petrology and geochemistry of mineralized intrusions and volcanic rocks. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Mechanics of Natural Deformation
description: Lectures and laboratory problems. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Instrumentation and Monitoring in Geological Engineering Practice
description: Investigative versus performance monitoring. Monitoring requirements, limitations and system support. Tactical versus strategic monitoring. Data analysis, utilization and communication. Integration of monitoring with geotechnical and groundwater modelling. Case histories. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Advanced Coal Geology
description: The origin and character of coal and associated strata. Petrology, chemistry and physical properties of coal. Sedimentology of peat, biochemical and geochemical stages of coalification and oxidation of coal. Use of organic matter as a geothermometer and inbasinal analysis. Structural analysis and character of coal deposits. Analytical methods applied to coal. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Topics in Geohazard Risk Management
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Advanced Igneous Petrology
description: Lectures, seminars and laboratories on the application of physical chemistry to the origin of igneous rocks; crystallization processes in silicate magmas; melt physical properties, heat transfer and fluid flow. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Exploration Methodology
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Field Laboratory in Groundwater Hydrology
description: Hydraulic head measurements, water-quality sampling, pump and slug testing, infiltration measurements, profiling techniques. Computer analysis of field data. Held after spring term at the Richmond groundwater hydrology field site. Enrolment limitations. Prerequisite: [EOSC533] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [EOSC533] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Groundwater Modelling in Practice
description: Models of steady-state and transient groundwater flow in the saturated and unsaturated zones; applications to regional groundwater flow, groundwater recharge, subsurface contributions to streamflow, aquifer evaluation; model calibration. Case histories. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Geological Engineering: Soils and Weak Rocks
description: Consult the credit exclusion list in the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar. https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Transport Processes in Porous Media
description: Transport of mass and heat in groundwater flow systems; modelling techniques including an introduction to the finite-element method; modelling of groundwater contamination. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Geotechnical Modelling in Practice
description: Application of geomechanics and engineering design tools in complex geological environments. Influence and treatment of geological uncertainty; use of field data, geotechnical monitoring and numerical analyses for tunnelling, mining and rock slope engineering projects. Case histories. See credit exclusion list www.vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/faculty-sc… This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Diamond Exploration
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Geochemistry of Hydrothermal Ore Deposits
description: Prerequisite: Completion of a course in Economic Geology This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Completion of a course in Economic Geology This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Advanced Groundwater Geochemistry
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Multi-component Reactive Transport Modelling in Groundwater
description: Prerequisite: Either(a) EOSC 430 or (b) EOSC 540; and EOSC 533. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either(a) EOSC 430 or (b) EOSC 540; and EOSC 533. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Advanced Volcanology
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Geodynamics
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Advanced Models in Mineral Deposits
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Advanced Field Methods in Earth Science
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Tunneling and Underground Engineering
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Graduating Paper for Masters Candidates without Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Linear Inverse Theory
description: Model construction, appraisal of nonuniqueness, and inference in linear problems. Tomographic inversions. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Streamflow Generation Mechanisms
description: Streamflow generation mechanisms, hydrologic processes, transit time distribution, environmental changes, landscape evolution and ecohydrology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Mechanics of Earthquakes and Faulting
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Paleoceanography
description: [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Methods in Oceanography
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: The Biology and Ecology of Marine Zooplanktonic Organisms
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Inorganic Chemical Tracers in the Study of Marine Systems
description: The chemical composition of seawater, cycles of gases, trace metals and radionuclides within the sea, chemical tracers in the study of water mixing, water movement and changes in ocean currents over time. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Seminal Papers in Biological Oceanography
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Dynamic Oceanography
description: Consult the Credit Exclusion List in the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar. Prerequisite: EOSC 512. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: EOSC 512. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Satellite Remote Sensing: Applications to Oceanography and Meteorology
description: A review of the satellite-sensed data products used in research and operational aspects of oceanography and meteorology. Equivalency: GEOG515 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Circulation Processes and Transport Mechanisms in Observational Oceanography
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: M.Eng. Graduating Paper
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EOSC
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: For Ph.D. (Engineering). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EPSE
title: Education in the Adolescent Years
description: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EPSE
title: Teaching Adolescents with Special Learning Needs
description: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EPSE
title: Teaching Highly Able Learners
description: Identification and appraisal of developmental and educational needs of highly able learners. [3-0]

subject: EPSE
title: Education during the Adolescent Years
description: Developmental characteristics of persons from pre-school age through adulthood. Physical, social, cognitive, moral, and emotional growth of both normal and exceptional children in grades 8-12. The teacher's role in assisting such students to deal with major developmental issues and problems. Pass/Fail. [2-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EPSE
title: Applying Developmental Theories in the Classroom
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EPSE
title: Development, Learning and Culture in the Classroom
description: This course is designed to provide teacher candidates with a broad overview of how children develop, learn and grow in diverse societies, in order to build safe, supportive, caring and respectful relationships and environments. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EPSE
title: Introduction to the Study of Exceptional Children
description: An examination of all groups of exceptional children in terms of definition, incidence, characteristics, diagnosis and treatment. Prerequisite to most other courses in Special Education. Can be taken concurrently with several other introductory courses in Special Education. [3-0]

subject: EPSE
title: Educational Application of Developmental Theories
description: Theories of human development; physical, social, cognitive, moral, and emotional developmental characteristics from infancy to adolescence; implications for educational practice with students of different age and developmental status during the elementary school years. Pass/Fail. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EPSE
title: Learning Disabilities
description: Identification, assessment and needs of children with learning disabilities. Recommended pre-requisites: one of EPSE 312, EPSE 317. [3-0-0]

subject: EPSE
title: Development and Exceptionality in the Regular Classroom
description: The teacher's role in dealing with major developmental and special educational issues and problems within the regular classroom program, including working with supportive services, parents, and communities. Designated sections will focus on early childhood, middle childhood or adolescence. Pass/Fail. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EPSE
title: Classroom Inclusion of Students who are Blind and Visually Impaired
description: Inclusion issues of students with visual impairments in general education classrooms; information about visual impairment, classroom adaptations and accommodations, and application of Universal Design. Appropriate for education majors and classroom teachers. [3-0]

subject: EPSE
title: Field Experiences with Individual Atypical Children
description: Supervised experience working with several atypical children in a community setting. Diagnosing needs, planning programs and integrating instruction and materials on an individual basis. [1-9] Prerequisite: Permission of the department is required.
prerequisite_raw: Permission of the department is required.

subject: EPSE
title: Programming in Special Education: Developing Perspective
description: An examination of the range of educational methodologies and teaching procedures and a discussion of their implications for the establishment of programs useful in working with exceptional children. The course comprises a practical examination and a detailed comparison of the major special educational methodologies. [3-1]

subject: EPSE
title: Family-Centred Practice for Children with Special Needs

subject: EPSE
title: Education and Culture in the Deaf Community
description: Designed for students intending to work with deaf persons.

subject: EPSE
title: Education of Students with Developmental Disabilities in Inclusive Settings

subject: EPSE
title: Principles of Applied Behaviour Analysis
description: Credit will be given for only one of EPSE 404 or 405. Recommended pre-requisites: one of EPSE 312, EPSE 317. [3-0-0]

subject: EPSE
title: Typical and Atypical Development in Infants and Children

subject: EPSE
title: Educational Programming for Highly Able Learners
description: Planning elementary and secondary level programs for highly able learners. [3-0]

subject: EPSE
title: Assistive Technologies in Special Education
description: The use of microcomputers, adaptive technology, and software across age levels and areas of exceptionality in special education and health care settings. [2-1]

subject: EPSE
title: Augmentative and Alternative Communication for Individuals with Severe Speech and/or Physical Impairments

subject: EPSE
title: Technology for the Visually Impaired
description: Preparation of teachers to work with a variety of technological devices designed for students who are blind or visually impaired, e.g., computers, electronic reading devices, and closed circuit television. This course is restricted to students enrolled in a program for Education of Visually Impaired Children. [2-2]

subject: EPSE
title: Assessment of Learning Difficulties
description: Theories of learning and instruction; principles and practices of diagnosis and assessment as these relate to students with relevant special needs.

subject: EPSE
title: Assessment of Classroom Learning
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EPSE
title: Provisions in the Education of the Visually Handicapped
description: Provisions, procedures and methodology in the teaching of specific curriculum for the blind and visually impaired. Life skills and adjustment to blindness. This course is restricted to students in a program of Education of Visually Impaired Children. [3-0]

subject: EPSE
title: Introduction to the Education of students Who are Deaf or Hard of Hearing
description: An introductory course focused on supporting the educational and social goals of students who are d/Deaf or hard of hearing.

subject: EPSE
title: Programming for Children with Specific Learning Disabilities
description: Methods and programs for learning disabilities are reviewed. Practical experience in the development and execution of a remedial program is required. [3-0] Prerequisite: [EPSE316]
prerequisite_raw: [EPSE316]

subject: EPSE
title: Assessment and Positive Behavioural Support in School and Community Settings

subject: EPSE
title: Survey of Behaviour Disorders in Children and Adolescents

subject: EPSE
title: Interventions for Children and Adolescents with Behaviour Disorders

subject: EPSE
title: Introduction to Orientation and Mobility for the Blind
description: Understanding the process of teaching independent travel to blind students, including orientation and mobility skills in school. Restricted to students enrolled in a program for Education of Visually Impaired Children or those who hold the Diploma or the equivalent. [2-2]

subject: EPSE
title: Advanced Orientation and Mobility Techniques
description: Recommended pre-requisite: EPSE 455. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: EPSE
title: Human Development in Education
description: Investigates selected concepts of developmental theory in terms of their influence upon teaching and learning. The course will explore development in a wide range of domains including: social, physical, emotional and cognitive development.

subject: EPSE
title: Introduction to Research in Education
description: The nature of scientific study and essentials of survey, experimental and other empirical research designs. Designed for students proceeding to graduate work. Prerequisite: EPSE 482 must be taken prior to or at the same time as EPSE 481.
prerequisite_raw: EPSE 482 must be taken prior to or at the same time as EPSE 481.

subject: EPSE
title: Introduction to Statistics for Research in Education
description: Basic concepts and principles of descriptive and inferential statistics. Designed for students proceeding to graduate work involving quantitative methodology. [3-0] Prerequisite: Proficiency in modern high school algebra. Equivalency: STAT 200, 203, BIOL 300, COMM 191, ECON 325, 327, FRST 231, GEOG 374, KIN 371, POLI 380, PSYC 218, 27, 366, SOCI 328
prerequisite_raw: Proficiency in modern high school algebra. Equivalency: STAT 200, 203, BIOL 300, COMM 191, ECON 325, 327, FRST 231, GEOG 374, KIN 371, POLI 380, PSYC 218, 27, 366, SOCI 328

subject: EPSE
title: Reading and Interpreting Research in Education
description: Introductory research methods course for students who wish to be critical readers rather than producers of educational research. Develops skills for locating, understanding, interpreting and critiquing educational empirical research. May not be used as a prerequisite to EPSE 592 or EPSE 596. [3-0] Prerequisite: Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… before registering.
prerequisite_raw: Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… before registering.

subject: EPSE
title: Nonparametric and Related Statistics
description: Distribution-free statistical techniques for analysis of ranked data, and analysis of discrete observations. [3-0] Prerequisite: [EPSE482]
prerequisite_raw: [EPSE482]
