description: Identification of preventive strategies in different age groups and their implementation in Family Practice. Examination of health belief models in caregivers and patients which inhibit or facilitate preventive measures. Admission to course at discretion of the Department of Family Practice. Prerequisite: [HCEP502] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [HCEP502] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FMST
title: Family Context of Human Development
description: The influence of family dynamics and social conditions on human development.

subject: FMST
title: Family Resource Management
description: Conceptual models of resource management as related to families.

subject: FMST
title: Parent-child Relationships
description: Parent-child interaction over the life span. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SOCI 200, FMST 210.

subject: FMST
title: Relationship Development
description: The study of the development, course, and decline of personal relationships. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SOCI 200, PSYC 100, PSYC 101, PSYC 102, SOCI 240.

subject: FMST
title: Human Sexuality
description: An examination of human sexual development and behaviour. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SOCI 200, PSYC 100, PSYC 101, PSYC 102, SOCI 240.

subject: FMST
title: Social Context of Child Development
description: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment affect the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes. Credit will be granted for only one of FMST 441 or SOWK 441. Credit will be granted for only one of FMST 441 or SOWK 441. Equivalency: SOWK 441
exclusion_raw: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment affect the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes. Credit will be granted for only one of FMST 441 or SOWK 441. Credit will be granted for only one of FMST 441 or SOWK 441. Equivalency: SOWK 441

subject: FMST
title: Family Development
description: An examination of research and theory on the timing and sequencing of the course of family life in North American families. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNEL
title: Introduction to the Haida Language I
description: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of this language is assumed. Not offered every year.

subject: FNEL
title: Introduction to the Haida Language II
description: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Prerequisite must be in same language. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: FNEL 151.
prerequisite_raw: FNEL 151.

subject: FNEL
title: Introduction to the Ktunaxa (Kootenay) Language I
description: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of this language is assumed. Not offered every year.

subject: FNEL
title: Introduction to the Ktunaxa (Kootenay) Language II
description: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Prerequisite must be in same language. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: FNEL 161.
prerequisite_raw: FNEL 161.

subject: FNEL
title: Introduction to Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
description: Foundational concepts in the critical study of cultural, historical, social, and political factors that impact language loss, retention, and revival. Introducing strategies and practical methodologies for collaborative, interdisciplinary, community-based documentation and revitalization projects for First Nations and Indigenous languages. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNEL
title: Intermediate Haida Language I
description: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Prerequisite must be in same language. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: FNEL 152.
prerequisite_raw: FNEL 152.

subject: FNEL
title: Intermediate Haida Language II
description: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Prerequisite must be in same language. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: FNEL 251.
prerequisite_raw: FNEL 251.

subject: FNEL
title: Intermediate Ktunaxa (Kootenay) Language I
description: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Prerequisite must be in same language. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: FNEL 162.
prerequisite_raw: FNEL 162.

subject: FNEL
title: Intermediate Ktunaxa Language II
description: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Prerequisite must be in same language. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: FNEL 261.
prerequisite_raw: FNEL 261.

subject: FNEL
title: Sounds of Endangered Languages: Conservation and Revitalization
description: Development of skills in the perception and transcription of speech sounds in endangered languages, focusing on the diversity within BC Indigenous languages. Capacity-building techniques for digital recording, editing, analysis, and archiving; guided by community-based ethical protocols and conservation/revitalization goals. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNEL
title: Structures of Endangered Languages: Conservation and Revitalization
description: Development of skills in the documentation, transcription and analysis of grammatical structures in endangered languages, focusing on the diversity within BC Indigenous languages. Applied techniques in documentation, workflow and multi-media digital annotation, guided by community-based ethical protocols and conservation/revitalization goals. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNEL
title: Technologies for Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
description: Digital tools for endangered language documentation, conservation, and revitalization. Overview of best practices, introduction to community engagement and capacity-building, protocols and ethics, project design, cultural context, orthographies, use of audio, video and still photography, data management, archiving and web publishing. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNEL
title: Biocultural Diversity: Language, Community, and Environment
description: Critical exploration of the links between linguistic, biological and cultural diversity; including connections with linguistic relativity, linguistic identity, language and place; and strategies for collective, interdisciplinary action to promote and support the protection of languages, cultures, and the environment. Restricted to Undergraduate Students.

subject: FNEL
title: Lexicography for Endangered Languages
description: Foundational concepts in the discipline of compiling, editing, managing and hosting dictionaries, also known as lexicography. Special focus on the technical and ethical considerations for community-based lexicography projects for endangered and BC First Nations languages. Restricted to Undergraduate Students.

subject: FNEL
title: Collaborative Heritage Research in First Nations Languages: Practicum and Workshop
description: Hands-on experience planning and producing a Breath of Life Language Reclamation Workshop for endangered BC First Nations languages, during which community-based researchers access and interpret relevant heritage resources at UBC and other local institutions for the revitalization of their languages. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Corequisites must be in same language. Corequisite: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 389.
corequisite_raw: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 389.

subject: FNEL
title: Heritage Resources in Endangered First Nations Language Revitalization
description: Examines the complementary and intersecting roles of libraries, archives, and museums in collections acquisition, development, curation, preservation, and access traditions pertaining to First Nations languages, to explore how each can contribute to endangered language and cultural heritage sustainability. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite must be in same language. Prerequisite: One of FNEL 180, FNEL 281, FNEL 282. or permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FNEL 180, FNEL 281, FNEL 282. or permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNEL
title: Applied Research in Endangered Language Reclamation
description: Application of research skills and methodologies in the design and implementation of a research project relevant to endangered language conservation and/or revitalization. Project co-constructed in collaboration with a First Nations community, guided by community-based ethical protocols. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Pre-requisite must be in same language. Recommended pre-requisite: FNEL 481. Corequisite: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282, FNEL 389. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 482. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282, FNEL 389. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 482. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNEL
title: Indigenous Languages of BC: Diversity and Vitality
description: Genetic affiliation, areal contact, typological diversity, and initiatives to sustain the vitality and diversity of BC First Nations Languages. Restricted to Undergraduate Students.

subject: FNH
title: Integrated Physiology for Human Nutrition I
description: Basic principles in human physiology, including function of the nervous, endocrine, musculoskeletal and digestive systems, integration across systems, maintenance of homeostasis, and application to human nutrition. Prerequisite: One of CHEM 11, CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, ATPH 12, BIOL 12, BIOL 111. FNH 160 and 161 together are credit-excluded with BIOL 153 and 155.
prerequisite_raw: One of CHEM 11, CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, ATPH 12, BIOL 12, BIOL 111. FNH 160 and 161 together are credit-excluded with BIOL 153 and 155.

subject: FNH
title: Integrated Physiology for Human Nutrition II
description: Basic principles in human physiology, including function of the cardiovascular, immune, respiratory, urinary and reproductive systems, integration across systems, maintenance of homeostasis, and application to human nutrition. Prerequisite: FNH 160. FNH 160 and 161 together are credit-excluded with BIOL 153 and 155.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 160. FNH 160 and 161 together are credit-excluded with BIOL 153 and 155.

subject: FNH
title: Exploring Our Food
description: Chemical and physical properties of foods; issues pertaining to safety, nutritive value and consumer acceptability; government regulations pertaining to food safety, quality and additives; preservation techniques and transformation of agricultural commodities to food products; foods of the future. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: At least second year standing required.
prerequisite_raw: At least second year standing required.

subject: FNH
title: Nutrition Concepts and Controversies
description: Fundamental concepts and principles of human nutrition applied to current nutrition issues. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FNH 160, FNH 161 or (b) one of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155 or (c) all of KIN 131, KIN 132. At least second-year standing required.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FNH 160, FNH 161 or (b) one of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155 or (c) all of KIN 131, KIN 132. At least second-year standing required.

subject: FNH
title: Food Engineering
description: Units and dimensions, mass balance, energy balance, steady state and transient heat flow, fluid handling and measurement. Prerequisite: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 170.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 170.

subject: FNH
title: Food Chemistry
description: Chemical and physical properties and reactions of food constituents, including water, carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, minerals and vitamins. Prerequisite: Either CHEM_V 203 or CHEM_V 233.
prerequisite_raw: Either CHEM_V 203 or CHEM_V 233.

subject: FNH
title: Food Analysis
description: Principles of and procedures for analysis of the chemical and physical properties of food; proximate analysis; introduction to instrumental analysis; reporting and analysis of data. Prerequisite: Either (a) CHEM_V 205, (b) CHEM_V 210, or (c) CHEM_V 211; and either (a) CHEM_V 203 or (b) CHEM_V 233.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) CHEM_V 205, (b) CHEM_V 210, or (c) CHEM_V 211; and either (a) CHEM_V 203 or (b) CHEM_V 233.

subject: FNH
title: Food Product Development
description: Introduction to and application of concepts involved in food product formulation and development. Prerequisite: One of LFS 252, BIOL 300, EPSE 482, FRST 231, STAT 200. FNH 301 recommended.
prerequisite_raw: One of LFS 252, BIOL 300, EPSE 482, FRST 231, STAT 200. FNH 301 recommended.

subject: FNH
title: Food Processing
description: Preservation of tissue and fluid food systems by selected physical and chemical treatments with emphasis on product-process interactions. Prerequisite: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100, PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 170.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100, PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 170.

subject: FNH
title: Food Microbiology
description: Roles of microorganisms in food production, preservation, spoilage, and foodborne disease; factors affecting growth, survival and inactivation of microorganisms in foods; methods for identifying, enumerating, and eliminating microorganisms in food-production environments. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 112. third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 112. third-year standing.

subject: FNH
title: Food Science Laboratory I
description: Laboratory techniques used in food chemistry, microbiology and processing; statistical analysis and presentation of experimental data; scientific report writing. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students. Prerequisite: FNH 200. Corequisite: All of FNH 301, FNH 309, FNH 313.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 200. Corequisite: All of FNH 301, FNH 309, FNH 313.
corequisite_raw: All of FNH 301, FNH 309, FNH 313.

subject: FNH
title: Food Science Laboratory II
description: Laboratory techniques used in food analysis, food processing, sensory science and product development; statistical analysis and presentation of experimental data; scientific report writing. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students. Prerequisite: FNH 325. Corequisite: All of FNH 302, FNH 303.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 325. Corequisite: All of FNH 302, FNH 303.
corequisite_raw: All of FNH 302, FNH 303.

subject: FNH
title: Introduction to Wine Science I
description: Principles of viticulture, enology, and wine microbiology and chemistry; marketing, regulation and classification of wines from selected regions of the world; social, economic and health aspects of wine consumption; wine appreciation. Prerequisite: Third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing or higher.

subject: FNH
title: Introduction to Wine Science II
description: Review of diverse styles of wine with consideration of classic wine-producing areas. Concepts in wine microbiology/chemistry; overview of steps in grape processing for diverse wine styles. Comparison of regulations for Canadian VQA systems with international systems. Wine sensory analysis. [3-1-0] Prerequisite: FNH 330. and third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 330. and third-year standing or higher.

subject: FNH
title: Food Theory Applications
description: Experimental and practical application of scientific principles and theories to problems of food preparation. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe I certificate. [0-3-0] Corequisite: FNH 340. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: FNH 340. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Critical Perspectives on Consumer Food Practices
description: Personal, collective, and policy factors affecting food choices, including perceptions of healthy eating, gender, identity, family structures, and economic, sociocultural, and political forces. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: At least third year standing required.
prerequisite_raw: At least third year standing required.

subject: FNH
title: Counselling Skills in Dietetics
description: Counselling in dietetics: communication theory and foundational counselling skills. Prerequisite: FNH 370. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 370. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Fundamentals of Nutrition
description: Fundamentals of energy and macronutrient metabolism. Prerequisite: FNH_V 250 and one of BIOL_V 201, BIOC_V 202, BIOC_V 203.
prerequisite_raw: FNH_V 250 and one of BIOL_V 201, BIOC_V 202, BIOC_V 203.

subject: FNH
title: Vitamins, Minerals, and Health
description: Vitamin and mineral nutrition and their role in maintaining and promoting health. Prerequisite: FNH_V 250 and one of BIOL_V 201, BIOC_V 202, BIOC_V 203.
prerequisite_raw: FNH_V 250 and one of BIOL_V 201, BIOC_V 202, BIOC_V 203.

subject: FNH
title: International Nutrition
description: Conceptualization and scientific analyses of global problems in food and nutrition; complexities of food habits and malnutrition in various cultures around the world. [3-0-0]

subject: FNH
title: Nutrition Assessment
description: The use of dietary, anthropometric, biochemical, and related information for the assessment of nutritional status of individuals and populations. Prerequisite: FNH 250.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 250.

subject: FNH
title: Human Nutrition Over The Life Span
description: Nutritional requirements and dietary patterns of healthy individuals throughout the life span. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: FNH 250.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 250.

subject: FNH
title: Nutrition Care I
description: Fundamentals of nutrition care: the nutrition care process (NCP), documentation, nutritional risk and nutritional status assessment, metabolic stress, supplements, pharmacology, and body weight. NCP applied to food allergies and intolerances, gastrointestinal symptoms. Introduction to chronic diseases. Restricted to students in year 3 of the dietetics major. Prerequisite: All of FNH_V 350, FNH_V 370 and either (a) one of BIOL_V 153, BIOL_V 155, CAPS_V 301 or (b) all of FNH_V 160 and FNH_V 161. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of FNH_V 350, FNH_V 370 and either (a) one of BIOL_V 153, BIOL_V 155, CAPS_V 301 or (b) all of FNH_V 160 and FNH_V 161. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Professional Dietetic Practice I
description: Introduction to the profession of dietetics in Canada. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the Dietetics Major. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing in the Dietetics Major. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Dietetics Practice Education Placement I
description: Practice education placements in settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Prerequisite: All of FNH 375, FNH 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of FNH 375, FNH 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Research Methods in Human Nutrition
description: Process of research; principles and processes in utilizing research. Restricted to students in majors in the FNH program. Prerequisite: FNH 250 and either (a) LFS 252 or (b) BIOL 300 or (c) EPSE 482 or (d) FRST 231 or (e) STAT 200.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 250 and either (a) LFS 252 or (b) BIOL 300 or (c) EPSE 482 or (d) FRST 231 or (e) STAT 200.

subject: FNH
title: Advances in Plant and Cell-Based Foods
description: Examination of meat, egg, fish, and dairy analogues made using plants, recombinant proteins, and cell cultures, from the molecular to the macroscopic level. Relation of molecular details to physical and sensory properties. Health and sustainability impacts. Prerequisite: FNH 301 and 3rd-year standing or higher, or permission from the instructor.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 301 and 3rd-year standing or higher, or permission from the instructor.

subject: FNH
title: Functional Foods
description: Functional food concepts related to efficacy and safety; examples of bioactive component-disease relationships; natural health products; approval of functional food and health claims; the importance of clinical studies in support of efficacy for health claims; market determinants of functional foods. Prerequisite: One of BIOL_V 201, BIOC_V 202, BIOC_V 203, and third-year standing. Equivalency: PHAR_V 431
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL_V 201, BIOC_V 202, BIOC_V 203, and third-year standing. Equivalency: PHAR_V 431

subject: FNH
title: Food Laws, Regulations and Quality Assurance
description: Canadian and international laws governing food composition, grading, quality and safety; hazard analysis critical control points; statistical quality assurance. Prerequisite: One of LFS_V 252, STAT_V 200, FRST_V 231, BIOL_V 300, EPSE_V 482, or equivalent background in statistics.
prerequisite_raw: One of LFS_V 252, STAT_V 200, FRST_V 231, BIOL_V 300, EPSE_V 482, or equivalent background in statistics.

subject: FNH
title: Food Safety and Quality Management
description: Food production plant sanitation, environmental monitoring, global food safety standards, and food plant internal audits. Prerequisite: FNH 403.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 403.

subject: FNH
title: Microbiology of Food and Beverage Fermentation
description: Fermentation methods, mechanism and microbiology of nonalcoholic fermented foods and alcoholic fermented beverages (beer, cider, sake). Prerequisite: One of MICB_V 211, MICB_V 212, BIOL_V 201, BIOL_V 203, BIOC_V 202, BIOC_V 203. Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: One of MICB_V 211, MICB_V 212, BIOL_V 201, BIOL_V 203, BIOC_V 202, BIOC_V 203. Third-year standing.

subject: FNH
title: Food Safety
description: Microbial and chemical factors that underlie public health challenges in the food supply chain; prevalence and nature of organisms which cause foodborne diseases; approaches and technologies for improvement of food safety. Prerequisite: One of MICB_V 211, MICB_V 212, CHEM_V 233, FNH_V 313.
prerequisite_raw: One of MICB_V 211, MICB_V 212, CHEM_V 233, FNH_V 313.

subject: FNH
title: Sustainability in the Food Industry
description: Regenerative sustainability and the sustainability nexus; health and environmental impacts of the food industry; environmental performance indicators and management systems; approaches to enhance sustainability in the food industry. Prerequisite: One of FNH 309, FNH 313.
prerequisite_raw: One of FNH 309, FNH 313.

subject: FNH
title: Business Concepts in Food, Nutrition, and Health
description: Introduction to and application of business activities in food, nutrition, and health settings. Credit will only be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515, or FRE 515. Prerequisite: At least third-year standing in the Faculty of Land and Food Systems.
prerequisite_raw: At least third-year standing in the Faculty of Land and Food Systems.

subject: FNH
title: Interfacial Phenomena
description: Outline of the physics and chemistry of interfaces; discussion of the part played by surface effects in technical processes. Credit will be granted for only one of FNH 419 and FOOD 519. Prerequisite: FNH 300. or equivalent. Equivalency: CHBE 487
prerequisite_raw: FNH 300. or equivalent. Equivalency: CHBE 487
exclusion_raw: Outline of the physics and chemistry of interfaces; discussion of the part played by surface effects in technical processes. Credit will be granted for only one of FNH 419 and FOOD 519. Prerequisite: FNH 300. or equivalent. Equivalency: CHBE 487

subject: FNH
title: Food Science Laboratory III
description: Integrated course designed to illustrate principles of research and product development in the food industry. [0-3-1] Prerequisite: All of FNH 325, FNH 326.
prerequisite_raw: All of FNH 325, FNH 326.

subject: FNH
title: Enology and Wine Biotechnology
description: Yeasts and bacteria involved in wine making, metabolic pathways leading to the production of flavour and spoilage compounds, genetic improvement of wine yeasts, and red and white wine fermentations. Approaches and technologies for the improvement of wine safety. Sensory evaluation of wines. Prerequisite: One of BIOL 335, MICB 325, FNH 313, BIOC 302.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 335, MICB 325, FNH 313, BIOC 302.

subject: FNH
title: Integrated Functional Genomics
description: Global transcript, protein and metabolite profiling technologies, their integration, application, and furtherance of our understanding of how higher organisms function in general. Prerequisite: BIOL 335. Equivalency: BIOL436
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 335. Equivalency: BIOL436

subject: FNH
title: Food Service Systems Management
description: Management responsibilities in quantity food production with emphasis on menu planning, purchasing and service. Includes planning and equipping food services. Restricted to students in the Dietetics major. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe II certificate. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: FNH 340. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 340. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Nutrient Metabolism and Implications for Health
description: Integration of nutrient and energy metabolism on a whole-body and individual tissue basis and the implication for health. Emphasis will be on regulation of nutrient metabolism. Prerequisite: FNH_V 350, one of BIOC_V 302 or BIOC_V 303, and either (a) one of BIOL_V 153, BIOL_V 155, CAPS_V 301 or (b) all of FNH_V 160 and FNH_V 161.
prerequisite_raw: FNH_V 350, one of BIOC_V 302 or BIOC_V 303, and either (a) one of BIOL_V 153, BIOL_V 155, CAPS_V 301 or (b) all of FNH_V 160 and FNH_V 161.

subject: FNH
title: Fish Nutrition
description: Physiology of digestion and excretion, nutrient requirements, sources of nutrients, diet formulation, feeding management. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: [FNH 350]

subject: FNH
title: Applied International Nutrition
description: Applying nutrition concepts and principles in addressing problems of malnutrition and food insecurity in international settings. Basics of developing culturally acceptable, sustainable nutrition intervention programs. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: FNH 355. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 355. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Nutrition Care II
description: Enteral nutrition, parenteral nutrition, and the nutrition care process are applied to select diseases or conditions, including trauma, surgery, critical care, respiratory diseases, gastrointestinal diseases, liver diseases, and diseases of the gallbladder and exocrine pancreas. Restricted to students in year 4 of the dietetics major. Prerequisite: All of FNH_V 371, FNH_V 375. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of FNH_V 371, FNH_V 375. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Maternal and Fetal Nutrition
description: Metabolic adaptations, nutrient metabolism, and special issues during pregnancy that may influence the maternal-fetal nutritional supply. [3-0-0] Corequisite: FNH 350. Third-year standing.
corequisite_raw: FNH 350. Third-year standing.

subject: FNH
title: Applied Public Health Nutrition
description: Theory and methods in public health nutrition and health promotion program planning to assess, plan, implement, and evaluate nutrition-related programs for communities and populations. Considers factors affecting behavior and the social determinants of health. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: FNH 250 and fourth-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 250 and fourth-year standing.

subject: FNH
title: Sport Nutrition
description: Nutritional needs of athletes, including energy, carbohydrate and protein; hydration; pre-and post-event nutrition, weight management and body composition issues; ergogenic aids; sports-specific guidelines; and special athlete populations. Prerequisite: All of FNH 350, FNH 351.
prerequisite_raw: All of FNH 350, FNH 351.

subject: FNH
title: Nutrition Care III
description: Nutrition care process applied to select diseases and conditions including dysphagia, cancer, neurological conditions, metabolic syndrome, eating disorders, cardiovascular diseases, endocrine diseases, and renal diseases. Restricted to students in year 4 of the dietetics major. Prerequisite: All of BIOC_V 302, FNH_V 470. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of BIOC_V 302, FNH_V 470. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Nutrition and Disease Prevention
description: Evidence-based examination of the role of nutrition in the prevention of chronic disease. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: FNH 398.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 398.

subject: FNH
title: Professional Dietetic Practice II
description: Skill development and application for practice education placements and dietetic practice settings. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Prerequisite: All of FNH 380, FNH 381. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of FNH 380, FNH 381. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Dietetics Practice Education Placement II
description: Practice education placements in settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: All of FNH 380, FNH 381, FNH 480. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of FNH 380, FNH 381, FNH 480. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Dietetics Practice Education Placement III
description: Practice education placements in settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: FNH 481. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 481. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Dietetics Practice Education Placement IV
description: Practice education placements in settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: FNH 482. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: FNH 482. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNH
title: Undergraduate Thesis
description: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to preparation of a thesis. Prerequisite: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year.
prerequisite_raw: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year.

subject: FNIS
title: Indigenous Politics and Self-Determination
description: The cultural, historical, political, economic, and gender dynamics that structure the relationship between Indigenous peoples and the state in Canada; Indigenous self-determination struggles in relation to constitutional recognition, self-government, land claims, and economic development. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, or FNSP 210. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Recommended pre-requisite: FNIS 100.
exclusion_raw: The cultural, historical, political, economic, and gender dynamics that structure the relationship between Indigenous peoples and the state in Canada; Indigenous self-determination struggles in relation to constitutional recognition, self-government, land claims, and economic development. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, or FNSP 210. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Recommended pre-requisite: FNIS 100.

subject: FNIS
title: Representation and Indigenous Cultural Politics
description: Representation, identity, and cultural politics through Indigenous literature, film, and the visual arts; the relationship between these sites of cultural production and the self-determination struggles of Indigenous peoples. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 200, FNIS 220, or FNSP 220. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Recommended pre-requisite: FNIS 100
exclusion_raw: Representation, identity, and cultural politics through Indigenous literature, film, and the visual arts; the relationship between these sites of cultural production and the self-determination struggles of Indigenous peoples. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 200, FNIS 220, or FNSP 220. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Recommended pre-requisite: FNIS 100

subject: FNIS
title: Writing First Nations
description: writing-intensive course examining approaches to writing Indigenous research: Representation & the Other; Indigenous critiques of research & representation; Indigenous, feminist and cultural studies approaches to writing ethnography, oral history, and related research methods. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS_V 300 or FNSP_V 300. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: Either (a) one of FNIS_V 210, FNIS_V 220 or (b) one of FNSP_V 210, FNSP_V 220. Equivalency: FNSP_V 300. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) one of FNIS_V 210, FNIS_V 220 or (b) one of FNSP_V 210, FNSP_V 220. Equivalency: FNSP_V 300. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: writing-intensive course examining approaches to writing Indigenous research: Representation & the Other; Indigenous critiques of research & representation; Indigenous, feminist and cultural studies approaches to writing ethnography, oral history, and related research methods. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS_V 300 or FNSP_V 300. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: Either (a) one of FNIS_V 210, FNIS_V 220 or (b) one of FNSP_V 210, FNSP_V 220. Equivalency: FNSP_V 300. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNIS
title: Critical Indigenous Theory Seminar
description: Adapting and integrating current conceptual paradigms in the humanities, social sciences, performing arts, and Indigenous studies into approaches in First Nations/Indigenous Studies, including identity construction, political and cultural self-determination, representation, essentialism/authenticity, ethics, and decolonization. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 310 or FNSP 310. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: Either (a) FNSP 200 or (b) all of FNIS 210, FNIS 220 or (c) all of FNSP 210, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) FNSP 200 or (b) all of FNIS 210, FNIS 220 or (c) all of FNSP 210, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Adapting and integrating current conceptual paradigms in the humanities, social sciences, performing arts, and Indigenous studies into approaches in First Nations/Indigenous Studies, including identity construction, political and cultural self-determination, representation, essentialism/authenticity, ethics, and decolonization. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 310 or FNSP 310. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: Either (a) FNSP 200 or (b) all of FNIS 210, FNIS 220 or (c) all of FNSP 210, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNIS
title: Critical Indigenous Methodologies and Ethics
description: Responsible and community-based research from a critical Indigenous perspective; methods for identifying and assessing research materials, critical analysis, oral history/qualitative research interviewing and analysis, and research ethics in the design and implementation of community-based student research projects. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 320 or FNSP 320. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: Either (a) FNIS 310 or (b) FNSP 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) FNIS 310 or (b) FNSP 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Responsible and community-based research from a critical Indigenous perspective; methods for identifying and assessing research materials, critical analysis, oral history/qualitative research interviewing and analysis, and research ethics in the design and implementation of community-based student research projects. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 320 or FNSP 320. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: Either (a) FNIS 310 or (b) FNSP 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNIS
title: Practicum/Advanced Research Seminar
description: Applied research/community oriented project designed and implemented in collaboration with student, faculty and Aboriginal community organization. Emphasis on examining ethical issues and developing culturally respectful and academically rigorous forms of research. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS_V 400 or FNSP_V 400. Restricted to Majors in First Nations and Indigenous Studies. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FNIS_V 310, FNIS_V 320 or (b) all of FNSP_V 310, FNSP_V 320. Students must pass FNIS_V 320 or FNSP_V 320 with a B- or higher or request program approval. Equivalency: FNSP_V 400. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FNIS_V 310, FNIS_V 320 or (b) all of FNSP_V 310, FNSP_V 320. Students must pass FNIS_V 320 or FNSP_V 320 with a B- or higher or request program approval. Equivalency: FNSP_V 400. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Applied research/community oriented project designed and implemented in collaboration with student, faculty and Aboriginal community organization. Emphasis on examining ethical issues and developing culturally respectful and academically rigorous forms of research. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS_V 400 or FNSP_V 400. Restricted to Majors in First Nations and Indigenous Studies. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FNIS_V 310, FNIS_V 320 or (b) all of FNSP_V 310, FNSP_V 320. Students must pass FNIS_V 320 or FNSP_V 320 with a B- or higher or request program approval. Equivalency: FNSP_V 400. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNIS
title: Indigenous Feminisms
description: The historical, cultural, political, and activist roots of contemporary Indigenous feminisms. Indigenous feminist methodologies, theory, and praxis in relation to contemporary Indigenous politics and social justice movements. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 401D, FNIS 451, or FNSP 451. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The historical, cultural, political, and activist roots of contemporary Indigenous feminisms. Indigenous feminist methodologies, theory, and praxis in relation to contemporary Indigenous politics and social justice movements. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 401D, FNIS 451, or FNSP 451. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNIS
title: Indigenous Social Movements
description: Draws on Indigenous and non-Indigenous intellectual traditions to explore the theoretical, cultural, political, economic, and historical bases of Indigenous peoples decolonization struggles in Canada. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 401A, FNIS 452, or FNSP 452. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Draws on Indigenous and non-Indigenous intellectual traditions to explore the theoretical, cultural, political, economic, and historical bases of Indigenous peoples decolonization struggles in Canada. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 401A, FNIS 452, or FNSP 452. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNIS
title: Indigenous Legal Traditions
description: Socio-historical, political and cultural context of Indigenous legal traditions and strategies for ethical engagement within state and Indigenous polities. Methods include oral history analysis, legal theory, literary/narrative studies, and philosophy from an Indigenous studies perspective. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNIS
title: Indigenous New Media
description: New media and digital storytelling works designed and implemented by Indigenous artists, authors, and programmers. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNIS
title: Indigenous Geographies: Our Home on Native Land
description: Indigenous people's place-based relations, colonial processes of de-territorialization, and spatial negotiations of settler colonialism. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FNIS 100, FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FNIS
title: Indigenous Two-Spirit and Queer Studies
description: Cultural contexts, scholarship, literature, and artistic expressions of Queer, LGBTI, and Two-Spirited Indigenous people, both as an academic area of study and as lived experience and relationship. Restricted to Undergraduate Students. Prerequisite: One of FNIS 100, FNIS 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 200, FNSP 210, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FNIS 100, FNIS 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 200, FNSP 210, FNSP 220. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Sustainable Forest Management in a Changing World
description: Origins of sustainable forest management; criteria and indicators of sustainable forest management used globally and how these will need to be adapted to our changing climate. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Geomatics in Forestry: Data Collection and Management
description: Fundamental concepts of spatial technologies and geo-spatial analysis. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Introduction to Urban Forestry in the Asian Pacific Region
description: Principles behind urban forest governance, urban forest planning and green-space management, and their role in human health and wellbeing in the Asia-Pacific Region. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Climate Modelling and Forest Applications
description: Potential impacts of climate change on global forest systems. Concepts and techniques of climate change modelling; adaptive management strategies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Structure and Composition of Tropical Forest Ecosystems
description: Ecological characteristics of tropical forests including their structure and composition. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Ecological Processes in Tropical Forests
description: The ecological processes found in tropical humid and dry forests, including a series of case studies drawn from tropical forests around the world. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: International Forestry Issues, Institutions, and Multilateral Agreements
description: Major contemporary global natural resources management issues emphasis on Forestry. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Forest Ecosystem Services and Community Livelihoods
description: Interdependence and dynamics of different forest ecosystem services and how they contribute to sustainable forest management and community livelihoods. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Introduction to Intensive Plantation Forestry
description: Case studies of plantation forestry systems from around the world; advantages and challenges of intensively managed forests. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Plantation Silviculture
description: Science of cultivating forest stands, including influence of climate and soil, characteristics of tree growth and stand development, and forest types and plantation designs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Wood Properties and Products
description: Manufacturing processes, applications and supply chains of solid wood, composite, and engineered wood products; pulp and paper, bio-based materials and bioenergy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Forest Economics
description: General and forestry-specific economic principles and concepts, including role of forests in sustainable development. Prerequisite: All of FOPE 509, FOPE 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of FOPE 509, FOPE 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Forest Finance
description: Theoretical and technical skills to analyze corporate financial management in the forest industry, including analytical tools to analyze cost and benefit, evaluate risk, and identify optimum investment. Prerequisite: All of FOPE 509, FOPE 510. Corequisite: FOPE 512. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of FOPE 509, FOPE 510. Corequisite: FOPE 512. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: FOPE 512. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPE
title: Forest Business Enterprise
description: Foundations of forest business enterprises (FBEs), including their role in forest management, interactions with stakeholders, and the drivers of successes and failures in FBEs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FOPR
title: Introduction to Forest Operations
description: Basic geomatics, surveying and forest operations. [2-4-0]

subject: FOPR
title: Harvesting Systems and Forest Access
description: The mechanics and productivity of a broad range of forest harvesting systems combined with topics on forest access. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of ECON_V 101, FRST_V 101. Corequisite: FRST_V 318.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON_V 101, FRST_V 101. Corequisite: FRST_V 318.
corequisite_raw: FRST_V 318.

subject: FOPR
title: Analytical Methods in Forest Hydrology
description: Analytical methods in forest hydrology and their applications in the planning of forest operations with a focus on the hydrologic and hydraulic design procedures for stream crossings. [3-2] Corequisite: FOPR 264.
corequisite_raw: FOPR 264.

subject: FOPR
title: Operational Planning and Management
description: A comprehensive overview of operational planning, financial and contractual management. Includes an experiential learning opportunity that focuses on critical thinking and teamwork. These skills combined with the theoretical course content are applied in a practical application with an external stakeholder. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: FOPR 362.
prerequisite_raw: FOPR 362.

subject: FREN
title: Beginners' French I
description: Basic vocabulary, the rudiments of grammar and familiarization with cultures of the French-speaking world. This course is aligned with level A1 objectives of the CEFR. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN 101 or FREN 103.
exclusion_raw: Basic vocabulary, the rudiments of grammar and familiarization with cultures of the French-speaking world. This course is aligned with level A1 objectives of the CEFR. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN 101 or FREN 103.

subject: FREN
title: Beginners' French II
description: A continuation of FREN 101. This course is aligned with level A1 objectives of the CEFR. Credits will be granted for only one of FREN 102 or FREN 103. Recommended pre-requisite: FREN 101.

subject: FREN
title: Intensive Beginners' French
description: Fundamentals of the French language. Recommended for students who are not complete beginners in French. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives. Credit will be granted for FREN 103 or both FREN 101, FREN 102.

subject: FREN
title: Elementary French I
description: Continued improvement in listening, speaking, reading and writing. This course is aligned with level A2 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN 11, FREN_V 102, or assignment based on placement test. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 201 or FREN_V 111. Equivalency: FREN_V 111
exclusion_raw: Continued improvement in listening, speaking, reading and writing. This course is aligned with level A2 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN 11, FREN_V 102, or assignment based on placement test. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 201 or FREN_V 111. Equivalency: FREN_V 111

subject: FREN
title: Elementary French II
description: A continuation of FREN_V 201. This course aligned with level A2 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN_V 111, FREN_V 201, or assignment based on placement test. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 202 or FREN_V 112. Equivalency: FREN_V 112.
exclusion_raw: A continuation of FREN_V 201. This course aligned with level A2 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN_V 111, FREN_V 201, or assignment based on placement test. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 202 or FREN_V 112. Equivalency: FREN_V 112.

subject: FREN
title: Intermediate French I
description: Refinement of reading, writing and speaking skills through the study of contemporary literature and other authentic documents of the French-speaking world. This course is aligned with level B1 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN 12, FREN_V 112, FREN_V 202, or assignment based on placement test. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 301 or FREN_V 122. Equivalency: FREN_V 122.
exclusion_raw: Refinement of reading, writing and speaking skills through the study of contemporary literature and other authentic documents of the French-speaking world. This course is aligned with level B1 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN 12, FREN_V 112, FREN_V 202, or assignment based on placement test. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 301 or FREN_V 122. Equivalency: FREN_V 122.

subject: FREN
title: Intermediate French II
description: A continuation of FREN_V 301. This course is aligned with level B1 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN_V 122, FREN_V 301, or assignment based on placement. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 302 or FREN_V 123. Equivalency: FREN_V 123.
exclusion_raw: A continuation of FREN_V 301. This course is aligned with level B1 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN_V 122, FREN_V 301, or assignment based on placement. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 302 or FREN_V 123. Equivalency: FREN_V 123.

subject: FREN
title: Introduction to Literature in French
description: Critical reading of foundational literary texts in French from genres of prose fiction, non-fiction, poetry, and theatre. Prerequisite: One of FREN 123, FREN 302.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 123, FREN 302.

subject: FREN
title: Critical Writing
description: Practical tools for university-level writing in French. Apply stylistic devices and rhetorical structures to form questions and arguments, analyse literary and cultural objects, and produce a variety of essay genres. Prerequisite: One of FREN 123, FREN 302.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 123, FREN 302.

subject: FREN
title: Introduction to Quebec Literature
description: Survey of representative literary texts from Quebec viewed in their historical, social, and cultural contexts. Prerequisite: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 311, FREN 321 and one of FREN 224, FREN 401.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 311, FREN 321 and one of FREN 224, FREN 401.

subject: FREN
title: Arts, Cultures and Society from the Middle Ages to the Revolution
description: Exploration of early French culture and literature from the Middle Ages to the close of the Early Modern period and the French Revolution; the impact of society on the arts and vice versa. Prerequisite: One of FREN 311, FREN 321 and one of FREN 224, FREN 401.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 311, FREN 321 and one of FREN 224, FREN 401.

subject: FREN
title: Arts, Cultures and Society from Romanticism to the Present Day
description: Exploration of modern and contemporary French culture and literature from the early 19th century to the present day; the impact of society on the arts and vice versa. Prerequisite: One of FREN 311, FREN 321 and one of FREN 224, FREN 401.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 311, FREN 321 and one of FREN 224, FREN 401.

subject: FREN
title: French at Work
description: Communicative French for students preparing for a career in the francophone world. This course is aligned with the B1 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended pre-requisites: one of FREN 123, FREN 302.

subject: FREN
title: French Grammar
description: Principles of grammar theory and contextualized French grammatical concepts. Emphasis on terminology and analysis of grammatical issues. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives. Recommended pre-requisite: FREN 401, FREN 402. Prerequisite: One of FREN 123, FREN 302.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 123, FREN 302.

subject: FREN
title: Advanced French Grammar
description: Advanced grammar theory and critical analysis of difficult French grammatical structures. Emphasis on autonomous examination of complex grammatical issues. Recommended pre-requisite: FREN 401, FREN 402. Prerequisite: One of FREN 223, FREN 352.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 223, FREN 352.

subject: FREN
title: Translation
description: Principles, practical strategies and methods of translation from French to English and English to French. Overview of the main challenges involved in intercultural communication. Recommended pre-requisite: FREN 353. Prerequisite: One of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Introduction to French Linguistics
description: A survey of basic terminology, methods, problems, and theoretical trends in French linguistics, specifically designed to provide students with a foundation for advanced language study in French. Prerequisite: Either (a) FREN 223 or (b) all of FREN 352, FREN 401.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) FREN 223 or (b) all of FREN 352, FREN 401.

subject: FREN
title: Upper-Intermediate French I
description: Communicative proficiency at an autonomous level: vocabulary enrichment, pronunciation practice, grammatical analysis and development of efficient reading and writing techniques. This course is aligned with level B2 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN_V 123, FREN_V 302, or French Immersion 12, or assignment based on placement test. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 401 or FREN_V 224. Equivalency: FREN _V 224.
exclusion_raw: Communicative proficiency at an autonomous level: vocabulary enrichment, pronunciation practice, grammatical analysis and development of efficient reading and writing techniques. This course is aligned with level B2 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN_V 123, FREN_V 302, or French Immersion 12, or assignment based on placement test. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 401 or FREN_V 224. Equivalency: FREN _V 224.

subject: FREN
title: Upper-Intermediate French II
description: A continuation of FREN_V 401. This course is aligned with level B2 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN_V 224, FREN_V 401, or assignment based on placement test. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 402 or FREN_V 225. Equivalency: FREN _V 225.
exclusion_raw: A continuation of FREN_V 401. This course is aligned with level B2 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended prerequisites: one of FREN_V 224, FREN_V 401, or assignment based on placement test. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN_V 402 or FREN_V 225. Equivalency: FREN _V 225.

subject: FREN
title: Medieval French Literature
description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of French-language literature of the Middle Ages (11th-15th centuries) in their historical context Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Renaissance: Studies in 16th-century French Literature
description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of sixteenth-century French literature in their historical context. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Ancients and Moderns: Studies in 17th-century French Literature
description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of seventeenth-century French literature in their historical context. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Enlightenment and Revolution: Studies in 18th-century French Literature
description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of eighteenth-century French literature in their historical context. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Tradition and Modernity: Studies in 19th-century French Literature
description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of nineteenth-century French literature in their historical context. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: The Modern and Contemporary French Novel
description: Major historical, social and artistic movements reflected in representative novels published in France from the 19th Century to the present. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: French Digital Culture
description: Contemporary issues and debates on how media and digital technologies have impacted French culture and society. Examines how text, language, and writing are used in digital media. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Contemporary French Literature and Culture
description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of twentieth- and twenty-first century French literature in their historical context. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Popular Fiction
description: Popular genres in modern French fiction, including science fiction, crime, romance, fantasy and historical fiction. Aesthetic characteristics, historical context and cultural relevance. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: African and Caribbean Francophone Literatures
description: Representative and contemporary writings from African and Caribbean francophone cultures. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Women's Writing
description: Representative women's writings from the Middle Ages to the present; contemporary women's writings in the Francophone world. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Selected Topics in French Literature and Culture
description: Study of a literary or cultural topic that extends beyond one chronological period and/or place proper. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: French Cinema
description: Study of major past and contemporary French film productions. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Francophone Cinema
description: Study of major past and contemporary film productions from around the Francophone world. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Quebec Literature and Culture
description: Study of representative aspects of Quebec literature and culture through the study of literary texts, films, and artistic productions in their historical context. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Indigenous Literatures of Francophone Canada
description: Study of the literature and cinema of First Nations, Inuit and Métis creators working in French and in Francophone spaces in Canada. Recommendation: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Francophonie: History and Current Debates
description: Historical origins, cultural and linguistic paradoxes of Francophonie. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Francophone Literatures and Cultures of North America
description: Forms of French language cultural expression in North America in their historical context. Discussion of issues around minority linguistic and cultural rights. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Cultures of the Francophone World
description: Forms of cultural expression of the Francophone world studied in their context. Regions may include the Americas, Africa, East Asia, Europe, Indian Ocean, Middle East, and/or the Pacific. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Postcolonial Studies
description: Interdisciplinary approaches to Postcolonial Studies through francophone literature and theory. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Old French
description: The phonetics, grammar, and vocabulary of major Old French dialects; corpus of various literary texts. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 223, FREN 225, FREN 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 223, FREN 225, FREN 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FREN
title: French Phonetics
description: Theory and practice of the sound system of the French language. Anatomy of speech production, sound discrimination, phonetic description and transcription. Prerequisite: FREN 353 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: FREN 353 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Creative Writing in French
description: Theory, techniques and practice of creative writing in French in a variety of genres. Prerequisite: FREN 321 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.
prerequisite_raw: FREN 321 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

subject: FREN
title: Advanced Translation
description: Extensive practice in French-English and English-French translation of a wide range of texts and discourses, such as literary, legal, medical, administrative, commercial materials. Analysis of linguistic and cultural problems posed by translation of specialized material. Prerequisite: [FREN357]
prerequisite_raw: [FREN357]

subject: FREN
title: History of the French Language
description: Overview of the development of the French language from its Latin roots to its modern forms. Examination of the internal and external factors which brought about changes in its phonology, morphology, syntax and lexis. Prerequisite: FREN 353 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: FREN 353 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Studies in Modern French Linguistics
description: Current topics in French linguistics. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Prerequisite: All of FREN 353, FREN 370. Corequisite: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.
prerequisite_raw: All of FREN 353, FREN 370. Corequisite: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.
corequisite_raw: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.

subject: FREN
title: Morphology and Syntax of the French Language
description: Analytical principles pertaining to the study of words and word-stems (morphology), and phrases and sentences (syntax) in written and spoken French. Prerequisite: All of FREN_V 353, FREN_V 370. Corequisite: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.
prerequisite_raw: All of FREN_V 353, FREN_V 370. Corequisite: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.
corequisite_raw: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.

subject: FREN
title: Lexicology and Semantics of the French Language
description: Study of the vocabulary of modern French, focusing on basic principles in lexical semantics, lexicology, phraseology, lexicography, terminology and new technologies, neology. Prerequisite: All of FREN_V 353, FREN_V 370. Corequisite: FREN_V 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.
prerequisite_raw: All of FREN_V 353, FREN_V 370. Corequisite: FREN_V 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.
corequisite_raw: FREN_V 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.

subject: FREN
title: French Language and Societies
description: Study of language in its social context, covering aspects of sociolinguistics within and across the French-speaking communities of the world. Prerequisite: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

subject: FREN
title: Contemporary Varieties of French
description: Study of the different varieties (or dialects) of contemporary French and issues related to French-speaking communities around the world. Prerequisite: FREN 353 and one of FREN 353, FREN 225.
prerequisite_raw: FREN 353 and one of FREN 353, FREN 225.

subject: FREN
title: French Theory
description: Core ideas of French theorists. Influence of French theory on the social sciences and humanities, focusing on Marxism, feminism, structuralism, deconstruction, postmodernism and postcolonialism. Prerequisite: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

subject: FREN
title: History of the Book
description: A historical approach to the social transformations of the book trade in France. Prerequisite: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

subject: FREN
title: Early Encounters: Travel Literature and Colonial Writing in French
description: Narratives of travel and exploration in French before 1800 and their relationship to colonization, knowledge production and representations of the self and others. Prerequisite: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

subject: FREN
title: Research Seminar in French Literature and Culture
description: Research on critical topics related to French literature and culture. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Prerequisite: One of FREN_V 321, FREN_V 328, FREN_V 329 and one of FREN_V 225, FREN_V 402.
prerequisite_raw: One of FREN_V 321, FREN_V 328, FREN_V 329 and one of FREN_V 225, FREN_V 402.

subject: FREN
title: Research Seminar in French Language and Linguistics
description: Research on critical topics related to French language and linguistics. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Prerequisite: FREN_V 353 and FREN_V 370.
prerequisite_raw: FREN_V 353 and FREN_V 370.

subject: FREN
title: Directed Reading
description: Focus on a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of the department head and of a supervisory faculty member is required. Recommended pre-requisite: fourth-year standing

subject: FREN
title: Honours Essay
description: Restriction: this course is restricted to students in one of these programs: BA in fourth-year with one of these specializations: HON FREN or HON RMST.

subject: FREN
title: Bibliography and Research Methods
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FREN
title: Master's Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FREN
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Managerial Economics
description: Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Organization of the firm, demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON _V 301, ECON _V 304, COMM _V 295. Prerequisite: ECON_V 102, one of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101, and one of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 105, MATH_V 110, MATH_V 180.
prerequisite_raw: ECON_V 102, one of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101, and one of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 105, MATH_V 110, MATH_V 180.

subject: FRE
title: Small Business Management in Agri-food Industries
description: Emphasizes the building of a business plan by exploring topics such as the planning process and financing, marketing and human resource concepts, as applied to an agri-food business, domestically and internationally. Prerequisite: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.

subject: FRE
title: Introduction to Global Food Markets
description: An overview of global food markets including recent trends (e.g., vertical coordination, strategic alliances, multinationals and small firms in niche markets), marketing and trade institutions such as state-trading enterprises and WTO regulations, issues specific to developing nations, and case studies. Prerequisite: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.

subject: FRE
title: Empirical Methods for Food and Resource Economics
description: Introduction to empirical methods with applications for problems in food and resource economics; standard linear regression and methods to address data deficiencies; interpretation of regression results for forecasting and policy analysis. Prerequisite: One of LFS_V 252, STAT_V 200, BIOL_V 300, FRST_V 231, ECON_V 325. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of LFS_V 252, STAT_V 200, BIOL_V 300, FRST_V 231, ECON_V 325. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: International Agricultural Development
description: Characteristics, processes and sources of economic growth, role of agricultural and resource sectors in economic growth, analysis of output and input markets in those sectors, policy failures, tools for empirical analysis of rural markets, growth, and the environment. Prerequisite: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.

subject: FRE
title: Land and Resource Economics
description: Willingness to pay, opportunity costs, externalities, and market failures in natural resource markets; dynamic efficiency; economic applications including mineral, marine, forest, land, water, and biodiversity. Prerequisite: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101. Equivalency: ECON_V 374
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101. Equivalency: ECON_V 374

subject: FRE
title: Quantitative Methods for Business and Resource Management
description: Spreadsheet modeling and analysis of business and resource management problems: decision analysis, forecasting, linear programming, simulation modeling, and inventory management. Prerequisite: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101 and one of LFS_V 252, BIOL_V 300, FRST_V 231, STAT_V 200, ECON_V 325.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101 and one of LFS_V 252, BIOL_V 300, FRST_V 231, STAT_V 200, ECON_V 325.

subject: FRE
title: Environment, Society and Government
description: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy, emphasizing interactions with the environment and society, including Indigenous communities. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making. Prerequisite: One of COMM 295, ECON 301. Equivalency: COMM 394 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of COMM 295, ECON 301. Equivalency: COMM 394 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Market Research and Analysis in Agri-Food Industries
description: Macro and micro aspects of agri-food market and industry analysis, market strategy, consumer behaviour, secondary market research, quantitative and qualitative market research. Prerequisite: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.

subject: FRE
title: The Economics of International Trade and the Environment
