description: Market failure and gains from trade in the presence of environmental externalities; multilateral trade and environmental agreements; case studies, including biological invasions, transport emissions, climate-induced migration, carbon leakage, ivory trade, food miles. Prerequisite: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.

subject: FRE
title: Predictive Analytics for Food and Resource Economics
description: Statistical and machine learning algorithms for predictive analytics in the context of relevant problems in food, sustainability, and resource-related issues. Prerequisite: FRE 326.
prerequisite_raw: FRE 326.

subject: FRE
title: Spatial Data Science
description: Spatial data and its analysis in the R programming language including satellite remote sensing of environmental and human variables using color and texture-based approaches. Prerequisites: One of LFS_V 252, STAT_V 200, STAT_V 201, BIOL_V 300, ECON_V 325, ECON _V 326, ECON_V 327, COMM_V 191, FRST_V 231, GEOG_V 374. And either one of CPSC_V 203, CPSC_V 210, EOSC_V 211, ECON_V 323, FRE_V 326, COMM_V 337 or one of GEOS_V 370, GEOS_V 373.

subject: FRE
title: Economics of Food Consumption
description: Microeconomics of consumer decisions and public policy in food contexts; foodborne illness; economic causes and consequences of obesity; sin taxes and prohibitions; information campaigns and advertising; labeling; food waste and ethics. Prerequisite: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.

subject: FRE
title: Causal Inference in the Economics of Natural Resource Conservation
description: Estimating causal relationships in natural resource economics; applied data analysis; econometrics; counterfactual thinking, and applications to the economics of: natural resource conservation, species loss and extraction, protected areas, international trade of wildlife products, and endangered species legislation. Prerequisite: One of LFS_V 252, STAT_V 200, BIOL_V 300, ECON_V 325, COMM_V 291, FRST_V 231 and one of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.
prerequisite_raw: One of LFS_V 252, STAT_V 200, BIOL_V 300, ECON_V 325, COMM_V 291, FRST_V 231 and one of ECON_V 101, ECON_V 310, FRST_V 101, LFS_V 101.

subject: FRE
title: Undergraduate Thesis
description: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to preparation of a thesis. Prerequisite: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: MSc Seminar
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Strategic Economic Analysis of Agri-Food Markets
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Food Market Analysis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Agribusiness Management
description: Credit will be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515 or FRE 515. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Credit will be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515 or FRE 515. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Financial and Marketing Management in Agri-food Industries
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Professional Masters Seminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Applied Econometrics
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Graduating Project
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Quantitative Methods for Business and Natural Resource Management
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: PhD Seminar
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Advanced Microeconomic Theory for Food and Resource Economics
description: Prerequisite: ECON 500. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: ECON 500. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Advanced Econometrics for Food and Resource Economics
description: Prerequisite: ECON 527. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: ECON 527. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRE
title: Advanced Food and Resource Economics
description: Prerequisite: One of FRE 523, FRE 524, ECON 573 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRE 523, FRE 524, ECON 573 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Sustainable Forests
description: An overview of forests and forestry. Survey of the disciplines, areas of study, and values that frame sustainable management of forests in BC and the world. Assignments focus on critical thinking and written communication skills. [3-0-0]

subject: FRST
title: Principles of Microeconomics for Forestry and Land and Food Systems
description: Principles of microeconomics and their applications in forestry and land and food systems. The basic concept of the economy to focus on private and social decision making related to the use of land, especially in agriculture, forestry, and conservation. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 101, ECON 101, or LFS 101. [3-0-1] Equivalency: LFS101, ECON101
exclusion_raw: Principles of microeconomics and their applications in forestry and land and food systems. The basic concept of the economy to focus on private and social decision making related to the use of land, especially in agriculture, forestry, and conservation. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 101, ECON 101, or LFS 101. [3-0-1] Equivalency: LFS101, ECON101

subject: FRST
title: Introduction to Forestry Co-op
description: An introduction to Forestry Co-op including: completion of preemployment workshops, career skills toolkits, networking opportunities, interview training, individual coaching sessions, and job search skills. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Forestry Co-operative Education Program. Pass/fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Land One: First-year Integrative Seminar
description: Current issues and cases in Forestry and Land and Food Systems are examined with a focus on integration of first-year subjects and exposure to both First Nations and Western perspectives. [2-0-1;2-0-1] Equivalency: LFS_V 110, NRES_V 110. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Scholarly Writing and Argumentation in Forestry
description: Communicating concepts of forestry and links to human and environmental activities through writing, elements of argumentation, evaluating evidence, and searching for and citing references to back up claims; small-class experience. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES_V 150, FRST_V 150, or LFS_V 150. [3-0-0] Equivalency: LFS_V 150, NRES_V 150. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Communicating concepts of forestry and links to human and environmental activities through writing, elements of argumentation, evaluating evidence, and searching for and citing references to back up claims; small-class experience. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES_V 150, FRST_V 150, or LFS_V 150. [3-0-0] Equivalency: LFS_V 150, NRES_V 150. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Plant Biology I
description: The structure, diversity and development of trees and other plants, with emphasis on the angiosperms. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 200 or FRST 200. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 121. Equivalency: NRES 200
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 121. Equivalency: NRES 200
exclusion_raw: The structure, diversity and development of trees and other plants, with emphasis on the angiosperms. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 200 or FRST 200. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 121. Equivalency: NRES 200

subject: FRST
title: Forest Ecology
description: The structure and function of forest ecosystems, including: energetics; productivity; nutrient, carbon and water cycling; soils; the physical environment; population and community ecology; disturbance ecology; ecological succession; biological diversity and ecological resilience. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 201 or FRST 201. [3-2-0] Equivalency: NRES 201
exclusion_raw: The structure and function of forest ecosystems, including: energetics; productivity; nutrient, carbon and water cycling; soils; the physical environment; population and community ecology; disturbance ecology; ecological succession; biological diversity and ecological resilience. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 201 or FRST 201. [3-2-0] Equivalency: NRES 201

subject: FRST
title: Forest Ecology
description: The Ecosystem concept; energy biomass and nutrient cycling; the physical environment; population and community ecology; succession, Biogeoclimatic classification and some coastal ecosystems. Available only through Distance Education. [3-2]

subject: FRST
title: Silvics of Forest Trees of Western Canada
description: Ecological and silvical characteristics of forest trees; assessment of ecological site quality and biogeoclimatic classification; application of silvics in silviculture. A plant herbarium of at least 50 species is required. Only available through Distance Education. [3-2] Prerequisite: FRST202
prerequisite_raw: FRST202

subject: FRST
title: Forest Plant Biology II
description: The functional biology of trees and other forest plants in their environment, with an emphasis on gymnosperms. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 210 or FRST 210. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 200, NRES 200. Equivalency: NRES 210.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 200, NRES 200. Equivalency: NRES 210.
exclusion_raw: The functional biology of trees and other forest plants in their environment, with an emphasis on gymnosperms. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 210 or FRST 210. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 200, NRES 200. Equivalency: NRES 210.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Classification and Silvics
description: Forest classification and the application of silvics in forest management, including world forest classification systems, the Biogeoclimactic Ecosystem Classification system, and ecosystem diagnosis in the field. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 211 or FRST 211. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 201, NRES 201. Equivalency: NRES 211
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 201, NRES 201. Equivalency: NRES 211
exclusion_raw: Forest classification and the application of silvics in forest management, including world forest classification systems, the Biogeoclimactic Ecosystem Classification system, and ecosystem diagnosis in the field. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 211 or FRST 211. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 201, NRES 201. Equivalency: NRES 211

subject: FRST
title: Introduction to Biometrics
description: Basic theories of probability and statistics. Sampling distribution, methods of estimation and hypothesis testing; goodness of fit and tests for independence; analysis of variance, regression and correlation. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 231 or FRST 231. [3-2-0] Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 180, MATH 184, MATH 190. Equivalency: NRES 231
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 100, MATH 180, MATH 184, MATH 190. Equivalency: NRES 231
exclusion_raw: Basic theories of probability and statistics. Sampling distribution, methods of estimation and hypothesis testing; goodness of fit and tests for independence; analysis of variance, regression and correlation. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… . Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 231 or FRST 231. [3-2-0] Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 180, MATH 184, MATH 190. Equivalency: NRES 231

subject: FRST
title: Computer Applications in Forestry
description: Techniques involved in solving forestry problems with microcomputers using word processing, spreadsheet, procedural language, and database management tools. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 232 or FRST 232. [3-2] Equivalency: NRES 232
exclusion_raw: Techniques involved in solving forestry problems with microcomputers using word processing, spreadsheet, procedural language, and database management tools. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 232 or FRST 232. [3-2] Equivalency: NRES 232

subject: FRST
title: Tree and Stand Level Measurements
description: An introduction to measurement of individual trees and stands; use of aerial photographs, maps, and various measurement instruments. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 231, NRES 231 and one of FRST 232, NRES 232.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 231, NRES 231 and one of FRST 232, NRES 232.

subject: FRST
title: Co-operative Work Placement.
description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Orientation workshops required. Final work term report required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Genetics
description: Population genetics and conservation of genetic resources; principles of genetics and their application to forestry. [2-2]

subject: FRST
title: Into the Woods: An Introduction to Forest Science
description: Introduction to growth of trees and forests with emphasis on evolutionary, ecological and environmental aspects. Not available for credit to undergraduate students in the Faculty of Forestry. [3-0-0]

subject: FRST
title: Forest Stewardship in a Changing Climate
description: Forests can provide natural solutions to climate change and social well-being through innovative management and restoration including protection of mother trees and soils, carbon and conservation financing, and emergence of value-added industries. For students without strong science backgrounds. Not available for credit to Faculty of Forestry students. [3-0-0]

subject: FRST
title: Silviculture
description: Silviculture concepts and principles; stand dynamics; artificial and natural regeneration; cultural techniques for forest stand establishment and stand tending; silvicultural systems; decision making and development of prescriptions; connections to forest planning. [3-4*] Prerequisite: One of FRST 201, NRES 201 and one of FRST 350, FRST 351, UFOR 400.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 201, NRES 201 and one of FRST 350, FRST 351, UFOR 400.

subject: FRST
title: Biotic Disturbances
description: Concepts of disturbance ecology with special reference to insects and diseases in the forests of British Columbia; forest health problems in the biogeoclImatic zones of BC; present management strategies and future potentials in a scenario of climate change. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 210, NRES 210 and one of FRST 211, NRES 211.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 210, NRES 210 and one of FRST 211, NRES 211.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Entomology
description: An introduction to insects that cause damage to forests and forest products; how insects live; life cycles and attack symptoms of representatives of major groups of insects; principles for control and management. Available only through Distance Education.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Pathology
description: Biology and management of forest tree diseases. Available only through Distance Education.

subject: FRST
title: Soil Biology
description: The diversity and interactions of soil organisms (bacteria, protozoa, fungi, animals, plants) in natural and managed ecosystems; roles in primary production, nutrient cycling, decomposition and reclamation; responses to environmental change. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: BIOL 121. Equivalency: APBI342
prerequisite_raw: BIOL 121. Equivalency: APBI342

subject: FRST
title: Plant Physiology I
description: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. CHEM 203, CHEM 213, or CHEM 233 and CHEM 235 is recommended. [3-3-0] Equivalency: BIOL351, APBI351

subject: FRST
title: Forest and Conservation Economics
description: Practical problem solving of economic issues related to forestry and conservation, touching on investment analysis, capital budgeting, non-timber economics, ecosystem services, and forest certification. Completion of FRST 232 or NRES 232 or intermediate knowledge of MS Excel essential. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: One of ECON 101, FRST 101.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON 101, FRST 101.

subject: FRST
title: Principles of Forestry Economics
description: Introduction to the economics of production, distribution and consumption of goods and services produced by, and dependent on, the forest resource. Available only through Distance Education.

subject: FRST
title: Abiotic Disturbances: Fire and Climate
description: Ecological effects of fire and climatic (wind, temperature, and snow) disturbances; fire danger rating, principles of fire management and prescribed fire use; windthrow risk modelling and management. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 210, NRES 210 and one of FRST 211, NRES 211.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 210, NRES 210 and one of FRST 211, NRES 211.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Level Measurement and Productivity
description: Obtaining and forecasting information for stands and forests. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: FRST 239.
prerequisite_raw: FRST 239.

subject: FRST
title: Co-operative Work Placement.
description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Co-operative Work Placement
description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Co-operative Work Placement.
description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Foundational Field School
description: Field study concentrating on outdoor skills, forest measurements, site diagnosis, and an integrated overview of the ecological, social and economic basis for forest management. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST_V 350 or 351. Prerequisite: FRST_V 211 or NRES_V 211; FRST_V 201 or NRES_V 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: FRST_V 211 or NRES_V 211; FRST_V 201 or NRES_V 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Field study concentrating on outdoor skills, forest measurements, site diagnosis, and an integrated overview of the ecological, social and economic basis for forest management. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST_V 350 or 351. Prerequisite: FRST_V 211 or NRES_V 211; FRST_V 201 or NRES_V 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Interior Field School
description: Field study at an interior BC location concentrating on land use, management and silviculture. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses. Students with FRST_V 351 and FRST_V 350 can only count 3 credits toward their program requirements. Prerequisite: FRST_V 210 or NRES_V 210. Corequisite: FRST_V 211 or NRES_V 211.
prerequisite_raw: FRST_V 210 or NRES_V 210. Corequisite: FRST_V 211 or NRES_V 211.
corequisite_raw: FRST_V 211 or NRES_V 211.

subject: FRST
title: Community Forests and Community Forestry
description: Community forests and community forestry throughout the world, with special attention to participation by aboriginal peoples; emphasis is on forms of governance, public participation, and adaptive learning. [3-0-0]

subject: FRST
title: Watershed Hydrology
description: Measurement and analysis of hydrological processes in response to forest management activities. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: Third- or fourth-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third- or fourth-year standing.

subject: FRST
title: Aquatic Ecosystems and Fish in Forested Watersheds
description: Effects of forest management activities on fish and aquatic ecosystems. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: Third- or fourth-year standing in Forestry, Science, Applied Science or Applied Biology.
prerequisite_raw: Third- or fourth-year standing in Forestry, Science, Applied Science or Applied Biology.

subject: FRST
title: Wildlife Ecology and Management
description: Ecology, management, and conservation of terrestrial vertebrate wildlife, focusing primarily on socio-economically important, forest-dwelling species of mammals, birds, amphibians and reptiles. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 201, BIOL 230, BIOL 306.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 201, BIOL 230, BIOL 306.

subject: FRST
title: Introduction to Research Methods
description: Lectures and seminars in research philosophies and the scientific method, with special emphasis on field research. [2-1] Prerequisite: One of FRST 150, LFS 150, NRES 150, WRDS 150, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, WOOD 225, NRES 225.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 150, LFS 150, NRES 150, WRDS 150, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, WOOD 225, NRES 225.

subject: FRST
title: Living Language: Science and Society
description: Multi-disciplinary course in which students, individually and in groups, examine, integrate and apply subject-specific knowledge through the lens of language and the framework of the language sciences, with a focus on themes of real-world importance. Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor. Equivalency: APSC402, ASTU402, LFS 402, LLED402, PHAR402
prerequisite_raw: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor. Equivalency: APSC402, ASTU402, LFS 402, LLED402, PHAR402

subject: FRST
title: The Sustainability of Production in Managed Forest Ecosystems
description: Study of the functional and dynamic characteristics of forest ecosystems and their response to forest management using ecosystem-level microcomputer simulation models. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 201, NRES 201.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 201, NRES 201.

subject: FRST
title: Advances in Silviculture
description: Fundamental silvicultural problems; the application of research findings to the practice of silviculture. [4-0] Prerequisite: FRST 305.
prerequisite_raw: FRST 305.

subject: FRST
title: Advanced Forest Pathology
description: Hereditary, physiological, anatomical, environmental, and microbiological factors influencing forest tree diseases. Given in alternate years. [2-2]

subject: FRST
title: Advanced Forest Insect Ecology
description: Role of climate and climate change in the population dynamics, outbreak potentials and resultant impacts to forest ecosystems associated with herbivorous forest insects. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 307, APBI 327, BIOL 327.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 307, APBI 327, BIOL 327.

subject: FRST
title: Introduction to Landscape Ecology and Management
description: Current concepts, methods, and applications of landscape ecology with emphasis on spatial patterning, spatial heterogeneity, and dynamics; problem-solving approaches to natural resource issues through the application of landscape ecological principles and tools. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Fourth-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Complex Adaptive Systems, Global Change Science, and Ecology Sustainability
description: Concepts of complex adaptive systems (CAS); exploration of how CAS can be used to manage natural and social environments for multiple goals under changing climatic and socio-economic conditions. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing

subject: FRST
title: Ecological Plant Biochemistry.
description: The structure, biosynthesis, distribution and biological function of secondary plant metabolites. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201 and one of BIOL 209, BIOL 210; or (b) one of FRST 200, NRES 200 and one of FRST 210, NRES 210. Equivalency: BIOL462
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201 and one of BIOL 209, BIOL 210; or (b) one of FRST 200, NRES 200 and one of FRST 210, NRES 210. Equivalency: BIOL462

subject: FRST
title: Sustainable Forest Policy
description: The development, implementation, and analysis of forest policy. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third- or fourth-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third- or fourth-year standing.

subject: FRST
title: Quantitative Forest Management
description: Introduction to the quantitative tools necessary in forest management. Available only through Distance Education.

subject: FRST
title: Mathematical Modelling in Forest Resource Analysis
description: Modelling techniques used in strategic and tactical forest resources analyses. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the BSF degree.
prerequisite_raw: Fourth-year standing in the BSF degree.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Management Planning
description: Forest management designs to identify and integrate economic, social, and environmental objectives across a forested landscape both strategically and tactically. [4-2-2] Prerequisite: FRST 422.
prerequisite_raw: FRST 422.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Planning
description: Analyze and interpret existing management plans, prescribe solutions for achieving specific forest management goals at multiple scales, use basic tools to evaluate the financial implications of such solutions, and create a forest management plan for a virtual forest. Offered entirely online. Students in any of the Forestry programs requiring FRST 423 (6 cr) in order to graduate will not be granted the 3 cr of FRST 425 toward degree completion.

subject: FRST
title: Advanced Biometrics
description: Analysis of variance, multiple regression and analysis of covariance. Design and analysis of experiments. [3-2] Prerequisite: One of FRST 231, NRES 231, BIOL 300, STAT 200. And FRST 399 or equivalent. Restricted to students with 4th year standing or by permission of instructor.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 231, NRES 231, BIOL 300, STAT 200. And FRST 399 or equivalent. Restricted to students with 4th year standing or by permission of instructor.

subject: FRST
title: Ecological Genomics
description: The genomic basis of adaptation to environments. Topics progress through community structure, life history patterns, stress responses, and variation and adaptation. [3-0-0]

subject: FRST
title: Growth and Yield
description: Techniques of growth and yield projection and discussion of modelling approaches. Exploration of stand dynamics, quantitative implications of management treatments and environmental limitations to tree and stand growth. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: FRST339
prerequisite_raw: FRST339

subject: FRST
title: International Forestry
description: The socio-economic, biological and technological aspects of forestry within the international frame, in both the developed and developing world. Regional studies and the role of national and international agencies. [2-2-0]

subject: FRST
title: Remote Sensing for Ecosystem Management
description: Basic biological concepts related to interpretation of remote sensing data for land management, including the use of films and filters, and interpretation of air photographs, and other imagery. [2-2-0]

subject: FRST
title: Agroforestry
description: Ecological, economic and social benefits of incorporating trees into agricultural landscapes. Lectures and groupwork designing agroforestry systems in temperate and tropical contexts. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 201, NRES 201, APBI 260. Equivalency: APBI444
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 201, NRES 201, APBI 260. Equivalency: APBI444

subject: FRST
title: Co-operative Work Placement.
description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Co-operative Work Placement.
description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Co-operative Work Placement.
description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Coastal Field School
description: Site diagnosis and preparation of management options in coastal forests. Extrasessional course; fees will be assessed to meet expenses. Prerequisite: FRST_V 350 or 351; FRST_V 305; Third- or fourth-year standing in the B.S.F. program, or Forest Management major or Forest Operations major in B.Sc. in Natural Resources program.
prerequisite_raw: FRST_V 350 or 351; FRST_V 305; Third- or fourth-year standing in the B.S.F. program, or Forest Management major or Forest Operations major in B.Sc. in Natural Resources program.

subject: FRST
title: The Role of Natural and Planted Forests in the Global Bioeconomy
description: (Go Global Seminar Series) An intensive one-month field school in Chile focused on fast-growing industrial forest plantations, innovative wood products, land use strategies for natural and planted forests, and their impact on society. Prerequisite: Third-year standing
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing

subject: FRST
title: Forests and Society
description: Social aspects of forestry and forest communities. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Third- or fourth-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third- or fourth-year standing.

subject: FRST
title: Indigenous Ecologies
description: Application of Indigenous worldviews and knowledges to ecology. Colonial history of modern ecology, foundations and examples of Indigenous ecologies, restoration applying multiple worldviews, and Indigenized, culturally appropriate ecological research and decision-making processes. Prerequisite: One of BEST 203, BIOL 230, FRST 201, APBI 260, GEOS 207. and third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of BEST 203, BIOL 230, FRST 201, APBI 260, GEOS 207. and third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Watershed Management
description: Effects of land management on quality, quantity and timing of water flow. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: FRST385
prerequisite_raw: FRST385

subject: FRST
title: Visual Resource Management and Planning for Aesthetics
description: Methodologies for visual analysis, perceptions, planning & management of urban, natural and working landscapes, and implications for sustainable land-use management & community engagement. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 490 or FRST 551. [2-2] Prerequisite: Third-year standing. Equivalency: LARC542
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing. Equivalency: LARC542
exclusion_raw: Methodologies for visual analysis, perceptions, planning & management of urban, natural and working landscapes, and implications for sustainable land-use management & community engagement. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 490 or FRST 551. [2-2] Prerequisite: Third-year standing. Equivalency: LARC542

subject: FRST
title: Visualization and Forest Design
description: GIS-based spatial planning and 3D landscape visualization for forest management. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Third- or fourth-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third- or fourth-year standing.

subject: FRST
title: Environmental Perception
description: How individuals perceive their environment. Emphasis will be given visual perception in the context of natural resource issues and the effects of those perceptions on individuals including issues of human wellbeing. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing

subject: FRST
title: Biological Diversity and Conservation
description: Principles, problems, and practices of managing natural habitats for biological diversity; current issues in biological diversity important to researchers, policymakers, and the general public. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 201, NRES 201 and FRST 395. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 201, NRES 201 and FRST 395. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Communications and Professionalism
description: Preparing professional reports and presentations; professionalism and professional ethics. [2-0-2] Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Fourth-year standing.

subject: FRST
title: B.Sc. Thesis in Forestry
description: An independent study or research project of a subject of special interest to the student under the direction of a staff member. Available only to students in the BSFS Honours specialization.

subject: FRST
title: B.S.F. Thesis
description: An independent study or research project on an approved topic, developed under the guidance of a Faculty member. Available only to students in their graduating year.

subject: FRST
title: Teaching and Learning in Forestry
description: An evidence-based examination of teaching and learning in forestry, focusing on instructional design, classroom practices and field instruction. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Tropical Rainforests: Evolution, Biology, Ecology
description: Evolution and current structure, functions and diversity of moist evergreen and semi-evergreen forests of the humid tropics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Plant Molecular Biology Laboratory
description: Techniques of purification, cloning, sequencing, restriction-hybridization analysis of plant nucleic acids, in-vitro labeling of plant nucleic acids and proteins, and electrophoresis and immunodetection of plant proteins. Offered by the Biotechnology Teaching Laboratory in cooperation with the Department of Forest and Conservation Sciences. Admission to the course is limited and requires recommendation from the department head. Equivalency: PLNT_V 540, BOTA_V 544. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Landscape Ecology
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Advanced Forest Pathology
description: Hereditary, physiological, anatomical, environmental, and microbiological factors influencing forest tree diseases. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Advanced Forest Insect Ecology
description: Role of climate and climate change in the population dynamics, outbreak potentials and resultant impacts to forest ecosystems associated with herbivorous forest insects. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Advanced Biometrics
description: Linear model theory and application for observational data and randomized experiments. Multiple linear regression, analysis of variance, and analysis of covariance. Design and analysis of experiments. Prerequisite: One of FRST_V 231, NRES_V 231, BIOL_V 300, or STAT_V 200. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST_V 231, NRES_V 231, BIOL_V 300, or STAT_V 200. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Applied Population Genetics
description: Equivalency: BIOL_V 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Belowground Forest Ecosystems
description: Review of current literature on specific topics in forest soil ecology, including bacterial endophytes, microbial diversity, nutrient cycling, and mycorrhizae. Students with either APBI 412 or CONS 412 will not be allowed to take FRST 512. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Biotechnology in Tree Improvement
description: Advanced research topics and their application to forest genetics. Emphasis on molecular genetics and experimental protocols. Prerequisite: [BIOL335] or permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [BIOL335] or permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Climate Change Communications and Engagement
description: Psychological, social, and systemic dimensions of climate change communication; approaches for engaging diverse groups for low-carbon futures; overcoming climate inaction. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Tree Physiology
description: Growth and development of woody plants; physiological responses to abiotic and biotic environmental factors; consequences of silvicultural practices on physiological processes. [3-2] Prerequisite: One of FRST 311, BIOL 351, APBI 351. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 311, BIOL 351, APBI 351. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Economics of Forest Management
description: Applying economics to forest and forestland management, including analysis of how government policies and market designs affect forest management outcomes. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Land, Extraction, and The Corporation
description: Political ecology of resource extraction. History of the extractive corporate form. Theories of land ownership, access, and sovereignty in relation to market forces. Tensions between society, state, and the market. Global approaches to governing extraction. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Forests and Society
description: Emphasis on tropical and sub-tropical countries, where the majority of forest-dependent people live. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Land and Forest Resource Economics
description: Applications of advanced theory and quantitative analysis to problems in forest resource and land economics; multiple land use; institutions for sustainable land use; optimal management and policy. [3-0] Equivalency: AGEC_V 520. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Social, Community, and Indigenous Forestry
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Forest and Environmental Policy
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Environmental Perception
description: Perceptual processes mediating behaviour in humans, with special attention given to the emotional processing of visual stimuli. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Visualisation Theory and Applications
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Directed Studies in International Forestry
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: People and Forests: An International Perspective
description: Biodiversity loss, deforestation, desertification, salinization, air pollution and climate change facing world forests. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 439 or FRST 527. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Biodiversity loss, deforestation, desertification, salinization, air pollution and climate change facing world forests. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 439 or FRST 527. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Social Science Research Methods for Forestry and Conservation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Ecological Economics
description: Emphasis on forested ecosystems. Prerequisite: ECON 301. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: ECON 301. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Advanced Modelling Methods for Natural Resources Applications
description: Linear, nonlinear, and generalized linear models, including mixed effects versions of each. Examples include applications to forests and other natural environments. Prerequisite: FRST_V 430 or FRST_V 509 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: FRST_V 430 or FRST_V 509 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Multivariate Statistical Methods
description: Multivariate analysis of variance, cluster, principal components, factor, canonical and discriminant analysis. Theory and conceptual background are presented but emphasis is on selection of appropriate analysis and interpretation of results. Examples from forestry and related fields are analysed by computer programs at UBC. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Natural Resources Economics
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Global Environmental Issues and Forests
description: Socio-economic, biological, and technological problems affecting forests and forest-dependent communities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Advanced Geomatics for Natural Resource Management
description: Advanced geospatial technologies are examined and applied to pressing management issues. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Application of Operational Research Methods in Forest Management
description: Use of operational research methods in forest planning models; emphasis on algorithms, problem formulation and interpretation of results. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Policy and Law
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: International Forestry Institutions, Diplomacy and Negotiation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Technical Communication Skills I
description: Principles and practice of oral presentations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Technical Communication Skills II
description: Theory and practice of technical communication necessary for preparation of effective scientific reports, reviews, grant proposals, journal articles and theses. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Research Methods and Philosophies in Science
description: Lectures and seminars in research philosophies and methods with special emphasis on field and applied research. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Forestry in British Columbia
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Landscape Planning for Sustainability
description: Analysis, perception, planning of landscapes, and integration of social acceptability with sustainability. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 490 or FRST 551. Equivalency: LARC542 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Analysis, perception, planning of landscapes, and integration of social acceptability with sustainability. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 490 or FRST 551. Equivalency: LARC542 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Tropical Forests: Management and Conservation
description: The use, management, and conservation of tropical and sub-tropical forests. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: International Forest Governance and Policy
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Products and Services
description: Global trends in products and services. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Fundamentals of Sustainable Forest Land Management
description: Concepts and principles at the site and landscape scale. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Land Information Acquisition and Analysis
description: Principles and application of data acquisition and use. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Site-Level Forest Land Management
description: Design and implementation of site-level plans that integrate ecological, social, and economic components: silviculture, forest operations, and forest health. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Landscape-Level Forest Land Management
description: Preparation of landscape-level sustainable forest management plans that integrate ecological, social, and economic components. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Natural Resources Planning
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Forest Business Enterprise
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Quantitative Methods in Wildlife Ecology
description: Concepts and applications of statistical methods for common questions in the ecology, conservation, and monitoring of animal populations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Topics in International Forestry
description: Contemporary and emerging issues in international forestry. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Indigenous Ecologies
description: Application of Indigenous worldviews and knowledges to ecology. Colonial history of modern ecology, foundations and examples of Indigenous ecologies, restoration applying multiple worldviews, and Indigenized, culturally appropriate ecological research and decision-making processes. Prerequisite: A second-year or higher ecology course. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: A second-year or higher ecology course. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Fluvial Ecohydrology
description: Hydrology, geomorphology and ecology of streams and their catchments; significance of stream processes within the fluvial network; management issues, particularly in the context of forest harvesting. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Statistical Methods in Hydrology
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Hydrological Modelling Applications in Forestry
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Climate Adaptation in Socio-Ecological Systems
description: Theory and evolution of adaptation at different scales in organizations and resource management systems, utilizing existing case studies, examining opportunities and barriers to adaptation, considering strategies and practices to manage climate impacts and risks. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Transformative Environmental Research
description: Scholarly foundations of and emerging approaches for engaging creatively and critically in environmental research that recognizes (and potentially addresses) issues of power, difference, and complexity, transforming both the researcher and the research discipline. Prerequisite: Graduate-level standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Graduate-level standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FRST
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FSCT
title: Introduction to Forensic Science
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 7320.

subject: FSCT
title: Applied Ethics
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT LIBS 7002.

subject: FSCT
title: Report Writing and Communication for Forensic Investigation
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT COMM 7200.

subject: FSCT
title: Introductory Forensic Science I
description: Block registration for the introduction to forensic science course taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

subject: FSCT
title: Introductory Forensic Science II
description: Block registration for the applied ethics and report writing and communication for forensic investigation courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

subject: FSCT
title: Forensic Biology; DNA Typing Theory
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 8150.

subject: FSCT
title: Quality Assurance for Forensic Science
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 8370.

subject: FSCT
title: Business Management for Forensic Science
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 8371.

subject: FSCT
title: Research Methodology and Measurement Models
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 7910.

subject: FSCT
title: Forensic Biology: Evidence Recovery
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 8155.

subject: FSCT
title: Medico-Legal Aspects of Alcohol
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 8230.

subject: FSCT
title: The Science of Fingerprints - Theory
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 8320.

subject: FSCT
title: Forensic Toxicology
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 8240.

subject: FSCT
title: Intermediate Forensic Science I
description: Block registration for the forensic biology: DNA typing theory, quality assurance, and business management for forensic science courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

subject: FSCT
title: Intermediate Forensic Science II
description: Block registration for the forensic biology: evidence recovery, research methodology, and elective courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

subject: FSCT
title: Co-op Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in either an industrial, public, or academic laboratory or a law enforcement agency for a minimum of 14 weeks. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Prerequisite: Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry and Forensic Science Honours program is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry and Forensic Science Honours program is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FSCT
title: Co-op Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in either an industrial, public, or academic laboratory or a law enforcement agency for a minimum of 14 weeks. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Prerequisite: FSCT 398. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: FSCT 398. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FSCT
title: Forensic Biology: DNA Typing Applications
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 8160.

subject: FSCT
title: Law for Forensic Science
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 7009.

subject: FSCT
title: The Expert Witness - Prepared for Court
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 7010. [2-0-0]

subject: FSCT
title: Instrumental Analysis for Forensic Chemistry
description: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT FSCT 8156. [3-0-0]

subject: FSCT
title: Advanced Forensic Science I
description: Block registration for the forensic biology: DNA typing applications, law and forensic science courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

subject: FSCT
title: Advanced Forensic Science II
description: Block registration for the expert witness testimony instrumental analysis for forensic chemistry and forensic toxicology courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

subject: FSCT
title: Co-op Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in either an industrial, public, or academic laboratory or a law enforcement agency for a minimum of 14 weeks. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Prerequisite: FSCT 399. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: FSCT 399. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: FSCT
title: Co-op Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in either an industrial, public, or academic laboratory or a law enforcement agency for a minimum of 14 weeks. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Prerequisite: FSCT 498. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: FSCT 498. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEM
title: Landscape Ecology and Management
description: Current concepts and skills in ecological modelling and spatial analysis. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEM
title: Geographic Information Systems for Forestry and Conservation
description: Principles and practices of Geographic Information Systems (GIS). [2-2-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEM
title: Advanced Geographic Information Systems for Environmental Management
description: Advanced topics, techniques and functions in Geographic Information Systems. [2-2-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEM
title: Remote Sensing for Ecosystem Management
description: Capturing spatial data and the use of remote sensing systems to map, monitor and better manage forest, vegetation and ecosystem resources. [2-2-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEM
title: Advanced Earth Observation and Image Processing
description: Advanced topics and techniques in remote sensing and image processing. [2-1-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEM
title: Geospatial Data Analysis
description: Understanding geo-spatial data structures, databases and developing, maintaining and utilizing geo-spatial data. [2-2-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEM
title: Linear Regression Models and Introduction to Spatial Statistics
description: [3-2-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEOG
title: Geography, Environment and Globalization
description: Human geography of the modern world with particular attention to human-environment relationships, urbanization, and regional growth; trade and communications; environment and war; environmental governance and sustainability.

subject: GEOG
title: Geography, Modernity and Globalization
description: The human geography of the modern world since 1945: global interdependence in economic geography, geopolitics, and cultural geography; consequences of modernization, including demography, urbanization and environmental effects; regional case studies; reactions to modernization.

subject: GEOG
title: Climate Emergency
description: Science, impacts, and parallel crises of the climate emergency; decarbonization challenge and measuring progress towards emission targets; strategies and tools for climate action at local, national, and global levels. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 202 or ENST 202. Recommended: Second-year standing. Equivalency: ENST 202
exclusion_raw: Science, impacts, and parallel crises of the climate emergency; decarbonization challenge and measuring progress towards emission targets; strategies and tools for climate action at local, national, and global levels. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 202 or ENST 202. Recommended: Second-year standing. Equivalency: ENST 202

subject: GEOG
title: Vancouver and Its Region
description: An integrated approach to the physical and human geography of the Lower Mainland of British Columbia. Field trips.

subject: GEOG
title: The State of the Earth
description: The demographic, economic, ecological, and technological factors that underlie current environmental challenges, considering their effects to date and their possible impact in the future. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 211 or ENST 211. Recommended: Second-year standing. Equivalency: ENST 211
exclusion_raw: The demographic, economic, ecological, and technological factors that underlie current environmental challenges, considering their effects to date and their possible impact in the future. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 211 or ENST 211. Recommended: Second-year standing. Equivalency: ENST 211

subject: GEOG
title: Geopolitics
description: Introduction to the political geographic perspectives on today's interdependent world through three themes: borders, regions, and flows.

subject: GEOG
title: Cities
description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization. Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG_V 250 or URST_V 200. Equivalency: URST_V 200.
exclusion_raw: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization. Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG_V 250 or URST_V 200. Equivalency: URST_V 200.

subject: GEOG
title: People, Places & Landscapes
description: Relationships among individuals, social groups, and place, with a focus on everyday spaces. Examines how social identities are intertwined with the places we live.

subject: GEOG
title: Geography of the Pacific Rim
description: An introduction to changing geographies (social, economic, and political) of the Pacific Rim, with special emphasis on the relationships between Canada and Japan.

subject: GEOG
title: Introduction to the Geography of Canada
description: Selected topics in human geography focusing on the regional distribution of natural resources, population, urban systems, and economic activities.

subject: GEOG
title: Climate Justice
description: Concepts and debates in the interdisciplinary field and practice of climate justice; the role of systemic processes and patterns underlying climate change and climate injustices. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 302 or ENST 302. Recommended: Second-year standing. Equivalency: ENST 302
exclusion_raw: Concepts and debates in the interdisciplinary field and practice of climate justice; the role of systemic processes and patterns underlying climate change and climate injustices. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 302 or ENST 302. Recommended: Second-year standing. Equivalency: ENST 302

subject: GEOG
title: Environment and Sustainability
description: Concepts of environment, resources and sustainability; the roles of physical and human geography in understanding the interaction of humans and the environment; introduction to management of environment-resource systems. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 310 or ENST 310. Equivalency: ENST310
exclusion_raw: Concepts of environment, resources and sustainability; the roles of physical and human geography in understanding the interaction of humans and the environment; introduction to management of environment-resource systems. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 310 or ENST 310. Equivalency: ENST310

subject: GEOG
title: Urban Environments
description: The impact of urban development on the natural environment and vice versa. Study of the ecology and metabolism of cities and green urban design, using global and local case studies. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 311 or ENST 311. Equivalency: ENST311
exclusion_raw: The impact of urban development on the natural environment and vice versa. Study of the ecology and metabolism of cities and green urban design, using global and local case studies. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 311 or ENST 311. Equivalency: ENST311

subject: GEOG
title: Climate Change: Science and Society
description: Climates over the geological, historical and instrument periods. Theories of climatic change. Monitoring and modelling the climate system. Impacts of change on environmental and socio-economic systems. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 312 or ENST 312. Recommended pre-requisites: one of GEOS 102, GEOB 102, GEOS 200, GEOB 200, GEOS 204, GEOB 204, ATSC 201, EOSC 112. Third-year standing. Equivalency: ENST312
exclusion_raw: Climates over the geological, historical and instrument periods. Theories of climatic change. Monitoring and modelling the climate system. Impacts of change on environmental and socio-economic systems. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 312 or ENST 312. Recommended pre-requisites: one of GEOS 102, GEOB 102, GEOS 200, GEOB 200, GEOS 204, GEOB 204, ATSC 201, EOSC 112. Third-year standing. Equivalency: ENST312

subject: GEOG
title: Environmental Justice and Social Change
description: Economic, social, political and cultural structures and institutions that shape contemporary socioecological challenges. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG_V 313 or ENST_V 313. Recommended pre-requisite: GEOG_V 121. Equivalency: ENST_V 313 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Economic, social, political and cultural structures and institutions that shape contemporary socioecological challenges. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG_V 313 or ENST_V 313. Recommended pre-requisite: GEOG_V 121. Equivalency: ENST_V 313 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEOG
title: Analysing Environmental Problems
description: Concepts and techniques employed in environmental research; challenges in the areas of climate change, water use, knowledge translation and natural hazards. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG_V 314 or ENST_V 314. Restricted to students with at least third-year standing. Prerequisite: One of GEOG_V 211, GEOB_V 102, GEOB_V 103, GEOS_V 102, GEOS_V 103, EOSC_V 110 or EOSC_V 112. Equivalency: ENST_V 314. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of GEOG_V 211, GEOB_V 102, GEOB_V 103, GEOS_V 102, GEOS_V 103, EOSC_V 110 or EOSC_V 112. Equivalency: ENST_V 314. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Concepts and techniques employed in environmental research; challenges in the areas of climate change, water use, knowledge translation and natural hazards. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG_V 314 or ENST_V 314. Restricted to students with at least third-year standing. Prerequisite: One of GEOG_V 211, GEOB_V 102, GEOB_V 103, GEOS_V 102, GEOS_V 103, EOSC_V 110 or EOSC_V 112. Equivalency: ENST_V 314. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEOG
title: Human and Environmental Geography Field Course
description: Engage in primary field-based research in British Columbia on important issues concerning intercultural understanding, engagement with local communities and sustainability. Focus will shift on a bi-annual basis in accordance with location and available community partners. Special fees and liability insurance are required. Third year standing is recommended. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.
prerequisite_raw: Permission of the instructor.

subject: GEOG
title: Geography of Natural Hazards
description: The role of geophysical events, human ecology, environmental perception, world social and political order in explaining the risk of natural disasters. Assessment of acceptable risk, disaster relief and reconstruction and contrasts between developed and developing nations. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 316 or ENST 316. Recommended pre-requisites: one of GEOB 102, GEOS 102 and one of GEOB 103, GEOS 103. Equivalency: ENST 316
exclusion_raw: The role of geophysical events, human ecology, environmental perception, world social and political order in explaining the risk of natural disasters. Assessment of acceptable risk, disaster relief and reconstruction and contrasts between developed and developing nations. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 316 or ENST 316. Recommended pre-requisites: one of GEOB 102, GEOS 102 and one of GEOB 103, GEOS 103. Equivalency: ENST 316

subject: GEOG
title: Sustainability in a Changing Environment
description: Biophysical and human causes of short- and long-term environmental change at various spatial scales, including measurement, interpretation, and policy. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 318 or ENST 318. Recommended pre-requisite: GEOG 310. Equivalency: ENST 318
exclusion_raw: Biophysical and human causes of short- and long-term environmental change at various spatial scales, including measurement, interpretation, and policy. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 318 or ENST 318. Recommended pre-requisite: GEOG 310. Equivalency: ENST 318

subject: GEOG
title: Environmental Impact Assessment
description: The principles, implementation, and role of environmental impact assessment in environmental management, in Canada and internationally. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 319 or ENST 319. Equivalency: ENST319
exclusion_raw: The principles, implementation, and role of environmental impact assessment in environmental management, in Canada and internationally. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 319 or ENST 319. Equivalency: ENST319

subject: GEOG
title: Historical Geography of Urbanization: Cities, Space, and Power
description: From the origins of urbanism to the modern era.

subject: GEOG
title: Creating Canada
description: Canada from the beginning of European contact to the mid-19th century, stressing the changing geographical patterns of settlement, economy, and culture.

subject: GEOG
title: Constructing Canada
description: The construction of Canadian political space after Confederation, aboriginal-newcomer relations, regional development and conflict, industrialization, urbanization, and war.

subject: GEOG
title: Political Geography
description: Review of political geography and geopolitics; relations among space, power and politics; cases from current global affairs.

subject: GEOG
title: Post- and Anti-colonial Geographies
description: An examination of some key postcolonial and anticolonial theories to engage with questions of geographical difference, uneven development, and the politics of knowledge production at the global scale.

subject: GEOG
title: Theory and Practice in Human Geography
description: A consideration of major intellectual issues and debates in the development of contemporary human geography, in relation to developments in other fields and changes in politics, culture and society.

subject: GEOG
title: Urban Worlds
description: City systems and theories of urban location; internal spatial structure of the city; commercial and industrial location; social areas; neighbourhood and land use change; urban trends and public policy.

subject: GEOG
title: Urban Environmental Politics
description: Effects of urbanization and global environmental change on the geographies of cities across the world. Specific focus on urban environmental justice and inequality. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 351 or ENST 351. Equivalency: ENST351
exclusion_raw: Effects of urbanization and global environmental change on the geographies of cities across the world. Specific focus on urban environmental justice and inequality. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 351 or ENST 351. Equivalency: ENST351

subject: GEOG
title: Urbanization in the Global South
description: The role of cities in development and global capital circulation, and urban politics with emphasis on regions in Latin America, Africa, and Asia. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 352 or URST 352. Equivalency: URST 352
exclusion_raw: The role of cities in development and global capital circulation, and urban politics with emphasis on regions in Latin America, Africa, and Asia. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 352 or URST 352. Equivalency: URST 352

subject: GEOG
title: Geographies of Migration and Settlement
description: International regimes regulating migration, changes in global demographics, immigration policies of nation states, international migration patterns, settlement policies and outcomes.

subject: GEOG
title: Geographies of Urban Indigeneity
description: Examines the geographies of urban Indigenous communities in settler colonial contexts, with a focus on urban Indigenous communities within Canadian cities.

subject: GEOG
title: Society, Culture & Space
description: The development of social and behavioural geography, focusing on how places, landscapes, and environments both reflect and shape social life. Third year standing is recommended.

subject: GEOG
title: Critical Geographies of the Economy
description: History and methods of economic geography. Location of resource industries, manufacturing, and service activities with emphasis on British Columbia in its North American and world setting. Recommended for students with no previous exposure to geographies of the economy, before taking other courses in the 36x and 46x series. Recommended pre-requisite: GEOG 122.

subject: GEOG
title: Geography of Economic Development
description: Geographical approaches to economic development; models of economic development and spatial change; influences on spatial economic change; case studies from the developed, third, and socialist worlds. Recommended pre-requisites: either (a) GEOG 122 or (b) GEOG 260.

subject: GEOG
title: Globalization, Cities, and Regions
description: Forms of economic development; changing location of economic activities and functions; implications for government and politics; local strategies for growth and equity. Recommended pre-requisites: one of GEOG 121, GEOG 122.

subject: GEOG
title: Research Strategies in Geography
description: Formulating a research problem and selecting an appropriate research strategy. Research strategies range from social scientific survey methods to ethnography. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEOG
title: Statistics in Geography
description: Introduction to statistical techniques and their application to geographical problems. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… .

subject: GEOG
title: Geography of Asia
description: A comparative regional analysis stressing the historical development and changing cultural, economic, and political patterns of the area. Special reference to India, Indonesia, China, and Japan.

subject: GEOG
title: Cities, Places, and Borders in Modern Europe
description: Present-day human geography of the cities and regions of Europe. Restricted to students with at least second-year standing.

subject: GEOG
title: Culture, Nature, and Coloniality in Latin America
description: Socio-ecologies in 1491; Spanish colonialism and biological imperialism; contemporary coloniality and neoliberalism; and social movements.

subject: GEOG
title: Geography of Africa
description: A comparative regional analysis of Africa with a focus on contemporary environmental and development issues. Credit will be allowed for only one of GEOG_V 396 or GEOG_V 496. Equivalency: GEOG_V 496. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEOG
title: Climate Studies and Action Capstone
description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website or contact the instructor for details. Restricted to Certificate of Climate Studies and Action students. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG_V 402 or ENVR_V 402. Prerequisite: ENVR_V 401. Equivalency: ENVR_V 402 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: ENVR_V 401. Equivalency: ENVR_V 402 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website or contact the instructor for details. Restricted to Certificate of Climate Studies and Action students. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG_V 402 or ENVR_V 402. Prerequisite: ENVR_V 401. Equivalency: ENVR_V 402 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEOG
title: Environment and Society
description: Geographical analysis of society-environment relations. Relates resource management to environmental politics, political economy, and sustainable development. Perspectives drawn from political ecology and political economy, environmental history and environmental philosophy. Registration is restricted to Geography Majors and Minors or permission of instructor. Recommended: GEOG 310. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 410 or ENST 410. Equivalency: ENST 410 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Geographical analysis of society-environment relations. Relates resource management to environmental politics, political economy, and sustainable development. Perspectives drawn from political ecology and political economy, environmental history and environmental philosophy. Registration is restricted to Geography Majors and Minors or permission of instructor. Recommended: GEOG 310. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 410 or ENST 410. Equivalency: ENST 410 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEOG
title: Dynamics of Agriculture and the Global Environment
description: Contemporary geographies of global agriculture and food production systems in relation to global environmental change and crisis. Restricted to students with 3rd year standing or higher (or permission of instructor).

subject: GEOG
title: Water Management: Theory, Policy, and Practice.
description: Interdisciplinary analysis of critical water issues, in Canada and internationally. Focus on social science perspectives. Emphasis on presentation, research, and essay-writing skills. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 412 or ENST 412. Prerequisite: GEOG 310. Equivalency: ENST 412 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: GEOG 310. Equivalency: ENST 412 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Interdisciplinary analysis of critical water issues, in Canada and internationally. Focus on social science perspectives. Emphasis on presentation, research, and essay-writing skills. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 412 or ENST 412. Prerequisite: GEOG 310. Equivalency: ENST 412 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: GEOG
title: Research in Environmental Geography
description: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year. Registration is restricted to Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of instructor. Recommended: GEOG 313 and 314. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 419 or ENST 419. Equivalency: ENST 419
exclusion_raw: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year. Registration is restricted to Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of instructor. Recommended: GEOG 313 and 314. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 419 or ENST 419. Equivalency: ENST 419

subject: GEOG
title: Development of Environmental Thought
description: An examination of how attitudes toward human nature and non-human nature have changed from Mesolithic times to the present in Western society. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 423 or ENST 423. Equivalency: ENST 423.
exclusion_raw: An examination of how attitudes toward human nature and non-human nature have changed from Mesolithic times to the present in Western society. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 423 or ENST 423. Equivalency: ENST 423.

subject: GEOG
title: Feminist Geographies
description: An introductory survey of contemporary feminist approaches to human geography.

subject: GEOG
title: Historical Geography of British Columbia, I
description: Colonialism, resistance, and land use in early British Columbia. Prerequisite: GEOG 327 and GEOG 328 are recommended.
prerequisite_raw: GEOG 327 and GEOG 328 are recommended.

subject: GEOG
title: Research in Historical Geography
