description: Integration of concepts of history, politics, First Nations, rural development, and forest ecology in natural resources management in Haida Gwaii. A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.

subject: HGSE
title: History and Politics of Resource Management
description: Historical examination of resource management in Canada and conflicts arising therefrom, with emphasis on forests.

subject: HGSE
title: Indigenous Governance and Land Stewardship
description: The political, economic, and legal environment of Aboriginal-Canadian relations and its influence on resource use and management; review of historic relationships, emerging case law, and new reconciliation frameworks.

subject: HGSE
title: Rainforest Ecology and Management
description: Ecology of the temperate rainforests of Haida Gwaii. A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.

subject: HGSE
title: Diversifying Resource-Dependent Communities
description: Examination of the forces that restructure local economies, both historically and contemporarily; link between rural economic development and the legacy of resource development in Aboriginal communities across British Columbia. A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.

subject: HGSE
title: Applied Ecology of Coastal Terrestrial Ecosystems
description: Processes that shape coastal terrestrial ecosystems through time and applications to current ecological reality. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing.

subject: HGSE
title: Marine-Terrestrial Interactions
description: Nutrient cycling between the marine environment and coastal forest ecosystems, how the physical characteristics of this interface can affect these inputs, and which species play a pivotal role in driving interactions.

subject: HGSE
title: Ecology and Management of Island Wildlife
description: Unique biological attributes of island wildlife, such as subspecies, isolated populations, and distinct evolutionary pathways, with a focus on endemic species on Haida Gwaii. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 395 or HGSE 357. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing.
exclusion_raw: Unique biological attributes of island wildlife, such as subspecies, isolated populations, and distinct evolutionary pathways, with a focus on endemic species on Haida Gwaii. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 395 or HGSE 357. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.

subject: HGSE
title: Systems Thinking for Resource Management
description: Introduction to systems thinking and resilience to understand dynamics of social change and innovation; use of case studies to demonstrate applications of different types of ecological knowledge, including traditional knowledge and experiential knowledge. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing.

subject: HGSE
title: Ecosystem-Based Management Seminar
description: History, definitions, and applications of EBM; challenges of achieving both economic and environmental well-being with a focus on resource use and management on Haida Gwaii. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing.

subject: HGSE
title: Ocean People, Culture and Tradition
description: The relationship between the culture of the Haida people and their marine environment; and traditional and modern approaches to management of marine resources.

subject: HGSE
title: Fisheries Co-Management of the North Pacific Coast
description: Concepts of fisheries co-management with a focus on the North Pacific Coast; examples of other comanagement structures regionally and internationally.

subject: HGSE
title: Marine Protected Areas
description: Key elements inherent in MPA and MPA network design, governance, implementation, management, compliance and monitoring.

subject: HGSE
title: Applications in Marine Conservation
description: Exposure to field settings and research techniques in local marine environments.

subject: HGSE
title: Ocean Governance
description: Introduction to key marine conservation and management issues, pairing broad topics with examples on Haida Gwaii to bring theory into practice.

subject: HGSE
title: Introduction to Resilience Theory in Community
description: Theory of social-ecological resilience as applied to cross-cultural community settings, using case studies from communities on Haida Gwaii and other exceptional cases of community resilience.

subject: HGSE
title: Re-Storying History: Indigenous Perspective
description: Exploration of the diversity of Indigenous peoples of British Columbia and Canada and their unique histories, beginning with origin stories and oral histories and moving on to the histories and relationships that Indigenous groups have with the federal, provincial and territorial governments.

subject: HGSE
title: Language and Cultural Continuity
description: An exploration of language as a means of looking at culture, and cultural continuity. Using Xaad Kilthe Haida language as a framing device, students will explore the integral connections between language, culture, history, land, health and resilience.

subject: HGSE
title: Community Planning and Development for Resilience
description: An examination of the challenges and opportunities of developing and diversifying resilient resource dependent cross-cultural, rural communities using Haida Gwaii's comprehensive community planning as a case study.

subject: HGSE
title: Community Resilience Seminar
description: The application of theory, concepts, stories, and histories of community resilience through focused readings, group discussions and engagement with local speakers to provide the opportunity to engage deeply and work at the theory-practice interface.

subject: HGSE
title: Systems Thinking and Social-Ecological Change
description: Theories of systems change, including complex systems thinking, resilience/transformation, transition management and other social science-based change theories. Corequisite: All of HGSE 382, HGSE 383, HGSE 384.
corequisite_raw: All of HGSE 382, HGSE 383, HGSE 384.

subject: HGSE
title: Ecological Economics
description: Underlying philosophy and principles of ecological economics, including the cascading effects of change, unintended consequences of change, and why it might be difficult to separate our ecological goals from our political realities.

subject: HGSE
title: Political and Legal Aspects of Systems Change
description: An examination of the emergence of Aboriginal Law in Canada, with a focus on the development of Aboriginal law as an innovation in shaping new contexts for Federal-, Provincial- and Corporate-Indigenous relations and its implications for systems transformation. Corequisite: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 383, HGSE 384.
corequisite_raw: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 383, HGSE 384.

subject: HGSE
title: Social Innovation and Entrepreneurship
description: An examination of the relationships between culture, ingenuity, creativity, entrepreneurship and innovation required to understand and foster systems change through Indigenous and cross-cultural examples. Corequisite: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 382, HGSE 384.
corequisite_raw: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 382, HGSE 384.

subject: HGSE
title: Case Studies in Social-Ecological Change
description: An exploration of complex issues of social-ecological change in the current social-economic-political context of reconciliation initiatives and Indigenous governance, highlighting the Haida worldview and Haida ways of knowing and being with western understandings of social-ecological systems. Corequisite: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 382, HGSE 383.
corequisite_raw: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 382, HGSE 383.

subject: HGSE
title: Marine Conservation in British Columbia
description: Perspectives and methodologies applied to the conservation of marine environments in British Columbia.

subject: HINU
title: Introductory Hindi-Urdu I
description: Spoken Hindi and Urdu, and written Hindi. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100 or 102.
exclusion_raw: Spoken Hindi and Urdu, and written Hindi. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100 or 102.

subject: HINU
title: Introductory Hindi-Urdu II
description: Continuation of HINU 100. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 101 or 102. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 100.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of HINU 100. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 101 or 102. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 100.

subject: HINU
title: Introductory Hindi-Urdu
description: Spoken and written Hindi and Urdu. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100/101 or HINU 102.

subject: HINU
title: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu
description: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 201/202 or HINU 200. Recommended pre-requisites: one of HINU 101, HINU 102.

subject: HINU
title: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu I
description: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 201. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 101.
exclusion_raw: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 201. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 101.

subject: HINU
title: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu II
description: Continuation of HINU 201. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 202. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 201.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of HINU 201. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 202. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 201.

subject: HINU
title: Introduction to the Devanagari Script
description: The writing system of Hindi for those with some background in the spoken language. May be taken at the same time as HINU 200.

subject: HINU
title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu
description: Further study of the grammar of Hindi and Urdu; advanced conversation; literary readings in Hindi and Urdu; Hindi film. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 301/302 or HINU 300. Recommended pre-requisites: one of HINU 200, HINU 202.

subject: HINU
title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu I
description: Further study of the grammar of Hindi and Urdu; advanced conversation; literary readings in Hindi and Urdu; Hindi film. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 301 or HINU 300. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 202.
exclusion_raw: Further study of the grammar of Hindi and Urdu; advanced conversation; literary readings in Hindi and Urdu; Hindi film. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 301 or HINU 300. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 202.

subject: HINU
title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu II
description: Continuation of HINU 301. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 302 or HINU 300. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 301.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of HINU 301. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 302 or HINU 300. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 301.

subject: HINU
title: Introduction to the Perso-Arabic (Urdu) Script
description: The writing system of Urdu for those with some background in the spoken language. Corequisite: One of HINU 300, HINU 400.
corequisite_raw: One of HINU 300, HINU 400.

subject: HINU
title: Introduction to Hindi and Urdu Literature
description: Readings of various literary genres in Hindi, Urdu and their medieval equivalents. Modern fiction from India and Pakistan; the Urdu ghazal; medieval Hindi bhakti poetry; readings from the Adi Granth of the Sikhs Hindi film. Discussion in Hindi-Urdu of all materials. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 300.

subject: HINU
title: Hindi Film
description: Regional, religious, and historical dialects of Hindi and Urdu as represented in films. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 200 or fluency in Hindi.

subject: HIST
title: What is History?
description: The discipline of history through the study of questions, sources, methods, and controversies. Includes case studies of key turning points in world history to examine what historians do and why it matters.

subject: HIST
title: Global History to 1500 CE
description: Introduction to premodern human societies of Asia, Africa, Europe, and the Americas and cultural, political, social, economic, and religious exchanges from a global history perspective and introduction to historical practices.

subject: HIST
title: World History from 1500 to the Twentieth Century
description: The civilizations of Asia, Europe, Africa and the Americas, with emphasis on the political, economic, ecological and cultural links among them, and the impact of oceanic contact, imperialism, warfare, migration, and globalization.

subject: HIST
title: World History Since 1900
description: International relations; changes in the nation-state system; the emergence and impact of major political ideologies; genocide; decolonization; the globalization of trade; and the dynamics of economic, social, cultural, and environmental change in a global context.

subject: HIST
title: Topics in World History
description: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.

subject: HIST
title: Contemporary Global Issues in Historical Perspective
description: Places issues and problems of current relevance such as disease, terrorism, drugs, or ethnic conflict in historical perspective. Each section will explore a single theme. Check with department for course offerings.

subject: HIST
title: Cultural Histories of Media: From Writing to Tweeting
description: The history of different forms of media in global perspective, with particular attention to audiovisual electronic media.

subject: HIST
title: Global History from the 15th to 20th Century
description: Survey of global history from the 15th to the 20th century, a transformative period marked by profound social, political, economic and environmental changes.

subject: HIST
title: Global History Since 1900
description: Historical survey of the 20th and 21st centuries. Includes international relations, colonialism, decolonization, and political ideologies. Application of historical sources and methods to examine the dynamics of change in a global context.

subject: HIST
title: History Through Photographs
description: The discipline of history through the study of photographs. Explores themes such as colonialism, orientalism, the mass media, representations of gender and sexuality, and protest through photographic evidence.

subject: HIST
title: The Global War on Terror
description: Critically examines the origins, impacts, and legacies of the nebulous “Global War on Terror”.

subject: HIST
title: History Through Video Games
description: Exploration of global histories through video games and uses of video games for research by historians.

subject: HIST
title: Introduction to Historical Archaeology
description: An introduction to the study of medieval and modern material culture, with special emphasis on Canada, using archaeological evidence to illustrate the principles, aims, and techniques of historical archaeology and related disciplines.

subject: HIST
title: Magic, Miracles, and Witchcraft: The Supernatural in Medieval Europe
description: Social, religious, and political functions of the supernatural in late antique, early medieval, and medieval European society (400-1400 CE). Emphasis on the different roles and impacts of magic, witchcraft, and the occult in pre-modern European conceptions of the cosmos.

subject: HIST
title: Global Environmental History
description: The impact humans have had on the environment, and the ways in which the physical environment has shaped human history: climate, agriculture, energy use, and urbanization. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST_V 207 or HIST_V 106. Equivalency: HIST_V 106
exclusion_raw: The impact humans have had on the environment, and the ways in which the physical environment has shaped human history: climate, agriculture, energy use, and urbanization. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST_V 207 or HIST_V 106. Equivalency: HIST_V 106

subject: HIST
title: Global Indigenous Histories
description: An introduction to the experiences of Indigenous peoples and the nature of colonialisms around the world since 1500, and an introduction to historical practices and perspectives. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST_V 208 or HIST_V 107. Equivalency: HIST_V 107
exclusion_raw: An introduction to the experiences of Indigenous peoples and the nature of colonialisms around the world since 1500, and an introduction to historical practices and perspectives. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST_V 208 or HIST_V 107. Equivalency: HIST_V 107

subject: HIST
title: Global History of Capitalism
description: The history of capitalism in its global dimension from the beginnings to the age of industrialization. An investigation of economies - in both their practices and cultures - around the world and across the ages from ancient times to the modern era. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST_V 209 or HIST_V 108. Equivalency: HIST_V 108
exclusion_raw: The history of capitalism in its global dimension from the beginnings to the age of industrialization. An investigation of economies - in both their practices and cultures - around the world and across the ages from ancient times to the modern era. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST_V 209 or HIST_V 108. Equivalency: HIST_V 108

subject: HIST
title: History of Global Migration
description: Explores the mass migration of people in the modern world through a global perspective. Industrial and export-oriented economies in the mid-nineteenth century to contemporary issues of border regulation and refugees. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 211 or HIST_V 110. Equivalency: HIST_V 110.
exclusion_raw: Explores the mass migration of people in the modern world through a global perspective. Industrial and export-oriented economies in the mid-nineteenth century to contemporary issues of border regulation and refugees. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 211 or HIST_V 110. Equivalency: HIST_V 110.

subject: HIST
title: History Through Film
description: Explores films as a powerful medium for making history. Analyze visual arguments and historical representations, claims, and narratives made in films.

subject: HIST
title: History of Canada: Moments that Matter
description: An introduction to major turning points in Canadian history. Exploration of the social, political, cultural, and environmental transformations/revolutions that have shaped Canada from early European colonialism to the twenty-first century.

subject: HIST
title: Introduction to Public History in Canada: Confronting the Canadian Past
description: An introduction to public history in Canada that explores the politics and practice of representing the past in a variety of sites, such as museums, monuments, and films, and examines questions of historical interpretation, memory, and audience.

subject: HIST
title: Health, Illness and Medicine I: From the Ancient World to the Early Modern Period
description: History of western medicine, from the Ancient World to the Enlightenment, with a focus on social and cultural ideas surrounding the body, health, and disease, and the development of medical institutions.

subject: HIST
title: Health, Illness and Medicine II: The Modern World from 1700 to the Present
description: Western medicine from 1700 to the present, with a focus on social and cultural ideas surrounding the body, health and disease, and the development of medical institutions.

subject: HIST
title: Modern Caribbean History
description: A survey of social, cultural and political history of Anglophone, Francophone and Spanish Caribbean from the Haitian Revolution to the present.

subject: HIST
title: History of Africa
description: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST_V 256 or HIST_V 256. Equivalency: AFST_V 256
exclusion_raw: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST_V 256 or HIST_V 256. Equivalency: AFST_V 256

subject: HIST
title: Science, Medicine, and Technology in the Ancient and Medieval Worlds
description: The history of science, medicine, and technology, emphasizing networks, exchanges, and encounters in a global context.

subject: HIST
title: Science and Society in the Contemporary World
description: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 260 or PHIL_V 260. Equivalency: PHIL_V 260.
exclusion_raw: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 260 or PHIL_V 260. Equivalency: PHIL_V 260.

subject: HIST
title: Japan and Global History, 1550 - 1900
description: Thematic study of comparisons and relations between Japan and the world outside (primarily Europe and China). Commercial expansion, systems of world order, social institutions, religious and ideological expression, and state organization.

subject: HIST
title: History of India
description: Societies, cultures, and politics of the Indian subcontinent from its ancient civilizations to the formation of the modern nation-states of South Asia.

subject: HIST
title: Steppe Empires in World History
description: Powerful empires that flourished over the Eurasian Steppe, from the earliest to modern times, and how regimes and cultures associated with these empires have changed the world.

subject: HIST
title: Islamic World History
description: The history of the Islamic world in its global dimensions from its origins to the present day through the themes of religion, law, politics, culture, and modernity.

subject: HIST
title: Vikings: Then and Now
description: Historical and archaeological study of Viking-Age and premodern Scandinavia and the Vikings complex legacies in contemporary cultural heritage.

subject: HIST
title: Global Medieval Heritage and Policy
description: Examination of cultural heritage work and policy based on contemporary international case studies that engage the global medieval past.

subject: HIST
title: Researching Local History from the Ground Up
description: Sources and methods for reconstructing local history that can be used by Social Studies teachers in B.C. The aim is to develop an appreciation of the formative processes and past experiences that created one's familiar community.

subject: HIST
title: History of British Columbia
description: The social, political, cultural, environmental, and economic transformations that have made British Columbia. Topics include the histories of Indigenous and settler peoples, the modern state, migration, activism, and identity.

subject: HIST
title: Quebec from the End of the 18th Century to the Present
description: Relations between the English and the Canadians prior to the Rebellions of 1837-38, the emergence of French Canadian nationalism after 1840, the impact of State formation and industrialization in Quebec, the Quiet Revolution, and the independence movement.

subject: HIST
title: The British Empire after 1850
description: Transformation of the British imperial system from the mid-nineteenth century to de-colonization and neo-colonialism after the second World War.

subject: HIST
title: Southern Africa
description: Pre-colonial, colonial, and contemporary, emphasizing South Africa. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST_V 312 or HIST_V 312. Equivalency: AFST_V 312
exclusion_raw: Pre-colonial, colonial, and contemporary, emphasizing South Africa. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST_V 312 or HIST_V 312. Equivalency: AFST_V 312

subject: HIST
title: Modern Africa
description: Africa in the 19th and 20th Centuries: Islamic revolutions, the end of the slave trades, colonial conquest, labour struggles, Christianity’s new appeal, PanAfricanism, nationalist resistance, and decolonization. Post-independence challenges of nation-building and economic development. Cultural renaissances and the politics of tradition. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST_V 313 or HIST_V 313. Equivalency: AFST_V 313
exclusion_raw: Africa in the 19th and 20th Centuries: Islamic revolutions, the end of the slave trades, colonial conquest, labour struggles, Christianity’s new appeal, PanAfricanism, nationalist resistance, and decolonization. Post-independence challenges of nation-building and economic development. Cultural renaissances and the politics of tradition. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST_V 313 or HIST_V 313. Equivalency: AFST_V 313

subject: HIST
title: Early Modern Britain
description: The social, economic, political, religious, cultural, and intellectual history of Britain between the Reformation and the Industrial Revolution, emphasizing the rise of modern industrial society.

subject: HIST
title: History of Vancouver
description: Selected themes in the history of Vancouver, exploring how the study of the past illuminates or explains major debates in the city today. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 316 or HIST_V 415 Equivalency: HIST_V 415.
exclusion_raw: Selected themes in the history of Vancouver, exploring how the study of the past illuminates or explains major debates in the city today. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 316 or HIST_V 415 Equivalency: HIST_V 415.

subject: HIST
title: Britain, 1850-1918
description: Britain from the Great Exhibition to the Great War: the creation of a mass electorate, the New Imperialism, the New Woman, and the ways that class, race, gender, and sexuality shaped modern Britain.

subject: HIST
title: Britain, 1945 to the Present
description: Survey of recent British history, with emphasis on de-colonization, emergence of the welfare state, new social movements and patterns of immigration, and Britain's changing relationship with Europe.

subject: HIST
title: Constitutions in Canadian History: From Pre-Contact to the Charter of Rights
description: European precedents, Colonial self-government, Canadian Confederation, and issues such as gay rights, abortion, and First Nations land rights. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 320 or HIST_V 414. Equivalency: HIST_V 414.
exclusion_raw: European precedents, Colonial self-government, Canadian Confederation, and issues such as gay rights, abortion, and First Nations land rights. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 320 or HIST_V 414. Equivalency: HIST_V 414.

subject: HIST
title: Empires, Wars, and Revolutions in Europe and the Americas,1763-1838
description: Political, social, cultural, and intellectual transformations that reshaped the Atlantic world between 1763 and 1838; special attention will be given to the American, French, and Haitian Revolutions, the Latin American Wars of Independence and Canadian rebellions.

subject: HIST
title: Inventing Canada, 1840-1896
description: An examination of political, cultural and national developments within the British North American colonies in the second half of the nineteenth century. Credit will not be granted for both HIST 324 or 326, if 326 was taken before 2007W.

subject: HIST
title: Canada 1896-1945: Boom, Bust and War
description: Includes Aboriginal policy, immigration and national identity; Canada, Britain and the US; World Wars; economic modernization; the Great Depression; regionalism; political and social movements; and the creation of 'Canadian' culture. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST_V 325 or HIST_V 426.
exclusion_raw: Includes Aboriginal policy, immigration and national identity; Canada, Britain and the US; World Wars; economic modernization; the Great Depression; regionalism; political and social movements; and the creation of 'Canadian' culture. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST_V 325 or HIST_V 426.

subject: HIST
title: Canada Since 1945: Affluence and Anxiety in the Atomic Age
description: Includes immigration policy; the welfare state; Aboriginal peoples; the Cold War; resource economies and national politics; continentalism and free trade; constitutional crises; conflicting nationalisms; and new social movements. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST_V 326 or HIST_V 426.
exclusion_raw: Includes immigration policy; the welfare state; Aboriginal peoples; the Cold War; resource economies and national politics; continentalism and free trade; constitutional crises; conflicting nationalisms; and new social movements. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST_V 326 or HIST_V 426.

subject: HIST
title: Colonial America: Encounter and Settlement, 1607 - 1763
description: Encounters between European, African, and Indigenous North American peoples as well as the history of the colonies within the Atlantic world, from the late sixteenth century to the eve of the American Revolution.

subject: HIST
title: Rebels in America: Revolution to Civil War, 1763 - 1865
description: Issues in U.S. history from the colonial era through the Civil War, including the causes of the American Revolution; slavery; aboriginal peoples; labour, gender, and industrialization.

subject: HIST
title: Heroes, Rebels, Villains, Folks: The People Who Shaped Canada
description: Canadian history through the lens of individual people's lives and their social impact. Themes include race, class, gender, sexuality, indigeneity, colonialism, slavery, immigration, moral regulation, and activism.

subject: HIST
title: History of the Global Financial Order
description: Origins and transformation of the global financial order (18th century onward) in relation to war, state-building, international political economy, and colonialism.

subject: HIST
title: The United States, 1865-1900: Labour, Race, Gender, and Empire
description: The complicated political, economic and social history of the United States in the three decades following the Civil War.

subject: HIST
title: Slave Societies in the Americas
description: A comparative analysis of the institution of chattel slavery, its growth, its effects on slaves and masters, its relation to the larger society, and the causes of its decline, in the various cultures of the Americas. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 332 or HIST_V 444. Equivalency: HIST_V 444.
exclusion_raw: A comparative analysis of the institution of chattel slavery, its growth, its effects on slaves and masters, its relation to the larger society, and the causes of its decline, in the various cultures of the Americas. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 332 or HIST_V 444. Equivalency: HIST_V 444.

subject: HIST
title: African-American History, 1450 - 1850
description: The history of African Americans from the beginnings of the African slave trade in the 15th Century through the mid-1800s and the coming of the U.S. Civil War.

subject: HIST
title: African-American History, 1850 to the Present
description: The history of African-Americans from the Civil War and emancipation through the present. Topics include the Jim Crow system; the Harlem Renaissance; the Civil Rights Movement; and the current economic and political status of Americans of African ancestry.

subject: HIST
title: Imperial and Colonial Archaeology and Museums
description: The impact of imperialism and colonialism on archaeological practice, museum collecting, and the telling of historical narratives.

subject: HIST
title: The 1960s in Global Perspective
description: The history of the 1960s from a transnational perspective: culture, social change, student activism, and global conflict. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 337 or HIST_V 418. Equivalency: HIST_V 418.
exclusion_raw: The history of the 1960s from a transnational perspective: culture, social change, student activism, and global conflict. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 337 or HIST_V 418. Equivalency: HIST_V 418.

subject: HIST
title: American Modernity: The United States, 1890-1945
description: U.S. emergence as an industrial powerhouse and, eventually, a global superpower; responses to industrial society, meaning of modern times, economic upheaval and social change, U.S.'s role as a world power, and politics of race, ethnicity, and gender.

subject: HIST
title: The United States Since 1945: The Limits of Power
description: American military and geo-political power during and after Cold War; wars in Korea, Vietnam, and Middle East; domestic issues including McCarthyism, social movements (blacks, women, youth, gays and lesbians, and Native Americans), consumerism, immigration, and rise of New Right.

subject: HIST
title: Histories of the American West
description: Frontier ideologies in relation to race, gender, class, sexuality. Place-making and historical narrative in and about the western part of the United States.

subject: HIST
title: Medieval Jewish History
description: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the time of the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the expulsion of professing Jews from Spain and Portugal at the end of the fifteenth century.

subject: HIST
title: Modern Jewish History
description: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the beginning of the sixteenth century to the present with special emphasis on changing attitudes to Jews and Judaism, social and cultural transformations.

subject: HIST
title: Medieval Gender, Christianity, and the Body
description: Medieval representations and treatments of gendered bodies through disciplines of history, religion, and archaeology. Implications of a dominant male standard in early Christian thought.

subject: HIST
title: Crime and Punishment in Canadian History
description: The relationship between law and society; the development of legal institutions and the evolving character of crime in Canada. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 345 or HIST_V 419. Equivalency: HIST_V 419.
exclusion_raw: The relationship between law and society; the development of legal institutions and the evolving character of crime in Canada. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 345 or HIST_V 419. Equivalency: HIST_V 419.

subject: HIST
title: Medieval and Imperial Russian History, 998 to 1800
description: Russian politics, society, culture, and empire, beginning with the medieval period extending through the era of Peter the Great's modernization efforts and the Enlightenment.

subject: HIST
title: History of the Holocaust
description: A study of the systematic attempt to destroy European Jewry during the Nazi regime, 1933- 1945. Topics of special importance include: the motivations and behaviour of the perpetrators; the reactions of the victims; the roles of bystanders. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 348 or HIST_V 441. Equivalency: HIST_V 441.
exclusion_raw: A study of the systematic attempt to destroy European Jewry during the Nazi regime, 1933- 1945. Topics of special importance include: the motivations and behaviour of the perpetrators; the reactions of the victims; the roles of bystanders. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 348 or HIST_V 441. Equivalency: HIST_V 441.

subject: HIST
title: Imperial Russian History, 1800 to 1917
description: History of Russia from the time of Catherine the Great to the Russian Revolution with particular focus on social and cultural history.

subject: HIST
title: Modern Middle Eastern History
description: Politics, culture, society, war, and diplomacy; themes include colonialism, nationalism, and authoritarianism; emphasis on the 20th and 21st centuries.

subject: HIST
title: The Ottoman Empire
description: The rise and fall of the Ottoman empire; themes include Islamic law, politics, art, culture, gender relations, and the influence of religion on statecraft.

subject: HIST
title: Nineteenth Century Germany
description: The political, social, and cultural history of modern Germany during the long nineteenth century (1780s to the early twentieth century).

subject: HIST
title: Twentieth-Century Germany
description: The political, social, and cultural history of Germany in the twentieth century.

subject: HIST
title: History of Mexico
description: Examines themes in the last five hundred years of Mexican history, with an emphasis on the critical reading of primary sources and the use of a variety of texts that may include letters, diaries, paintings, photographs, novels, and movies.

subject: HIST
title: State and Society in 20th century Cuba
description: The history and historiography of 20th century Cuba, with particular attention to changing state structures and their impact on everyday life.

subject: HIST
title: International Relations, 1900-1945
description: The evolution of the contemporary international system from its nineteenth-century origins to the global order of the mid-twentieth century. Credit will only be granted for only one of HIST_V 360 or HIST_V 432.

subject: HIST
title: International Relations Since 1945
description: The evolution of the contemporary international system from the end of the Second World War to the beginning of the twenty-first century. Credit will only be granted for only one of HIST_V 361 or HIST_V 432.

subject: HIST
title: The Islamic Golden Age
description: Political, economic, social, and cultural history of the premodern Islamic World and its global connections during the Abbasid Caliphate, with attention to the relevance of this past to our contemporary world.

subject: HIST
title: Europe in the Early Middle Ages
description: A survey of the development of institutions, ideas and the economy in Europe from about 400 through about 1000 CE.

subject: HIST
title: Europe in the Late Middle Ages
description: A survey of the development of institutions, ideas and the economy in Europe from about 1000 CE through the fourteenth century.

subject: HIST
title: Europe During the Renaissance
description: The interplay between new and traditional ideas, styles, and institutions from the fourteenth to the mid-sixteenth century, with emphasis upon the relationship of social, economic, and political factors to intellectual and cultural change.

subject: HIST
title: Europe During the Reformation
description: An examination of European history that place both the Protestant Reformation and the Catholic Reformation in the broader context of the political, social, cultural, and economic changes during the early modern era.

subject: HIST
title: Europe in the Age of the Enlightenment
description: Europe during the age of the Enlightenment, from the end of the religious wars to the French Revolution, with emphasis on political, social, cultural, and intellectual changes in their global context.

subject: HIST
title: Europe in the 19th Century
description: An investigation of main themes in European history from the French Revolution to the beginning of the 20th century. Topics of particular importance are: domestic politics; the interaction of states; the formation of new states; social and economic transformations affecting the whole civilization; major cultural expressions of the century.

subject: HIST
title: Europe, 1900-1950
description: Europe in the first half of the twentieth century. Themes include the imperialist system, two world wars and their aftermaths, political and social movements of the interwar years, the Depression, and the crisis of liberal democracy. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 369 or HIST_V 462. Equivalency: HIST_V 462.
exclusion_raw: Europe in the first half of the twentieth century. Themes include the imperialist system, two world wars and their aftermaths, political and social movements of the interwar years, the Depression, and the crisis of liberal democracy. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 369 or HIST_V 462. Equivalency: HIST_V 462.

subject: HIST
title: Europe Since 1950
description: Europe since the middle of the twentieth century. Themes include the Cold War, the development of separate social and political systems in Western and Eastern Europe, the emergence of the welfare state, and the problems of European integration.

subject: HIST
title: U.S. Foreign Relations from Independence to World War II
description: U.S. foreign policy and international history. Examines the American rise to power and political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 371 or HIST_V 408. Equivalency: HIST_V 408.
exclusion_raw: U.S. foreign policy and international history. Examines the American rise to power and political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 371 or HIST_V 408. Equivalency: HIST_V 408.

subject: HIST
title: U.S. Foreign Relations since 1945
description: U.S. foreign policy and international history. Political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 372 or HIST_V 409. Equivalency: HIST_V 409.
exclusion_raw: U.S. foreign policy and international history. Political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 372 or HIST_V 409. Equivalency: HIST_V 409.

subject: HIST
title: History of Hong Kong
description: History, culture, and identities of Hong Kong from the early 1800s to the present. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 373 or ASIA_V 373. Equivalency: ASIA_V 373.
exclusion_raw: History, culture, and identities of Hong Kong from the early 1800s to the present. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 373 or ASIA_V 373. Equivalency: ASIA_V 373.

subject: HIST
title: The First World War
description: WWI as a global war; cultural history and legacy; impact of imperialism on the war; military technology. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 374 or HIST_V 404. Equivalency: HIST_V 404.
exclusion_raw: WWI as a global war; cultural history and legacy; impact of imperialism on the war; military technology. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 374 or HIST_V 404. Equivalency: HIST_V 404.

subject: HIST
title: The Second World War
description: Precursors and consequences of the war; military, political, cultural, social, and economic histories of how the war shaped and reflected its global context. Themes include totalitarianism, genocide, and imperialism and decolonization. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 375 or HIST_V 406. Equivalency: HIST_V 406.
exclusion_raw: Precursors and consequences of the war; military, political, cultural, social, and economic histories of how the war shaped and reflected its global context. Themes include totalitarianism, genocide, and imperialism and decolonization. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 375 or HIST_V 406. Equivalency: HIST_V 406.

subject: HIST
title: History of Cantonese Worlds
description: The history, culture, languages, and identities of the multi-faceted Cantonese worlds, in the context of Chinese history and the Cantonese diaspora. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 377 or ASIA_V 323. Equivalency: ASIA_V 323. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The history, culture, languages, and identities of the multi-faceted Cantonese worlds, in the context of Chinese history and the Cantonese diaspora. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 377 or ASIA_V 323. Equivalency: ASIA_V 323. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: History of Early China
description: History of China from the earliest times to the disintegration of the Tang Empire. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the origins and foundations of Chinese society. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 378 or ASIA_V 320. Equivalency: ASIA_V 320.
exclusion_raw: History of China from the earliest times to the disintegration of the Tang Empire. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the origins and foundations of Chinese society. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 378 or ASIA_V 320. Equivalency: ASIA_V 320.

subject: HIST
title: History of Later Imperial China
description: History of China from the end of Tang to the eve of its modern transformation. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the political, socio-economic, and cultural changes in imperial China. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 379 or ASIA_V 340. Equivalency: ASIA_V 340.
exclusion_raw: History of China from the end of Tang to the eve of its modern transformation. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the political, socio-economic, and cultural changes in imperial China. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 379 or ASIA_V 340. Equivalency: ASIA_V 340.

subject: HIST
title: Imperialism and Nationalism in Southeast Asia
description: The history of European imperial rule, the forms of resistance to it, and the formation of nationalist movements in Southeast Asia. The countries studied include Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines, Burma, and Thailand.

subject: HIST
title: Post-Colonial Southeast Asia
description: The history of the Japanese occupation, wars of independence, international relations of the independent nation-states, and internal armed conflicts. Special attention will be paid to the wars in Vietnam, Indonesia, and East Timor.

subject: HIST
title: Foundations of Sikh Traditions
description: Sikh religious beliefs, practices, institutions, and thought. Emphasis on the history of the Sikh Gurus and their writings, and the larger social and cultural forces within which the tradition developed.

subject: HIST
title: The Making of Modern Sikhism
description: Historical, social, and cultural forces that shaped Sikh religious beliefs, practices, institutions, and thought in the modern period, including both colonial and post-colonial contexts and the transnational Sikh community.

subject: HIST
title: India from Raj to Republic
description: Exploration of the rise of the East India Company as territorial power, the formation of a colonial society in India, competing responses to British rule, the struggle for independence, and the legacies of partition.

subject: HIST
title: Voices from Medieval India
description: History of medieval India explored through different stories from and about India's pre-modern past. Studies trends in society, religion, politics, and material life to reveal the dynamism of this period and to challenge simplified narratives of Hindu-Muslim confrontation.

subject: HIST
title: India in the Early Modern World: Kings, Courtesans, and Saints
description: History of India during the period of Mughal rule (roughly 1500-1750). Studies the role of India and the Mughals within the global dynamics of the early modern world.

subject: HIST
title: Asian Cities
description: Urban, environmental, and cultural history through Asian Cities.

subject: HIST
title: Human Rights in World History
description: Changing ideas about humanity and rights. Considers the relationship between human rights and the nation-state, imperialism, and capitalism. Assesses the efforts to end large-scale human rights violations and the role of the United Nations.

subject: HIST
title: Scientific Revolution: Circulation of Knowledge in the Early Modern World
description: The profound transformation of knowledge about the world in the context of the first global encounter of civilizations between 1450 and 1800. Explores the foundations for modern science.

subject: HIST
title: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science
description: An examination of historical, conceptual, and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 393 or PHIL_V 360. Equivalency: PHIL_V 360
exclusion_raw: An examination of historical, conceptual, and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 393 or PHIL_V 360. Equivalency: PHIL_V 360

subject: HIST
title: Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History
description: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 394 or PHIL_V 364. Equivalency: PHIL_V 364.
exclusion_raw: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 394 or PHIL_V 364. Equivalency: PHIL_V 364.

subject: HIST
title: The Nuclear Century: Scientists, Atoms, and the World Order Since 1900
description: Science and the military-industrial complex; quantum and relativistic revolutions in physics; nuclear energy and weapons of mass destruction; international tensions, environmental damage, and global perils.

subject: HIST
title: Environmental History of North America
description: Overview of land use and environmental change in Canada and the United States; examines ideas and practices that shaped indigenous and non-indigenous resource exploitation, management, and activism to the end of the twentieth century.

subject: HIST
title: Environmental History of the Modern World
description: Major themes in global environmental history and historiography since 1500, with a particular focus on the nineteenth through twenty-first centuries.

subject: HIST
title: The History of Modern Medicine
description: The history of health and disease in the modern world, focusing in particular on the emergence and history of modern biomedicine.

subject: HIST
title: The Practice of Oral History
description: The practice, ethics, and politics of oral history. Provides research training, where students design and complete projects based on oral history interviews.

subject: HIST
title: Seafaring in the Age of Sail
description: Humankind's encounter with its ocean frontier through exploration, trading, fishing, whaling, piracy, and naval warfare from 1400 to 1850.

subject: HIST
title: Problems in International Relations
description: Selected topics such as trade, migration, diplomacy, war, migration, colonialism, and post- colonialism. Priority for registration to majors in History or International Relations.

subject: HIST
title: Seminar in the History of International Relations
description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or International Relations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Diplomacy and Conflict in the Middle East, 1914 to the Present
description: International relations in the Middle East in the aftermath of the Ottoman Empire, with special attention to the conflicts between Jews of Palestine/Israel and their Arab neighbours.

subject: HIST
title: Imagining the Nation: 19th- and 20th-Century Canada
description: The political and intellectual history of the concept of the nation in French and English Canada, and the different forms of nationalism it inspired from the middle of the nineteenth century to the 1995 Quebec Referendum.

subject: HIST
title: Economic and Business History of Modern Japan
description: From 1800 to the present; emphasis on the business strategies of Japan's largest companies; attention also to broader economic topics such as international trade, government policy, social impact of industry, business and politics, labour, and post-1971 multi-nationalism.

subject: HIST
title: Economic History of the Pre-Modern World
description: Historic origins and drivers of economic growth around the globe.

subject: HIST
title: War and Society
description: Continuity and change in the relations of war and society, the connections between the economy, society, the military, and government in peacetime as well as war; not a course in military history.

subject: HIST
title: Fourth-Year Honours Seminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Gender and Sexuality in the Modern U. S.
description: Gender roles and gender relations from the Gilded Age to the present day. Topics include political movements such as suffrage and feminism; labour and recreation; marriage, family, and children's socialization; sexuality; and popular culture.

subject: HIST
title: Politics and Culture in Fin-de-Sicle Europe (1890-1914)
description: Explores relationships between politics, culture, and social change in Europe. Topics include the changing role of intellectuals: literary aestheticism, painting, design and the city, origins of psychology.

subject: HIST
title: History of Global Health
description: The emergence of global health since 1800. Medical and social response to infectious diseases and epidemics, the ethical foundations of global health, and the relationship among health, colonialism, international collaboration, and the developing world.

subject: HIST
title: History of North American Children and Youth
description: Children's history from settler days to the present. Topics include education, work and play, ideologies of childhood and adolescence, children's material and popular culture, and differences of identity based on region, class, race, and gender.

subject: HIST
title: Selected Topics in United States History
description: Examines in depth a significant period, theme, or topic in the history of the United States. Possible subjects include The West, the Great Depression, the Sixties, and Class, Race, and Gender.

subject: HIST
title: Honours Essay
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Family and Community in Latin America
description: The role of family and community from the colonial period to the present. Emergence of the nation state as it affected community and family structures.

subject: HIST
title: Class and Culture in Latin America
description: The relationship between culture and class formation from the late colonial period to the present.

subject: HIST
title: Gender and Sexuality in Latin America
description: The construction of gender ideologies and gendered and sexual identities, including masculine, feminine, and transgendered, in modern Latin America. [3-0-0]

subject: HIST
title: Race in the Americas
description: Legacies of African, European, and Asian migrations, and colonial encounters with indigenous peoples in the Americas. Includes the creation of racial categories, the making of transnational and transracial families, and the emergence of race-based social and cultural movements.

subject: HIST
title: Revolution and Resistance in the Third World
description: Revolutionary movements in the Third World during the second half of the twentieth century; the radicalisation of anticolonial nationalism; the impact of anticolonial radicalism in the developed world; the decline of Marxism as a revolutionary inspiration.

subject: HIST
title: First Contacts in the Pacific
description: An interdisciplinary history of early European contact with the Indigenous peoples of the northwest coast of North America and the Pacific Islands.

subject: HIST
title: Topics in Indigenous History of Canada
description: Selected interdisciplinary topics in the history of Canada's Indigenous peoples after European contact, including historical demography, economic interdependency, missionary encounters, gender relations, and interactions with colonial powers and the nation state. Recommended: HIST 302 or other background in the field. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Topics in Indigenous History of the United States
description: Interdisciplinary topics in the history of the United States' Indigenous peoples from before European contact. HIST 302 or other background in the field is recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Topics in Comparative Indigenous History
description: Comparative interdisciplinary analysis of selected topics in Indigenous history in North America and beyond. HIST 302 or other background in the field is recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Aboriginal Title in British Columbia: History and Legacy
description: Colonial land policy, Indigenous resistance and organizing, treaties, and court decisions. Some previous knowledge of Indigenous history is strongly recommended.

subject: HIST
title: Imagining the Middle Ages
description: Influence of nostalgia for the history, literature, arts, architecture, and traditions of medieval European centuries on modern intellectual, artistic, and nationalist and racist political movements in Europe and North America. Restricted to students with third-year standing or higher.

subject: HIST
title: Women in the Middle Ages
description: A study of women's roles in the family, society, law, religion, the economy, and literature from about 500 to 1500 CE.

subject: HIST
title: Ideas and Religions of the Middle Ages
description: A survey and exploration of the development, interpenetration, conflict, and transformation of various intellectual and religious traditions during the Middle Ages.

subject: HIST
title: Documenting Punjabi Canada
description: Exploration of the history of the Punjabi Canadian community through traditional text-based methods and oral history collection. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 475 or ASIA_V 475. Equivalency: ASIA_V 475. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Exploration of the history of the Punjabi Canadian community through traditional text-based methods and oral history collection. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST_V 475 or ASIA_V 475. Equivalency: ASIA_V 475. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Law and Society in the Middle Ages
description: The history of law in the Middle Ages, including English common law, civil (Roman) law, and canon law, and how changes in both medieval law and society affected the development of each.

subject: HIST
title: Constitutional History of Medieval Europe
description: The evolution of political institutions, the emergence of royal governments as well as representative assemblies and urban republic and conflicts within and among them leading to the emergence of modern structures.

subject: HIST
title: Medieval Portraits and Personalities
description: The lives of leading and controversial figures in the Middle Ages and the means by which they have portrayed themselves and been portrayed by others.

subject: HIST
title: Education and Society in Modern China
description: The relationship between education and society in China since 1600; classical learning and the civil service examination system; popular literacy; sino-foreign interactions in education; education and gender; nationalism and education; the education revolution in China after 1949.

subject: HIST
title: Chinese Migration
description: This history of Chinese migrations from the founding of the state to the present day. Migration is used as a focus through which to examine some key themes of Chinese history; ethnicity, boundary creation, economic growth and international relations.

subject: HIST
title: Asian Migrations to the Americas
description: Examines both the historical and contemporary contexts for migration from Asia to Canada and the Americas.

subject: HIST
title: East Asian Military systems and warfare China
description: Confucian societies are often thought of as ones in which the brush is mightier than the sword. In fact the military has been a crucial factor in East Asia, and warfare has been the engine which has driven many of the most significant changes in East Asian history. This course will look at the evolution of East Asian military systems, and at the impact of recurrent warfare on East Asia societies.

subject: HIST
title: Asian Migrant Communities in Vancouver
description: This course will examine the history of Asian migration to Vancouver and British Columbia, focusing on the development of local communities and provide a background in historical research methods that will enable the students to conduct research on the history of these communities.

subject: HIST
title: History of Alternative and Complementary Medicine: Acupuncture to Yoga
description: Alternative and complementary healing in history, including Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), yoga, meditation, and alternative drug therapies. Specific themes may vary from year to year.

subject: HIST
title: Seminar for Majors in History
description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Science and the Enlightenment
description: Examines the relationship between science and society in the long eighteenth century. Topics include empiricism, classification, academies, print culture, and voyages of exploration.

subject: HIST
title: History and Social Relations of Modern Sciences.
description: Science and society in the 19th to 21st Centuries. [3-0-0]

subject: HIST
title: Machines, Media, and Modernity: Frankenstein to Cinema
description: The cultural contexts and consequences of science and nineteenth century technology. European and North American developments.

subject: HIST
title: Evolution and the Sciences of Mind, Brain, and Behaviour
description: Examines how Darwin's theory of evolution changed the investigation of human nature. Questions will be historical and scientific, but will also concern the social, ethical, and existential stakes raised by the human mind as a product of evolution.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in Canadian History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in American History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in British History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in Medieval History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Professional Development for Historians
description: Offers essential skills for academic and non-academic paths in the historical profession as well as identifying alternative career possibilities for historians. Offers essential skills for academic and non-academic paths in the historical profession as well as identifying alternative career possibilities for historians. Restricted to students in the following programs: PhD in History, MA in History This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in French History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in Central European History

title: Readings in Russian and East European History

description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

title: Readings in Early Modern European History

title: Readings in Modern European History

subject: HIST
title: Readings in Chinese History (to 1911)
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in Chinese History (post-1911)
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Methodology and Sources in Chinese History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in 20th-Century Japanese History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in Early Modern Japanese and World History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Methodology and Sources in Japanese History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Seminar in Japanese History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in Southeast Asian History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in International and Global History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in South Asian History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in Latin American History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in Environmental History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Readings in Aboriginal History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Oral History
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: M.A. Research Seminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HIST
title: Ph.D. Research Seminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HPB
title: Green Building Contemporary Practice
description: Enhanced building environmental performance and the integration of green building principles, strategies and technologies. Equivalency: ARCH574 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HPB
title: Regenerative Development
description: The relationship between human and natural systems in the context of regenerative design. Provides an understanding of how regenerative approaches differ from green design and how they can offer new insights and directions for design. Equivalency: ARCH575 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HPB
title: Whole Building Energy Modelling and Simulation
description: Modelling energy in a high performance building. Introduction to indoor space requirements. Heat and mass transfer through building envelopes. Climate. Fenestration, daylighting, solar energy. Introduction to major energy models. Modelling project. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HPB
title: Building Energy Systems Design
description: Designing the energy system for a high performance building. Heating, cooling and ventilation load estimation. Heating and cooling using solar, electrical and chemical energy. Air, water, and refrigerant distribution systems. Energy storage. System design project. Design performance assessment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HPB
title: Capstone: Greening Existing Buildings
description: Students will analyze the performance and design data of an existing building and propose design changes that will improve performance, considering the real priorities of the client, a building owner or operator. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HPB
title: Capstone: New Building Energy Systems Design
description: Students will take a building under design and work with the designers towards a high performance energy system. The project will be a proposed high performance building with a client, a design team, and energy performance objectives. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Research Methods in Human Nutrition
description: Experimental design, methods of survey research, nutritional epidemiology, clinical research, and laboratory animal research. Issues such as animal models, ethics in animal and human research, statistical methods, and preparation of written reports and manuscripts, etc., will be addressed. Required of all M.Sc. and Ph.D. students in Human Nutrition. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Current Issues in Nutrition and Metabolism
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Current Issues in Applied Nutrition
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Nutrition Assessment Across the Lifespan
description: [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Business & Entrepreneurship in Dietetics
description: [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Indigenous Health in Dietetics
description: [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: M.Sc. Seminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Food Provision and Management in Dietetics
description: Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics graduate program. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: All of HUNU 540, HUNU 573, HUNU 575. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of HUNU 540, HUNU 573, HUNU 575. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Dietetics Practice Education Placement III.I Management
description: Practice education placement in management and leadership settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics program. Pass/fail. Prerequisite: All of HUNU_V 541, HUNU_V 578, HUNU_V 580, HUNU_V 581. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of HUNU_V 541, HUNU_V 578, HUNU_V 580, HUNU_V 581. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Counselling Skills in Dietetics
description: Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics graduate program. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: HUNU 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: HUNU 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: M.Sc. Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Advances in Human Nutrition
description: [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Leadership in Dietetics and Health
description: Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics graduate program. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Population and Public Health Dietetics
description: Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics graduate program. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Nutrition Care I
description: Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics graduate program. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: All of HUNU 500, HUNU 510, HUNU 550. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of HUNU 500, HUNU 510, HUNU 550. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Nutrition Care II
description: Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics program. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: All of HUNU_V 500, HUNU_V 575, HUNU_V 578. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of HUNU_V 500, HUNU_V 575, HUNU_V 578. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Nutrition Care III
description: Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics program. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: All of HUNU_V 545, HUNU_V 573, HUNU_V 575, HUNU_V 576, HUNU_V 578. Corequisite: HUNU_V 525. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of HUNU_V 545, HUNU_V 573, HUNU_V 575, HUNU_V 576, HUNU_V 578. Corequisite: HUNU_V 525. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: HUNU_V 525. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Dietetics Practice Education Placement I.I Introduction to Nutrition Care
description: First practice education placement in clinical settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics program. Pass/fail. Prerequisite: All of HUNU_V 545, HUNU_V 575. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of HUNU_V 545, HUNU_V 575. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Dietetics Practice Education Placement I.II Population Health
description: Practice education placement in public health and/or community settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics program. Pass/fail. Prerequisite: All of HUNU_V 540, HUNU_V 573. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of HUNU_V 540, HUNU_V 573. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Professional Dietetic Practice II
description: Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics program. Pass/fail. Prerequisite: All of FNH_V 380, HUNU_V 578. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of FNH_V 380, HUNU_V 578. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Dietetics Practice Education Placement II Research Capstone
description: Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics program. Prerequisite: All of HUNU_V 500, HUNU_V 578. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of HUNU_V 500, HUNU_V 578. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Dietetics Practice Education Placement III.II Nutrition Care
description: Practice education placement in clinical settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics program. Pass/fail. Prerequisite: All of HUNU_V 578, HUNU_V 580, HUNU_V 581. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of HUNU_V 578, HUNU_V 580, HUNU_V 581. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Dietetics Practice Education Placement IV Nutrition Care
description: Final clinical practice education placements in clinical settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Master of Nutrition and Dietetics program. Pass/fail. Prerequisite: HUNU_V 582. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: HUNU_V 582. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU
title: Ph.D. Seminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: HUNU

subject: IAR
title: Perspectives and Methods in Asia Pacific Policy Studies
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IAR
title: The New Institutionalism in Asia
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IAR
title: Culture & Globalization in Asia-Pacific
description: Interdisciplinary investigation of the idea that globalization is not limited to the economic sphere but also includes popular culture, communications, travel, food and desire of the other. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IAR
title: East Asian Organizations in Comparative Perspective
description: Contemporary theories of organizational behavior applied to economic organizations in Japan, with some comparisons to South Korean, Taiwanese and Chinese firms. Historical and theoretical conceptualizations of business organizations with empirical applications as applied to East Asian firms. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IAR
title: The City and the National Imagination
description: Examines relations between the idea of the nation and its embodiment in the spaces of the city through visual, spatial, and architectural representations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IAR
title: Cross-National Comparisons in the Social Sciences
description: The methodological and epistemological underpinnings of cross-national comparative research across the social sciences. Focused on but not limited to Northeast Asia. Credit will be granted for only one of IAR_V 511 or SOCI_V 511. Equivalency: SOCI_V 511. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The methodological and epistemological underpinnings of cross-national comparative research across the social sciences. Focused on but not limited to Northeast Asia. Credit will be granted for only one of IAR_V 511 or SOCI_V 511. Equivalency: SOCI_V 511. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IAR
title: Multinational Firms and Policy Issues in Asia-Pacific
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IAR
title: Issues in East Asian Diplomacy
description: Political, transnational, and bilateral diplomatic issues. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IAR
title: Master's Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IAR
title: Practicum in Asia Pacific Policy Studies
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IEST
title: Pro-Seminar European Studies
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IEST
title: Internship/European Exchange
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IEST
title: Extended Essay
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IEST
title: M.A. Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IEST
title: The Economics of European Integration
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IEST
title: External Relations of the European Union
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IEST
title: Political and Legal Foundations of the European Union
description: Credit will not be given for both IEST 541 and LAW 341. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IEST
title: Citizenship and Migration in Contemporary Europe
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IEST
title: Geography of Europe
description: Credit will not be given for both IEST 591 and GEOG 493. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: IGEN
title: Integrated Technical Communication
