description: Processes, techniques and considerations in the planning, implementation and evaluation of physical education, sport and exercise programs in both public and private agencies. [3-0] Prerequisite: All of KIN 140, KIN 262 and Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: All of KIN 140, KIN 262 and Third-year standing.

subject: KIN
title: Exploring Alternative Methods for Teaching Games and Sports
description: Examination of innovative, developmentally appropriate, conceptual and tactical approaches to team game instruction. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: One of KIN 140.
prerequisite_raw: One of KIN 140.

subject: KIN
title: Inclusive Approaches to Sport Psychology
description: Examination of the psychological and behavioural processes of athletes from a social justice perspective. The focus will be on the role of social structures, sociocultural norms, power relations, and social identities in shaping athletes’ perceptions and lived experiences in sport. [3-0-0]Prerequisite: All of KIN 150, KIN 160, and third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: All of KIN 150, KIN 160, and third-year standing.

subject: KIN
title: Understanding and Changing Physical Activity Behaviour
description: Examining the influence of psychological factors across different settings and populations, with a particular focus on interventions aimed at enhancing mental health. Understanding psychology can be used to design effective interventions at the individual and community level. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: KIN 150.
prerequisite_raw: KIN 150.

subject: KIN
title: Psychobiology of Physical Activity
description: Exploration of the role of physical activity and exercise on brain health, mental health, and underpinning psychological and biological mechanisms. This course deepens students’ capacity to read and interpret scientific evidence. [3-0] Prerequisite: All of KIN 150, KIN 205, KIN 206.
prerequisite_raw: All of KIN 150, KIN 205, KIN 206.

subject: KIN
title: Aging, Health, and Society
description: Examination of current issues in the sociology of aging and health. Prerequisite: All of KIN 160, KIN 262.
prerequisite_raw: All of KIN 160, KIN 262.

subject: KIN
title: Health Promotion and Physical Activity
description: Current perspectives on health promotion and health education; design and implementation of health promotion strategies in a variety of arenas, particularly health promotion/education strategies aimed at encouraging physical activity. [3-0] Prerequisite: All of KIN 150, KIN 160, KIN 205, KIN 262.
prerequisite_raw: All of KIN 150, KIN 160, KIN 205, KIN 262.

subject: KIN
title: Interculturalism, Health and Physical Activity
description: Examination of multiculturalism and interculturalism in the delivery of community-based physical activities for diverse populations; connections between physical activity and health in different cultural contexts. Community service learning and participation in culturally unfamiliar physical activities are core elements. Prerequisite: All of KIN 160, KIN 262.
prerequisite_raw: All of KIN 160, KIN 262.

subject: KIN
title: Indigenous Health and Wellness
description: The complex social, cultural, historical, and economic factors that shape health and wellness within Indigenous communities will be explored through extensive blended learning and experiential learning opportunities. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: All of KIN 160, KIN 262.
prerequisite_raw: All of KIN 160, KIN 262.

subject: KIN
title: Exercise Management of Chronic Neurological Balance and Mobility Conditions
description: Work with an inter-professional health team to assess and rehabilitate neurological balance and mobility deficits. Students will assist in the delivery of exercise-based rehabilitation at the Physical Therapy Rehabilitation Clinic and the BC Brain Well Program. Restricted to students in the BKIN program with third- or fourth-year standing. Pass/Fail. Corequisite: KIN_V 320 and KIN_V 411. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: KIN_V 320 and KIN_V 411. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Undergraduate Research Experience in Kinesiology
description: Opportunity for independent study that includes original data collection, under the direction of a KIN faculty member. Prerequisite: Third-year standing and permission of the Associate Director, Undergraduate Program.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing and permission of the Associate Director, Undergraduate Program.

subject: KIN
title: Computational Methods for Data Acquisition and Signal Processing in Kinesiology
description: Hands-on laboratory course with an emphasis on developing critical computational research skills for the acquisition, processing and presentation of data related to human movements. Recommended prerequisite: Undergraduate degree in Kinesiology (or related field) including neuromechanical science courses. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Gap Analysis
description: Using analytics to obtain, describe, and visualize data to create a sport profile. Determine optimal programming decisions for coached athletes based on their performance pathway and gold medal profile. Apply research methods and principles of scientific inquiry, performance analysis, descriptive, prescriptive, and predictive analytics to improve athlete development and performance. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Psychology of Leadership and Group Processes
description: Contemporary theory, research and application with regard to leadership and group processes in the context of sport and exercise. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Business of High Performance Sport in Canada
description: Canada's sport system, its governance and stakeholders; financial management for high performance sport; communications, marketing, and sponsorship of high performance sport. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Bioenergetics of Physical Activity
description: Basic energy systems of the human body; primarily concentrating on the bioenergetics of the skeletal muscle cell, recovery from muscular work, substrate utilization, muscle fiber types, strength, endurance and the physiological assessment of maximal performance. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Measurement of Human Motion
description: A critical evaluation of research tools used to measure and assess human motor performance including electromyography, anthropometry, ergometers, indirect calorimetry, cinematography, and indirect dynamics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Psycho-Social Aspects of Physical Activity
description: Selected psycho-social considerations in sport: initial and continuing involvement in the competitive sport environment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Physiological Aspects of Physical Activity
description: Survey of research regarding the physiological aspects of activity; the effects of altitude and environmental temperature on man's performance in exercise and sports. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Skill Acquisition: Practice Design & Instruction
description: Research and theories on learning, maintaining, and excelling at movement skills, with a particular emphasis on sport. Effective practice conditions for learning and elite athletic performance. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Seminar in Human Sensorimotor Control
description: Reports and discussions of research literature concerning theories and findings in human sensorimotor control. Emphasis is given to understanding the basic mechanisms underlying sensorimotor control, utilizing frameworks drawn from motor behaviour, cognitive neuroscience, and neurophysiology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Research Methods in Kinesiology
description: Research methods applied to the study of sport and physical activity, the nature of scientific inquiry, the design of experiments, the survey as a research medium, the historical and philosophical methods of inquiry, the writing of the research report. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Qualitative Methods in Sport, Leisure, and Health Studies
description: Theoretical, methodological, and ethical debates about and approaches to qualitative methods; issues in and approaches to qualitative inquiry. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Research Methods for Sport & Health Sciences
description: Interpretation and evaluation of research methods and scientific findings related to coaching sciences and exercise and health-related professions. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Seminar in Mechanical Analysis of Human Movement
description: An investigation of human movement using cinematographical and other research methods. The case study approach will be used to examine kinesiological concepts and principles. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Seminar in Health Promotion Through Physical Activity
description: The relationship of new concepts in health to the promotion of health through physical activity; the application of research findings from a number of disciplines to the identification, selection, and targeting of health promotion/education strategies related to physical activity. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Principles of Applied Sports Analytics
description: Technical and applied knowledge in data science and analytics related to high performance sports. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Seminar in Body, Exercise, and Society
description: Personal, social, and cultural significance of the body in sport, exercise, and physical culture. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Sport, Leisure and Consumer Culture
description: Sport and leisure are viewed in the context of theoretical debates about mass society and consumer culture. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Physical Education, Sport and Exercise Programs
description: The development of curricula, implementation and evaluation techniques in physical education, sport and exercise programs; relationships of programs in schools, community centres and other institutions. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Performance Planning
description: Application of findings from sport profile and gap analysis to the planning and design of high performance training and coaching programs. Focuses on quadrennial, annual, meso and microcycle planning to integrate key factors that impact athlete performance and progression along the athlete development pathway. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Coaching Effectiveness
description: Analysis of athlete performance and appropriate design and application of coaching intervention and skill acquisition for athlete and coach development. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Seminar in the Organizational Analysis of Leisure
description: Selected topics in organizational theory as applied to the analysis of leisure and sport organizations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Master's Graduating Paper
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: High Performance Sport Inquiry
description: Blended learning approach in a problem-based setting. Students support their own research interests within the high performance sport arena. Prerequisite: KIN 572. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: KIN 572. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Practical Applications in High Performance Sport
description: Apply and reflect on professional competency within existing coach or leader context in relevant High Performance sport environment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Directed Field Studies in Kinesiology
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KIN
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KORN
title: Basic Korean I
description: An introduction to the grammar and syntax of modern spoken and written Korean. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 100 or KORN 102.
exclusion_raw: An introduction to the grammar and syntax of modern spoken and written Korean. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 100 or KORN 102.

subject: KORN
title: Basic Korean II
description: Continuation of KORN 100. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 101 or KORN 102. Recommended pre-requisite: KORN 100.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of KORN 100. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 101 or KORN 102. Recommended pre-requisite: KORN 100.

subject: KORN
title: Basic Korean
description: An introduction to the grammar and syntax of modern spoken and written Korean. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 100/101 or KORN 102.

subject: KORN
title: Basic Korean Grammar
description: Emphasis on grammar, writing, and reading. For heritage learners and students with prior background in spoken Korean.

subject: KORN
title: Enriched Summer Intensive Beginning
description: An integrated language course developing communicative competence in speaking, listening to, reading, and writing modern Korean. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KORN
title: Intermediate Korean
description: Reading and writing of modern colloquial Korean at an intermediate level. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 201/202 or KORN 200. Recommended pre-requisites: one of KORN 101, KORN 102.

subject: KORN
title: Intermediate Korean I
description: Reading and writing of modern colloquial Korean at an intermediate level. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 201 or KORN 200. Recommended pre-requisite: KORN 101.
exclusion_raw: Reading and writing of modern colloquial Korean at an intermediate level. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 201 or KORN 200. Recommended pre-requisite: KORN 101.

subject: KORN
title: Intermediate Korean II
description: Continuation of KORN 201. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 202 or KORN 200. Recommended pre-requisite: KORN 201.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of KORN 201. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 202 or KORN 200. Recommended pre-requisite: KORN 201.

subject: KORN
title: Readings in Korean Topics
description: Readings in intermediate-level Korean on aspects of Korean culture, customs, and contemporary life, along with structured conversations based on those readings. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300. Recommended pre-requisites: one of KORN 200, KORN 202.

subject: KORN
title: Readings in Korean Topics I
description: Readings in intermediate-level Korean on aspects of Korean culture, customs, and contemporary life, along with structured conversations based on those readings. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300. Recommended pre-requisite: KORN 202 or permission of instructor.

subject: KORN
title: Readings in Korean Topics II
description: Continuation of KORN 301. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300. Recommended pre-requisite: KORN 301 or permission of instructor.

subject: KORN
title: Introduction to Hancha: Sinographs and Sino-Korean Vocabulary I
description: Chinese characters in their Korean pronunciations and shapes. Students learn approximately 250 sinographs, related sinographic vocabulary, and do structured readings in mixed scripts on aspects of Korean culture and contemporary life. Prerequisite: One of KORN 200, KORN 202. or placement approval. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of KORN 200, KORN 202. or placement approval. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KORN
title: Introduction to Hancha: Sinographs and Sino-Korean Vocabulary II
description: Continuation of KORN 351. Students learn an additional 250 sinographs and related sinographic vocabulary. Prerequisite: KORN 351. or placement approval. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: KORN 351. or placement approval. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: KORN
title: Readings in Middle and Early Modern Korean
description: History and structure of the Korean language through targeted close readings in different editions of an illustrated text from the 15th and 18th centuries. Prerequisite: Non-heritage speakers should have completed KORN 410 or be taking it concurrently. Heritage and native speakers of Korean welcome.
prerequisite_raw: Non-heritage speakers should have completed KORN 410 or be taking it concurrently. Heritage and native speakers of Korean welcome.

subject: LAIS
title: Seminar in Advanced Research Methods
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAIS
title: Doctoral Proseminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAIS
title: Academic and Research Practices in Library, Archival and Information Studies
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAIS
title: Advanced Study in Major Area
description: Prerequisite: All of LAIS 605, LAIS 607 and one of LAIS 608, LAIS 609. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of LAIS 605, LAIS 607 and one of LAIS 608, LAIS 609. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAIS
title: Advanced Study in Minor Area
description: Prerequisite: All of LAIS 605, LAIS 607 and one of LAIS 608, LAIS 609. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of LAIS 605, LAIS 607 and one of LAIS 608, LAIS 609. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAIS
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Trees and Shrubs in Landscape
description: Culture and identification of landscape materials with emphasis on woody plants. Elementary principles of landscape composition. Suitable for students of other faculties and departments interested in landscape materials and their uses, but priority given to Agroecology and Landscape Architecture students. [2-2]

subject: LARC
title: Landscape Architecture Design Studio I
description: Landscape design methods and processes. Corequisite: LARC 511. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: LARC 511. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Landscape Architecture Design Studio II
description: Prerequisite: All of LARC 316, LARC 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of LARC 316, LARC 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Landscape Architecture Design Studio III
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Landscape Architecture Design Studio IV
description: Prerequisite: One of LARC 502, ARCH 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of LARC 502, ARCH 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Landscape Architecture Design Studio V
description: Prerequisite: LARC 504. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: LARC 504. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Introductory Workshop
description: Commences in August one week prior to Labour Day. Enrolment mandatory for all incoming students. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 511 or ARCH 502. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Commences in August one week prior to Labour Day. Enrolment mandatory for all incoming students. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 511 or ARCH 502. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Planting Design
description: Functional, ecological, and behavioural theory and practice applied to planting design at different scales. Prerequisite: LARC 316. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: LARC 316. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Landscape Architecture History I
description: History, principles, and theory of landscape architecture in Europe, America and Asia. Influence of cultural attitudes and societal change upon natural environments, parks, gardens, and town planning. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Landscape Architecture Theory
description: Theoretical positions in landscape architecture and their relation to designed landscapes. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Landscape Architecture History II
description: The spatial and material practices of a range of individuals and groups who have expanded, reframed, or subverted methods germane to landscape architecture. Includes diverse perspectives primarily situated in a twentieth-century North American context. Prerequisite: LARC_V 522. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: LARC_V 522. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Design Research Methods
description: Examination of various design research methods in contemporary practice in landscape architecture. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Landscape Technologies I
description: Terrain design, drainage and stormwater management. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 531 or LARC 431. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Terrain design, drainage and stormwater management. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 531 or LARC 431. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Landscape Technologies II
description: Hard landscape materials. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Site Analysis and Planning
description: Site analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing stormwater management design. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 540, LARC 440 or DES 231. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Site analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing stormwater management design. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 540, LARC 440 or DES 231. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Landscape Planning and Management
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Aesthetics and Sustainability
description: Analysis and planning of landscapes to communicate sustainability and to inform public awareness and design by exploring the relationship between aesthetics and sustainability. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Environment and Urban Form
description: Ecological structures and the structure and quality of urban life. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Professional Practice
description: Ethical, legal and business context of professional practice, including contracts, project management. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Green Network Planning
description: Theory and methods of long-range green space planning for urban areas. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Graduate Project Part I
description: Preparation of a graduation design project proposal including literature review. Prerequisite: LARC 525. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: LARC 525. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Graduate Project Part II
description: Design component, completion, and defense of the graduation design project. Prerequisite: LARC 595. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: LARC 595. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LARC
title: Research Thesis
description: Open only to M.A.S.L.A. candidates. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LASO
title: Introduction to Law and Society
description: Ideas, concepts, and frameworks for thinking about the nature of law and legal processes in both Canadian and global contexts.

subject: LASO
title: Against the Law
description: Competing approaches to law and legal authority shaped by conflicts over historical and contemporary inequalities, including the exercise of and challenges to coercive law enforcement and claims made for legal redress.

subject: LAST
title: Introduction to Latin American Studies
description: An overview of the culture and society of Latin America from ancient to contemporary times and from Argentina to Mexico.

subject: LAST
title: Popular Culture in Latin America
description: The culture of everyday life, both rural and urban: issues of identity, popular memory, resistance, negotiation, as expressed through ritual, crafts, the body, social movements, films, music, and literature.

subject: LAST
title: Issues of Development in Modern Latin America
description: Theory of development in the Latin American context: current problems and development alternatives.

subject: LAST
title: Climate Justice in Latin America
description: Survey of the geographic, colonial, racialized, and gendered underpinnings and materialities of the climate crisis in Latin America.

subject: LAST
title: Human and Civil Rights in Latin America
description: Focuses on human rights movements; state violence and impunity; reform of criminal justice systems; rights of indigenous peoples, women, and minorities; international protection of human rights; the UN and inter-American systems.

subject: LAST
title: Indigenous Latin America
description: Historical and contemporary cultures, struggles, and experiences of Indigenous peoples in what is now Latin America. Different cultural areas or regions may be selected to illustrate the course's principal themes.

subject: LAST
title: Afro-Latin America
description: The Black experience and the diversity of the African diaspora in Latin America.

subject: LATN
title: Beginning Latin I
description: Classical Latin, Part I.

subject: LATN
title: Beginning Latin II
description: Classical Latin, Part II. Prerequisite: LATN 101.
prerequisite_raw: LATN 101.

subject: LATN
title: Intermediate Latin I
description: Completion of the grammatical foundations of classical Latin, Part I. Prerequisite: LATN 102.
prerequisite_raw: LATN 102.

subject: LATN
title: Intermediate Latin II: Beginning Reading
description: Completion of the grammatical foundations of classical Latin, Part II; an introduction to the reading of unadapted passages of Latin literature and discussion of their cultural contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of LATN_V 202 or LATN _V 301. Pre-requisites: LATN _V 201. Equivalency: LATN _V 202.
exclusion_raw: Completion of the grammatical foundations of classical Latin, Part II; an introduction to the reading of unadapted passages of Latin literature and discussion of their cultural contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of LATN_V 202 or LATN _V 301. Pre-requisites: LATN _V 201. Equivalency: LATN _V 202.

subject: LATN
title: Advanced Latin: Readings
description: Readings in Latin. Prerequisite: One of LATN _V 301, LATN _V 202, LATN _V 200.
prerequisite_raw: One of LATN _V 301, LATN _V 202, LATN _V 200.

subject: LATN
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Indigenous Settler Legal Relations
description: Critical examination of the history and legacy of colonial legal orders in Canada. This course is compulsory for students who commence their Juris Doctor degree in September 2020 or later. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Canadian Constitutional Law
description: Principles of Canadian constitutional law, including Canadian federalism, the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, and the unique constitutional status and rights of Aboriginal Peoples in Canada. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Advocacy
description: Introduction to principles of written and oral advocacy. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Contracts
description: Historical development; formation and enforceability of contracts; parties; contractual terms; changes of circumstances; remedies for breach. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Criminal Law and Procedure
description: Bases of criminal responsibility; principles and objectives of the criminal law and procedure; pre-trial procedure. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Property Law
description: The legal concept of ownership and its changing nature and application, including equitable principles, the acquisition and transfer of interests, the regulation of use, Aboriginal title, and statute-based systems for registering interests in land. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Torts
description: A study of the bases of civil liability for intentionally and accidentally caused harms. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Public Law
description: An overview of the constitutional and statutory law governing the legislative, executive, and judicial branches of government in Canada, including an introduction to statutory construction and analysis and the administration of law in Canada. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Introduction to Public Law and the Charter
description: An introduction to the structure, powers, duties of and relationships among the various institutions and actors that comprise the Canadian state, the principles of statutory interpretation, and the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Legal Research and Writing
description: Introduction to legal research and writing skills and the use of legal databases. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Aboriginal and Treaty Rights
description: An overview of the unique constitutional status and rights of Aboriginal Peoples in Canada. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Jurisprudence and Critical Perspectives
description: Introduction to the basic principles of legal theory and critical perspectives on law. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Philosophy of Law
description: An examination of the principal schools of legal theory, such as legal positivism, legal realism, sociological jurisprudence, and contemporary rights theory. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Fundamental Concepts of Law
description: A study of some of the fundamental principles and ideas that cut across many areas of the substantive law, including such concepts as fault, intent, legal personality, possession, ownership, justice, and causation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Legal Traditions and Ideas of Law
description: Historical and comparative study of the evolution of legal systems from custom and proto law emphasizing influences and sharing ideas among traditions of the Ancient Near East, Athens, Roman Empire, Western Europe and China. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Transnational Law
description: Introduction to principles of public and private international law and research methods for international legal materials.

subject: LAW
title: Law, Society and State
description: Theories of the relationship between the legal system, social relations and the state. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Corporate Social Responsibility and the Law
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Women, Law and Social Change
description: A survey of feminist approaches to law, with reference to selected substantive areas of the law. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Feminist Legal Theory
description: Recent developments in feminist legal theory. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Economic Analysis of Law
description: Economic analysis used to explore, describe, evaluate and offer prescriptive suggestions for legal decision-making. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Property Law and Theory
description: The idea of property, its origins, its justifications, its uses, its effects, and the rules that surround and create it. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Legal History
description: The relationship between law, society and historical change, normally emphasizing 19th and 20th century issues. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: International Law
description: The history, sources and evidence of international law and its relation to municipal law; international personality; state jurisdiction; and treaties. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 316 or POLI 376. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The history, sources and evidence of international law and its relation to municipal law; international personality; state jurisdiction; and treaties. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 316 or POLI 376. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Marine Resources Law
description: Legal regimes governing the protection and exploitation of ocean resources. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: International Human Rights
description: The recognition and protection of human rights in international law. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Indigenous Peoples in Comparative and International Law
description: The legal situation of indigenous peoples in various states and in modern international law. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Law of Armed Conflict
description: The legal basis for armed conflict or military operations; the rights and obligations of combatants and civilians in a region of armed conflict; war crimes. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: International Law Problems
description: Selected issues in international law. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: International Environmental Law
description: Customary international law and treaties relating to the environment; institutional structures. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Conflict of Laws
description: A study of the private legal problems arising in cases in which the relevant facts cut across provincial or national boundaries. Recommended to be taken in third year. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 325 or LAW 592. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: A study of the private legal problems arising in cases in which the relevant facts cut across provincial or national boundaries. Recommended to be taken in third year. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 325 or LAW 592. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: International Trade Law
description: Rules and regulatory systems that govern the international movement of capital, goods and services. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: International Business Transactions
description: Legal problems in international financial and commercial transactions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: International Commercial Disputes
description: International commercial arbitration and other means for resolving legal disputes relating to international commercial transactions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Maritime Law
description: Canadian maritime law and admiralty practice. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Cultural Law
description: Relationship of law to cultural activities and phenomena. International, national, and indigenous laws as they apply to various forms of tangible and intangible cultural expression. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Introduction to Asian Legal Systems
description: Introduction to the comparative study of legal systems of East and South-East Asia, including those of China and Japan. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Chinese Law: Implications for Canada-China Relations
description: Overview of the laws and legal system in the People's Republic of China with some introduction to Taiwan law. Legal interpretation of implications for Canada-China relations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Japanese Law
description: Constitutional foundation and protection of human rights under Japanese law. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Human Rights in Asia
description: Legal issues relating to civil, political, social and cultural rights in particular areas in Asia. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Comparative Law
description: Basic theory of comparative law and the differences between the civil law tradition and the common law tradition. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: European Union Law
description: The legal system of the European Union as created by the treaties establishing the Union and by the Union's institutions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Innovation, Law, and Regulation
description: Examines and applies interdisciplinary research on regulation, governance, and institutional and legal design under conditions of change and uncertainty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Comparative Constitutional Law
description: Comparison of the constitutional history, government structure and powers, and protection of individual rights between the United States and Canada. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Aboriginal Peoples and Canadian Law
description: Survey of the history and present status of the legal relationships between Canada's Aboriginal peoples and the state. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Aboriginal and Treaty Rights
description: Rights of Aboriginal people stemming from their aboriginal status and from treaties. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: First Nations Self-Government
description: Issues relating to First Nations' assumption of self-government powers. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: First Nations and the Administration of Justice
description: The justice system and its operation in relation to First Nations people. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: First Nations and Economic Development
description: Legal issues affecting land use and economic activity involving First Nations' resources. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Children and the Law
description: The civil and criminal law affecting juveniles; custody, guardianship and adoption. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Racism and Law
description: Legal issues relating to race and racism, including related issues of gender, culture or identity. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Women, Law and Family
description: Feminist and other critical perspectives on the relationship between unequal gender relations and laws embodying a concept of family. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Reproduction and Law
description: Legal issues relating to human reproduction. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Sexuality and Law
description: Legal issues relating to sexual activity, orientation and identification. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Municipal Law
description: The municipality as a legal entity; its creation, operation and powers; by-laws and their validity; contractual liability; judicial review; business regulation; expropriation and land use control. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Land Use Planning
description: The legal and administrative aspects of the regulation of land use and development, especially at the local level. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Immigration Law
description: Admission of immigrants into Canada; refugee protection; practice and procedure before immigration tribunals and the courts. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 377 or LAW 577. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Admission of immigrants into Canada; refugee protection; practice and procedure before immigration tribunals and the courts. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 377 or LAW 577. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Refugee Law
description: International and Canadian refugee law; the Refugee Convention and its implementation in Canada; the practice of refugee law in Canadian courts and tribunals. Course content does not duplicate LAW 377. Credit will only be given to one of LAW 378 or LAW 578. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Disabilities and Law
description: Legal issues relating to people with disabilities. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Health Law
description: Legal and policy issues relating to the health care system, including legal aspects of individual and public health decision-making. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Mental Health Law
description: The law relating to commitment and treatment issues for persons with mental disabilities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Social Welfare Law
description: Aspects of the law structuring the provision of welfare and other social services in Canada. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Sustainable Development Law
description: The linkages, intersections, and tensions between the legal regulation of the environment and competing social and economic priorities. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 386 or LAW 586. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The linkages, intersections, and tensions between the legal regulation of the environment and competing social and economic priorities. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 386 or LAW 586. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Environmental Law in Practice
description: Jurisdiction, remedies and administrative schemes as they apply in practice to selected environmental law problems. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Environmental Law Workshop
description: Legal research and writing for environmental agency or NGO under supervision of faculty member and lawyer. Not offered every year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 390 or LAW 591. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Legal research and writing for environmental agency or NGO under supervision of faculty member and lawyer. Not offered every year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 390 or LAW 591. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Natural Resources Law
description: A foundation course dealing with legal problems common to the management of natural resources such as fisheries, mines and minerals, petroleum, forests, and water resources. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Green Rights and Warrior Lawyers
description: Explore the human right to a healthy environment and the rights of nature through the stories of environmental lawyers and defenders worldwide who struggle for environmental justice through law. No pre- or co-requisites. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Mining Law
description: Acquisition of mineral interests; development, financing and organization of mining companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Forest Law
description: Acquisition of timber interests; development, financing and organization of timber companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year; consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 395 or LAW 595. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Acquisition of timber interests; development, financing and organization of timber companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year; consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 395 or LAW 595. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Fisheries Law

subject: LAW
title: Oil and Gas Law
description: Legal regimes for the disposition of interests in petroleum; government regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Advanced Criminal Law

subject: LAW
title: Advanced Criminal Procedure

subject: LAW

subject: LAW
title: Principles of Sentencing
description: This course is designed to teach students the law and policy involved in sentencing persons convicted of crimes. Students will develop an in-depth understanding of statutory and case law rules regarding sentencing and will be required to apply those rules to actual sentencing scenarios. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: The Law of Homicide
description: Available in online distance education format only. Elements of sentencing for murder, manslaughter and infanticide; defences to homicide; parties to homicide; and corporate homicide. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW

exclusion_raw: Survey of statutory provisions and judicial decisions governing the taxation of corporations and shareholders. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 408 or LAW 562. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Taxation of Partnerships

exclusion_raw: Survey of statutory and judicial rules governing the taxation of income earned through partnerships. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 409 or LAW 563. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW

exclusion_raw: The tax aspects of international transactions. Not offered each year; consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 410 or LAW 565. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

exclusion_raw: Legal issues arising from the development of the Internet and cyberspace. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 425 or LAW 572. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Rise Women's Legal Centre - Clinic
description: The Clinic is a family law legal clinic where students are temporarily articled under the Law Society of BC and practice primarily family law, providing legal advice and assistance to clients, under the supervision of instructors. Pass/Fail. Corequisite: LAW 431. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: LAW 431. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Advanced Legal Research

description: This seminar explores issues of social justice for families in the legal system, necessary to undertake the Rise Women's Legal Centre Clinic in the Fall, Spring and Summer terms. Corequisite: LAW 429.
corequisite_raw: LAW 429.

exclusion_raw: Remedies of an unsecured creditor; fraudulent conveyances and preferences; builders' liens; bankruptcy. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 443 or LAW 599. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

title: Sports Law
description: Legal issues relating to the sports industry and those who participate in it. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 448 or LAW 548. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Legal issues relating to the sports industry and those who participate in it. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 448 or LAW 548. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Media and Entertainment Law
description: Selected legal issues relating to the media and entertainment industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 449 or LAW 573. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Selected legal issues relating to the media and entertainment industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 449 or LAW 573. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Trusts

subject: LAW
title: Succession

exclusion_raw: The law of wills and intestate succession, variation of wills, principles of probate and administration of estates. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 452 or LAW 574. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW

exclusion_raw: The history and development of equitable remedies such as specific performance, injunctions, declarations, relief against forfeiture, and tracing. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 453 or LAW 575. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Real Estate Transactions

subject: LAW
title: Real Estate Development

subject: LAW
title: Advanced Corporate Law
description: Selected topics such as the nature of shares, equity financing, corporate structure and reorganization, and shareholder squeezeouts. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Corporate Transactions

subject: LAW

exclusion_raw: The law relating to the distribution of securities. Continuous and timely disclosure requirements and civil liability. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 463 or LAW 576. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

title: Competition Policy

subject: LAW

subject: LAW

subject: LAW

Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 468 or LAW 588. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Ethical dimensions of legal practice in Canada, including legislation, regulations, rules and cases, as well as the roles of lawyers, the legal profession and the legal system. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 468 or LAW 588. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW

Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 469 or LAW 590. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Problems in the conduct of civil litigation including: ethical considerations; substantive problems such as notice, pleading, and discovery; and selected procedural problems. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 469 or LAW 590. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Innocence Project

subject: LAW

description: Substantive legal principles and rules of evidence that can cause or help to prevent wrongful convictions or other miscarriages of justice. Roles of the participants in the criminal justice system. Not offered each year; consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW

subject: LAW

subject: LAW
title: Foundations of Dispute Resolution
description: Theoretical premises underlying the dispute-resolving process; arbitration, other non-judicial means of resolving legal disputes, and their relationship to litigation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Mediation
description: Mediation of legal disputes; negotiation theory and practice as they relate to mediation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Law Review Credit

One time credit only; cannot be repeated. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Clinical Term
description: Designed to explore the legal system in relation to disadvantaged members of society. Under supervision, students will act for clients in a range of legal matters and can expect to appear before courts and tribunals. Students will also work with community-based organisations. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 488, LAW 490, or LAW 491. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Designed to explore the legal system in relation to disadvantaged members of society. subject: LAW
title: Fundamental Concepts in Tax Law
description: Introduction to key concepts in comparative and Canadian tax law. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 407 or LAW 506 or LAW 561. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Introduction to key concepts in comparative and Canadian tax law. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 407 or LAW 506 or LAW 561. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Taxation of Corporations and Shareholders
description: Survey of statutory provisions and judicial decisions governing the taxation of corporations and shareholders. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 408 or LAW 562. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Survey of statutory provisions and judicial decisions governing the taxation of corporations and shareholders. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 408 or LAW 562. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Taxation of Partnerships
description: Survey of statutory and judicial rules governing the taxation of income earned through partnerships. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 409 or LAW 563. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Survey of statutory and judicial rules governing the taxation of income earned through partnerships. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 409 or LAW 563. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Taxation of Trusts and Estates
description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 412 or LAW 564. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 412 or LAW 564. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: International Taxation
description: The tax aspects of international transactions. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 410 or LAW 565. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The tax aspects of international transactions. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 410 or LAW 565. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Tax Policy
description: The policies underlying the creation and implementation of tax laws. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 411 or LAW 566 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The policies underlying the creation and implementation of tax laws. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 411 or LAW 566 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Tax Administration and Dispute Resolution
description: Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 413 or LAW 567. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 413 or LAW 567. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Intellectual Property
description: Copyright, patents, trade marks, industrial design, the protection of computer software, and torts such as passing-off and breach of confidence. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 570 or LAW 422. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Copyright, patents, trade marks, industrial design, the protection of computer software, and torts such as passing-off and breach of confidence. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 570 or LAW 422. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Communications Law
description: Selected legal issues relating to the communications industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 571 or LAW 424. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Selected legal issues relating to the communications industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 571 or LAW 424. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Cyberspace Law
description: Legal issues arising from the development of the Internet and cyberspace. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 572 or LAW 425. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Legal issues arising from the development of the Internet and cyberspace. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 572 or LAW 425. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Media and Entertainment Law
description: Selected legal issues relating to the media and entertainment industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW449 or LAW 573. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Selected legal issues relating to the media and entertainment industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW449 or LAW 573. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Succession
description: The law of wills and intestate succession, variation of wills, principles of probate and administration of estates. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 452 or LAW 574. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The law of wills and intestate succession, variation of wills, principles of probate and administration of estates. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 452 or LAW 574. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Equitable Remedies
description: The history and development of equitable remedies such as specific performance, injunctions, declarations, relief against forfeiture, and tracing. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 575 or LAW 453. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The history and development of equitable remedies such as specific performance, injunctions, declarations, relief against forfeiture, and tracing. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 575 or LAW 453. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Securities Regulation
description: The law relating to the distribution of securities. Continuous and timely disclosure requirements and civil liability. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 576 or LAW 463. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The law relating to the distribution of securities. Continuous and timely disclosure requirements and civil liability. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 576 or LAW 463. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Immigration Law
description: Admission of immigrants into Canada; refugee protection; practice and procedure before immigration tribunals and the courts. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 577 or LAW 377. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Admission of immigrants into Canada; refugee protection; practice and procedure before immigration tribunals and the courts. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 577 or LAW 377. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Refugee Law
description: International and Canadian refugee law; the Refugee Convention and its implementation in Canada; the practice of refugee law in Canadian courts and tribunals. Course content does not duplicate LAW_V 377. Credit will only be given to one of LAW_V 578 or LAW_V 378. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Sustainable Development Law
description: The linkages, intersections, and tensions between the legal regulation of the environment and competing social and economic priorities. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 586 or LAW 386. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The linkages, intersections, and tensions between the legal regulation of the environment and competing social and economic priorities. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 586 or LAW 386. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Ethics and Professionalism
description: The ethical dimensions of legal practice in Canada, including legislation, regulations, rules of professional conduct and cases, and the roles of lawyers, the legal profession and the legal system including their role in securing access to justice. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 588 or LAW 468. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: The ethical dimensions of legal practice in Canada, including legislation, regulations, rules of professional conduct and cases, and the roles of lawyers, the legal profession and the legal system including their role in securing access to justice. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 588 or LAW 468. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Civil Procedure
description: Problems in the conduct of civil litigation including: ethical considerations; substantive problems such as notice, pleading, and discovery; and selected procedural problems. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 590 or LAW 469. [2-0] or [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Problems in the conduct of civil litigation including: ethical considerations; substantive problems such as notice, pleading, and discovery; and selected procedural problems. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 590 or LAW 469. [2-0] or [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Environmental Law Workshop
description: Legal research and writing for environmental agency or NGO under supervision of faculty member and lawyer. Not offered every year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 591 or LAW 390. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Legal research and writing for environmental agency or NGO under supervision of faculty member and lawyer. Not offered every year, consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 591 or LAW 390. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Conflict of Laws
description: A study of the private legal problems arising in cases in which the relevant facts cut across provincial or national boundaries. Credit will only be granted to one of Law 325 or LAW 592. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Forest Law
description: Acquisition of timber interests; development, financing and organization of timber companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year; consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 595 or Law 395. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Acquisition of timber interests; development, financing and organization of timber companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year; consult Faculty. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 595 or Law 395. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Creditors' Remedies
description: Remedies of an unsecured creditor; fraudulent conveyances and preferences; builders' liens; bankruptcy. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 599 or LAW 443. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Remedies of an unsecured creditor; fraudulent conveyances and preferences; builders' liens; bankruptcy. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 599 or LAW 443. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LAW
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LFS
title: Introduction to Land, Food and Community
description: Orientation to the programs, learning environment and core values of the Faculty of Land and Food Systems; career programs; survey of professional opportunities and requirements. [1-0-0]

subject: LFS
title: Principles of Microeconomics with Applications to Land and Food Systems
description: Microeconomic principles focused on private and social decision making related to the use of land, especially in agriculture, forestry, and conservation. Restricted to Faculty of Land and Food Systems students in Land One Option. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 101, LFS 101, ECON 101, or ECON 310 Equivalency: FRST 101, ECON 101 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Microeconomic principles focused on private and social decision making related to the use of land, especially in agriculture, forestry, and conservation. Restricted to Faculty of Land and Food Systems students in Land One Option. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 101, LFS 101, ECON 101, or ECON 310 Equivalency: FRST 101, ECON 101 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LFS
title: Land One: First-year Integrative Seminar
description: Current issues and cases in Forestry and Land and Food Systems are examined with a focus on integration of first-year subjects and exposure to both Indigenous and Western perspectives. Restricted to Faculty of Land and Food Systems students in the Land One option. Equivalency: FRST 110 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LFS
title: Scholarly Writing and Argumentation in Land and Food Systems
description: Communicating concepts of food systems and links to human and environmental health through writing, elements of argumentation, evaluating evidence, and searching for and citing references to back up claims; small-class experience. Enrolment limited to LFS students with first year status. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES_V 150, FRST_V 150, or LFS_V 150. Equivalency: FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Communicating concepts of food systems and links to human and environmental health through writing, elements of argumentation, evaluating evidence, and searching for and citing references to back up claims; small-class experience. Enrolment limited to LFS students with first year status. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES_V 150, FRST_V 150, or LFS_V 150. Equivalency: FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LFS
title: Land, Food and Community I: Introduction to Food Systems and Sustainability
description: Managed systems and concepts of sustainability; economic, ecological and social components; managed landscapes, agri-food systems, and communities; urban and rural systems; the land, food, nutrition and human health continuum.

subject: LFS
title: Land, Food, and Community: Quantitative Data Analysis
description: Introduction to tools needed for data analysis of the economic, ecological, health, and scientific components of land and food systems. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

subject: LFS
title: Aquaculture Field Studies
description: An orientation to the aquaculture system in BC. Participating students are assessed a fee.

subject: LFS
title: International Field Studies in Policy Analysis for Agriculture and Natural Resources
description: Field studies carried out abroad under the direction of the instructor. Students will be guided to apply selected tools for analysis of agricultural and natural resource policy in developing countries with input from local policymakers. Participating students are assessed a fee. Prerequisite: One of ECON 101, LFS 101. Third-year standing and permission of instructor. 9 credits of upper level ECON, FRE or COMM courses are strongly recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON 101, LFS 101. Third-year standing and permission of instructor. 9 credits of upper level ECON, FRE or COMM courses are strongly recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LFS
title: First Nations Health and the Traditional Role of Plants
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the First Nations medical systems and medicinal plants. Bridging the traditional with modern sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of LFS 340 or IHHS 301.
exclusion_raw: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the First Nations medical systems and medicinal plants. Bridging the traditional with modern sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of LFS 340 or IHHS 301.

subject: LFS
title: Land, Food, and Community II: Principles and Practice of Community Food Security
description: Project-based application of the principles and processes of community food security. Emphasis on developing skills required to address economic, ecological, social, and technological components of managed landscapes, agri-food systems, and communities comprising the land, food, nutrition and health continuum. Prerequisite: LFS 250.
prerequisite_raw: LFS 250.

subject: LFS
title: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings. Work terms are normally four months long. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: Must attend all Co-op pre-employment workshops. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Must attend all Co-op pre-employment workshops. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LFS
title: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings. Work terms are normally four months long. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: LFS 398. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: LFS 398. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LFS
title: Audio Storytelling
description: Adopts a journalistic framework to communicate powerful stories and present academic content in new ways through the use of audio and podcasting technology. Prerequisite: Third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing or higher.

subject: LFS
title: Living Language: Science and Society
description: Multidisciplinary course in which students, individually and in groups, examine, integrate and apply subject-specific knowledge through the lens of language and the framework of the language sciences, with a focus on themes of real-world importance. Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor. Equivalency: APSC402, ASTU402, FRST402, LLED402, PHAR402
prerequisite_raw: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor. Equivalency: APSC402, ASTU402, FRST402, LLED402, PHAR402

subject: LFS
title: Land, Food, and Community III: Leadership in Campus Food System Sustainability
description: Design, analysis, recommendation or implementation of solutions in response to a food sustainability issue faced by community partners. Emphasis is on professional communication, leadership development, project management and decision-making skills.

subject: LFS
title: Topics in Land and Food Systems
description: Analysis and interpretation of current issues related to land and food systems.

subject: LFS
title: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings. Work terms are normally four months long. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: LFS 399. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: LFS 399. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

prerequisite_raw: LFS 498. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
