subject: LIBR
title: Program Synthesis Portfolio
description: For students enrolled in the M.L.I.S. program with a minimum of 36 credits. For students enrolled in the M.A.S./M.L.I.S. dual program with a minimum of 69 credits. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
description: Study of language as a universal and uniquely human cognitive system: What universals do all languages share and how do languages differ? An investigation of sound systems, word-building, grammatical principles, language change, dialect variation, language acquisition, neurolinguistics. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linguistics or speech sciences.

subject: LING
title: Languages of the World
description: A survey of the linguistic map of the world, examining how languages are genetically classified and how different languages evolve. Principles underlying different writing systems and the decipherment of historical documents. Issues of languages in contact, minority language endangerment, language death and the role of English as a world language. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linguistics or speech sciences.

subject: LING
title: Challenging Language Myths
description: Critical consideration of a broad range of commonly held beliefs about language and its relation to the brain and cognition, learning, society, change and evolution. Note. This is an elective course that does not fulfill writing requirements in any faculty or the literature requirement in the Faculty of Arts. Credit will be granted for only one of LING_V 140 or ENGL_V 140. Equivalency: ENGL_V 140. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Critical consideration of a broad range of commonly held beliefs about language and its relation to the brain and cognition, learning, society, change and evolution. Note. This is an elective course that does not fulfill writing requirements in any faculty or the literature requirement in the Faculty of Arts. Credit will be granted for only one of LING_V 140 or ENGL_V 140. Equivalency: ENGL_V 140. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Language in the Age of AI
description: Examines the impact of generative AI, large language models, and virtual assistants on human communication. Includes evolving language trends, ethics, and applications like speech recognition, text-to-speech, and machine translation. No computational or programming background required.

subject: LING
title: Introduction to How to Learn a Language
description: Skills and strategies for second language acquisition, through the foundations of pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar, and pragmatics, connected to the practical, social, and personal challenges of language learning.

subject: LING
title: Linguistic Theory and Analysis I
description: Introduction to phonetics and phonology; training in the identification and production of speech sounds; principles and methods for describing and writing the sound system of a language; phonological theory with reference to selected languages; the interface between phonology and morphology. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.

subject: LING
title: Linguistic Theory and Analysis II
description: Introduction to grammatical analysis; morphology, syntax, semantics; synchronic analysis and description with illustrations from various languages. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.

subject: LING
title: Clinical Topics in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
description: Introduction to speech and hearing sciences, with emphasis on the clinical perspectives of audiology and speech pathology.

subject: LING
title: Language Acquisition
description: Audition and speech perception, phonological organization, word learning, syntax, and pragmatics.

subject: LING
title: Computational Tools for Linguistic Analysis
description: Practical skills for analyzing language using the Python programming language and relevant packages. Prerequisite: One of LING 100, LING 101, LING 140, LING 170, LING 200, LING 201, ENGL 330, ENGL 331. Recommended: LING 201 and CPSC 103 or CPSC 110 (or other programming experience).
prerequisite_raw: One of LING 100, LING 101, LING 140, LING 170, LING 200, LING 201, ENGL 330, ENGL 331. Recommended: LING 201 and CPSC 103 or CPSC 110 (or other programming experience).

subject: LING
title: Introduction to Studies in Second Language Acquisition
description: Linguistic systems that learners of an additional language develop as they approximate towards the target language, and key questions about what this 'interlanguage' system reveals about how we learn languages. Prerequisite: One of LING 100, LING 101, LING 140, LING 170.
prerequisite_raw: One of LING 100, LING 101, LING 140, LING 170.

subject: LING
title: Studies in Grammar
description: Introduction to syntactic analysis and theory, with emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages. Prerequisite: LING 201.
prerequisite_raw: LING 201.

subject: LING
title: The Languages of Africa
description: Linguistic survey of the languages of Africa, including typological and historical connections between languages, individual and comparative surveys of sound systems, word structures, sentence structures, semantics, and sociolinguistic properties of a representative selection of languages. Credit will only be granted for one of LING_V 308 or AFST_V 308. Equivalency: AFST_V 308.
exclusion_raw: Linguistic survey of the languages of Africa, including typological and historical connections between languages, individual and comparative surveys of sound systems, word structures, sentence structures, semantics, and sociolinguistic properties of a representative selection of languages. Credit will only be granted for one of LING_V 308 or AFST_V 308. Equivalency: AFST_V 308.

subject: LING
title: Studies in Phonology
description: Introduction to phonological analysis and theory, with a strong emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages. Prerequisite: LING 200.
prerequisite_raw: LING 200.

subject: LING
title: Introduction to Linguistic Phonetics and Speech Science
description: The articulatory and acoustic properties of speech production and perception, including practice in phonetic transcription, instrumental recording, and the analysis of normal speech. Prerequisite: [LING200]
prerequisite_raw: [LING200]

subject: LING
title: Instrumental Phonetics
description: Physiological and/or acoustic phonetics. Focus on experimental methods and analysis techniques. Topics may include: source-filter theory; spectral and temporal acoustic analysis, inter-articulator timing and motor coordination. Prerequisite: LING 200. Recommended: LING 313
prerequisite_raw: LING 200. Recommended: LING 313

subject: LING
title: Sociolinguistics
description: The systematic study of language as a social phenomenon. Credit will be granted for only one of LING 445 or 315. Prerequisite: All of LING 200, LING 201.
prerequisite_raw: All of LING 200, LING 201.
exclusion_raw: The systematic study of language as a social phenomenon. Credit will be granted for only one of LING 445 or 315. Prerequisite: All of LING 200, LING 201.

subject: LING
title: Historical Linguistics
description: How and why languages change over time, and how languages can be grouped into families based on historical relationships. Methods of comparative and internal reconstruction of phonological, morphological, syntactic, semantic change. Social factors in language change. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: LING 200 and LING 201.
prerequisite_raw: LING 200 and LING 201.

subject: LING
title: Introduction to Semantics
description: The analysis and theory of linguistic meaning with emphasis on formal techniques for semantic analysis and their application to empirical phenomena in language, including pragmatics. Prerequisite: LING 201.
prerequisite_raw: LING 201.

subject: LING
title: Research Methods for Linguistics
description: Research methods used in linguistics and speech science. Emphasis on scientific reasoning, critical thinking, experimental design, and the ethics and methods of linguistic data-collection. Prerequisite: All of LING 200, LING 201.
prerequisite_raw: All of LING 200, LING 201.

subject: LING
title: Computational Models of Language
description: A re-examination of major areas of linguistics from a computational perspective, including popular formalisms and algorithms associated with morphology, syntax, semantics, and discourse. Prerequisite: LING 242 and one of LING 201, ENGL 331 and one of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 251, STAT 302, MATH 302, PSYC 218.
prerequisite_raw: LING 242 and one of LING 201, ENGL 331 and one of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 251, STAT 302, MATH 302, PSYC 218.

subject: LING
title: Pragmatics
description: Selected topics in pragmatics and information structure, including variations in their cross-linguistic expression and the corresponding influence of sentence form on context. Prerequisite: One of LING 201, ENGL 331, PHIL 220, PHIL 222.
prerequisite_raw: One of LING 201, ENGL 331, PHIL 220, PHIL 222.

subject: LING
title: Morphology
description: Analytic and theoretical consideration of the interrelation of word formation, sound patterning, and meaningful sentence structure. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: All of LING 300, LING 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of LING 300, LING 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Advanced Phonology
description: Current issues in phonological theory. Prerequisite: LING 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: LING 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Language Across Time, Geography, and Society
description: A cross-linguistic exploration of language change, discussing theories, data, and methods. Topics can include change across historical time periods, lifespan; change across regions, within areas; change due to language contact and other social and cultural factors. Prerequisite: One of LING 319, LING 315, LING 445, ENGL 318, ENGL 319, ENGL 324 and two of LING 300, LING 311, LING 313, LING 327.
prerequisite_raw: One of LING 319, LING 315, LING 445, ENGL 318, ENGL 319, ENGL 324 and two of LING 300, LING 311, LING 313, LING 327.

subject: LING
title: Introduction to Linguistics
description: General background to linguistic studies; the different approaches to the analysis of languages; synchronic and diachronic linguistics; phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics. Not available for credit toward a Major or Honours program in Linguistics.

subject: LING
title: Advanced Syntax
description: Current issues in syntactic theory. Prerequisite: LING 300.
prerequisite_raw: LING 300.

subject: LING
title: Advanced Semantics
description: Current issues in semantic theory. Prerequisite: One of LING 327, PHIL 220, PHIL 222. A basic introduction to syntax is recommended (e.g., LING 100, LING 201, or ENGL 331). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of LING 327, PHIL 220, PHIL 222. A basic introduction to syntax is recommended (e.g., LING 100, LING 201, or ENGL 331). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Field Methods I
description: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied. Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment. Prerequisite: All of LING 300, LING 311.
prerequisite_raw: All of LING 300, LING 311.

subject: LING
title: Field Methods II
description: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied. Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment. Prerequisite: LING 431.
prerequisite_raw: LING 431.

subject: LING
title: Native Languages of the Americas
description: Survey of the indigenous languages of the Americas. Study of the basis of genetic classification and areal similarities. The structure of representative languages will be presented and contrasted. The present status of American Indian languages will be considered. Note: this course is not necessarily offered every year.

subject: LING
title: Community-based Language Research
description: Research methods and partnerships, ethical paradigms, the social, cultural and historical context of language research, and the relation of language research to pedagogy, policy and planning.

subject: LING
title: Language as a Social Instrument
description: Language as a tool that shapes and is shaped by technology, media, politics and power relations in society. Considers multiple levels of linguistic structure from a cross-linguistic perspective. Prerequisite: All of LING 200, LING 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of LING 200, LING 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Acquisition of Phonology
description: Development of the phonological system in typical first language acquisition from the perspective of diverse linguistic topics. Phonetic transcription of child speech. Prerequisite: All of LING 222, LING 311.
prerequisite_raw: All of LING 222, LING 311.

subject: LING
title: Acquisition of Syntax
description: Central issues in the first language acquisition of syntax, including early lexical and semantic development, acquisition of morphology, and syntactic development (e.g., word order, questions). Prerequisite: All of LING 222, LING 300.
prerequisite_raw: All of LING 222, LING 300.

subject: LING
title: Clinical Topics in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
description: Introduction to speech and hearing sciences with emphasis on the clinical perspectives of audiology and speech pathology.

subject: LING
title: Formal Foundations of Syntax & Semantics
description: Conceptual underpinnings of the study of sentence structure and meaning; core issues in syntax and semantics; the place of syntax and semantics in a model of grammar; interface issues. Prerequisite: LING 520 and 525 are recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: LING 520 and 525 are recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Topics in Language Acquisition
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Formal Foundations of Phonetics & Phonology
description: Conceptual underpinnings of the study of speech sounds; core issues in phonetics and phonology; the place of phonetics and phonology in a model of grammar; interface issues. Prerequisite: LING 508 and 510 are recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: LING 508 and 510 are recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Phonetic Theory & Analysis
description: Discussion and critical analysis of current issues in linguistic phonetics; instrumental analysis. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Phonological Theory and Analysis
description: Discussion and critical analysis of current issues in phonological theory. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Topics in Phonology
description: Prerequisite: LING 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: LING 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LING
title: Topics in Phonetics & Phonology
description: Advanced topics in phonetics and phonology; in-depth analysis of specific issues and problems. Prerequisite: One of LING_V 508, LING_V 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of LING_V 508, LING_V 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

prerequisite_raw: One of LING_V 520, LING_V 525. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: LLED

subject: LLED
title: Introduction to Intercultural Communication and Socialization in Diverse Contexts
description: This course examines intercultural communication and language socialization relevant to the formation and preservation of cultural groups, as well as relations between groups.

subject: LLED
title: Introduction to Translating in a Globalized Society
description: Basic tenets of translation as a methodology for increasing students' sociocultural understanding, intercultural communication, pragmatics, and written English.

subject: LLED
title: Language Maintenance and the Integration of Immigrants in Canada: An Introduction
description: The concept of societal and individual bilingualism/multilingualism in a variety of settings, including Canada in particular.

subject: LLED
title: Introduction to Public and Private Language Practices in a Globalized Society
description: Exploration of the interrelationships between language structure, usage and social context and the interpretive differences that may result from their interaction.

subject: LLED
title: Introduction to the Nature of World Englishes
description: Exploration of the emergence of new English varieties, as well as a critical examination of main reasons linked to the rise of English worldwide and its proposed role as a neutral global language.

subject: LWS
title: Advanced Soil Processes
description: Integration of soil physics, chemistry, and biology in understanding essential soil processes. Equivalency: SOIL501 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

description: Watershed evaluation, key aspects of hydrology, water quality, land use impacts on water resources and integration of multiple land use activities and their cumulative impacts. Equivalency: SOIL 515 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

title: Urban Watershed Management
description: Urbanization impacts on water resources with a focus on rainwater management, water quality, point and non-point sources of pollution, drinking water and waste water, riparian buffer zones, cumulative effects, and application of beneficial management practices. Equivalency: SOIL516 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
