description: Interactions between viruses and humans; pathogenesis; prompt virological diagnosis; rationale for antiviral chemotherapy and prophylaxis. [3-0-0] Equivalency: MICB407

subject: PATH
title: Directed Studies
description: An elective in clinical infection control, medical microbiology or molecular biology.

subject: PATH
title: Introduction to Laboratory Medicine
description: An elective course open to first-year medical students who spend at least three consecutive hours each week in one of the affiliated hospitals of the Department of Pathology, Vancouver Hospital, under the joint supervision of a Senior Resident in Pathology and the Professional Staff of the following Divisions: anatomical pathology, clinical biochemistry, hematology, pediatric pathology. Enrolment is limited.

subject: PATH
title: Systemic Pathology
description: A series of Pathology discussions in conjunction with various clinical departments designed to illustrate the role of Pathology in the diagnosis and management of various diseases. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Clerkship in Laboratory Medicine and Infection Prevention and Control
description: May involve attendance at an approved institution and/or a project assigned by the instructor(s). Instructor permission required. Enrolment may be limited.

subject: PATH
title: Clerkship in Anatomic Pathology
description: An elective course open to third-year medical students, designed to familiarize the student with Anatomic Pathology, including Surgical Pathology, Pediatric Pathology, Autopsy Pathology and Cytology. This elective may involve attendance at one or more affiliated hospitals. Registration requires consent of the Department and enrolment may be limited.

subject: PATH
title: Clinical Laboratory Hematology
description: Correlative seminars based on haematology case studies relating clinical features to laboratory investigations. Equivalency: MEDI452 (1970W) This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Clinical Laboratory Microbiology
description: Selected clinical laboratory exercises plus seminars to illustrate the diagnosis and management of patients with microbial infections. Elective course limited to third- and fourth-year medical students. Prerequisite: Departmental approval required.
prerequisite_raw: Departmental approval required.

subject: PATH
title: Basic Microbiology for Infection Control
description: The identification, clinical significance, and transmission of pathogenic organisms are presented. This course is available by correspondence or webCT. It may be taken towards fulfillment of the Certificate in Infection Control.

subject: PATH
title: Basic Epidemiology for Infection Control
description: Epidemiology, study, design and analysis, and outbreak investigation as it applies to institutional infection control. Equivalency: SPPH 401

subject: PATH
title: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in either industrial, public, or academic laboratory for a minimum of 14 weeks. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Coop Program in BMLSc. Prerequisite: PATH 399. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PATH 399. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in either industrial, public, or academic laboratory for a minimum of 14 weeks. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Coop Program in BMLSc. Prerequisite: PATH 498. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PATH 498. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Foundations of Human Histopathology
description: Microscopic anatomy of human tissues and organs in health and disease. Principles of histological analysis and applications in pathology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Current Topics in Pathology Research
description: General principles of etiology, pathogenesis, disordered physiology, and anatomic pathology of common disease processes. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Introduction to the Pathogenesis of Human Disease
description: Current medical research; cardiovascular and pulmonary disease. Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Permission of instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Principles of Antimicrobial Chemotherapy
description: Classification, structure and mode of action of antimicrobial agents. In-depth comparison of factors affecting the activity of antimicrobials in vivo and in vitro. Prerequisite: All of MICB_V 200, PATH_V 427. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of MICB_V 200, PATH_V 427. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Nutrition and Metabolic Aspects of Human Disease
description: Molecular effects of changes in nutrient status and metabolism on health. Prerequisite: Restricted to students registered in the Pathology Graduate Program or instructor approval required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Restricted to students registered in the Pathology Graduate Program or instructor approval required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Molecular and Cell Biology of Cancer
description: This course focuses on molecular and cell biology of cancer and consists of a series of lectures/reviews combined with discussions and presentations by students on the topics selected by the instructors. Emphasis will be on students' presentations and discussion. [3-0] Prerequisite: MEDG 421 is recommended. Course coordinator approval is required. Equivalency: MEDG521 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: MEDG 421 is recommended. Course coordinator approval is required. Equivalency: MEDG521 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Seminar
description: Attendance required of all M.Sc. candidates in the Department. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Techniques in Molecular Biology and Experimental Pathology
description: Nucleic acid purification and characterization; restriction enzyme digests; northern and southern blotting; cloning; DNA sequencing; polymerase chain reaction technology; electron microscopy; fluorescein-activated cell sorting. [0-6] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: M.Sc. Thesis
description: Honours/Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Cardiovascular Pathophysiology
description: Pathogenesis, abnormal physiology, and therapeutic approaches in heart disease including cardiac arrhythmia, heart failure, myocardial infarction, hypertension, atherosclerosis. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Toxicology III: Environmental Toxicology
description: Toxicology and risk assessment of air, water and soil pollutants; food additives; animal and plant toxins; pesticides; heavy metals; solvents. [3-0-0] Equivalency: PHAR582 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Seminar
description: Attendance required for all Ph.D. candidates in the department. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Pathology Conference
description: Review and analysis of current cases. Diagnostic and pathogenic significance of findings are assessed. One hour weekly. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Surgical Pathology
description: Five days per week, one-hour review of current diagnostic biopsy problems. Diagnostic and therapeutic implications are discussed. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Hematologic Pathology
description: Lectures and seminars on the pathology of hematological diseases. Two hours weekly. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Histochemical Pathology
description: A series of lectures and seminars to show current applications of histochemical techniques to contemporary pathological diagnosis. One hour weekly per quarter. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Hematologic Pathology
description: Analysis of pathology of bone marrow aspirates; taken in one half or whole year. One and one-half hours weekly. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Clinical Chemistry
description: A series of lectures, seminars, tutorials, and laboratory tuition to demonstrate the use of chemical analysis in clinical medicine. Two hours weekly. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Neuropathology
description: Sectioning of necropsy material with clinicopathological correlation. One hour weekly. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Neuropathology, Clinical Correlation
description: Pathology of central nervous system disease demonstrated to clinical staff, stressing correlation with clinical diseases. Two hours weekly. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Dermatopathology
description: Clinicopathological correlation of dermal lesions. Discussion of pathogenesis, clinical course, and prognostic implications. One hour weekly. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Renal Biopsy Rounds
description: Weekly correlation between clinical status and pathological findings in several patients. Equivalency: MEDI711 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Hepatic and Gastrointestinal Pathology
description: Clinicopathologial correlation of hepatic and gastrointestinal biopsy material with discussions of pathogenesis, etiology, and therapeutic implications. Alternate weeks, one hour. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Cytology
description: Daily review of cytopathology. Analysis of cervical and sputum smears and pleural, gastric, and bronchial aspirates with discussion of significance to patients, taken in one quarter of year. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Perinatal Mortality Conference
description: Discussion of perinatal mortality cases for the month, with review of clinical and laboratory findings, management, and pathology findings by pediatric, obstetrical, and pathology teaching staff. Methods of possible prevention of fetal or neonatal death are discussed and recommended as hypothetical reasons for preventability, where appropriate. Two hours monthly. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Seminars in Biochemical Pediatrics
description: A series of discussions on clinical problems which are chosen to illustrate the biochemical basis for the practice of pediatrics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Pediatric Pathology
description: Demonstration and dissection of congenital heart lesions; correlation of cardiological and pathological data. One hour weekly. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Microbiological Diagnosis
description: Conduct of bacterial, fungal, parasitological, and viral laboratory tests relevant to the microbiological examination of patients. For medical residents. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Microbiological Research
description: Conduct of research on some aspect of clinical or basic microbiology. For medical residents. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Microbial Infections
description: Review in depth of syndromes caused by common human pathogenic bacteria, fungi and viruses, including principles of current laboratory diagnostic procedures and the rational use of antibiotics and prophylactic agents. For medical residents. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Histopathology of Infectious Diseases
description: Gross and microscopic changes associated with infections, and the pathophysiology involved in their development. The course includes seminars based on histological specimens. For residents in Medical Microbiology, General and Anatomical Pathology, and Infectious Diseases. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Clinical Nuclear Medicine
description: See RADI 710. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Progress in Nuclear Medicine
description: See RADI 711. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Clinical Investigation/Research
description: See RADI 712. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PATH
title: Quality Correlation in Nuclear Medicine
description: See RADI 713. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: Drugs and Society
description: Introductory principles of drug action. Historical and present day medical and non-medical use of drugs. [3-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 12, BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155, SCIE 001. Second-year standing is required.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 12, BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155, SCIE 001. Second-year standing is required.

subject: PCTH
title: Introduction to Pharmacology
description: The concepts, language and techniques of scientific pharmacology. Intended primarily for Honours and Major students in Pharmacology. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: Either(a) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 233, CHEM 235 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 203, CHEM 204; and CHEM 211 and one of CHEM 205, CHEM 201. Permission of the undergraduate advisor is required.
prerequisite_raw: Either(a) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 233, CHEM 235 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 203, CHEM 204; and CHEM 211 and one of CHEM 205, CHEM 201. Permission of the undergraduate advisor is required.

subject: PCTH
title: Introduction to Pharmacology
description: Fundamental concepts of drug-receptor interactions in the context of autonomic, autacoid, and psychoactive pharmacology. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: All of CAPS 205, CAPS 206. or CAPS 301 as a co-requisite.
prerequisite_raw: All of CAPS 205, CAPS 206. or CAPS 301 as a co-requisite.

subject: PCTH
title: Introductory Pharmacology Laboratory
description: A series of experimental demonstrations and individual laboratory experiments illustrating the basic principles of pharmacology. [1-3-0;1-3-0] Corequisite: One of PCTH 300, PCTH 301.
corequisite_raw: One of PCTH 300, PCTH 301.

subject: PCTH
title: Pharmacology in Health and Disease
description: Pharmacological modulation of physiological systems in health and disease. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: PCTH 301 or CAPS 301 as a co-requisite.
prerequisite_raw: PCTH 301 or CAPS 301 as a co-requisite.

subject: PCTH
title: Basic Human Pharmacology
description: Lectures and assigned reading on the effects, mechanisms of action, absorption, distribution, fate and excretion of major classes of therapeutic agents. Indications for the use of particular drugs will be discussed in terms of risk versus benefit for the individual and for society. [3-0-0; 3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203. Corequisite: CAPS 301.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203. Corequisite: CAPS 301.
corequisite_raw: CAPS 301.

subject: PCTH
title: Rational Basis of Drug Therapy
description: The principles and applications underlying the action and disposition of therapeutic agents (including alternative medicines) in the body. Use of drugs as tools in experimental research. [3-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOC 300.
prerequisite_raw: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOC 300.

subject: PCTH
title: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology. Prerequisite: One of PCTH 300, PCTH 303. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of PCTH 300, PCTH 303. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology. Prerequisite: [PCTH398] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [PCTH398] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: Systematic Pharmacology
description: Lectures and discussions in scientific pharmacology, with a concentration on the scientific aspects of the pharmacology of neurohumoral transmission; mathematics of pharmacology; cardiovascular, respiratory and clinical pharmacology; and to a lesser extent on the pharmacology of various organs and tissues. [3-0-0; 3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) PCTH 303 or (b) one of PCTH 300, PCTH 305.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) PCTH 303 or (b) one of PCTH 300, PCTH 305.

subject: PCTH
title: Systematic Pharmacology Laboratory
description: A series of demonstrated, group, and individual laboratory experiments designed to illustrate the concepts and hypotheses of pharmacology. The course is restricted to Honours students in Pharmacology, but may be taken by others with permission of the department head. [0-7-0;0-7-0] Prerequisite: All of PCTH 302, PCTH 303.
prerequisite_raw: All of PCTH 302, PCTH 303.

subject: PCTH
title: Drug Assay and Pharmacometrics
description: The techniques, including methods of statistical analysis, used to detect and measure the actions of endogenous or exogenous chemicals, using chemical assays and bioassays as appropriate. Enrolment limited to students in Pharmacology and others with permission of the department head. [1-0; 2-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) PCTH 303 or (b) one of PCTH 300, PCTH 305; and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) PCTH 303 or (b) one of PCTH 300, PCTH 305; and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.

subject: PCTH
title: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology. Prerequisite: [PCTH399] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [PCTH399] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer after fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology. Prerequisite: [PCTH498] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [PCTH498] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: Molecular Aspects of Drug Action at the Membrane Level
description: Lectures, discussions and assigned reading on actions of drugs on ion channels, receptors and intracellular processes and the methodologies used including electrophysiology, fluorescence measurements, molecular neurobiology and microdialysis. Given in even-numbered and alternate years. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: Structure-Activity Relationships in Pharmacology
description: Lectures, discussions and assigned reading on physicochemical approaches to drug design - the relationship between molecular structure and pharmacological activity in various representative classes of drugs. Given in odd-numbered and alternate years. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: Drugs and Intercellular Communication (including Neuropharmacology)
description: Lectures, discussions and assigned reading on the actions of drugs on the production, release and cellular effects of hormones and neurotransmitters. Given in odd-numbered and alternate years. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: Experimental Design and Analysis in Pharmacology
description: A series of lectures, tutorials and exercises designed to improve student skills in the design and statistical analyses of pharmacological experiments. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: Pharmacology of Anesthesia
description: Pharmacology of drugs used in anesthesia. Conferences, assigned reading and laboratory exercises demonstrating the actions of drugs as currently applied in the practice of anesthesia. Prerequisite: Permission of the department head is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Permission of the department head is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: Seminar in Pharmacology or Therapeutics
description: To give students experience in the presentation of data and to enhance communication skills in the discussion of scientific topics. All students will present at least one seminar during their graduate work and would be expected to attend all seminars. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: M.Sc. Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PCTH
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PERS
title: Basic Persian I
description: Basic vocabulary and the fundamentals of modern Persian grammar, structure, and pronunciation, as well as reading, writing, listening, and speaking.

subject: PERS
title: Basic Persian II
description: Continuation of PERS 100. Recommended pre-requisite: PERS 100.

subject: PERS
title: Persian Reading and Writing for Persian-Speaking Students
description: Reading and writing of standard Persian; lexical and syntactic differences between written and spoken Persian. Restricted to Persian heritage speakers with aural/oral knowledge but no reading/writing skills.

subject: PERS
title: Intermediate-Low Persian I
description: Reading of simple texts with emphasis on reading and writing, conversation skills, grammar, and syntax. Recommended pre-requisite: one of PERS 101, PERS 104.

subject: PERS
title: Intermediate-Low Persian II
description: Continuation of PERS 200. Recommended pre-requisite: PERS 200.

subject: PERS
title: Intermediate-High Persian I
description: Graded reading, writing, exposure to textual history, newspaper reading, and translation. Cultural materials presented as appropriate. Recommended pre-requisites: PERS 201 or Persian heritage speakers with basic reading/writing skills (no more than Grade 6 formal education in Iran).

subject: PERS
title: Intermediate-High Persian II
description: Continuation of PERS 300. Recommended pre-requisite: PERS 300.

subject: PERS
title: Persian Media
description: Reading, understanding and participating in contemporary registers of Persian Language as used in newspapers, radio/TV, as well as in online news and social media. Recommended pre-requisites: PERS 104, 201, or 3 credits of PERS at the 300 level, or permission of instructor.

subject: PERS
title: Persian Short Story for Native and Heritage Speakers
description: Modern short stories from mid-19th century to present. Recommended pre-requisites: one of PERS 104, PERS 300, or Persian heritage speakers with strong reading/writing skills (High School). NOT eligible to students who have studied at the post-secondary level in Iran.

subject: PERS
title: Contemporary Iranian Cinema for Advanced Speakers of Persian
description: Iranian cultural norms, and sociopolitical information about Iranian society and history, as conveyed through Iranian cinema. Emphasis on speaking, writing, and vocabulary development of Persian language. Recommended pre-requisites: PERS 300, or native or proficient heritage speaker of Persian with permission of the instructor.

subject: PERS
title: Persian through Shahnameh for Advanced Speakers of Persian
description: Persian through Shahnameh, with a focus on speaking, reading, writing and vocabulary development. Emphasis on Iranian cultural norms, mentalities and values. Recommended pre-requisite: PERS 300 or native or proficient heritage speaker of Persian, with permission of the instructor.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmaceutical Topics and Communication Seminar I
description: Current topics in the Pharmaceutical Sciences and basic skills for a short presentation on a biological science topic. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Biochemical Pharmacology
description: Biochemical pharmacology including fundamental aspects of enzymology, biochemistry, enzyme kinetics, drug metabolism and pharmacokinetics. Prerequisite: BIOL_V 112, BIOL_V 155, one of CHEM_V 111 or 121, CHEM_V 123, and one of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 120 or MATH_V 180. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: BIOL_V 112, BIOL_V 155, one of CHEM_V 111 or 121, CHEM_V 123, and one of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 120 or MATH_V 180. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Drug Delivery Technologies and Personalized Medicine Theory and Laboratory
description: Theoretical and practical knowledge of biopharmaceuticals, pharmaceutics, formulations, nanomedicine, and precision medicine as they apply to pharmaceutical sciences. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 202 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 202 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmaceutical Research
description: Types of research scientists in Academia and Industry across the broad range of Pharmaceutical Science Disciplines. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Clinical Epidemiology & Pharmaceutical Outcomes I
description: Population-level study designs and critical appraisal skills in evidence evaluation, with a special emphasis on evidence-based pharmacy practice. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmaceutical Topics and Communication Seminar II
description: Current topics in the Pharmaceutical and Biotechnology Industry and intermediate level skills for a short presentation. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 180 and WRDS_V 150. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 180 and WRDS_V 150. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmacokinetics
description: Basic pharmacokinetic concepts: absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion. Evaluation of how drug physicochemistry, organism physiology, and pharmacogenetics affect pharmacokinetics. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Nanomedicine
description: Advanced nanomedicine concepts for drug packaging, delivery, and efficacy. Prerequisite: PHAR 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Techniques in Molecular Biology and Pharmacology Theory and Laboratory
description: Theoretical and practical knowledge of the foundational techniques used in pharmaceutical research in both Academic Research and the Pharmaceutical and Biotechnology Industries. Prerequisite: All of CHEM_V 211, CHEM_V 233, CHEM_V 235, PHAR_V 203, PHAR_V 204, MICB_V 212, and STAT_V 200. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of CHEM_V 211, CHEM_V 233, CHEM_V 235, PHAR_V 203, PHAR_V 204, MICB_V 212, and STAT_V 200. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Clinical Epidemiology & Pharmaceutical Outcomes II
description: Population-level study designs and their critical appraisal skills in evidence evaluation, with a special emphasis on evidence-based pharmacy practice and the practical application of population-level data analysis and interpretation. Prerequisite: PHAR 205. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR 205. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Medicinal Chemistry of High-Impact Pharmaceuticals in Major Diseases
description: Structure and mechanism of action of drugs used in the treatment of major chronic diseases: heart disease, cancer, lung disease, and diabetes. Prerequisite: All of CHEM 233, PHAR 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of CHEM 233, PHAR 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Analytical Sciences Theory and Laboratory
description: Theoretical and practical knowledge of the analytical sciences commonly used in Academic Research as well as the Pharmaceutical and Biotechnology Industries. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 304 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 304 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Systematic Pharmacology
description: General principles of pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics: drug action on nervous, cardiovascular, GI and endocrine systems; beneficial and detrimental effects of drug action. Prerequisite: PHAR 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmaceutical Cases I
description: Application and problem solving in the pharmaceutical sciences. Integration of knowledge and skills from multiple courses to problem solve authentic cases and problems of increasing complexity. Development of self-directed learning skills. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 202, PHAR_V 203, PHAR_V 204, PHAR_V 205, and PHAR_V 280. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 202, PHAR_V 203, PHAR_V 204, PHAR_V 205, and PHAR_V 280. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmaceutical Topics and Communication Seminar III
description: Preliminary skills and concepts for planning, delivering and critiquing a scientific presentation using selected topics in the pharmaceutical sciences. Prerequisite: PHAR 280. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR 280. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Topics in Pharmaceutics and Biopharmaceutics
description: A study of selected topics in the field of pharmaceutics and biopharmaceutics. Registration restricted. Permission of instructor required. [2-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Precision Medicine
description: Precision medicine approaches in research and medical practice to mitigate drug toxicity and improve drug efficacy. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 203. Equivalency: PHRM_V 327. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 203. Equivalency: PHRM_V 327. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmacoeconomics
description: Evidence evaluation skills and understanding the role of, and the methods and principles used in, health economics and economic evaluation in healthcare, with a focus on health technology assessment studies. Prerequisite: PHAR 305. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR 305. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Statistical Methods for Pharmaceutical Outcomes Research
description: Basic principles of biostatistics and epidemiology. Application of epidemiologic and statistical knowledge in the area of health outcomes. Prerequisite: PHAR 305. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR 305. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Financing and Therapeutics in the Canadian Health Care System
description: Foundation in Canadian health care delivery systems and policies, with a focus on pharmaceutical policy and on comparison with other types of health care systems. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Biologics
description: Biologics as a therapeutic; how biologics are developed as drugs; synthesis and unique properties of biologics as drugs. Prerequisite: All of PHAR_V 303, PHAR_V 306, PHAR_V 307. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of PHAR_V 303, PHAR_V 306, PHAR_V 307. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Advanced Anesthetics and Analgesics
description: Advanced concepts in anesthetic and analgesic drugs, their uses and abuses. Prerequisite: PHAR 308. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR 308. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Drug Structures in Medicinal Chemistry
description: Therapeutically important privileged scaffolds and functional groups, and selectivity achieved through different chemical modifications. Prerequisite: All of CHEM_V 233, PHAR_V 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of CHEM_V 233, PHAR_V 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Clinical Chemistry
description: Principles, practices and procedures of medical laboratory clinical chemistry. Prerequisite: CHEM 211. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: CHEM 211. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Adverse Drug Reactions
description: Molecular and physiological basis of common adverse drug reactions (ADRs). ADRs in the context of current understanding of drug metabolism and pharmacogenetics. New approaches to prediction, detection and treatment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Biomolecular Pharmaceutical Chemistry
description: Chemical principles and their application to drugs used to regulate enzyme activity. [4-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Functional Foods
description: Functional food concepts related to efficacy and safety; examples of bioactive component-disease relationships; natural health products; approval of functional food and health claims; the importance of clinical studies in support of efficacy for health claims; market determinants of functional foods. Credit will be granted for only one of PHAR_V 431 or FNH_V 402. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 202, PHAR_V 203. Equivalency: FNH_V 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 202, PHAR_V 203. Equivalency: FNH_V 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Functional food concepts related to efficacy and safety; examples of bioactive component-disease relationships; natural health products; approval of functional food and health claims; the importance of clinical studies in support of efficacy for health claims; market determinants of functional foods. Credit will be granted for only one of PHAR_V 431 or FNH_V 402. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 202, PHAR_V 203. Equivalency: FNH_V 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Toxicology
description: Biochemical, cellular, and molecular processes that govern toxicity elicited by drugs and environmental toxins at the molecular, cellular, tissue, and organ system levels. Adverse drug reactions and precision medicine approaches to mitigate drug toxicity. Prerequisite: PHAR 308. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR 308. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Advanced Pharmacokinetics
description: Polyexponential pharmacokinetics, pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic modeling, pharmacokinetic predictions, physiologically-based pharmacokinetic modeling and population-based pharmacokinetic modeling. Credit will be granted for only one of PHAR 433 or PHAR 502. Prerequisite: PHAR 302. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR 302. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Polyexponential pharmacokinetics, pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic modeling, pharmacokinetic predictions, physiologically-based pharmacokinetic modeling and population-based pharmacokinetic modeling. Credit will be granted for only one of PHAR 433 or PHAR 502. Prerequisite: PHAR 302. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmaceutical Cases II
description: Advanced application and problem solving in the pharmaceutical sciences. Integration of knowledge and skills from multiple courses to problem solve authentic cases and problems of increasing complexity. Further development and practice of self-directed learning skills. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 370. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 370. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmaceutical Topics and Communication Seminar IV
description: Senior level skills and concepts for planning, delivering and critiquing a scientific seminar using extended topics in the pharmaceutical sciences and beyond. Prerequisite: PHAR 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Research Project
description: Provides research experience equivalent to one full-time term of work on a defined research project in an area of pharmaceutical research. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 302, PHAR_V 303, PHAR_V 304, PHAR_V 305, PHAR_V 306, PHAR_V 307, PHAR_V 308, PHAR_V 370 and PHAR_V 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 302, PHAR_V 303, PHAR_V 304, PHAR_V 305, PHAR_V 306, PHAR_V 307, PHAR_V 308, PHAR_V 370 and PHAR_V 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Honours Thesis
description: Research project and production of a thesis document in an area of pharmaceutical research according to national/international standards. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 485 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 485 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Practicum
description: Provides practicum experience equivalent to one full-time term of work in a professional area of pharmaceutical research. Prerequisite: PHAR_V 302, PHAR_V 303, PHAR_V 304, PHAR_V 305, PHAR_V 306, PHAR_V 307, PHAR_V 308, PHAR_V 370 and PHAR_V 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHAR_V 302, PHAR_V 303, PHAR_V 304, PHAR_V 305, PHAR_V 306, PHAR_V 307, PHAR_V 308, PHAR_V 370 and PHAR_V 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Advanced Concepts in Pharmacokinetics
description: Models of linear and dose-dependent systems in pharmacokinetics including sustained release, volumes of distribution, drug clearance, metabolite kinetics, multiple dosing and computer modelling. Credit will be granted for only one of PHAR 502 or PHAR 433. [4-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Models of linear and dose-dependent systems in pharmacokinetics including sustained release, volumes of distribution, drug clearance, metabolite kinetics, multiple dosing and computer modelling. Credit will be granted for only one of PHAR 502 or PHAR 433. [4-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Nanomedicines
description: Nano-sized drug delivery systems and their interactions with biological systems. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Polymeric Drug and Protein Delivery
description: Advances in polymer-based drug delivery systems. [2-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Lipid-Based Drug Delivery
description: Advances in lipophilic drug delivery systems. [2-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Diagnostic Imaging and Radiopharmaceuticals
description: Radiation-related, optical, and other imaging methods (SPECT, PET, CT, MRI, microscopy, ultrasound) and their application in research. [3-4*-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Applied Omics Science for Drug Discovery and Development
description: General principles of genomics, proteomics, glycomics, and metabolomics; advanced functional omics techniques and their applications in pharmaceutical research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Basic Theory and Practice of Liquid Chromatography - Mass Spectrometry in Pharmaceutical Research
description: Fundamental and practical knowledge and skills to run liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Basic Theory & Practice of Isothermal Titration Calorimetry
description: Isothermal titration calorimetry thermodynamic concepts and practical applications in measuring molecular interactions. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Cell Culture and New Biomedical Approaches
description: Basic cell culture techniques and novel insights into alternative methods in biomedical research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmaceutical Research Techniques I
description: Spectroscopic, GC, HPLC, LCMS and NMR analytical techniques for drug analysis, pharmacokinetics and metabolism. [2-6] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmaceutical Research Techniques II
description: Immunological assays, capillary and gel electrophoresis, radioisotope techniques, PET, peptide analysis and receptor binding studies. [2-6-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Drug Metabolism and Toxicology
description: The biotransformation of drugs, pesticides, carcinogens and other foreign chemicals in animals and humans. The biochemical mechanisms responsible, particularly the cytochrome P-450 mono-oxygenases, will be emphasized. The formation of toxic reactive metabolites and their effects will be discussed. Enrolment restricted. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Central Nervous System Pharmacology
description: A course comprised of lectures, assigned readings and reports on selected topics dealing with drug actions in the central nervous system. Given in alternate years. Permission of instructor required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Advanced Laboratory in Pharmacology
description: A laboratory course giving instruction in the methods and techniques used in pharmacological research. Registration limited. [0-6] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Cardiovascular Pharmacology
description: A course composed of lectures, assigned readings and conferences dealing with aspects of drug actions and cardiovascular function. Topics include the role of adenylate cyclase in cardiac function, the role of calcium in myocardial contractility and the effect of drugs on myocardial and vascular function. Enrolment restricted. Given in alternate years. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Etiology of Diabesity, from Cell to Society
description: Advanced course on pathophysiology and patient care for obesity and diabetes focusing on healthcare quality improvement, patient safety and optimising outcomes. Equivalency: PHRM346 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: M.Sc. Seminar
description: Attendance at regular seminars throughout the session and presentation of one or more papers on selected topics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Advanced Economic Evaluation in Health Care
description: Economic evaluation of health technologies, considering, in detail, the policy context for the use of economic evaluation. Prerequisite: SPPH 541. Or equivalent training. Equivalency: SPPH 549 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SPPH 541. Or equivalent training. Equivalency: SPPH 549 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Pharmacoepidemiology
description: Principles and applications of pharmacoepidemiology. Practical skills in designing, conducting, and appraising studies of medications in large populations. Prerequisite: Previous coursework in statistics or biostatistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Previous coursework in statistics or biostatistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Research in the Pharmaceutical Sciences: Principles and Methods
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Scholarly Integrity and Research Ethics
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Seminar for Ph.D. Students
description: Attendance at regular seminars throughout the session and presentation of one or more papers on selected topics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHAR
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophy
description: Basic problems and methods of Philosophy. Topics such as the existence of God, the nature and scope of human knowledge, the relationship between mind and body, personal identity, free will, issues and problems in moral philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 and either or both PHIL 101 or PHIL 102.
exclusion_raw: Basic problems and methods of Philosophy. Topics such as the existence of God, the nature and scope of human knowledge, the relationship between mind and body, personal identity, free will, issues and problems in moral philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 and either or both PHIL 101 or PHIL 102.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophy
description: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as the nature and scope of human knowledge, the existence of God, and the relationship between mind and body. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 or PHIL 101.
exclusion_raw: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as the nature and scope of human knowledge, the existence of God, and the relationship between mind and body. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 or PHIL 101.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophy II
description: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as morality, personal identity, free will and determinism, and the meaning of life. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 or PHIL 102.
exclusion_raw: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as morality, personal identity, free will and determinism, and the meaning of life. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 or PHIL 102.

subject: PHIL
title: Happiness
description: What makes for deep, lasting happiness, joy, and wellbeing? Contemporary and classical works of philosophy and important debates in related fields such as psychology, economics, political theory, and sociology.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Critical Thinking
description: Tools for dealing with both everyday and more technical arguments and concepts. Analysis and resolution of confusions, ambiguities, and fallacies. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Scientific Reasoning
description: Historical and logical analysis of various types of scientific hypotheses and the data that support or undermine them. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.

subject: PHIL
title: Greek Philosophy I: Socrates and Plato
description: The Pre-Socratics; Socrates; Sophists; Plato. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310. Credit will only be granted for one of PHIL 211, CLST 211 or AMNE 235. Equivalency: CLST211, AMNE235
exclusion_raw: The Pre-Socratics; Socrates; Sophists; Plato. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310. Credit will only be granted for one of PHIL 211, CLST 211 or AMNE 235. Equivalency: CLST211, AMNE235

subject: PHIL
title: Greek Philosophy II: Aristotle and After
description: Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic and Late Antique Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310. Credit will only be granted for one of PHIL 212, CLST 212 or AMNE 236. Equivalency: CLST212, AMNE236
exclusion_raw: Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic and Late Antique Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310. Credit will only be granted for one of PHIL 212, CLST 212 or AMNE 236. Equivalency: CLST212, AMNE236

subject: PHIL
title: Symbolic Logic
description: Sentential and predicate logic. Translation from natural language; truth tables and interpretations; systems of natural deduction up to relational predicate logic with identity; alternative proof methods. Some sections may use computer-based materials and tests. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 220 and PHIL 222. Equivalency: PHIL 222
exclusion_raw: Sentential and predicate logic. Translation from natural language; truth tables and interpretations; systems of natural deduction up to relational predicate logic with identity; alternative proof methods. Some sections may use computer-based materials and tests. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 220 and PHIL 222. Equivalency: PHIL 222

subject: PHIL
title: Enriched Symbolic Logic
description: Naïve set theory, relations and functions, recursion and induction; Propositional and predicate logic; Symbolizations, semantics, and formal proof theory; Metatheory for propositional logic. Recommended for students interested in pursuing upper-level courses in logic or formal philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 220 and PHIL 222.
exclusion_raw: Naïve set theory, relations and functions, recursion and induction; Propositional and predicate logic; Symbolizations, semantics, and formal proof theory; Metatheory for propositional logic. Recommended for students interested in pursuing upper-level courses in logic or formal philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 220 and PHIL 222.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Ethics
description: Theories of obligation and value; moral reasoning; normative ethics, descriptive ethics and meta-ethics. Readings in classic and contemporary texts.

subject: PHIL
title: Contemporary Moral Issues
description: Moral issues such as life and death decisions, paternalism, markets, animal welfare, technology, and global justice.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Epistemology
description: Topics in epistemology such as skepticism, truth, justification, a priori and a posteriori knowledge. Readings from classic and contemporary texts.

subject: PHIL
title: Minds and Machines
description: Philosophical and theoretical issues that pertain to how mental phenomena fit into the material world. Examine questions such as whether a sophisticated enough computer should be deemed a conscious intelligent being. Focus on philosophical literature on consciousness, intelligence, animal minds, and the mind-body relation.

subject: PHIL
title: Science and Society in the Contemporary World
description: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 260 or HIST 260. Equivalency: HIST 260.
exclusion_raw: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 260 or HIST 260. Equivalency: HIST 260.

subject: PHIL
title: The Philosophy of Plato
description: A study of Plato's dialogues and his influence on subsequent philosophy. PHIL/CLST 211 or AMNE 235 and PHIL/CLST 212 or AMNE 236 are recommended.

subject: PHIL
title: The Philosophy of Aristotle
description: A study of Aristotle's writings and his influence on subsequent philosophy. Recommended pre-requisite: PHIL 310.

subject: PHIL
title: Medieval Philosophy
description: Survey of Western European thought from Augustine to the 14th century. Possible topics and authors include: Augustine; Abelard; the influence of Islam; the rediscovery of Aristotle; Aquinas; Scotus; Ockham. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 313 and RELG 328. Equivalency: RELG 328
exclusion_raw: Survey of Western European thought from Augustine to the 14th century. Possible topics and authors include: Augustine; Abelard; the influence of Islam; the rediscovery of Aristotle; Aquinas; Scotus; Ockham. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 313 and RELG 328. Equivalency: RELG 328

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy in the 17th Century
description: Survey of 17th-century philosophy from Bacon to Leibniz, including the writings of Hobbes, Descartes, and Spinoza. The influence of science and religion on philosophy.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy in the 18th Century
description: Survey of 18th-century philosophy from Locke to Kant, including the writings of Berkeley, Rousseau, and Hume. The influence of science and religion on philosophy.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy After 1800
description: Survey of 19th and 20th century philosophy. May include Hegel, Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Mill, Meinong, Brentano, the British Idealists, Russell, and Moore. Social and political currents in 19th century philosophical thought.

subject: PHIL
title: Logic: Metatheory and Computability
description: Continuation of PHIL 220. A system of deduction for predicate logic is selected for further study. Completeness of this system and other metatheoretic results are proved. Other topics include computability, recursive function theory, incompleteness and decidability. Recommended pre-requisite: one of PHIL 220, PHIL 222. PHIL 222 is recommended.

subject: PHIL
title: Induction, Decision and Game Theory
description: Formal methods relevant to probabilistic and inductive reasoning. Decision theory, game theory, axiomatic probability theory and its interpretations, belief dynamics, simulation and modelling. Recommended pre-requisite: one of PHIL125, PHIL 220, PHIL 222 or instructor permission.

subject: PHIL
title: Modal Logic
description: Logic of the modal operators It is necessary that and It is possible that. Possible-world semantics and a method of derivation for this logic. Recommended pre-requisite: one of PHIL 220, PHIL 222. PHIL 222 is recommended.

subject: PHIL
title: Non-Classical Logics
description: One or more of conditional logic, deontic logic, epistemic logic, many-valued logic, systems of belief dynamics. Recommended pre-requisite: one of PHIL 220, PHIL 222. PHIL 222 is recommended.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Logic
description: Fundamental concepts and methods of logic; the logistic method, syntax and semantics; the conditional; entailment; consequence; modal logic; problems concerning extensionality and intentionality. Frege's distinction between sense and reference; Russell's theory of definite descriptions; Tarski's definition of truth. Recommended pre-requisite: one of PHIL 220, PHIL 222. PHIL 222 is recommended.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Language I
description: Philosophical discussion of language, meaning, and communication. Prerequisite: At least one of LING 201/PHIL 220/PHIL 222, plus 6 additional credits of PHIL/LING at the 200-level or above.
prerequisite_raw: At least one of LING 201/PHIL 220/PHIL 222, plus 6 additional credits of PHIL/LING at the 200-level or above.

subject: PHIL
title: Social and Political Philosophy
description: Theories of political and legal obligation and authority, legal reasoning, society and the state. Readings in classic and contemporary texts. Prerequisite: PHIL 230 is strongly recommended.
prerequisite_raw: PHIL 230 is strongly recommended.

subject: PHIL
title: Business and Professional Ethics
description: Moral problems in contemporary business and professional practice, general moral theory, the law, and policy formation. Corporate social and environmental responsibility, employee rights, preferential hiring and affirmative action programs, conflicts of interest, advertising, whistle blowing and self-regulation.

subject: PHIL
title: Environmental Ethics
description: Moral problems arising in the context of human relationships to nature and to non-human living things, considered in terms of both general moral theory and policy formation. Topics include moral standing, animal rights, obligations to future generations, pollution, hazardous materials, the depletion of natural resources and the treatment of non-human living things.

subject: PHIL
title: Bio-Medical Ethics
description: Moral problems arising in the health sciences, especially in medicine but also in biology, psychology, and social work. Topics include abortion, death and euthanasia, genetic engineering, behaviour modification, compulsory treatment, experimentation with human beings and animals, and the relationship between professionals and their patients, subjects or clients. No philosophical background is required.

subject: PHIL
title: Sex, Gender and Philosophy
description: Relationship between sex, gender, and philosophy. Topics may include ethics, epistemology, science, social relations, law, and personhood.

subject: PHIL
title: Power and Oppression
description: Philosophical approaches to historical problems of inequality and social harm, with readings drawn from historical and contemporary sources. Topics to be studied may include slavery, colonialism, labour, and the position of women in society.

subject: PHIL
title: Big Data, Artificial Intelligence, and Ethics
description: Survey of the main ethical questions and challenges from mass data collection and analysis, automated decision making, and artificial intelligence. Some prior study of philosophical ethics and data analysis is helpful but not required. Recommended for both Major in Philosophy students and other students interested in this topic. Credit will only be granted for one of PHIL_V 336 or CPSC_V 430.
exclusion_raw: Survey of the main ethical questions and challenges from mass data collection and analysis, automated decision making, and artificial intelligence. Some prior study of philosophical ethics and data analysis is helpful but not required. Recommended for both Major in Philosophy students and other students interested in this topic. Credit will only be granted for one of PHIL_V 336 or CPSC_V 430.

subject: PHIL
title: Ethics for the Sciences
description: Philosophical exploration of ethical issues in the non-medical sciences, including topics such as intellectual integrity, responsible conduct of research, protection of human subjects, ethics of animal experimentation, and the social responsibilities of scientists. Credit will be granted for only one of ISCI_V 433 or PHIL_V 337.
exclusion_raw: Philosophical exploration of ethical issues in the non-medical sciences, including topics such as intellectual integrity, responsible conduct of research, protection of human subjects, ethics of animal experimentation, and the social responsibilities of scientists. Credit will be granted for only one of ISCI_V 433 or PHIL_V 337.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Law
description: Concepts of law, constitution and sovereignty; law and morality; natural law theories and legal positivism; obligation, responsibility, and punishment. Prerequisite: Restricted to second- or higher-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Restricted to second- or higher-year standing.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Art
description: Topics include art and perception, art and reality, imagination, expression, censorship, and the role of art in human life.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Metaphysics
description: Topics in metaphysics such as the nature of physical reality, personal identity, the mind/body problem, free will, causation and action theory. Readings from classic and contemporary texts. Prerequisite: PHIL 240 is recommended.
prerequisite_raw: PHIL 240 is recommended.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Religion
description: A critical and analytical examination of arguments for and arguments against the existence of God, and other related topics.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Continental Philosophy
description: Major themes and figures in the Continental philosophy tradition; possible topics include 19th century precursors, 20th century philosophers, and comparisons between analytic and continental philosophy.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophical Perspectives on Cognitive Systems Research
description: Philosophical exploration of questions and theories arising from research into the mind, as conducted in psychology, linguistics, and computer science. Prerequisite: 3 credits selected from any of PHIL 211, 212, 220, 222, 230, 235, 240, 250, 260, or COGS 200
prerequisite_raw: 3 credits selected from any of PHIL 211, 212, 220, 222, 230, 235, 240, 250, 260, or COGS 200

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science
description: An examination of historical, conceptual and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 360 or HIST 393. Equivalency: HIST 393
exclusion_raw: An examination of historical, conceptual and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 360 or HIST 393. Equivalency: HIST 393

subject: PHIL
title: Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History
description: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 364 or HIST 394. Equivalency: HIST 394
exclusion_raw: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 364 or HIST 394. Equivalency: HIST 394

subject: PHIL
title: Foundations of Chinese Thought
description: Early (pre 221 BCE) Chinese thought (Confucianism, Daoism, Mohism, Legalism), its contemporary implications, and the role of philosophy and religion in human flourishing./ Credit will only be granted for one of PHIL 371 or ASIA 371. Equivalency: ASIA371
exclusion_raw: Early (pre 221 BCE) Chinese thought (Confucianism, Daoism, Mohism, Legalism), its contemporary implications, and the role of philosophy and religion in human flourishing./ Credit will only be granted for one of PHIL 371 or ASIA 371. Equivalency: ASIA371

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy and Literature
description: Philosophical issues in works of literature or arising from theories of literary interpretation. Topics include issues relating to relativism, the nature of morality, free will, personal identity, the nature of the emotions.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophical Wisdom of Early India
description: Epistemological and ontological thought from the Vedic Period to the period of the rise of philosophical schools or systems. Philosophy in the Mahabharata, Gita; early Buddhist and Jain views on knowledge and reality; views on language. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 378 or ASIA 378. Equivalency: ASIA 378
exclusion_raw: Epistemological and ontological thought from the Vedic Period to the period of the rise of philosophical schools or systems. Philosophy in the Mahabharata, Gita; early Buddhist and Jain views on knowledge and reality; views on language. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 378 or ASIA 378. Equivalency: ASIA 378

subject: PHIL
title: Existentialism
description: Meaning, identity and alienation as explored in the works for example of Kierkegaard, Dostoyevsky, Tolstoy, Sartre, and Camus.

subject: PHIL
title: Classical South Asian Philosophy
description: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical traditions of classical South Asia. PHIL 378/ASIA 378 is recommended. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 388 or ASIA 388. Equivalency: ASIA 388
exclusion_raw: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical traditions of classical South Asia. PHIL 378/ASIA 378 is recommended. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 388 or ASIA 388. Equivalency: ASIA 388

subject: PHIL
title: Morals, Politics and the Individual
description: Introduction to major themes in moral and political philosophy. Primarily for fourth-year and graduate students who have had no previous course in Philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 400, PHIL 100 or PHIL 101 and 102.
exclusion_raw: Introduction to major themes in moral and political philosophy. Primarily for fourth-year and graduate students who have had no previous course in Philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 400, PHIL 100 or PHIL 101 and 102.

subject: PHIL
title: Knowledge, Explanation, and the Nature of Things
description: Introduction to major themes in epistemology and metaphysics. Primarily for fourth-year and graduate students who have had no previous course in Philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 401, PHIL 100 or PHIL 101 and 102.
exclusion_raw: Introduction to major themes in epistemology and metaphysics. Primarily for fourth-year and graduate students who have had no previous course in Philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 401, PHIL 100 or PHIL 101 and 102.

subject: PHIL
title: The Philosophy of Immanuel Kant
description: Study of Kant's critical philosophy. Recommended pre-requisite: one of PHIL 314, PHIL 315, PHIL 340

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of History
description: Concepts of history and historical explanation, historical progress, purpose, necessity, law and causation. Hegel, Marx, Vico, Spengler, Pareto, Collingwood, Croce, and Toynbee, as well as contemporary figures. Students will be expected to have an adequate knowledge of ancient or modern history.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Mathematics
description: Logicism, formalism and constructivism, implications of metatheorems such as those of Gödel and Church, mathematical truth, mathematics and mental construction, mathematics and the physical world. Prerequisite: Philosophy or mathematics courses totaling 9 credits at the 200-level or above.
prerequisite_raw: Philosophy or mathematics courses totaling 9 credits at the 200-level or above.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Perception
description: The contribution of the senses to knowledge of the external world; the nature of perception and its contribution to empirical knowledge. Recommended pre-requisites: Either (a) PHIL 240 or (b) COGS 200. If COGS 200, accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Mind
description: The nature of the mental and physical; the relation between minds and bodies; the character of psychological explanation. Recommended pre-requisites: Either (a) PHIL 240 or (b) COGS 200. If COGS 200, accompanied by 3 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Action
description: Explanation of human actions; the conditions of responsibility; freedom of the will; the domains of rational and moral appraisal; the category of action and the individuation of actions. Recommended pre-requisite: PHIL 340.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Social Science
description: Topics in the philosophy of science of special concern to the social sciences: the problem of objectivity, the use of models and evidence, causation and causal reasoning, formal methods, the status of social kinds and norms, scientific explanation, laws. Prerequisite: 9 credits at the 200-level or above from philosophy, anthropology, geography, economics, history, political science, psychology or sociology.
prerequisite_raw: 9 credits at the 200-level or above from philosophy, anthropology, geography, economics, history, political science, psychology or sociology.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Biology
description: Methodological, historical, philosophical and social science questions about biology. Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in any degree program or 9 credits of philosophy.
prerequisite_raw: Fourth-year standing in any degree program or 9 credits of philosophy.

subject: PHIL
title: Comparative Conceptions of the Self
description: Ways in which the 'self' has been portrayed in eastern and western religious traditions. Thinkers to be considered include Aristotle, Mencius, Freud, Xunzi (Hsün-tzu), Nietzche, and Zhuangzi (Chuang-tzu). Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 470 or ASIA 470. Equivalency: ASIA 470
exclusion_raw: Ways in which the 'self' has been portrayed in eastern and western religious traditions. Thinkers to be considered include Aristotle, Mencius, Freud, Xunzi (Hsün-tzu), Nietzche, and Zhuangzi (Chuang-tzu). Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 470 or ASIA 470. Equivalency: ASIA 470

subject: PHIL
title: Directed Reading
description: Same as PHIL 486-9.

subject: PHIL
title: Philosophy of Action
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHIL
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Foundations of Pharmacy
description: Scientific concepts and pharmacy practice principles. Role of the pharmacist, patient assessment skills, professional identity, communication skills, and an understanding of legal and ethical responsibilities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Medication Management I
description: Modules and integration activities focusing on: an introduction to infectious diseases; musculoskeletal disorders; dermatology; eyes, ears, nose, and throat disorders; and hematology. Prerequisite: PHRM 100. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHRM 100. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Study Design and Interpretation I
description: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on biostatistical foundations, randomized controlled trials, and systematic review of randomized controlled trials. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice I
description: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Technology in Healthcare
description: Knowledge and skills related to the role and applications of technology in health care. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Community Service Learning I
description: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail. Not offered in 2023/24. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient I
description: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world outpatient environments. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: All of PHRM 100, PHRM 111, PHRM 131, PHRM 141, PHRM 161. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of PHRM 100, PHRM 111, PHRM 131, PHRM 141, PHRM 161. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Medication Management II
description: Modules and integration activities focusing on respirology and cardiovascular disorders. Corequisite: PHRM 231. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: PHRM 231. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Medication Management III
description: Modules and integration activities focusing on nephrology, endocrinology, and neurology. Prerequisite: PHRM 211. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHRM 211. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Nutrition for Pharmacists
description: Foundations of nutrition, nutrition for healthy individuals through the lifespan, and selected clinical applications of nutrition in pharmacy practice. Prerequisite: PHRM 171.
prerequisite_raw: PHRM 171.

subject: PHRM
title: Study Design and Interpretation II
description: Principles of screening and diagnostic tests, clinical prediction rules, clinical practice guidelines, conflicts of interest, economic evaluation of therapeutics and medical technologies, harm-benefit analysis, and how to incorporate the best available evidence into practice. Corequisite: PHRM 211. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: PHRM 211. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice II
description: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice, focusing on the roles and training opportunities for pharmacists in specialty areas of outpatient and inpatient practice. Prerequisite: PHRM 171. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHRM 171. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Institutional Practice Skills
description: Preparation for experiential learning in the hospital setting. Focuses on enhancing familiarity with the care environment and developing skills suited for students to apply to patient care during institutional experiential rotations. Prerequisite: PHRM 171. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHRM 171. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Clinical Skills: Administration of Injections
description: Training for authorization to administer injections. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Indigenous Health and Cultural Safety
description: Overview of Indigenous health in Canada and the role a pharmacist can have in collaborating with Indigenous communities in providing culturally safe care and healing Prerequisite: PHRM 171. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHRM 171. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Community Service Learning II
description: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: PHRM 171. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHRM 171. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient II
description: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world outpatient environments. Focus on direct patient care activities. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: All of PHRM 211, PHRM 212, PHRM 221, PHRM 231, PHRM 241, PHRM 251, PHRM 252, PHRM 261, PHRM 270. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of PHRM 211, PHRM 212, PHRM 221, PHRM 231, PHRM 241, PHRM 251, PHRM 252, PHRM 261, PHRM 270. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Inpatient and Health Authority-Based
description: Application of problem-solving skills to patient care activities in real world inpatient and/or health authority-based settings. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Medication Management IV
description: Modules and integration activities focusing on psychiatry, gastroenterology disorders, and oncology and palliative care. Prerequisite: All of PHRM_V 271, PHRM_V 272.
prerequisite_raw: All of PHRM_V 271, PHRM_V 272.

subject: PHRM
title: Medication Management V
description: Modules and integration activities focusing on reproductive health, sexual health, and genitourinary disorders; special infectious diseases; and toxicology. Prerequisite: One of PHRM 271, PHRM 272. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHRM 271, PHRM 272. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Travel Health
description: Providing a consultative service to patients based on patient medical and travel history. Recommending and administering vaccinations according to guidelines. Making recommendations regarding oral medications needed for safe travel. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Peer Teaching in Pharmacy Skills
description: Development and delivery of patient counselling role-playing activities.

subject: PHRM
title: Pharmaceutical Care in Indigenous Health
description: Indigenous health in Canada and the role pharmacists' cultural humility and safety can play when collaborating with other health professionals and Indigenous communities to provide care and healing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Primary Care Pharmacy Practice
description: Strategies for leveraging opportunities and addressing barriers to effective pharmacist integration into multidisciplinary primary care teams and optimizing patient care. Co-requisite: PHRM 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Clinical Pharmacokinetics
description: Lectures and discussions of topics on the application of pharmacokinetic principles and the use of therapeutic drug level monitoring in clinical pharmacy practice. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Renal Pharmacotherapeutics
description: Case-based approach to pathophysiology, pharmacology, clinical pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapy in nephrology with emphasis on the integration and application of fundamental principles to clinical situations in class. Prerequisite: Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Precision Medicine
