description: Precision medicine approaches in research and medical practice to mitigate drug toxicity and improve drug efficacy. Equivalency: PHAR_V 421. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Pharmacology of Drugs of Misuse and Abuse
description: Biological, pharmacological, and psychological aspects of drugs of misuse and abuse. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Leadership Experience Applied to Pharmacy (LEAP)
description: Leadership skills in preparation for the practice of pharmacy in direct or non-direct patient care settings and contexts. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Pharmacy Practice in Acute and Critically Ill Patients
description: Pharmaceutical care concepts for managing acute and critically ill patients. Prerequisite: Third-year standing and a combined grade average of 70% in PHRM 211 and PHRM 212. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing and a combined grade average of 70% in PHRM 211 and PHRM 212. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Practical Applications of Pharmacoepidemiology & Health Economics
description: Principles and methods of collecting epidemiological and economic evidence used to assess the value of pharmaceuticals and services provided by pharmacists. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Pharmacotherapy in Oncology
description: Common oncological diseases and their drug treatment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Pain Research and Therapy
description: Basic mechanisms and the clinical management of acute and chronic pain. Prerequisite: Third Year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Third Year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice III
description: Current and potential roles for pharmacists, and contemporary issues in pharmacy practice. Focus on the role of pharmacists as patient educators, researchers and collaborators in interprofessional teams. Prerequisite: One of PHRM 271, PHRM 272. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHRM 271, PHRM 272. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Diabesity
description: Current issues in obesity and diabetes from pathophysiology to patient care, with a focus on healthcare quality improvement, patient safety, and optimizing outcomes. Prerequisite: Third-year standing. Equivalency: PHAR 546
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing. Equivalency: PHAR 546

subject: PHRM
title: Practice Management and Leadership
description: Application of management and leadership principles and skills to pharmacy operations. Prerequisite: All of PHRM 271, PHRM 272. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of PHRM 271, PHRM 272. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Clinical Skills: Administration of Injections
description: Training for authorization to administer injections. Equivalency: PHRM 252. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient III
description: Direct patient care activities in an outpatient setting. Building on existing pharmaceutical knowledge and problem solving ability. Increased involvement in diverse patient care situations. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: One of PHRM 311, PHRM 312, PHRM 341, PHRM 351. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHRM 311, PHRM 312, PHRM 341, PHRM 351. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Seminar: Advanced Topics in Pharmacy Practice
description: Pharmacists in practice, emerging pharmacy practice issues and pharmacists as preceptors. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: PHRM 371. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHRM 371. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: PharmD Seminar
description: Seminar course about current and potential roles for pharmacists. Students will also deliver an individual and a group seminar. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Critical Appraisal of Pharmacotherapy Literature
description: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on randomized controlled trials, systematic reviews, epidemiologic studies (cohort, case-control), pharmacoeconomic analyses, clinical prediction rules, and guidelines. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Patient Assessment Skills
description: Principles and practices of patient assessment, applied to the monitoring of drug efficacy and toxicity. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Applied Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacogenomics
description: Pharmacokinetic monitoring of drug therapy in common clinical situations with foundations for application to other drugs. Pharmacogenomics and personalized medicine principles and applications to practice. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Practice Management
description: Values, concepts, issues and responsibilities of individuals exercising leadership and management roles in pharmacy practice and health care settings. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHRM
title: Pharmacotherapeutics 1
description: Therapeutic foundations. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

title: Pharmacotherapeutics 2

prerequisite_raw: PHRM 461. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Introductory Physics
description: Kinematics, force, energy, momentum, use of graphs and vectors in physics; thermal energy, heat transfer, Earth's energy balance; electricity. Students with credit for Physics 12 may not obtain credit for this course unless they took AP, IB, or A-level Physics and were offered advanced credit for PHYS 100. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: Not open to students with credit for PHYS 12. Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 is required; Physics 11 is required for first-year students, strongly recommended for others.
prerequisite_raw: Not open to students with credit for PHYS 12. Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 is required; Physics 11 is required for first-year students, strongly recommended for others.

subject: PHYS
title: Energy and Waves
description: Fluids, harmonic oscillator, travelling waves, standing waves, sound, and interference of light waves, including diffraction. [3-3*-1*] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

subject: PHYS
title: Electricity, Light and Radiation
description: Introduction to optics, electricity and magnetism, electric circuits, radioactivity, including biological applications. [3-3*-1*] Prerequisite: One of PHYS_V 101, PHYS_V 107. Corequisite: One of MATH_V 101, MATH_V 103, MATH_V 105, MATH_V 121.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS_V 101, PHYS_V 107. Corequisite: One of MATH_V 101, MATH_V 103, MATH_V 105, MATH_V 121.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH_V 101, MATH_V 103, MATH_V 105, MATH_V 121.

subject: PHYS
title: Enriched Physics 1 (lecture)
description: Classical mechanics including conservation laws, angular momentum of rigid bodies and simple harmonic motion, wave phenomena, with an introduction to special relativity, quantum mechanics, nuclear physics, statistical mechanics and solid state physics. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Either (a) a score more than 85% in all of PHYS 12, MATH 12 or (b) a score more than 85% in all of PHYS 12, PREC 12 or (c) a score more than 85% in all of PHYS 12, CALC 12 or (d) a score more than 85% in PHYS 100. PHYS 12 = Physics 12; MATH 12 = Principles of Mathematics 12; PREC 12 = Pre-Calculus 12; CALC 12 = Calculus 12. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) a score more than 85% in all of PHYS 12, MATH 12 or (b) a score more than 85% in all of PHYS 12, PREC 12 or (c) a score more than 85% in all of PHYS 12, CALC 12 or (d) a score more than 85% in PHYS 100. PHYS 12 = Physics 12; MATH 12 = Principles of Mathematics 12; PREC 12 = Pre-Calculus 12; CALC 12 = Calculus 12. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

subject: PHYS
title: Enriched Physics 1
description: Classical mechanics including conservation laws, angular momentum of rigid bodies and simple harmonic motion, wave phenomena, with an introduction to special relativity, quantum mechanics, nuclear physics, statistical mechanics and solid state physics. [3-3*-1*] Prerequisite: Either (a) a score of 85% or higher in all of PHYS 12, MATH 12 or (b) a score of 85% or higher in all of PHYS 12, PREC 12 or (c) a score of 85% or higher in all of PHYS 12, CALC 12 or (d) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 100. MATH 12 = Principles of Mathematics 12; PREC 12 = Pre-Calculus 12; CALC 12 = Calculus 12; PHYS 12 = Physics 12. Corequisite: One of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 102, MATH_V 104, MATH_V 120, MATH_V 180, MATH_V 184.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) a score of 85% or higher in all of PHYS 12, MATH 12 or (b) a score of 85% or higher in all of PHYS 12, PREC 12 or (c) a score of 85% or higher in all of PHYS 12, CALC 12 or (d) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 100. MATH 12 = Principles of Mathematics 12; PREC 12 = Pre-Calculus 12; CALC 12 = Calculus 12; PHYS 12 = Physics 12. Corequisite: One of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 102, MATH_V 104, MATH_V 120, MATH_V 180, MATH_V 184.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 102, MATH_V 104, MATH_V 120, MATH_V 180, MATH_V 184.

subject: PHYS
title: Enriched Physics II
description: Electricity and magnetism, electrical circuits, induction, electromagnetic waves, Maxwell's equations and applications. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of PHYS_V 106, PHYS_V 107 or (b) a score of 85% or higher in one of PHYS_V 101, PHYS_V 117, PHYS_V 131. Corequisite: One of MATH_V 101, MATH_V 103, MATH_V 105, MATH_V 121.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) one of PHYS_V 106, PHYS_V 107 or (b) a score of 85% or higher in one of PHYS_V 101, PHYS_V 117, PHYS_V 131. Corequisite: One of MATH_V 101, MATH_V 103, MATH_V 105, MATH_V 121.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH_V 101, MATH_V 103, MATH_V 105, MATH_V 121.

subject: PHYS
title: Enriched Experimental Physics
description: A laboratory course accompanying PHYS 108 with emphasis on data collection and analysis and experimental techniques. [0-3-0] Prerequisite: PHYS 107. Corequisite: One of PHYS 108, PHYS 118.
prerequisite_raw: PHYS 107. Corequisite: One of PHYS 108, PHYS 118.
corequisite_raw: One of PHYS 108, PHYS 118.

subject: PHYS
title: Dynamics and Waves
description: Kinematics including curvilinear motion. Forces and Newton's laws of motion. Work-energy theorem, conservation of energy. Conservation of momentum, collisions. Torque, rotational dynamics, angular momentum. Oscillations and waves. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

subject: PHYS
title: Electricity, Light and Radiation
description: Optics, electricity and magnetism, electric circuits, electromagnetic waves. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of PHYS_V 101, PHYS_V 106, PHYS_V 107, PHYS_V 117, PHYS_V 131, PHYS_V 157 and one of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 102, MATH_V 104, MATH_V 110, MATH_V 120, MATH_V 180, MATH_V 184. Corequisite: One of MATH_V 101, MATH_V 103, MATH_V 105, MATH_V 121.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS_V 101, PHYS_V 106, PHYS_V 107, PHYS_V 117, PHYS_V 131, PHYS_V 157 and one of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 102, MATH_V 104, MATH_V 110, MATH_V 120, MATH_V 180, MATH_V 184. Corequisite: One of MATH_V 101, MATH_V 103, MATH_V 105, MATH_V 121.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH_V 101, MATH_V 103, MATH_V 105, MATH_V 121.

subject: PHYS
title: Experimental Physics Lab I
description: Introductory laboratory course, with emphasis on data collection, data analysis techniques, and scientific reasoning. [0-3-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

subject: PHYS
title: Experimental Physics Lab II
description: A second laboratory course emphasizing the synthesis and development of further sophistication around the data collection, data analysis techniques and scientific reasoning developed in PHYS 119. [0-3-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 107, PHYS 119.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 107, PHYS 119.

subject: PHYS
title: Energy and Waves (Lecture)
description: Fluids, harmonic oscillator, travelling waves, standing waves, sound, and interference of light waves, radioactivity including biological applications. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 12, PHYS_V 100. Corequisite: One of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 102, MATH_V 104, MATH_V 110, MATH_V 120, MATH_V 180, MATH_V 184.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 12, PHYS_V 100. Corequisite: One of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 102, MATH_V 104, MATH_V 110, MATH_V 120, MATH_V 180, MATH_V 184.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH_V 100, MATH_V 102, MATH_V 104, MATH_V 110, MATH_V 120, MATH_V 180, MATH_V 184.

subject: PHYS
title: Elements of Physics
description: Thermometry, thermal properties of matter, heat, oscillations, waves, sound, wave optics; geometrical optics, elementary electricity and magnetism, simple DC and AC circuits. [3-0-1; 3-3-1] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

subject: PHYS
title: Introductory Physics for Engineers I
description: Heat, thermodynamics, oscillations, waves, and sound. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

subject: PHYS
title: Introductory Physics for Engineers II
description: Electricity and magnetism, DC and AC circuits, optics. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: PHYS 157. Corequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.
prerequisite_raw: PHYS 157. Corequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

subject: PHYS
title: Introductory Physics Laboratory for Engineers
description: A laboratory course with emphasis on experimental design, measurement and analysis techniques. [0-3-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of PHYS 157, PHYS 158.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100. Corequisite: One of PHYS 157, PHYS 158.
corequisite_raw: One of PHYS 157, PHYS 158.

subject: PHYS
title: Mechanics I
description: Statics of particles, equilibrium or rigid bodies, rigid body statics and internal forces, trusses; kinematics: rectilinear motion; dynamics: Newton's second law, friction, impulse, momentum, work and energy. Recommended pre-requisites: one of PHYS 12, PHYS 100 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184. Recommended co-requisite: one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121. [3-0-1]

subject: PHYS
title: Relativity and Quanta
description: Special relativity: Lorentz transformation, dynamics and conservation laws. Quantum physics: the experimental evidence for quantization; a qualitative discussion of the concepts of quantum mechanics and their application to simple systems of atoms and nuclei. [4-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121; or (b) SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121; or (b) SCIE 001.

subject: PHYS
title: Thermal Physics I
description: Fundamentals of thermodynamics and statistical physics; entropy, laws of thermodynamics, heat engines, free energy, phase transitions, Boltzmann statistics, quantum statistics. [4-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.

subject: PHYS
title: Intermediate Experimental Physics
description: Use of analog electronics and amplifiers, digital electronics and analog-to-digital conversion and the use of computers in data analysis and simulations in thermodynamic, electronic and modern physics experiments. [0-3-1*] Prerequisite: Either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153 or (c) SCIE 001 or (d) all of PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (e) all of PHYS 118, PHYS 119 or (f) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 119. Corequisite: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153 or (c) SCIE 001 or (d) all of PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (e) all of PHYS 118, PHYS 119 or (f) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 119. Corequisite: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.

subject: PHYS
title: Introduction to Computational Physics
description: Introduction to UNIX/Linux; software tools for processing, fitting and displaying data; numerical methods and application in the physical sciences. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

subject: PHYS
title: Intermediate Mechanics
description: Review of kinematics, Newton's laws, angular momentum and fixed axis rotation. Rigid body motion, central forces, non-inertial frames of reference. Introduction to Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 170, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223. Corequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 170, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223. Corequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.

subject: PHYS
title: Intermediate Experimental Physics I
description: Analog electronics and amplifiers, digital electronics, analog-to-digital converters and an introduction to use of computers in data analysis and simulations. [1-3-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of PHYS 108, PHYS 118 and one of PHYS 109, PHYS 119; or (b) PHYS 102 or (c) all of PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (d) SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) one of PHYS 108, PHYS 118 and one of PHYS 109, PHYS 119; or (b) PHYS 102 or (c) all of PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (d) SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253.

subject: PHYS
title: Intermediate Experimental Physics II
description: Thermodynamics experiments, modern physics experiments and use of computers in data analysis. [0-3-1*] Prerequisite: PHYS_V 219. Corequisite: MATH_V 215.
prerequisite_raw: PHYS_V 219. Corequisite: MATH_V 215.
corequisite_raw: MATH_V 215.

subject: PHYS
title: Introduction to Modern Physics
description: Wave-particle duality of matter, special relativity, processes in atomic, nuclear and solid state, and introduction to quantum mechanical devices and techniques. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

subject: PHYS
title: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the winter term of the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics. Prerequisite: PHYS 200. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHYS 200. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics. Prerequisite: [PHYS298] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [PHYS298] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Electricity and Magnetism
description: Maxwell's equations and their applications, electrical fields and potentials of static charge distributions, current, fields of moving charges, magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.

subject: PHYS
title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
description: Principles and applications of quantum mechanics, wave mechanics, the Schroedinger equation, expectation values, Hermitian operators, commuting observables, one-dimensional systems, harmonic oscillators, angular momentum, three-dimensional systems. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 200, PHYS 250. Corequisite: One of MATH 257, MATH 316, PHYS 312.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 200, PHYS 250. Corequisite: One of MATH 257, MATH 316, PHYS 312.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 257, MATH 316, PHYS 312.

subject: PHYS
title: Introduction to Biophysics
description: Physical principles involved in biological systems at the microscopic and molecular scales. Diffusion, low Reynolds number dynamics, the physicist's view of biomolecular structure, models of molecular motors and membranes. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and either (a) PHYS 203 or (b) one of ENPH 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 205 and one of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and either (a) PHYS 203 or (b) one of ENPH 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 205 and one of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302.

subject: PHYS
title: Advanced Mechanics
description: Variational calculus, Lagrangian dynamics, rigid body motion including free and forced precession, Hamiltonian mechanics, Poisson brackets, canonical coordinates, Hamilton-Jacobi theory, action angle variables. Introduction to dynamical chaos: determinism, Lyapunov exponents. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 216, ENPH 270 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 216, ENPH 270 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.

subject: PHYS
title: Electrical Laboratory
description: Selected experiments in electromagnetism and electronics; computer data acquisition; advanced data analysis and simulation. [1-4-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 209, PHYS 229, ENPH 259.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 209, PHYS 229, ENPH 259.

subject: PHYS
title: Machine Learning for Physics and Astronomy Data Analysis
description: Fundamental principles and applications of data-centric research techniques in Physics and Astronomy. Topics include algorithms for data structuring, dimensionality reduction, linear regression and classification, artificial neural nets, convolutional neural nets, unsupervised learning. [1-4-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, MATH 318 and one of PHYS 210, CPSC 103, CPSC 110, APSC 160, EOSC 211 and one of PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, MATH 318 and one of PHYS 210, CPSC 103, CPSC 110, APSC 160, EOSC 211 and one of PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, SCIE 001.

subject: PHYS
title: Introduction to Mathematical Physics
description: The application of ordinary and partial differential equations to physical problems; boundary and initial value problems associated with heat, wave and Laplace equations. Fourier analysis; expansions in Bessel and Legendre functions. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 312 and MATH 316. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: [MATH215]
prerequisite_raw: [MATH215]
exclusion_raw: The application of ordinary and partial differential equations to physical problems; boundary and initial value problems associated with heat, wave and Laplace equations. Fourier analysis; expansions in Bessel and Legendre functions. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 312 and MATH 316. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: [MATH215]

subject: PHYS
title: Fluids
description: Kinetic theory: Diffusion, viscosity and sound waves. Introduction to hydrodynamics: Laminar flow, capillary and gravity waves, convection and turbulence. Dimensional analysis. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MATH 215. Corequisite: PHYS 203.
prerequisite_raw: MATH 215. Corequisite: PHYS 203.
corequisite_raw: PHYS 203.

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Physics of Materials
description: Crystal structure, elasticity and phonons, elementary electronic transport, defects, alloys, liquid crystals and polymers. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 203, ENPH 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 205, CHEM 304 and one of PHYS 200, PHYS 250, CHEM 312. Corequisite: [MATH215]
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 203, ENPH 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 205, CHEM 304 and one of PHYS 200, PHYS 250, CHEM 312. Corequisite: [MATH215]
corequisite_raw: [MATH215]

subject: PHYS
title: Experimental Acoustics
description: Experimental techniques of acoustics: data acquisition hardware and software, microphones, loudspeakers, noise, vibration and modal analysis. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: One of ENPH 259, PHYS 209, PHYS 229.
prerequisite_raw: One of ENPH 259, PHYS 209, PHYS 229.

subject: PHYS
title: Electronics Laboratory
description: A project-oriented lab introducing the design and construction of microprocessor-controlled devices. [1-4-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 209, PHYS 219, ENPH 259.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 209, PHYS 219, ENPH 259.

subject: PHYS
title: Modern Physics
description: Quantum physics, nuclear energy and particle physics at a level suitable for third- and fourth-year Science students not proceeding to a physics degree. Not for credit towards a B.Sc. in Astronomy, Biophysics or Physics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 180, MATH 184 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157; or (b) SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 180, MATH 184 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157; or (b) SCIE 001.

subject: PHYS
title: Energy and Climate
description: The fundamental physics behind global issues of energy use and climate change. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 102, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, PHYS 158; or (b) SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 102, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, PHYS 158; or (b) SCIE 001.

subject: PHYS
title: Revolutions in Understanding the Universe
description: Ancient Greek ideas of substance and forms and modern concepts of forces and fields. The twentieth-century quantum revolution. The modern universe, from quarks and atoms to the big bang. Quantum paradoxes. Not for credit in the faculties of Science and Applied Science. No mathematics beyond Grade 10 required. [3-0-0]

subject: PHYS
title: Physics of Music
description: An introduction to the physical principles important to the production, transmission and perception of musical sounds. The treatment will be non-mathematical; with emphasis on demonstrations. Topics may include the description of sound waves, resonances, scales, physics of hearing, examination of specific musical instruments, etc. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. [3-0-0]

subject: PHYS
title: Physical Science by Inquiry
description: A guided sequence of hands-on science modules intended primarily for prospective elementary schoolteachers, to help them to work constructively in a science teaching role. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. [0-6-0] Prerequisite: Secondary school algebra.
prerequisite_raw: Secondary school algebra.

subject: PHYS
title: Frontiers in Physics and Astronomy
description: Current research topics in physics and astronomy are investigated and explored. Technical communication and research skills are studied and developed via oral presentations and written scientific reports on these current research topics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing in a physics honours program or fourth-year standing in a physics or astronomy major program.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing in a physics honours program or fourth-year standing in a physics or astronomy major program.

subject: PHYS
title: Directed Research Project in Physics
description: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a written report. This course requires approval of the course instructor and program advisor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. [1*-6-0]

subject: PHYS
title: Applications of Classical Mechanics
description: Review of principles. Particle mechanics: Euler's equations, tops and gyroscopes, motion of the Earth, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian methods. Variational principles in optics and mechanics, Liouville's theorem and statistical mechanics. The relationship between classical and quantum mechanics. [3-0-0]

subject: PHYS
title: Electric and Magnetic Fields
description: Applications of electricity and magnetism. Maxwell's equations. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 153, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 153, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317.

subject: PHYS
title: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics. Prerequisite: [PHYS299] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [PHYS299] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Introduction to Elementary Particles
description: Standard model, classification of elementary particles and forces of nature, symmetries, conservation laws, quark model, quantum electrodynamics, quantum chromodynamics, and the theory of weak interactions. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 304, PHYS 450.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 304, PHYS 450.

subject: PHYS
title: Electromagnetic Theory
description: Applications of Maxwell's theory. Wave propagation in dielectrics, conductors and plasmas, wave guides, radiation, antennae, and special relativity. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 301, PHYS 354.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 301, PHYS 354.

subject: PHYS
title: Applications of Quantum Mechanics
description: Spin and angular momentum addition, perturbation methods, and applications in the fields of Atomic, Molecular, Nuclear, and Solid State Physics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 304, PHYS 450.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 304, PHYS 450.

subject: PHYS
title: Statistical Mechanics
description: Principles and applications of statistical mechanics. Ideal gases, degenerate Fermi gases, Bose-Einstein condensation, black body radiation, fluctuations and phase transitions. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 203, ENPH 257, PHYS 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 304 and one of PHYS 304, PHYS 450, CHEM 312. One of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302 is recommended.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 203, ENPH 257, PHYS 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 304 and one of PHYS 304, PHYS 450, CHEM 312. One of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302 is recommended.

subject: PHYS
title: Introduction to Medical Physics
description: Radiotherapy, X-ray imaging, nuclear medicine, magnetic resonance imaging and biomedical optics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third year standing in Science or Applied Science is required. MATH 200 (or MATH 217 or MATH 226) is recommended.
prerequisite_raw: Third year standing in Science or Applied Science is required. MATH 200 (or MATH 217 or MATH 226) is recommended.

subject: PHYS
title: Radiation Biophysics
description: Physical and chemical interactions of ionizing radiations and their biological effects at the cellular, tissue and whole-animal levels. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001. and third year standing in Science or Applied Science.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001. and third year standing in Science or Applied Science.

subject: PHYS
title: Introduction to General Relativity
description: Physical consequences of Einstein's equations, including the principle of equivalence, curved space-time, geodesics, the Schwarzschild solution, deflection of light, black holes, and gravitational radiation. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255. PHYS 301 and one of PHYS 206, PHYS 306 are recommended.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255. PHYS 301 and one of PHYS 206, PHYS 306 are recommended.

subject: PHYS
title: Optics
description: Principles and applications of optical physics. Interference, diffraction, coherence, polarization, Fresnel relations, optical coatings, waves in dielectric media, Gaussian beams, waveguides, optical cavities, lasers, fibre optics, and Fourier optics. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 301, PHYS 354 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 301, PHYS 354 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.

subject: PHYS
title: Computational Physics
description: Scientific programming applied to problems in physics. Fundamentals of numerical analysis for continuum problems. Solution of linear and non-linear algebraic systems, ordinary differential equations and stochastic problems. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 312, MATH 257, MATH 316 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 110, CPSC 103, APSC 160.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 312, MATH 257, MATH 316 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 110, CPSC 103, APSC 160.

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Physics
description: Fundamentals of atomic, nuclear, particle, and condensed matter physics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MATH 215 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 200.
prerequisite_raw: MATH 215 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 200.

subject: PHYS
title: Physics of Biocellular Structure and Machinery
description: Molecular structure and architecture of biological cells, interactions of molecules in aqueous solution and at interfaces, physical properties of polymers and surfactants, mechanisms of cell membranes and cytoplasmic structures, thermodynamics of molecular machines and mechanical enzymes. Credit can not be given for both PHYS_V 437 and 537. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS_V 313, PHYS_V 403, PHYS_V 455, CHEM_V 304.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS_V 313, PHYS_V 403, PHYS_V 455, CHEM_V 304.

subject: PHYS
title: Zoological Physics
description: Animal systems viewed from a physicist's perspective. Topics include sensory systems, energy budgets, locomotion, internal flows, physical advantages of grouping. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. BIOL 325 is recommended. Equivalency: BIOL438
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. BIOL 325 is recommended. Equivalency: BIOL438

subject: PHYS
title: Honours Thesis
description: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a thesis. [1*-6-0]

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Mechanics
description: Postulates of quantum mechanics, expectation values, hermitian operators, commuting observables, applications to one-dimensional systems, harmonic oscillators, angular momentum, applications in three dimensions, hydrogen atom, time dependent perturbations. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 304, 450 or CHEM 312. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 200, PHYS 250.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 200, PHYS 250.
exclusion_raw: Postulates of quantum mechanics, expectation values, hermitian operators, commuting observables, applications to one-dimensional systems, harmonic oscillators, angular momentum, applications in three dimensions, hydrogen atom, time dependent perturbations. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 304, 450 or CHEM 312. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 200, PHYS 250.

subject: PHYS
title: Applied Electromagnetic Theory
description: Wave propagation and related phenomena in dielectrics, conductors and plasmas. Wave guides, radiation, antennae, special relativity. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS_V 301, PHYS_V 354.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS_V 301, PHYS_V 354.

subject: PHYS
title: Statistical Mechanics
description: Introduction to quantum statistical mechanics and its application to systems of varying complexity from the simple ideal gas to the degenerate gas. Quantum fluids, phase transitions and simulation methods will also be introduced. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 403 or PHYS 455. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 257, PHYS 203, PHYS 313 and one of PHYS 304, PHYS 450.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 257, PHYS 203, PHYS 313 and one of PHYS 304, PHYS 450.
exclusion_raw: Introduction to quantum statistical mechanics and its application to systems of varying complexity from the simple ideal gas to the degenerate gas. Quantum fluids, phase transitions and simulation methods will also be introduced. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 403 or PHYS 455. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 257, PHYS 203, PHYS 313 and one of PHYS 304, PHYS 450.

subject: PHYS
title: Applied Optics
description: Basic applications of lasers, geometrical optics, fibre optics, diffraction, and Fourier optics. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: All of PHYS_V 250, PHYS_V 354.
prerequisite_raw: All of PHYS_V 250, PHYS_V 354.

subject: PHYS
title: Applied Nuclear Physics
description: Radioactive decay and radiations, nuclear properties, interactions of neutrons, physical principles of power reactors, nuclear fusion, radiation monitoring, and safety. [3-0-1*] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 304, PHYS 450.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 304, PHYS 450.

subject: PHYS
title: Applied Solid State Physics
description: Symmetry of crystal structures, reciprocal lattice, band theory, conduction in metals and semiconductors, phonons and superconductivity. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS_V 450, PHYS_V 304.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS_V 450, PHYS_V 304.

subject: PHYS
title: Student Directed Seminar
description: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. Cannot be used as a specialization requirement in any PHYS and/or ASTR specialization. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics. Prerequisite: [PHYS399] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [PHYS399] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Co-operative Work Placement V
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics. Prerequisite: [PHYS498] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [PHYS498] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Mechanics I
description: Non-relativistic quantum mechanics with applications to atomic, nuclear and particle physics. Perturbation theory, multielectron atoms, molecular structure, WKB, scattering theory. Recommended pre-requisite: PHYS 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Mechanics II
description: Time-dependent perturbation theory, density matrix formalism, NMR, emission and absorption of radiation. Elementary field theory techniques for many body systems. Quasiparticles, phonons, magnons, holes. Relativistic Klein-Gordon and Dirac equations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Condensed Matter Physics I
description: One-electron theory of solids, energy bands, lattice vibration, transport theory. Prerequisite: A background in undergraduate solid state physics such as covered in PHYS 474 is highly recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: A background in undergraduate solid state physics such as covered in PHYS 474 is highly recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Condensed Matter Physics II
description: Interacting electrons, electron-phonon interaction, Hubbard model, magnetism, superconductivity, use of Green functions. Prerequisite: [PHYS502] Corequisite: [PHYS500] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [PHYS502] Corequisite: [PHYS500] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: [PHYS500] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Special Relativity and Classical Electromagnetism
description: Boundary-value problems, Green's functions and multipole expansions, magnetostatics, Faraday's law of induction, retarded potentials, Poynting's theorem and conservation laws, gauge invariance. Propagation of electromagnetic waves. Presentation of radiation from moving charges, classical electron theory. Prerequisite: A background in electricity and magnetism such as covered PHYS 401 is highly recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: A background in electricity and magnetism such as covered PHYS 401 is highly recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Nuclear Physics
description: Nucleons and their structure, hadrons and isospin, two-nucleon systems and interactions, bulk properties of nuclei and models, nuclear excitations and radioactivity, strong and electromagnetic decay, symmetries and weak interaction, reactions, nuclear astrophysics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Elementary Particle Physics
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Field Theory II
description: Prerequisite: PHYS 526. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: PHYS 526. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Statistical Mechanics
description: Mean field theory, Landau theory of phase transitions, critical phenomena, renormalization theory. Monte Carlo method, linear response theory, fluctuations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Quantum Field Theory I
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Laser Physics
description: Classical and semi-classical treatment of interaction of EM-radiation with atomic systems; semi-classical laser theory; Gaussian beams and optical resonators; specific laser types and systems; femtosecond lasers and amplifiers; Raman lasers; lasing with inversion; topics of current research interest. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Radiotherapy Physics I
description: Principles of dosimetry of ionizing radiation with emphasis on applications to radiotherapy and radiobiology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Radiotherapy Physics II
description: A continuation of PHYS 534, including an extension of the topics discussed in that course. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Advanced Radiation Biophysics
description: Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 536 or PHYS 405. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 536 or PHYS 405. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Radiation Dosimetry
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Radiological Imaging
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Nuclear Medicine
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Imaging
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Biomedical Optics
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Anatomy, Physiology and Statistics for Medical Physicists
description: Restricted to graduate students in the M.Sc. (Medical Physics) Specialization. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Clinical Experience in Medical Physics
description: Clinical treatment planning techniques, quality assurance of treatment equipment and clinical decision making for radiation therapy. Quality assurance and decision making for medical imaging. Pass/fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Physics and Engineering of Particle Accelerators
description: Injectors, radio frequency acceleration, superconducting acceleration elements, beam dynamics, and applications of electron accelerators. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Applications of Radioisotopes in Science and in Medicine
description: Use of radioisotopes in nuclear medicine, materials science, environmental science, and nuclear physics in combination with the associated production, processing, and detection technologies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Physical Cosmology
description: Credit will be granted for only one of ASTR 403 or PHYS 571. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Credit will be granted for only one of ASTR 403 or PHYS 571. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Experimental Methods in Quantum Materials
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Modelling and Simulation of Quantum Materials
description: Prerequisite: A background in undergraduate solid state physics such as covered in PHYS 474 is highly recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: A background in undergraduate solid state physics such as covered in PHYS 474 is highly recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PHYS
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: City-Making: A Global Perspective
description: Contemporary city development trends, policies, and practices across the globe as explored against the backdrop of culture and technology. Includes hands-on learning.

subject: PLAN
title: City Visuals
description: An exploratory journey through the vast world of visualizing the city and ways of representing the built environment, including how to both interpret and use visualizations to read the city. Prerequisite: Second-year standing or above in any program.
prerequisite_raw: Second-year standing or above in any program.

subject: PLAN
title: Methods of Community Engagement
description: Examination of various approaches to hands-on engagement with urban communities while examining the meaning of public, community, and participation. Prerequisite: Second-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Second-year standing.

subject: PLAN
title: Indigeneity and the City
description: Place-based exploration of the multiple, complex and contested ways urban Indigeneity is constituted in Canada today, with opportunities for field trips and hands-on learning. Prerequisite: Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.

subject: PLAN
title: The Just City in a Divided World
description: Considers the city as a terrain for the manifestation and mediation of social justice. Explores how the allocation of land, goods, and services in cities (re)produces social stratification, and how institutions and civil society negotiate just and unjust outcomes. Prerequisite: Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.

subject: PLAN
title: Smart Cities: Concepts, Methods and Design
description: Rapid transformation of cities by information technology and socio-economic innovation; growth in citizen-generated data and the internet of things; emerging theory, methods, and frameworks for understanding Smart Cities. Prerequisite: Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Green Cities
description: The key social and technological challenges, contradictions, and opportunities in planning for ecologically sound urbanization. Prerequisite: Second-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Second-year standing.

subject: PLAN
title: Community Planning in a World of Diversity
description: Examination of how the diverse, multicultural, and cosmopolitan aspects of cities create challenges and opportunities for community planning. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing.

subject: PLAN
title: Urban Planning Issues and Concepts
description: Evolution, practice and future of urban planning and development, with emphasis on institutional arrangements, housing, transportation, urban design and development control. For third- and fourth-year undergraduate students interested in urban planning. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Special Topics in Urban Studies
description: Selected topics in urban studies.

subject: PLAN
title: Urban Studies Capstone II
description: Application of key elements of urban studies theory, concepts, and methods to a community-engaged urban challenge. Prerequisite: GEOG 451. Fourth-year standing. Equivalency: URST452
prerequisite_raw: GEOG 451. Fourth-year standing. Equivalency: URST452

subject: PLAN
title: Comparative Perspectives on Planning History and Futures
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Reconciliation and Planning
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Sustainability and Resilience in Planning
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

title: Urban Design and Visual Representation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Urban Economics, Infrastructure, and Real Estate Issues in Planning
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Making and Implementing Community and Regional Plans
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Indigenous Planning: Ways of Being, Knowing and Doing
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Indigenous Law, Governance and Community Planning
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Planning for Community Economic Development
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Theory and Methods of Urban Design
description: Application of urban design theory to a neighbourhood design. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Quantitative Skills for Planners
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Qualitative Data Collection and Analysis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: The Profession of Planning
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Legal Concepts for Professional Planning
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Planning Practice Methods
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Selected Topics in Experimental Learning: The Planning Studio
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Internship
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Affordable Housing Policy and Planning
description: The history of housing and homelessness policies as well as current issues and challenges faced by municipalities, regional governments, non-profit housing providers, and others. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Planning for Disaster-Resilient Communities
description: Natural disasters from the perspective of risk analysis, risk reduction, and planning for disaster-resilient communities. Focus primarily on Canada and the U.S. but includes disaster risk globally. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Strategic Planning: Developing and Implementing Policy Plans
description: Theory and practice of developing and implementing plans for sustainable regions, cities, and neighbourhoods. Combining land use, transportation, environment, socio-economic, and financial directions, managing plan making including public participation, and writing council reports. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems
description: Theory, history and capabilities behind GIS, with customized laboratory exercises that incorporate urban design and planning themes. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Transportation Planning & Analysis
description: Foundations of urban travel modelling: data needs; survey and sampling techniques; model calibration and validation; discrete choice modeling; 4-step travel demand forecasting (trip generation, distribution, modal choice, and assignment); activity based models; integrated land use/transport models. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 441, CIVL 583, or PLAN 535. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Foundations of urban travel modelling: data needs; survey and sampling techniques; model calibration and validation; discrete choice modeling; 4-step travel demand forecasting (trip generation, distribution, modal choice, and assignment); activity based models; integrated land use/transport models. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 441, CIVL 583, or PLAN 535. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Planning Praxis
description: Pass/fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Planning Studio
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Practical Practice: City Planning as a Craft
description: Approach, role, style, and essential skills of practical urban planning: working at the community level; developing overall policy; managing development; undertaking urban design; and engaging in the political process. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Indigenous Community Planning Practicum
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: The Role of Theory in Planning Research
description: This course will be taken in the first term of the Master's program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Design of Planning- and Policy-Oriented Research
description: Research design for SCARP thesis-based Master's students. Approaches for designing research methodologies and thesis structure. Selection processes for research focus; linking research problems to methodological sources; logics of structuring the thesis. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Master's Thesis Workshop
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Public Health, Transportation, and the Built Environment
description: Health issues associated with transportation and the built environment; design of urban form for non-motorized transportation for the improvement of personal and environmental health; factors that impact transportation choices; applying findings from research to specific transportation planning processes and projects. Credit will be granted for only one of PLAN 579 or SPPH 571. Equivalency: SPPH571 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Health issues associated with transportation and the built environment; design of urban form for non-motorized transportation for the improvement of personal and environmental health; factors that impact transportation choices; applying findings from research to specific transportation planning processes and projects. Credit will be granted for only one of PLAN 579 or SPPH 571. Equivalency: SPPH571 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Urban Transportation Planning
description: Topics include the relationship between transportation and urban activity systems; analysis of supply and demand; accessibility and environment; institutional arrangements and public finance. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Housing and Community Planning Policy
description: Homes and communities are a focus of public policy for local and senior governments. Overview of past and current policies addressing the design and development of homes and communities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Land Use and Environmental Policy
description: Identify potential impacts of human land use activities on environmental systems; review policies in place at various levels of government in Canada (and elsewhere) that promote sustainable development and reduce negative impacts; assess effectiveness of those policies; design new policies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Planning for Water Resources Management
description: The relationships among relevant bio-physical, socio-economic and institutional systems as applied to regional planning for watersheds, lakes, estuaries, coastal zones and international river basins. Water supply, waste disposal, fisheries, aquaculture, recreation, hydropower and flood control. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Research Methods Seminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Planning Theory Advanced Seminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Ph.D. Colloquium
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLAN
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLNT
title: Plant-Water Relations for Sustainable Agriculture
description: Water requirements of woody perennial crops for production and survival, application of physiological stress thresholds for irrigation management. Credit will be granted for only one of PLNT 505, APBI 405, APBI 351, BIOL 351, FRST 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Water requirements of woody perennial crops for production and survival, application of physiological stress thresholds for irrigation management. Credit will be granted for only one of PLNT 505, APBI 405, APBI 351, BIOL 351, FRST 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLNT
title: Advanced Pollination Biology
description: Fundamental and advanced research topics in pollination biology as they relate to natural selection, ecology, insect cognition, conservation and agriculture. Credit will be granted for only one of PLNT 506 or APBI 406. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Fundamental and advanced research topics in pollination biology as they relate to natural selection, ecology, insect cognition, conservation and agriculture. Credit will be granted for only one of PLNT 506 or APBI 406. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLNT
title: Graduate Research Seminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLNT
title: Plant Molecular Biology Laboratory
description: Techniques of purification, cloning, sequencing, restriction-hybridization analysis of plant nucleic acids, in vitro labelling of plant nucleic acids and proteins, and electrophoresis and immunodetection of plant proteins. Offered by the Biotechnology Teaching Laboratory in cooperation with Plant Science. Admissions to the course is limited and requires recommendation from the Program Coordinator. Recommended: BIOL 335. Equivalency: BOTA544, FRST503 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLNT
title: Wine Grape and Berry Biology
description: Credit will be granted for only one of PLNT 542, APBI 442 or APBI 443. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Credit will be granted for only one of PLNT 542, APBI 442 or APBI 443. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLNT
title: Indigenous Ecologies
description: Application of Indigenous worldviews and knowledges to ecology. Colonial history of modern ecology, foundations and examples of Indigenous ecologies, restoration applying multiple worldviews, and Indigenized, culturally appropriate ecological research and decision-making processes. Credit will only be granted for only one of APBI 475, FRST 475, PLNT 575 or FRST 575. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PLNT
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: POLI
title: Introduction to Politics
description: Political issues and case studies, drawn from Canadian and international contexts, will be used to introduce students to central debates and concepts of politics and political analysis.

subject: POLI
title: Introduction to Canadian Politics
description: Canadian governments, politics, and public policy. How policies emerge from politics contested through the interaction of institutions (Constitution, Parliament, federalism, elections, and the courts) and actors (individuals, parties, interest groups, nations). Insights are applied to explain current events and controversies.

subject: POLI
title: Investigating Politics: An Introduction to Scientific Political Analysis
description: The logic, challenges, and major strategies of empirical political research. Core research tasks including: asking answerable questions, defining concepts, formulating hypotheses, gathering evidence, measuring variables, constructing comparisons, drawing causal inferences, and reporting findings.

subject: POLI
title: Currents of Political Thought
description: A critical introduction to some major ideologies and traditions of Western political thought that examines their philosophical origins as well as their implications for political life. Prerequisite: POLI_V 100. Or second-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: POLI_V 100. Or second-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Introduction to Global Politics
description: Examines key themes and issues in the study of political interaction between states and non-state actors, including international security, armed conflict and conflict management, global governance and international institutions, the world economy, poverty and inequality, and climate change. Prerequisite: POLI_V 100. Or second-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: POLI_V 100. Or second-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Canadian Political Parties
description: The organization and operation of party politics and the systems of party competition in Canada. The focus is on national-level politics. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Federalism in Canada
description: Theory and practice of Canadian federalism, its relationship to public policy, cultural pluralism, social stresses, and role of the courts.​ Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: British Columbia Government and Politics
description: An examination of political history, party politics, and public policy in British Columbia.​ Prerequisite: Two of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: Two of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Canadian Political Ideas
description: Political theories and ideologies in Canada. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Local Government and Politics in Canada
description: Local and regional political institutions and public policies in Canada, with particular attention to those of Vancouver and other British Columbia localities. Prerequisite: Two of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: Two of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Quebec Government and Politics
description: The nature of politics and the conduct of government in contemporary Quebec. The course is open to students from fields other than political science. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Canadian Perspectives on Human Rights
description: Key issues in the theory and practice of human rights in Canada. Topics will vary from year to year. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: The Strategy of Politics
description: Uses game theory to show how politicians strike bargains, outmanoeuvre opponents, and manipulate institutional rules. Prerequisite: Two of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: Two of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Political Psychology
description: How psychology explains political behavior, exploring personality, cognition, emotion, and social influence in political identity, media effects, leadership, conflict, and decision-making. Prerequisite: Two of POLI_V 100, POLI_V 101, POLI_V 110, POLI_V 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: Two of POLI_V 100, POLI_V 101, POLI_V 110, POLI_V 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Threats to Contemporary Democracies
description: Domestic and international challenges to democracy, and innovative democratic responses to populism, polarization, globalization and disinformation. Prerequisite: Two of POLI_V 100, POLI_V 101, POLI_V 110, POLI_V 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: Two of POLI_V 100, POLI_V 101, POLI_V 110, POLI_V 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Japanese Government and Politics
description: Introduction to modern Japanese politics and public policy from various theoretical and comparative perspectives. Prerequisite: Two of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: Two of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 110, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Communist and Post-Communist Politics
description: An examination of the origins, development, and demise of Communist political systems, as well as the nature of post-Communist politics, with special emphasis on the Soviet Union and its successor states. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: European Politics: Selected Cases
description: The politics and government of one or more European countries: political development, institutional structure, party politics, and policy-making. The specific country or countries will vary by section. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: European Integration
description: Post-1945 integration of Europe, comparison of national politics and attitudes to integration, and the history and institutions of the European Union. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Gender and Politics
description: Relations between gender and political processes and institutions, including the impact of globalization and economic development. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Japanese Political Economy
description: Issues in contemporary Japanese political economy, including industrial policy, the Keiretsu groupings, the main-bank system, trends toward deregulation, and business-labour relations. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Korean Government and Politics
description: An introduction to the politics of Korea. The evolution of Korean politics from authoritarian rule to democratic transition, focusing on present and future political, economic and social issues. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Comparative Democratization
description: Literatures and theories on regime democratization around the world; the roles of political, economic, social, and international factors in encouraging or impeding democratization. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Associations and the State in Comparative Perspective
description: How organised groups (civil society organizations, NGOs, interest groups) interact with governments in a variety of countries. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: The U.S. Presidency in Comparative Perspective
description: Executive leadership of the U.S. presidency in comparison to the leadership of other Anglo-American systems, including the U.K., Canada, and Australia. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Modern Political Theory: Analysis of a Selected Theorist
description: A detailed examination of an acknowledged masterpiece of modern political theory. The text and attendant literature vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Theories of State and Society
description: Classical origins of contemporary theories of the state, market, and civil society, focused on the relationship between social order, politics, and democracy. Readings from Smith, Tocqueville, Weber, and contemporary sources. Prerequisite: All of POLI_V 100, POLI_V 101, POLI_V 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI_V 100, POLI_V 101, POLI_V 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Democratic Theory
description: An examination of both classical and contemporary theories of democracy. Representative democratic theory, participatory democratic theory, and their relationship to twentieth century concepts of democracy. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Political Theory and Public Policy
description: Application of frameworks to policy questions that factor in debates about citizenship and social inclusion, and an examination of contemporary normative frameworks that fall along, and transcend, the left-right political spectrum. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Environmental Politics and Policy
description: Domestic and international determinants of environmental policy; alternative approaches to environmental protection. The sustainable development paradigm; public opinion and interest group pressures; risk assessment; mandatory, voluntary and market-based policy instruments. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Public Opinion and Public Policy
description: The interaction of public opinion and public policies of climate change, inequality, poverty, and democratic institutions and values in Canada and other democracies. Prerequisite: Two of POLI_V 100, POLI_V 101, POLI_V 110, POLI_V 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: Two of POLI_V 100, POLI_V 101, POLI_V 110, POLI_V 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: The Great Powers and International Politics
description: An examination of the changing nature of Great Power relations, including procedures and institutions for managing their conflicts, in the pre-Cold War, Cold War, and post-Cold War international systems. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: International Political Economy
description: An analysis of governmental policies and international political bargaining in regard to such issues as international investment, trade, and monetary relations. Prerequisite: Two of POLI_V 100, POLI_V 101, POLI_V 110, POLI_V 240. Or third-year standing or higher.
prerequisite_raw: Two of POLI_V 100, POLI_V 101, POLI_V 110, POLI_V 240. Or third-year standing or higher.

subject: POLI
title: Topics in International Relations
