description: Restricted to students in one of MA PSYC, MSC NRSC, PhD PSYC, PhD NRSC. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PSYC
title: Advanced Research Skills in Neuroscience
description: Fundamental skills in planning, conducting, analyzing, interpreting, and presenting Neuroscience research. Restricted to students in MSc and PhD in Neuroscience, or MSc and PhD in Psychology. Credit will be granted for only one of NRSC_V 530 or PSYC_V 596. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Fundamental skills in planning, conducting, analyzing, interpreting, and presenting Neuroscience research. Restricted to students in MSc and PhD in Neuroscience, or MSc and PhD in Psychology. Credit will be granted for only one of NRSC_V 530 or PSYC_V 596. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PSYC
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: Restricted to students in PhD PSYC. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: PUNJ
title: Introductory Punjabi I
description: Spoken and written Punjabi. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 100 for credit.
exclusion_raw: Spoken and written Punjabi. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 100 for credit.

subject: PUNJ
title: Introductory Punjabi II
description: Continuation of PUNJ 100. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 101 for credit. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 100.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of PUNJ 100. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 101 for credit. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 100.

subject: PUNJ
title: Introductory Punjabi
description: Spoken and written Punjabi. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100/101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 102 for credit.

subject: PUNJ
title: Intermediate Punjabi
description: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201/202 or PUNJ 200. Recommended pre-requisites: one of PUNJ 101, PUNJ 102.

subject: PUNJ
title: Intermediate Punjabi I
description: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201 or PUNJ 200. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 101.
exclusion_raw: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201 or PUNJ 200. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 101.

subject: PUNJ
title: Intermediate Punjabi II
description: Continuation of PUNJ 201. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 202 or PUNJ 200. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 201.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of PUNJ 201. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 202 or PUNJ 200. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 201.

subject: PUNJ
title: Introduction to the Gurmukhi Script
description: The writing system of Punjabi for those with some background in the spoken language. May be taken at the same time as PUNJ 200.

subject: PUNJ
title: Advanced Punjabi
description: Advanced grammar and conversation. Major genres of Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 301/302 or PUNJ 300. Recommended pre-requisites: one of PUNJ 200, PUNJ 202.

subject: PUNJ
title: Devotional Literature in Punjabi
description: Emphasis is on reading and written expression. Analytical writing in English and Punjabi required. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.

subject: PUNJ
title: Waris Shah's Hir
description: A detailed study of Waris Shah's poetic narration of the story of Hir. Emphasis is on reading and written expression. Analytical writing in English and Punjabi required. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.

subject: PUNJ
title: Modern Punjabi Literature
description: Popular and literary works in modern Punjabi, with a focus on short stories and poetry. Emphasis on reading, writing, and vocabulary development. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.

subject: PUNJ
title: The Punjabi Novel (Advanced Punjabi)
description: Study of the modern Punjabi novel to deepen understanding and use of Punjabi, and strengthen analysis in English and Punjabi. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.

subject: PUNJ
title: Punjabi Theatre
description: Punjabi-language theatre, with emphasis on Canadian forms. Reading, writing, and performance of plays; examination of history of Punjabi theatre. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.

subject: PUNJ
title: Oral Histories in Punjabi
description: Develops students' oral expression and listening comprehension in Punjabi through Community Based Learning. Students engage in oral history collection in the Punjabi-speaking community and develop short video or sound projects. Analytical reading and writing required. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.

subject: RADI
title: Clinical Investigation or Research
description: Each resident is encouraged to complete an investigative project in each of the four years in Radiology, under the supervision of a faculty member, for possible presentation at an annual department meeting. Average 80 hours each year. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RADI
title: Clinical Nuclear Medicine
description: Daily discussions of the clinical applications of nuclear medicine. See PATH 730. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RADI
title: Progress in Nuclear Medicine
description: Weekly reviews of current literature topics in nuclear medicine. See PATH 731. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RADI
title: Clinical Investigation/Research
description: Participation in ongoing research projects within the division. See PATH 732. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RADI
title: Audit in Nuclear Medicine
description: Review of diagnostic nuclear medicine procedure, correlation with other diagnostic tests, and final patient diagnosis. Also offered as PATH 733. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RADS
title: Exploring Imaging in the Twenty-First Century
description: Interdisciplinary course that covers a wide range of topics regarding not only the scientific and technological basis of medical imaging, but also its origins and impact on society and the individual.

subject: RELG
title: Introduction to Religions in Asia
description: A survey of religious traditions of Asia, including communities, professionals, practices and beliefs of small-scale and large-scale societies. Approaches and theories drawn from the field of religious studies. Equivalency: ASIA110

subject: RELG
title: Introduction to Asian Religions
description: The religions of India, China, and Japan in their interactions and cultural contexts, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Taoism, Confucianism, and Shinto.

subject: RELG
title: Classical Islam
description: The history and culture, values, and achievements of Islamic societies from 700-1500; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.

subject: RELG
title: Modern Islam
description: The history and culture, values, and socio-political movements of the Islamic world from 1500 to the modern day; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in modern Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.

subject: RELG
title: History of Christianity II (15th C. C.E. - present)
description: The history of Christianity from the Reformation to the present day. Provides an historical overview of Christian thought and its institutions and significant people during the rise of the Reformation in various locales of Europe and beyond (Germany, France, Great Britain, Switzerland, and Scandinavia).

subject: RELG
title: Death and Afterlife in Western Religious Tradition
description: A survey of traditional attitudes toward death and beliefs regarding human existence after death in Western religions.

subject: RELG
title: Jews and Christians
description: Aspects of Jewish-Christian relations from the beginnings of Christianity to the present day. Emphasis on the study of Christian and Jewish texts in translation.

subject: RELG
title: Jewish Responses to Catastrophe
description: Topics include the destruction of the Second Temple, the Crusades, the expulsions from Spain and Portugal, and the Holocaust. A study of texts in translation.

subject: RELG
title: Jewish Literature in Translation
description: A survey of Jewish literature in medieval and modern times.

subject: RELG
title: Jews and Judaism in Canada
description: The history of the Jewish community in Canada, from New France to the present. Emphasis on the relationship between immigration and religious transformation, Jewish-Christian relations, the development of community structures.

subject: RELG
title: History of Christian Thought
description: Selected topics with special emphasis on doctrinal change and development, orthodoxy and heresy, tradition and authority, and Church and State in the Patristic, Medieval, Reformation, and Modern periods.

subject: RELG
title: Christianity in the Modern World
description: The interaction between Christianity and the major intellectual, social, and cultural developments since 1648 with special attention to the expansion of Christianity and its encounter with urban industrial society.

subject: RELG
title: Medieval Philosophy
description: Survey of Western European thought from Augustine to the fourteenth century. Possible topics and authors include: Augustine; Abelard; the influence of Islam; the rediscovery of Aristotle; Aquinas; Scotus; Ockham. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 328 or PHIL 313. Equivalency: PHIL 313
exclusion_raw: Survey of Western European thought from Augustine to the fourteenth century. Possible topics and authors include: Augustine; Abelard; the influence of Islam; the rediscovery of Aristotle; Aquinas; Scotus; Ockham. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 328 or PHIL 313. Equivalency: PHIL 313

subject: RELG
title: Medieval Jewish History
description: The political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the time of the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the expulsion of professing Jews from Spain and Portugal at the end of the fifteenth century.

subject: RELG
title: Modern Jewish History
description: The political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the beginning of the sixteenth century to the present, with special emphasis on changing attitudes to Jews and Judaism, and social and cultural transformations.

subject: RELG
title: Daoist (Taoist) Religion and Its Philosophical Background
description: A study of the Daoist religious traditions from their beginnings in the second century C.E. in cultural, intellectual and social contexts. Equivalency: ASIA381

subject: RELG
title: Buddhism in China
description: History, thought and practices of Chinese Buddhism from its beginnings until the twentieth century. Equivalency: ASIA382

subject: RELG
title: Concepts and Methods in the Study of Religion
description: Required of Major and Honours students in their third year. Open to others by permission of the instructor.

subject: RELG
title: Mystical Traditions: Jewish and Christian
description: Methodology, textual study and scholarly analysis of selected texts from these traditions.

subject: RELG
title: Topics in Medieval Judaism
description: The work of Maimonides and other Jewish philosophers, early developments in Jewish mysticism, the Jews as a minority culture in Islamic and Christian lands.

subject: RELG
title: Topics in Modern Judaism
description: The Jews in the ghetto culture, Hasidism, the Emancipation, Reform, Orthodox, and Conservative Movements.

subject: RELG
title: Seminar in the History of the Religion of Islam
description: A topic relevant to the study of Islam as a religion: e.g., the text and doctrines of the Qur'an; the Hadith (or Traditions) of the Prophet; Islamic Law; mysticism in Islam; the Shi'ah and the Isma'ilis. Not offered every year. Consult the departmental brochure for the topic to be offered.

subject: RELG
title: Readings in Hindu Religious Texts
description: Representative texts, in translation, of the Vedic, Epic, Puranic, Classical, Medieval, and Modern periods. Emphasis in the second term on texts of particular periods, movements, or sects, depending on the students' needs and interests. Those with the necessary preparation may read some texts in the original languages. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RELG
title: Images of Eve
description: The story of Adam and Eve, and its influence on the role and image of women in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

subject: RELG
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Development of Environmental Thought
description: History and philosophy of Western environmental thought; changes in concepts of human nature and external nature over time; critiques of modern industrial society. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Master's Seminar on Resources and Environment
description: Environment and resource management goals and issues. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Survey Design in Interdisciplinary Environmental Social Science
description: Survey design focusing on stated and revealed environmental preferences, choices, behaviour and values. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Qualitative Methods in Interdisciplinary Contexts
description: Research design, data quality, analysis, representation, ethics review, structured and unstructured interviews, field observations, survey design. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Human Dimensions of Conservation
description: History of wilderness and protected areas; ecological dynamics underpinning biodiversity; evaluating the success of protected areas and ecological dynamics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Human Technological Systems
description: Critical analysis of harms and benefits, and anticipation of global technological innovations, as they interact with social behaviour. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Ecosystem Services
description: Fostering sustainable management of ecosystem-based activities, for the competing and complementary ends of sustaining and enhancing human well-being and protecting biodiversity. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Advanced Conservation Science
description: Equivalency: ZOOL 509 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Social Ecological Systems
description: Dynamics of environmental issues across temporal and spatial scales using disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches to integrating sociological, cultural, and ecological perspectives. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Climate Change: Science, Technology and Sustainable Development
description: Interdisciplinary science of climate change and its impacts; options for mitigation and adaptation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Knowledge, Policy and Values in Risk and Resource Management
description: The course focuses on the role of values, science and validity of alternate knowledge systems. Included in the dialogue are the democratization of science, uncertainty, adaptive scientific practices and the values that govern management programs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Integrated Assessment
description: Basic skills for quantitative analysis including probability, validity of quantitative statements and experimental design to test hypothesis validity. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Environmental Policy Analysis
description: Determination of risks and values in environmental policy decisions. Equivalency: PLAN599 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Doctoral Seminar on Resources and Environment
description: Environment and resource management goals and issues. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RES
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RGST
title: Introduction to Religions: Judaism, Christianity, Islam
description: An overview of the foundational texts, histories, and contemporary expressions of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Key concepts and approaches used in the study of religion. Credit will be granted for only one of RGST_V 160, AMNE_V 160, or RELG_V 101. Equivalency: AMNE_V 160
exclusion_raw: An overview of the foundational texts, histories, and contemporary expressions of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Key concepts and approaches used in the study of religion. Credit will be granted for only one of RGST_V 160, AMNE_V 160, or RELG_V 101. Equivalency: AMNE_V 160

subject: RGST
title: Introduction to the Study of Religion
description: Study of religion through a comparative, cross-cultural, and interdisciplinary approach to humans' engagement with the sacred. Examines religions as complex systems that share certain fundamental common features.

subject: RGST
title: Theory and Method in the Study of Religion
description: Theories and methods for the critical study of religion as believed and practiced in different times and places. Explores methodologies for studying dimensions of religion such as space, bodily practices, cognition, and material culture.

subject: RGST
title: The Science of Religion
description: Explaining religious belief and practice using approaches and methodologies from evolutionary and cognitive science. Topics include gene-culture coevolution, ritual and supernatural belief, religion in groups, and digital humanities techniques.

subject: RGST
title: Advanced Seminar in the Study of Religion
description: Seminar focused on a special theme in the interdisciplinary study of religion (e.g., religious violence, religion and the secular, religious space). Analysis of the theme's contemporary manifestations and implications, through discussion of recent scholarship, both theoretical and case studies.

subject: RGST
title: Religion in Canada
description: An examination of Canadian religious development with special reference to the separation of church and state, the rise of denominationalism and religious pluralism, secularization and ecumenicity, and the emergence of new religious movements.

subject: RGST
title: Women and Religion
description: A study of the roles of women in the literature of one or more religious traditions.

subject: RGST
title: Honours Thesis
description: Undergraduate thesis on a subject in the study of religion. Restricted to students admitted to the Honours Program in the Study of Religion.

subject: RHSC
title: Elements of Neuroanatomy and Neurophysiology
description: An introduction to the structure and function of the human nervous system. [2-3-0]

subject: RHSC
title: Advanced Concepts for Rehabilitation Research
description: Issues relevant to clinical investigations in rehabilitation. Emphasis on research design, measurement issues, selection of analytical approaches, and relevant epidemiological concepts. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Evidence for Practice
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Rehabilitation Theory
description: The history, evolution and analysis of conceptual systems underlying practice in occupational therapy and physical therapy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Reasoning and Decision-Making
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Measurement for Assessment, Planning, and Evaluation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Developing Effective Rehabilitation Programs
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Cross-Cultural Issues in Rehabilitation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Facilitating Learning in Rehabilitation Contexts
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Disability: Social, Economic and Political Influence
description: Interrelationships between disability and the social, economic and political environment, with emphasis on factors shaping experiences of health and illness. The social consequences of disability in the context of family, community and workplace. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Directed Studies in Pathology in Rehabilitation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Neuroimaging: Basic Concepts and Applications to Research and Practice
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Physical Activity in Health and Chronic Conditions
description: Epidemiology, measurement, physiology, and adoption of physical activity in the prevention and treatment of chronic conditions. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Biomechanics in Musculoskeletal Rehabilitation
description: Biomechanical analysis of human movement as it pertains to musculoskeletal disorders. Hands-on human movement assessment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Society and Human Occupation
description: Explores society's influence on human occupation, conceptualized as all activities people do based on need, obligation, or preference. As the core construct of the discipline of occupational science and practice of occupational therapy, human occupation is examined for its impact across social, ethical and productive aspects of society. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Neurotrauma - from Basic to Community Research
description: Basic, clinical, and rehabilitation research. Challenges with translational approaches and clinical issues facing people living with spinal cord and traumatic brain injury as they transition into the community. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Neurorehabilitation
description: Therapeutic approaches and strategies in physical and occupational therapy for persons with motor control problems resulting from central nervous system dysfunction. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Rehabilitation Technology: Theory and Practice
description: Explores different technology models, and theories and approaches to assistive and rehabilitation technology design and development. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Research Proposal
description: Development, appraisal and formatting of a research proposal. Emphasis on research writing and critical analysis of a variety of research proposal formats. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Randomized Intervention Trials in Rehabilitation
description: Co-requisite: RHSC 500 or equivalent graduate or senior undergraduate course (300-400 level) on general quantitative and qualitative research methods. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: M.Sc. Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Directed Studies
description: Prerequisite: RHSC 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: RHSC 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Major Project, Part I
description: Prerequisite: Permission of the project coordinator is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Permission of the project coordinator is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Leadership in Rehabilitation
description: Leadership approaches, styles and research evidence applied to clinical rehabilitation contexts; Role and critique of emotional intelligence in effective personal leadership practices. Prerequisite: RHSC 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: RHSC 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RHSC
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RMST
title: Introduction to Romance Cultures
description: Explore the diverse cultures of France, Spain, Italy, Latin America and the Romance-speaking world from a comparative perspective.

subject: RMST
title: Made in Italy
description: Where do Italy's glamour, lifestyle, traditions come from? This course introduces Italy's multifaceted ways of being and the cultural creations of the peninsula in their context. Credit can only be applied for one of ITAL_V 110, ITST_V 110, or RMST_V 140. Equivalency: ITAL_V 110 or ITST_V 110.

subject: RMST
title: Introduction to Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World I: Medieval to Early Modern
description: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Romance World as its different national identities emerged in the Mediterranean sphere.

subject: RMST
title: Introduction to Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World II: Modern to Post-Modern
description: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Romance World in the age of the nation state, imperialism, colonization, and decolonization.

subject: RMST
title: Paris
description: A cultural history of Paris surveyed through selected works of literature, cinema and art.

subject: RMST
title: Introduction to Italian Culture I: From the Middle Ages to the Early Modern Period
description: The shift from the Medieval to the Early Modern worldview, explored through some of the major representatives of the verbal and visual arts, from Dante to Machiavelli, from Giotto to Leonardo. Credit can only be applied for one of ITAL_V 231, ITST_V 231 or RMST_V 241. Equivalency: ITAL_V 231 or ITST_V 231.

subject: RMST
title: Introduction to Italian Culture II: From the Modern to the Post-Colonial Age
description: The debate around nation vs. empire vs. republic, from the Napoleonic age to our days, as captured in Italy's microcosm, condensing and often anticipating issues that have later become global. Credit can only be applied for one of ITAL_V 232, ITST_V 232 or RMST_V 242. Equivalency: ITAL_V 232 or ITST_V 232.

subject: RMST
title: Introduction to Italian Cinema
description: A thematic course surveying major classics of Italian cinema, emphasizing their historical, political, social, philosophical and technical contexts. Credit can only be applied for one of ITAL_V 234, ITST_V 234 or RMST_V 250. Equivalency: ITAL_V 234 or ITST_V 234.

subject: RMST
title: Introduction to the Analysis of Portuguese and Brazilian Cultures
description: Critical analysis of different cultural genres, including music, film and visual art through the study of selected Portuguese and Brazilian texts. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 222 or RMST 260. Equivalency: PORT 222.
exclusion_raw: Critical analysis of different cultural genres, including music, film and visual art through the study of selected Portuguese and Brazilian texts. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 222 or RMST 260. Equivalency: PORT 222.

subject: RMST
title: Introduction to Hispanic Cultures
description: Cultural texts from Latin America and Spain. Examines their broad cultural and transnational impact on the Romance-speaking world of past and present.

subject: RMST
title: Revolution!
description: Concepts, theories, and practice of protest, revolt, and revolution in the Hispanic world, highlighting the intersection of politics and culture through novels, poetry, letters, diaries, and/or historical accounts of specific revolutionary uprisings. Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN_V 280 or RMST _V 280. Equivalency: SPAN_V 280.
exclusion_raw: Concepts, theories, and practice of protest, revolt, and revolution in the Hispanic world, highlighting the intersection of politics and culture through novels, poetry, letters, diaries, and/or historical accounts of specific revolutionary uprisings. Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN_V 280 or RMST _V 280. Equivalency: SPAN_V 280.

subject: RMST
title: History of the Romance Languages
description: Development of the Romance language family from its origins in Latin to contemporary varieties. Emphasis on French, Italian, Portuguese and Spanish. Prerequisite: A beginners' knowledge (A1) in at least of one of the Romance languages is highly recommended.
prerequisite_raw: A beginners' knowledge (A1) in at least of one of the Romance languages is highly recommended.

subject: RMST
title: Prose Fiction and Non-Fiction of the Romance World
description: Fiction and non-fiction of the Romance-speaking world from the Middle Ages to the present day from a comparative perspective.

subject: RMST
title: Theatre and Poetry of the Romance World
description: Theatre and poetry of the Romance-speaking world from the Middle Ages to the present day from a comparative perspective.

subject: RMST
title: Short Fiction in Romance Literatures
description: A study of the genres of the novella and the short story within and across Romance cultures.

subject: RMST
title: Afterlife of the Text: Rewritings and Adaptations
description: How stories travel across media and across national and linguistic boundaries in the Romance-speaking world. Dialogue between different versions and inter-media translations. Questions of authorship and reception.

subject: RMST
title: Introduction to Romance Language Cinema
description: Overview of the history, aesthetics and characteristics of films in French, Italian, Spanish, and/or Portuguese. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 234 or RMST 305. Equivalency: RMST 234.
exclusion_raw: Overview of the history, aesthetics and characteristics of films in French, Italian, Spanish, and/or Portuguese. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 234 or RMST 305. Equivalency: RMST 234.

subject: RMST
title: Language Contact and Multilingualism in the Romance-speaking World
description: A sociolinguistic examination of diverse multilingual contexts that characterise the Romance-speaking world.

subject: RMST
title: Myths, Legends and Tales in Romance Literatures and Cultures
description: Study of foundational narratives shared by Romance literatures and cultures from a comparative perspective.

subject: RMST
title: French Literature from the Middle Ages to the Revolution
description: French literature through reading and analysis of translated works. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST_V 321 or MDVL_V 301. Equivalency: MDVL_V 301.
exclusion_raw: French literature through reading and analysis of translated works. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST_V 321 or MDVL_V 301. Equivalency: MDVL_V 301.

subject: RMST
title: French Literature since the Revolution
description: French literature through reading and analysis of translated works.

subject: RMST
title: The French Enlightenment
description: A study of the cultural and intellectual dimensions of the Enlightenment period in France.

subject: RMST
title: Quebecois Literature and Culture
description: Study of the historical, political and cultural contexts that influenced the development of literature and culture in Quebec. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 324 or FREN 280.
exclusion_raw: Study of the historical, political and cultural contexts that influenced the development of literature and culture in Quebec. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 324 or FREN 280.

subject: RMST
title: French Cultural Identities
description: Aspects of French culture through a set of key concepts that weave across French history, politics, and social structures. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 325 or FREN 380.
exclusion_raw: Aspects of French culture through a set of key concepts that weave across French history, politics, and social structures. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 325 or FREN 380.

subject: RMST
title: Francophone Indigenous Literatures in Dialogue
description: Comparative studies of literature and visual culture from British Columbia and Quebec.

subject: RMST
title: Italian Food Cultures
description: Analyses of Italian or Italian-style foodways and the role they play in articulating larger cultural issues. Credit can only be applied for one of ITAL_V 380, ITST_V 380, or RMST_V 340. Equivalency: ITAL_V 380 or ITST_V 380.

subject: RMST
title: Italian Literature and Culture of the Medieval and Early Modern Period
description: A thematic approach to Italian literary works from the origins to the end of the sixteenth century considered in a broad cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL _V 303 or RMST _V 341. Equivalency: ITAL_V 303
exclusion_raw: A thematic approach to Italian literary works from the origins to the end of the sixteenth century considered in a broad cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL _V 303 or RMST _V 341. Equivalency: ITAL_V 303

subject: RMST
title: Italian Literature and Culture of the Modern and Contemporary Age
description: The development of modern and contemporary Italian literature and culture against the background of social and historical events. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL_V 304 or RMST_V 342. Equivalency: ITAL_V 304.
exclusion_raw: The development of modern and contemporary Italian literature and culture against the background of social and historical events. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL_V 304 or RMST_V 342. Equivalency: ITAL_V 304.

subject: RMST
title: Masterpieces of the Novella in Italian Literature
description: A study of the genre of the novella as an expression of social and political contexts within and across cultures from its inception in feudal times to the post-modern age. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL_V 333, ITST_V 333 or RMST_V 343. Equivalency: ITST_V 333 or ITAL_V 333
exclusion_raw: A study of the genre of the novella as an expression of social and political contexts within and across cultures from its inception in feudal times to the post-modern age. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL_V 333, ITST_V 333 or RMST_V 343. Equivalency: ITST_V 333 or ITAL_V 333

subject: RMST
title: Cultural Exchange between Modern Italy and China
description: Key moments and texts about intercultural exchange between Italy and China since the beginning of the twentieth century in their social, historical, and political contexts. Credit can only be applied for one of ITAL_V 377, ITST_V 377 or RMST_V 344. Equivalency: ITAL_V 377 or ITST_V 377.

subject: RMST
title: Italian Fascism in Interdisciplinary Perspective
description: The cultural, literary, philosophical roots of Fascism and its evolution: its policies in literature, sports, cinema, architecture, racial legislation, and colonial adventures. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL_V 345, ITST_V 345 or RMST_V 345. Equivalency: ITAL_V 345, ITST_V 345
exclusion_raw: The cultural, literary, philosophical roots of Fascism and its evolution: its policies in literature, sports, cinema, architecture, racial legislation, and colonial adventures. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL_V 345, ITST_V 345 or RMST_V 345. Equivalency: ITAL_V 345, ITST_V 345

subject: RMST
title: Colonial and Postcolonial Italy
description: Italian colonialism in the twentieth century and postcolonial legacy in recent decades through media, literary, and cinematic texts. Credit can only be applied for one of ITAL_V 378, ITST_V 378 or RMST_V 346. Equivalency: ITAL_V 378 or ITST_V 378

subject: RMST
title: Gender and Sexuality in Italian Cinema
description: Gender and sexuality in Italian cinema within the country's historical, sociopolitical, and cultural milieus. Credit can only be applied for one of ITAL_V 379, ITST_V 379 or RMST_V 347. Equivalency: ITAL_V 379 or ITST_V 379.

subject: RMST
title: Italian Cinema: Neorealism
description: A survey of the major classics of post-WWII Italian Neorealism in cinema emphasizing their historical, political, social, philosophical and technical contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL _V 385, ITST _V 385, or RMST _V 355. Equivalency: ITAL _V 385 or ITST _V 385
exclusion_raw: A survey of the major classics of post-WWII Italian Neorealism in cinema emphasizing their historical, political, social, philosophical and technical contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL _V 385, ITST _V 385, or RMST _V 355. Equivalency: ITAL _V 385 or ITST _V 385

subject: RMST
title: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Literature
description: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT_V 392 or RMST_V 361. Equivalency: PORT_V 392.
exclusion_raw: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT_V 392 or RMST_V 361. Equivalency: PORT_V 392.

subject: RMST
title: The Brazilian Amazon
description: Examines the complexity and diversity of the Brazilian Amazon, engaging in a variety of topics of interdisciplinary nature, with focus on the peoples, literatures and cultures of this region, and through the use of various genres.

subject: RMST
title: Brazilian and Portuguese Cultures
description: Examines materials from a variety of cultural genres, including Lusophone cultural manifestations such as fado, futebol, samba, cuisine, telenovelas and more.

subject: RMST
title: The Global Renaissance: Hispanic Cross-Cultural Contacts
description: Early modern (ca. 1400-1700) literature and culture. Exploration of Spain's Mediterranean, Transatlantic and Transpacific cross-cultural contacts.

subject: RMST
title: Hopscotch: Topics in Hispanic Literature
description: Spain and Latin America's contributions to global culture through popular Hispanic literature in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN _V 312 or RMST _V 372. Equivalency: SPAN_V 312.
exclusion_raw: Spain and Latin America's contributions to global culture through popular Hispanic literature in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN _V 312 or RMST _V 372. Equivalency: SPAN_V 312.

subject: RMST
title: Masterpieces in Hispanic Literature
description: Literary texts from Spain and the Hispanic world. Examines their broad cultural and transnational impact on the Romance-speaking world of yesterday and today. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RMST
title: Mapping Gendered Spaces in Hispanic Literature and Culture
description: Examines selected topics in gender and sexuality in diverse time periods, geographical contexts, and literary genres in Spain and Latin America.

subject: RMST
title: The Caribbean: Frontiers of the Romance World
description: Literature and culture from the island of Hispaniola (Haiti, Dominican Republic) and the French Caribbean from a comparative perspective.

subject: RMST
title: Genre Adaptations in the Hispanic World
description: Examines adaptations of works from the Hispanic World into various literary and cultural genres (including literature to film, novel to graphic novel), considering the historical and cultural context, themes, and narrative perspectives.

subject: RMST
title: Barcelona
description: An introduction to the city of Barcelona from a cultural studies perspective including the study of its art, literature, architecture, and social practices.

subject: RMST
title: Romance Linguistics
description: Vocabulary, phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and sociolinguistics of spoken and written Romance languages. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 400 or RMST 468. Prerequisite: 2nd year standing. A beginners knowledge (CFER A1) in at least one of the Romance languages is highly recommended.
prerequisite_raw: 2nd year standing. A beginners knowledge (CFER A1) in at least one of the Romance languages is highly recommended.
exclusion_raw: Vocabulary, phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and sociolinguistics of spoken and written Romance languages. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 400 or RMST 468. Prerequisite: 2nd year standing. A beginners knowledge (CFER A1) in at least one of the Romance languages is highly recommended.

subject: RMST
title: Visions of Nature and the Environment in the Romance World
description: History, literature and philosophy of anthropization and ecology in the Romance world. Recommended: Second-year standing or higher.

subject: RMST
title: Studies in Romance Languages and Literature
description: Study of a literary or cultural topic that extends beyond just one of the Romance Languages. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Recommended: Second-year standing or higher.

subject: RMST
title: Italian Cinema and Its Cultural Background
description: Films with English subtitles. Course content will vary. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 452, ITST _V 432 or ITAL _V 430. Equivalency: ITAL_V 430 or ITST_V 432.
exclusion_raw: Films with English subtitles. Course content will vary. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 452, ITST _V 432 or ITAL _V 430. Equivalency: ITAL_V 430 or ITST_V 432.

subject: RMST
title: Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy
description: A close reading of Dante's masterpiece, along with excerpts from some of his other works: Vita Nuova, Convivio, Monarchia, Epistles. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 453, ITST _V 413 or ITAL _V 403. Equivalency: ITST _V 413 or ITAL _V 403.
exclusion_raw: A close reading of Dante's masterpiece, along with excerpts from some of his other works: Vita Nuova, Convivio, Monarchia, Epistles. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 453, ITST _V 413 or ITAL _V 403. Equivalency: ITST _V 413 or ITAL _V 403.

subject: RMST
title: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Middle Ages
description: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 454, ITST _V 414 or ITAL _V 404. Equivalency: ITST _V 414 or ITAL _V 404.
exclusion_raw: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 454, ITST _V 414 or ITAL _V 404. Equivalency: ITST _V 414 or ITAL _V 404.

subject: RMST
title: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Renaissance
description: Masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance in literature and the other arts. Authors and artists studied range from Pico to Ariosto and Machiavelli, from Botticelli to Leonardo and Michelangelo. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 455, ITST _V 415 or ITAL _V 405. Equivalency: ITAL _V 405 or ITST _V 415
exclusion_raw: Masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance in literature and the other arts. Authors and artists studied range from Pico to Ariosto and Machiavelli, from Botticelli to Leonardo and Michelangelo. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 455, ITST _V 415 or ITAL _V 405. Equivalency: ITAL _V 405 or ITST _V 415

subject: RMST
title: Classics of Seventeenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
description: Classics of the Italian literature of the Mannerist and Baroque age in their intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST _V 416 or ITAL _V 406 or RMST _V 456. Equivalency: ITST _V 416 or ITAL _V 406
exclusion_raw: Classics of the Italian literature of the Mannerist and Baroque age in their intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST _V 416 or ITAL _V 406 or RMST _V 456. Equivalency: ITST _V 416 or ITAL _V 406

subject: RMST
title: Classics of Eighteenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
description: Classics of the Italian literature of the age of the Enlightenment in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST _V 417 or ITAL _V 407 or RMST _V 457. Equivalency: ITST _V 417 or ITAL _V 407
exclusion_raw: Classics of the Italian literature of the age of the Enlightenment in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST _V 417 or ITAL _V 407 or RMST _V 457. Equivalency: ITST _V 417 or ITAL _V 407

subject: RMST
title: Topics in Nineteenth-century Italian Literature and Culture
description: Italian literature of the 19th century in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST _V 418 or ITAL _V 408 or RMST _V 458. Equivalency: ITST _V 418 or ITAL _V 408
exclusion_raw: Italian literature of the 19th century in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST _V 418 or ITAL _V 408 or RMST _V 458. Equivalency: ITST _V 418 or ITAL _V 408

subject: RMST
title: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Italian Literature and Culture
description: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 459, ITST _V 419 or ITAL_V 409. Recommended pre-requisite: Second-year standing or higher. Equivalency: ITST_V 419 or ITAL_V 409.
exclusion_raw: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 459, ITST _V 419 or ITAL_V 409. Recommended pre-requisite: Second-year standing or higher. Equivalency: ITST_V 419 or ITAL_V 409.

subject: RMST
title: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Culture
description: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT_V 405 or RMST_V 460. Recommended: Second-year standing or higher. Equivalency: PORT_V 405.
exclusion_raw: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT_V 405 or RMST_V 460. Recommended: Second-year standing or higher. Equivalency: PORT_V 405.

title: Research Intensive Seminar in Romance Studies

title: Honours Essay

subject: RMST
title: Studies in Romance Languages and Cultures
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: RUSS
title: Learning Russian 1
description: Introduction to the language for beginners. Ability to enjoy communicating in everyday situations and cultural contexts. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 101 or RUSS _V 100.
exclusion_raw: Introduction to the language for beginners. Ability to enjoy communicating in everyday situations and cultural contexts. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 101 or RUSS _V 100.

title: Learning Russian 2
description: Continuation of RUSS _V 101. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 102 or RUSS _V 100.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of RUSS _V 101. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 102 or RUSS _V 100.
