title: Learning Russian 3
description: Continuation of RUSS_V 102. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 201 or RUSS _V 200.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of RUSS_V 102. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 201 or RUSS _V 200.

subject: RUSS
title: Learning Russian 4
description: Continuation of RUSS_V 201. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 202 or RUSS_V 200.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of RUSS_V 201. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 202 or RUSS_V 200.

subject: RUSS
title: Russian Conversation Practice 1
description: Emphasis on the study of oral communication skills and strategies. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 208 or RUSS_V 215. Equivalency: RUSS_V 215.
exclusion_raw: Emphasis on the study of oral communication skills and strategies. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 208 or RUSS_V 215. Equivalency: RUSS_V 215.

subject: RUSS
title: Learning Russian 5
description: Continuation of RUSS_V 202. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 301 or RUSS_V 300.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of RUSS_V 202. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 301 or RUSS_V 300.

subject: RUSS
title: Learning Russian 6
description: Continuation of RUSS_V 301. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 302 or RUSS_V 300.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of RUSS_V 301. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 302 or RUSS_V 300.

subject: RUSS
title: Readings in Russophone Texts
description: Texts are selected from 19th-, 20th-, and 21stcentury sources. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 304 or RUSS_V 305. Equivalency: RUSS_V 305.
exclusion_raw: Texts are selected from 19th-, 20th-, and 21stcentury sources. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 304 or RUSS_V 305. Equivalency: RUSS_V 305.

subject: RUSS
title: Russian through Film
description: Conversation and composition using Russian film. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 307 or RUSS_V 316. Equivalency: RUSS_V 316.
exclusion_raw: Conversation and composition using Russian film. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 307 or RUSS_V 316. Equivalency: RUSS_V 316.

subject: RUSS
title: Russian Conversation Practice 2
description: Continuation of RUSS_V 208. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 308 or RUSS_V 315. Equivalency: RUSS_V 315.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of RUSS_V 208. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 308 or RUSS_V 315. Equivalency: RUSS_V 315.

subject: RUSS
title: Learning Russian through Critical Contemporary Topics
description: Discussion and analysis of current issues in a Russian-speaking seminar format. Spoken and written communication about societal topics fostering advance competence. Continuation of RUSS_V 302. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 401 or RUSS_V 400.
exclusion_raw: Discussion and analysis of current issues in a Russian-speaking seminar format. Spoken and written communication about societal topics fostering advance competence. Continuation of RUSS_V 302. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 401 or RUSS_V 400.

subject: SANS
title: Introductory Sanskrit
description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 300 or SANS 102 or both SANS 100, SANS 101 or both SANS 301, SANS 302.
exclusion_raw: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 300 or SANS 102 or both SANS 100, SANS 101 or both SANS 301, SANS 302.

subject: SANS
title: Introductory Sanskrit I
description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. No prior proficiency in Sanskrit required. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 301 or SANS 100 or SANS 300.
exclusion_raw: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. No prior proficiency in Sanskrit required. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 301 or SANS 100 or SANS 300.

subject: SANS
title: Introductory Sanskrit II
description: Continuation of SANS 301. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 302 or SANS 101 or SANS 300. Recommended pre-requisite: SANS 301.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of SANS 301. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 302 or SANS 101 or SANS 300. Recommended pre-requisite: SANS 301.

subject: SANS
title: Intermediate Sanskrit
description: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 400 or SANS 200 or both SANS 201, SANS 202 or both SANS 401, SANS 402. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SANS 300, SANS 302.
exclusion_raw: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 400 or SANS 200 or both SANS 201, SANS 202 or both SANS 401, SANS 402. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SANS 300, SANS 302.

subject: SANS
title: Intermediate Sanskrit I
description: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 401 or SANS 201 or SANS 400. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SANS 300, SANS 302.
exclusion_raw: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 401 or SANS 201 or SANS 400. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SANS 300, SANS 302.

subject: SANS
title: Intermediate Sanskrit II
description: Continuation of SANS 401. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 402 or SANS 202 or SANS 400. Recommended pre-requisite: SANS 401.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of SANS 401. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 402 or SANS 202 or SANS 400. Recommended pre-requisite: SANS 401.

subject: SCIE
title: Science One
description: An innovative first-year multi-disciplinary course incorporating biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics with a strong focus on the connections between these traditional disciplines. Students with credit for SCIE_V 001 will be deemed to have satisfied all BIOL_V 112, BIOL_V 121, BIOL_V 180, CHEM_V 121, CHEM_V 123, MATH_V 100, MATH_V 101, PHYS_V 117, PHYS_V 118, PHYS_V119, and PHYS_V 129 requirements. See the Science One website ( www.scienceone.ubc.ca )for further information and the application process for admission to SCIE_V 001. [12-6-4;12-6-4] Prerequisite: All of: CALC 12, ENGL 12, and Pre-calculus 12; two of: CHEM 12, PHYS 12, High School Biology (either BIOL 11 or BIOL 12). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of: CALC 12, ENGL 12, and Pre-calculus 12; two of: CHEM 12, PHYS 12, High School Biology (either BIOL 11 or BIOL 12). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SCIE
title: Science One A
description: Block registration marker for the biology, chemistry, mathematics and physics components of the Science One program. Restricted to students in the Science One program. [12-6-4] Prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12; and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12. and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12; and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12. and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.

subject: SCIE
title: First-Year Focus Seminar
description: Seminar for First-Year Focus option focused on discipline-specific learning strategies for academic success and community and scholarly engagement. This course is restricted to first-year students in the First-Year Focus option. Pass/Fail [1*-0-1*] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SCIE
title: Pre-Calculus Mathematics
description: Algebra, functions and graphing, expone ntial and logarithmic functions, trigonometry. Restricted to students enrolled in the Indigenous STEM Bridging Pathway. [3-0-1] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SCIE
title: First-Year Seminar in Science
description: Small-group experience where students study science in society, scientific process, and how to communicate scientific concepts. Enrolment limited to students in the B. Sc. program in Science. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SCIE
title: Topics in Sustainability Science
description: Topics in sustainability, based on concepts introduced in first-year Science courses. [1-0-0] Corequisite: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121. Restricted to students with first-year standing in Science.
corequisite_raw: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121. Restricted to students with first-year standing in Science.

subject: SCIE
title: Communicating Science
description: Effective communication and presentation skills in science. [1-0-3] Corequisite: One of BIOL_V 300, STAT_V 200, STAT_V 241 and 3rd or 4th year standing in Combined Major in Science.
corequisite_raw: One of BIOL_V 300, STAT_V 200, STAT_V 241 and 3rd or 4th year standing in Combined Major in Science.

subject: SCIE
title: Socio-Ecological Systems Research
description: Research design and methods for socio-ecological systems research. Students work directly with faculty mentors to conduct research on contemporary topics such as climate resilience, food security, and environmental sustainability. [1.5-0-1] Prerequisite: Third-year standing and instructor's permission
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing and instructor's permission

subject: SCIE
title: Discipline-based Education Research Methodology
description: Overview of methodological approaches to education research in disciplines having natural, physical, and life-science foundations. Prerequisite: Third-year standing and permission of the instructor. Equivalency: SCIE500
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing and permission of the instructor. Equivalency: SCIE500

subject: SCIE
title: Sustainability for Community and the World
description: Explores systems thinking in the context of sustainability and also re-examines the familiar three pillar model of sustainability - society, ecology, and economics - highlighting its uses and limitations. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of ASIC 200, ASIC 220, APBI 260, APBI 265, ARCL 309, BIOL 230, CHEM 301, CHEM 302, CHEM 341, CIVL 200, CONS 330, ECON 210, ENDS 221, ENVR 200, ENVR 300, EOSC 270, EOSC 340, EOSC 345, FRST 100, GEOG 211, GEOG 310, HIST 106, ISCI 360, ISCI 361, LAW 386, LFS 250, PHYS 333, POLI 351, PSYC 321, PSYC 421, SCIE 120, SCIE 320. Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
prerequisite_raw: One of ASIC 200, ASIC 220, APBI 260, APBI 265, ARCL 309, BIOL 230, CHEM 301, CHEM 302, CHEM 341, CIVL 200, CONS 330, ECON 210, ENDS 221, ENVR 200, ENVR 300, EOSC 270, EOSC 340, EOSC 345, FRST 100, GEOG 211, GEOG 310, HIST 106, ISCI 360, ISCI 361, LAW 386, LFS 250, PHYS 333, POLI 351, PSYC 321, PSYC 421, SCIE 120, SCIE 320. Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

subject: SCIE
title: Discipline-based Education Research Methodology
description: Overview of methodological approaches to education research in disciplines having natural, physical, and life-science foundations. Equivalency: SCIE 400 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SCIE
title: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SCIE
title: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: SCIE_V 596. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SCIE_V 596. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SCIE
title: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: SCIE_V 597. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SCIE_V 597. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SCIE
title: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: SCIE_V 598. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SCIE_V 598. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SGES
title: Integration Project
description: Design, analysis, and implementation of technology to create a bench-scale smart grid energy system. Assessment of technology based on sustainability, market, policy and regulatory considerations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SGES
title: Renewable and Efficient Electric Power Systems
description: Electricity infrastructure, fundamentals of electric power, solar photovoltaic systems, wind electric conversion systems, other renewable energy systems, grid integration of renewables, smart grid, distributed energy resources, electricity storage. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SGES
title: Topics in Power and Energy
description: Current topics in smart grid systems and technologies in the context of sustainability, market, policy and regulation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SGES
title: Smart Grid Communication Systems
description: Review of probability theory, signals and noise, spectral analysis; information theory and applications; detection and estimation of signals in the presence of noise; performance calculations of modulation systems; digital communication techniques. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 531 or ELEC 431. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Review of probability theory, signals and noise, spectral analysis; information theory and applications; detection and estimation of signals in the presence of noise; performance calculations of modulation systems; digital communication techniques. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 531 or ELEC 431. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SGES
title: Power Electronic Devices
description: New devices and applications in power electronics with applications to smart grid systems. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 550 or EECE 550. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: New devices and applications in power electronics with applications to smart grid systems. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 550 or EECE 550. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SGES
title: Architecture for Learning Systems
description: Learning in neural networks, error backpropagation, simulated annealing, content addressable memories. Data representation topics. Implementation challenges in real world scale problems. Architectures for function approximation in Reinforcement Learning. Comparison with conventional artificial intelligence: history and emerging trends. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 592 or EECE 592. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Learning in neural networks, error backpropagation, simulated annealing, content addressable memories. Data representation topics. Implementation challenges in real world scale problems. Architectures for function approximation in Reinforcement Learning. Comparison with conventional artificial intelligence: history and emerging trends. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 592 or EECE 592. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SLAV
title: Introduction to Slavic and Eastern European Cultures
description: Cultural developments from the medieval period to the present. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 120 or SLAV_V 105. Equivalency: SLAV_V 105.
exclusion_raw: Cultural developments from the medieval period to the present. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 120 or SLAV_V 105. Equivalency: SLAV_V 105.

subject: SLAV
title: Introduction to Slavic Languages and Communication
description: Insights into Slavic languages in their shared and diverse cultural, social, literary, and political contexts over time. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ .

subject: SLAV
title: Nineteenth-Century Russophone Literature
description: Major works and writers in the Russian tradition of the 19th century. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 241 or RUSS_V 206. Equivalency: RUSS_V 206.
exclusion_raw: Major works and writers in the Russian tradition of the 19th century. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 241 or RUSS_V 206. Equivalency: RUSS_V 206.

subject: SLAV
title: Contemporary Russophone Literature
description: Literature written in Russian, in and beyond Russia, from the 20th and 21st century. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 207 or SLAV_V 242. Equivalency: RUSS_V 207.
exclusion_raw: Literature written in Russian, in and beyond Russia, from the 20th and 21st century. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 207 or SLAV_V 242. Equivalency: RUSS_V 207.

subject: SLAV
title: War and Peace in Slavic and Eastern European Life
description: Languages, discourses, and art forms which reflect present-day life in Slavic and Eastern European countries where violent conflicts, transformed by technologies, blur the boundaries between war and peace. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ .

subject: SLAV
title: Polish Literature and Film
description: Selected films and translated literature by Polish writers and filmmakers, with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 424 or POLS_V 424. Equivalency: POLS_V 424.
exclusion_raw: Selected films and translated literature by Polish writers and filmmakers, with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 424 or POLS_V 424. Equivalency: POLS_V 424.

subject: SLAV
title: The Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film
description: The Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 433 or POLS_V 426. Equivalency: POLS_V 426
exclusion_raw: The Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 433 or POLS_V 426. Equivalency: POLS_V 426

subject: SLAV
title: Tolstoy
description: Works, influence and critical reception of Leo Tolstoy. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 411 or SLAV_V 447. Equivalency: RUSS_V 411.
exclusion_raw: Works, influence and critical reception of Leo Tolstoy. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 411 or SLAV_V 447. Equivalency: RUSS_V 411.

subject: SLAV
title: Dostoevsky
description: Works, influence and critical reception of Fyodor Dostoevsky. Find out more at ttps://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS _V 412 or SLAV_V 448. Equivalency: RUSS_V 412
exclusion_raw: Works, influence and critical reception of Fyodor Dostoevsky. Find out more at ttps://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS _V 412 or SLAV_V 448. Equivalency: RUSS_V 412

subject: SOAL
title: Khichri: The South Asian Languages of Vancouver
description: A systematic introduction to the grammars and scripts of Hindi, Urdu, Punjabi and Sanskrit, primarily through the media of Indo-Canadian popular culture (film, radio, bhangra, etc.)

subject: SOCI
title: Introduction to Sociology
description: Introduction to problems in the analysis of social structures and processes. Basic sociological concepts will be introduced and their application demonstrated in various areas of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 100 or both SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
exclusion_raw: Introduction to problems in the analysis of social structures and processes. Basic sociological concepts will be introduced and their application demonstrated in various areas of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 100 or both SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Social Interaction and Culture
description: Culture, identity, social interaction, relationships and socialization. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 101 or SOCI 100.
exclusion_raw: Culture, identity, social interaction, relationships and socialization. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 101 or SOCI 100.

subject: SOCI
title: Inequality and Social Change
description: Inequality, institutions, social structure and social change. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 102 or SOCI 100.
exclusion_raw: Inequality, institutions, social structure and social change. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 102 or SOCI 100.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Family
description: An introduction to contemporary family forms and relations.

subject: SOCI
title: Ethnicity
description: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors.

subject: SOCI
title: Global Population Dynamics
description: Core processes that influence world population patterns and trends.

subject: SOCI
title: Canadian Social Structure
description: Descriptive and analytic survey of such features as demographic characteristics, class structure, ethnicity, and regional variation in Canadian society as a basis for understanding current social issues.

subject: SOCI
title: Research Methods
description: Introduction to research designs and methodologies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Indigenous Peoples
description: Sociological perspective of Indigenous peoples and issues both internationally and within Canada.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Personal Life
description: A sociological examination of everyday life exploring the social in the personal.

subject: SOCI
title: Shopping, Society, and Sustainability
description: Major theories of consumer society, evaluating impacts of shopping on human and non-human environments and popular solutions to these impacts.

subject: SOCI
title: Introduction to Social Interaction
description: Research on social interaction, with an emphasis on group (as opposed to individual) processes and behaviour.

subject: SOCI
title: Crime and Society
description: Crime as a social phenomenon, with emphasis on the changing definitions of crime in relation to social and political change in Canadian and other societies.

subject: SOCI
title: Work and Society
description: Social forces responsible for changing patterns of technological innovation and work organization in modern industrial societies. Emphasis on the organization of work, labour force dynamics, and technological change.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Creativity
description: The application of sociological concepts to the examination of creative processes.

subject: SOCI
title: Data and Society
description: Impacts of changing information and communication technologies on societies and social interactions.

subject: SOCI
title: Health and Society
description: An introduction to health and illness through a sociological lens. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Citizenship and Identity
description: The concepts of citizenship, identity, and human rights as social processes shaping individuals and communities (both local and global).

subject: SOCI
title: Global Pandemics
description: Global pandemics in relation to social inequality, social interaction and social institutions.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Development and Underdevelopment
description: Processes of social change in the Third World and other developing countries. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Ethnic and Racial Inequality
description: A critical examination of classical and contemporary theories and research evidence concerning ethnic and racial inequality at the societal and interpersonal levels. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Migration
description: Sociological approaches to the movement of peoples and its impact over time. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Canadian Society
description: Social organization of Canadian society: relationships between social institutions and social processes (e.g., economics, education, family, law, media, and politics); including issues of ancestry, ethnicity, gender, region, and social class. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Gender Relations
description: The nature of gender relations, their social and cultural expression, and theories of gender inequality. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Masculinity
description: How masculinity differs across social contexts and time periods. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Diversity in Family Forms
description: An examination of diversity within and between families and of diverse family forms. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of the Life Course
description: Individuals and families through the life course. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

subject: SOCI
title: Social Statistics I
description: The testing of sociological theories using quantitative data analysis techniques on numerical data from social surveys, experiments and official statistics. SOCI 328 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Credit Exclusion List ( https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… ) before registering. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Adornment
description: The application of sociological concepts to the understanding of objects that we use to adorn our bodies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI_V 100, SOCI_V 101, SOCI_V 102
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI_V 100, SOCI_V 101, SOCI_V 102

subject: SOCI
title: Consumers and Consumption
description: The structure and culture of consuming and consumption. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Aging
description: Demographic, economic, and social trends associated with aging, ageism, and aging populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 344 and SOCI 444. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: SOCI 444.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: SOCI 444.
exclusion_raw: Demographic, economic, and social trends associated with aging, ageism, and aging populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 344 and SOCI 444. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: SOCI 444.

subject: SOCI
title: Work and Inequality
description: The meaning of work and leisure, properties of work organization, the division of labour, and the relation of work and social inequality. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Community Studies
description: Study of the organization of human communities; a focus upon collective activities including family, work, neighbourhood, and formal and informal networks. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology and Natural Resources
description: Sociological perspectives on property, resource industries (such as agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining), resource development, and resource communities. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Social Inequality
description: Tendencies toward equality and inequality; manifestations of inequality (occupation, education, gender, ethnicity, income, power) and their consequences; caste and class features of major stratification systems; theories of social class; stratification profile of contemporary industrial societies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Built Environments
description: Physical, social, and economic aspects of built environments, including housing and community planning. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Sexualities
description: Historical and social construction of sexual identities, desires, communities, and politics in the twentieth century. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociological Theories: Classical and Contemporary Approaches
description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems, and current topics in the field of sociological theory. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 370 or both SOCI 371, SOCI 372. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
exclusion_raw: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems, and current topics in the field of sociological theory. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 370 or both SOCI 371, SOCI 372. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Classical Traditions in Theory
description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems and topics in the foundational theories of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 371 or SOCI 370. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
exclusion_raw: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems and topics in the foundational theories of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 371 or SOCI 370. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Contemporary Directions in Theory
description: A survey of theories in contemporary sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 372 or SOCI 370. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
exclusion_raw: A survey of theories in contemporary sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 372 or SOCI 370. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociological Methods: Survey Research
description: Questionnaire design, interviewing, sampling, and analysis of survey data. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 217.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 217.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociological Methods: Experimental Research
description: Research strategies associated with the implementation of experimental methods in sociology. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociological Methods: Qualitative Research
description: Examination of the different traditions of qualitative sociological inquiry and the associated methodological features used to study the interpretive practices and meanings in the everyday lives of individuals. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociological Methods: Historical Research
description: Methodological problems and research strategies associated with the interpretation of socio-historical data; contributions of classical and contemporary approaches to historical sociology and social history. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Health and Illness
description: Classic and contemporary sociological perspectives on health, illness, and health care. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Drugs and Society
description: Social dimensions of the causes, consequences, regulation, and treatment of substance use from Canadian and international perspectives. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Feminist Theory
description: The emergence of feminist theory, its relationship to sociology, and the major theoretical schools of thought. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Social Statistics II
description: Primary emphasis on applications of statistical techniques to data in Sociology. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 328.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 328.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of the Environment
description: Sociological approaches to the study of environmental conflicts, issues, movements, impact of changing technology, economic development on the environment. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Food
description: Cultural, economic, and political aspects of food production and consumption, including connections to class, ethnicity, and gender. Food-related social movements will be included. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Urban Sociology
description: Demographic, behavioural, and organizational aspects of urban structures and of urbanization in different societies and periods. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Global Citizenship
description: Sociology approaches to global citizenship, including its contested nature and intellectual lineage.

subject: SOCI
title: Economic Sociology
description: Analysis of economic actions and institutions using the concepts and methods of sociology. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Society, Economy and Family
description: The study of family in social and economic contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 and FMST 440. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: FMST 440
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: FMST 440
exclusion_raw: The study of family in social and economic contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 and FMST 440. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: FMST 440

subject: SOCI
title: Families and Work
description: The effect of combining family and work roles. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 442 and FMST 442. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: FMST 442.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: FMST 442.
exclusion_raw: The effect of combining family and work roles. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 442 and FMST 442. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: FMST 442.

subject: SOCI
title: Honours Tutorial
description: Requires the presentation of at least one research paper. Restricted to students in the Sociology Honours program. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Political Sociology
description: The social and economic bases of political power, including the study of the state, ideology, political movements, revolutions, and political violence. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Social Movements
description: A study of the sources, stages, and effects of social movements in developing and modernized societies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of the Arts
description: An examination of the arts as social practices from the standpoint of the relationships among artists, critics, patrons, and public; and the social institutions through which these relationships are structured. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Education
description: Examines the role of schooling in modern society including links with inequality, knowledge production, socialization and the economy. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Queer Theory and Politics
description: Empirical expressions and political possibilities of queer theory. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 369.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 369.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Crime and Justice
description: Critical examination of specific forms of crime in relation to the criminal justice system including law, enforcement, and corrections. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Mental Illness
description: A sociological approach to the meaning of mental illness; the organization of psychiatric treatment; problems in the explanation of the distribution of mental illness in a population. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Sociology of Soccer
description: Soccer and colonialism, soccer and global politics, and inequalities in soccer by gender, sexuality, race and class. Prerequisite: One of SOCI_V 100, SOCI_V 101, SOCI_V 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI_V 100, SOCI_V 101, SOCI_V 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Social Determinants of Health
description: Relationships between social phenomena (e.g., personal beliefs, lifestyle practices, social support, socio-economic status, social class, gender, and ethnicity) and the health of human populations. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Contemporary Chinese Society
description: Current social topics in Chinese society; perspectives on gender, inequality, culture, and social relations. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
prerequisite_raw: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

subject: SOCI
title: Foundations of Sociological Thought
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOCI
title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOCI
title: Research Design and Techniques (Quantitative)
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOCI
title: Research Design and Techniques (Qualitative)
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOCI
title: Methodology of Social Inquiry
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOCI
title: Cross-National Comparisons in the Social Sciences
description: Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 511 or IAR 511. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 511 or IAR 511. Equivalency: IAR 511 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 511 or IAR 511. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 511 or IAR 511. Equivalency: IAR 511 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOCI
title: Theories About the Family
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOCI
title: Analyzing Quantitative Data in Sociology
description: Prerequisite: SOCI 502 is a prerequisite for Sociology graduate students. A background in material such as that covered in SOCI 502 is highly recommended for all others. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SOCI 502 is a prerequisite for Sociology graduate students. A background in material such as that covered in SOCI 502 is highly recommended for all others. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOCI
title: Qualitative Data Analysis in Sociology
description: Prerequisite: SOCI 503. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SOCI 503. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOCI
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Graduate Seminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Advanced Soil Processes
description: Integrating the environmental factors influencing soil-forming processes and their ecological implications. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 501 or APBI 401. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Integrating the environmental factors influencing soil-forming processes and their ecological implications. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 501 or APBI 401. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Advanced Sustainable Soil Management
description: Integration of fundamental, unifying, soil science principles in sustainable ecosystem management. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 502 or APBI 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Integration of fundamental, unifying, soil science principles in sustainable ecosystem management. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 502 or APBI 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Advanced Soil Sampling, Analyses and Data Interpretation
description: Field and laboratory analytical techniques in the chemical, biological and physical assessment of soils. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 503 or APBI 403. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Field and laboratory analytical techniques in the chemical, biological and physical assessment of soils. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 503 or APBI 403. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Watershed Science
description: Watershed evaluation, key aspects of hydrology, water quality, land use impacts on water resources and integration of multiple land use activities and their cumulative impacts. Equivalency: LWS 515 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Urban Watershed Management
description: Urbanization impacts on water resources with a focus on rainwater management, water quality, point and non-point sources of pollution, drinking water and waste water, riparian buffer zones, cumulative effects, and application of beneficial management practices. Equivalency: LWS516 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Land and Water Resource Evaluation
description: Topics in land and water system evaluations and assessing resource development options; monitoring and modelling environmental systems. Equivalency: LWS 517. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Water in International Development
description: Key water issues associated with international development: global water demand, scarcity, efficiency of use, water as a commodity, biophysical and policy aspects of water management, water and health, land use impact, water harvesting, improved irrigation, and pollution prevention. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Agricultural Watershed Management
description: Intensive and extensive agriculture with a focus on water needs, water use, and impacts on water resources. Non-point sources of pollution, nutrient modelling, soil and land degradation, protection, and rehabilitation of watersheds including buffer zones, wetlands, and best management practices. Equivalency: LWS520 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Instrumentation for Biometeorology
description: The theory, design and evaluation of instrumentation for biometeorological research. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Permission of the instructor is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Master's Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOIL
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOWK
title: Introduction to Social Welfare
description: An introduction to the perspectives, concepts and theoretical foundations of social welfare, including an analysis of the institutional structures of social welfare in the modern state.

subject: SOWK
title: Introduction to Social Work Practice
description: An introduction to the knowledge, skills and values of social work practice in its many forms, emphasizing different ways of understanding the context of social and personal problems. Prerequisite: SOWK200
prerequisite_raw: SOWK200

subject: SOWK
title: Practicum I
description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail. Corequisite: SOWK 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: SOWK 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOWK
title: Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
description: Integrates students' learning from field, practice, policy and theory courses for the purposes of professional development.

subject: SOWK
title: Indigenous Peoples and Critical Social Work Analysis
description: Contemporary social issues facing Indigenous peoples and communities examined in the context of the history of Settler-Canadian/Indigenous relations; the impact of Settler-Canadian institutions upon Indigenous peoples; implications for social policy and social work practice. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 325 or 425. Enrolment is limited to students in the BSW program.
exclusion_raw: Contemporary social issues facing Indigenous peoples and communities examined in the context of the history of Settler-Canadian/Indigenous relations; the impact of Settler-Canadian institutions upon Indigenous peoples; implications for social policy and social work practice. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 325 or 425. Enrolment is limited to students in the BSW program.

subject: SOWK
title: Culture and Race in Social Work Practice
description: Issues and problems inherent in practising social work in diverse cultural settings.

subject: SOWK
title: Canadian Social Policy
description: Analysis of race, gender, class and culture as factors in the distribution and delivery of Canadian social benefits and social services.

subject: SOWK
title: Social Work Practice II
description: This course examines the principles of optimal social work process with individuals, small groups, families and larger collectivities.

subject: SOWK
title: Practicum II
description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOWK
title: Advanced Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
description: Development of professional judgement, evaluation, and self-evaluation in practice.

subject: SOWK
title: Introduction to Social Work Research
description: Theory and conduct of social research as applied to social welfare and social work practice. Development of social work research questions and design of studies. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the school. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 420 or 320. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Theory and conduct of social research as applied to social welfare and social work practice. Development of social work research questions and design of studies. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the school. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 420 or 320. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOWK
title: Social Context of Child Development
description: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 or FMST 441. Equivalency: FMST 441
exclusion_raw: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 or FMST 441. Equivalency: FMST 441

subject: SOWK
title: Policy and Practice in Child Welfare
description: Covers the statutory bases and practices associated with the continuum of child welfare services from prevention through permanency planning.

subject: SOWK
title: Social Work Practice in Community Mental Health
description: Online course providing overview of social work services to persons with a mental illness. Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in SOWK. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Fourth-year standing in SOWK. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOWK
title: Health Care Team Development
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the skills, knowledge, roles, and issues involved with working successfully in interprofessional health and human service teams. Intended for upper division students in any health and human service program. Offered as IHHS 400 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 451 or IHHS 400. Equivalency: IHHS 400.
exclusion_raw: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the skills, knowledge, roles, and issues involved with working successfully in interprofessional health and human service teams. Intended for upper division students in any health and human service program. Offered as IHHS 400 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 451 or IHHS 400. Equivalency: IHHS 400.

subject: SOWK
title: HIV Prevention and Care
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course prepares senior students to respond effectively to the HIV epidemic and its consequences. The knowledge and skills required for interprofessional and discipline-specific work are explored. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Offered as IHHS 402 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 452 or IHHS 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course prepares senior students to respond effectively to the HIV epidemic and its consequences. The knowledge and skills required for interprofessional and discipline-specific work are explored. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Offered as IHHS 402 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 452 or IHHS 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOWK
title: Disability and Justice
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course considers how health and human service professionals can effectively practice with people with disabilities from a social justice perspective. Social and personal context and practice responses are examined. Offered as IHHS 407 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 453 or IHHS 407.
exclusion_raw: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course considers how health and human service professionals can effectively practice with people with disabilities from a social justice perspective. Social and personal context and practice responses are examined. Offered as IHHS 407 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 453 or IHHS 407.

subject: SOWK
title: Interdisciplinary Practice with Children and Families
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers interprofessional perspectives, challenges, and strategies. Clinical experience and some knowledge of child protection issues required. Offered as IHHS 403 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 454 or IHHS 403.
exclusion_raw: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers interprofessional perspectives, challenges, and strategies. Clinical experience and some knowledge of child protection issues required. Offered as IHHS 403 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 454 or IHHS 403.

subject: SOWK
title: Palliative Care
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers attitudes, knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary for interprofessional and discipline-specific work in palliative care. For students registered in health and human service programs only. Offered as IHHS 405 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 455 or IHHS 405.
exclusion_raw: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers attitudes, knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary for interprofessional and discipline-specific work in palliative care. For students registered in health and human service programs only. Offered as IHHS 405 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 455 or IHHS 405.

subject: SOWK

description: Critical examination of research, teaching, proposal writing and publication. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SOWK
title: Social Theory, Ideology and Ethics
description: Critical analysis of major social theories, differentiating competing approaches to understanding human behaviour; social theory, social ideology, and social ethics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
