subject: SPAN
title: Beginners' Spanish I
description: Fundamentals of the Spanish language. Communicate with basic vocabulary in common tasks and situations related to present and future events. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives. Credit will be granted for either SPAN 103 or both SPAN 101, SPAN 102.

subject: SPAN
title: Beginners' Spanish II
description: Continuation of foundational elements of the language. Communicate using essential vocabulary in common tasks and situations related to past, present and future events. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives. Credit will be granted for either SPAN 103 or both SPAN 101, SPAN 102. Recommended pre-requisite: SPAN 101.

subject: SPAN
title: Intensive Beginners' Spanish
description: Fundamentals of the Spanish language. Ideal for students with Spanish 12 or expertise in another Romance language. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives. Credit will be granted for SPAN 103 or both SPAN 101, SPAN 102. Prerequisite: Grade 12 Spanish or for native or near-native speakers of other Romance Languages.
prerequisite_raw: Grade 12 Spanish or for native or near-native speakers of other Romance Languages.

subject: SPAN
title: Elementary Spanish I
description: Expansion of fundamentals. Enhanced ability to exchange information, discuss the past and future, and express wishes, hopes and feelings in common personal and social contexts. Aligned with CEFR level A1-A2 objectives. Credit will be granted for either SPAN 203 or both SPAN 201, SPAN 202. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SPAN 102, SPAN 103, SPAN 11.

subject: SPAN
title: Elementary Spanish II
description: Expansion of fundamental notions and presentation of more elaborate structures in a variety of tenses and modes. Communicate to explore Hispanic culture and to hypothesize about present and past situations. Aligned with CEFR level A2 objectives. Credit will be granted for either SPAN 203 or both SPAN 201, SPAN 202. Recommended pre-requisite: SPAN 201.

subject: SPAN
title: Intensive Elementary Spanish
description: Continuation of SPAN 103. Aligned with CEFR level A2 objectives. Credits will be granted for SPAN 203 or both SPAN 201, SPAN 202. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SPAN 103, SPAN 102, or placement test for native or near-native speakers of other Romance Languages.

subject: SPAN
title: Conversational Spanish I
description: Emphasizes communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; developing oral fluency and listening comprehension, through discussion of written texts and films. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community. Prerequisite: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, or SPAN 203.
prerequisite_raw: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, or SPAN 203.

subject: SPAN
title: Conversational Spanish II
description: Builds on communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; exploration of cultural topics through discussion of written texts and other media. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community. Aligned with CEFR A2 objectives. Prerequisite: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or SPAN 206.
prerequisite_raw: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or SPAN 206.

subject: SPAN
title: Conversational Spanish and Culture
description: Exploration of cultural topics, concepts, and practices and how they frame and relate to the diverse geographies and cultural traditions from Spain, Latin America, and the diaspora through oral and written expressions. This course is recommended for students who have completed SPAN_V 202 or SPAN_V 203.

subject: SPAN
title: Introduction to Hispanic Literature
description: Major texts, authors, periods, and genres of Hispanic literature; key concepts, terminology, and practices of literary analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish literature courses. Prerequisite: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203, or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.
prerequisite_raw: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203, or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

subject: SPAN
title: Introduction to Hispanic Culture
description: Media, figures, periods, and genres of Hispanic culture; key concepts, theories, and practices of cultural analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish culture courses. Prerequisite: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.
prerequisite_raw: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish I
description: Complex grammatical structures in context to enhance proficiency. Explores relevant cultural topics through reading, writing, and discussion. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives. Prerequisite: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203, SPAN 206, SPAN 207 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.
prerequisite_raw: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203, SPAN 206, SPAN 207 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish II
description: Expansion of and reflection on the use of complex grammatical structures in context to broaden lexical repertoire. Enhances proficiency through reading, writing, and discussion of relevant cultural topics. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives. Prerequisite: SPAN 301 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.
prerequisite_raw: SPAN 301 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

subject: SPAN
title: Conversational Spanish for Advanced Speakers
description: Expands the comprehension and communicative skills of upper-level students and heritage speakers through topics drawn from Hispanic culture and current events. Aligned with CEFR B1 objectives. Prerequisite: One of SPAN 206, 207, 302, or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.
prerequisite_raw: One of SPAN 206, 207, 302, or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

subject: SPAN
title: Spanish for Business
description: Language of commerce, finance, marketing, and economics. Competence in business practices of the Hispanic world. Prerequisite: One of SPAN 206, 207, 301, 302 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.
prerequisite_raw: One of SPAN 206, 207, 301, 302 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

subject: SPAN
title: Business Spanish of International Trade in the Hispanic World (in Spanish)
description: Language of international commerce through real world business practices in the Hispanic world; key issues concerning business practices, engaging with real-world materials, and interacting with professionals specializing in trade with the Hispanic world. Pre-requisites: One of SPAN 206, 207, 301, 302, 308. Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.

subject: SPAN
title: Literatures and Cultures of Spain: From Medieval to Present
description: Spanish Literature from the Middle Ages to Present. Literary analysis of narrative, poetic, dramatic, essay and other texts by considering the main literary genres and trends as well as historical and cultural context. This course is recommended for students who have completed SPAN_V 221 or SPAN_V 301.

subject: SPAN
title: Literatures and Cultures of Latin America: From Pre-Columbian to Present
description: Explore a diverse range of texts, themes and genres of Latin American literature from pre-Columbian times to present day. This course is recommended for students who have completed SPAN_V 221 or SPAN_V 301.

subject: SPAN
title: Tradition and Diversity in Spanish History and Culture
description: Conservation and progress on the Iberian Peninsula, from the Middle Ages to the present. Includes the first modern European state and its diverse cultures. Prerequisite: One of SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.
prerequisite_raw: One of SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

subject: SPAN
title: Dependency and Revolution in Latin American History and Culture
description: Continuities and changes in the Americas from before Columbus to the present. Includes the first modern global empire and its ambivalent legacies. Prerequisite: SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.
prerequisite_raw: SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

subject: SPAN
title: The Golden Age of Peninsular Literature and Culture
description: Tradition, faith, conflict, prosperity, and decadence in literature and everyday life from the Middle Ages to 1700. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

subject: SPAN
title: Divergent Visions: Peninsular Literature and Culture since 1700
description: Modern Spanish literature and culture, from Empire to the European Union. Includes Romanticism, Modernism, Republicanism, and Separatism. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

subject: SPAN
title: Colonial Encounters in Spanish-American Literature and Culture
description: Spanish colonialism in the Americas from the Conquest to the 1820's and the dawn of Independence. Includes coloniality, hybridity, subalternity, and autonomy. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

subject: SPAN
title: Modern Magics: Spanish-American Literature and Culture since the 1820s
description: Literary engagements with modernity in the Spanish Americas, from the 1820's to the present. Includes civilization, progress, politicization, and violence. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

subject: SPAN
title: Upper Intermediate Spanish I
description: Strengthening fluency and accuracy in spoken and written communication. Emphasis on mediation, interpretation, and metalinguistic competencies through translation and comparative stylistics. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

subject: SPAN
title: Upper Intermediate Spanish II
description: Continued strengthening of fluency, accuracy, and spontaneity in spoken and written communication. Emphasis on contextualized grammar and vocabulary; critical reading and discussion of texts. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

subject: SPAN
title: History of the Spanish Language
description: Major features of the development of the Spanish language, from its origins to the present. Includes the history of Spanish phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and dialectology. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

subject: SPAN
title: Breaking the Mold: Gender Representation(s) in Hispanic Literature and Culture
description: Gender and sexuality in Spain and Latin America. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

subject: SPAN
title: From Text to Stage: Topics in Hispanic Theatre
description: Selected areas of study relating to Hispanic Theatre. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

subject: SPAN
title: Hispanic Linguistics
description: Spanish as a linguistic system. Includes the structure of Spanish words and sentences, dialectal varieties in both Spain and Latin America, and linguistic theory. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN_V 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

subject: SPAN
title: Master's Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPAN
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPE
title: Sustainable Bioproducts Processing
description: Properties and characterization of macromolecules including rheology. Polymer processing and application to green products development including from lignocellulosic sources. Circular economy driven processing. Biomimetics engineering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPE
title: Sustainable Bioenergy and Biorefinery
description: Understanding technology of deriving biofuels and chemical feedstocks from forest biomass. Relating chemistry of biomass for production of liquid, solid and gaseous fuels. Processing options for value-added chemicals. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPE
title: Design Laboratory for New Ventures in the Chemical Industry
description: Commercialization of chemical and biochemical products and manufacturing processes; technology development; intellectual property; budgeting and grants; with a focus on venture creation, sustainability and environmental responsibility. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPE
title: Technology Commercialization for the Manufacturing Industries
description: Creation and leadership of new ventures for scale-up and commercialization of manufacturing processes, with a special emphasis on the chemical and ancillary industries. Includes assessment of manufacturing processes; techno-economic analyses; scaling up and de-risking processes; intellectual property; market penetration that are specific to the manufacturing sector. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
description: The idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. [3-0-0]

subject: SPPH
title: Working in Global Health
description: Planning/preparing for work in global health, with attention to health inequities and determinants internationally and domestically, the pursuit of partnerships to address this, power imbalances and ethical principles for carrying out this work. Health Science background not essential.

subject: SPPH
title: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
description: The idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. [3-0-0]

subject: SPPH
title: Topics in Health Informatics for Health/Life Sciences Students
description: Basic literacy in health informatics. Innovative approaches to healthcare implementation, access to care, and data utilization.

subject: SPPH
title: Environmental Impacts on Human Health
description: Harmful environmental exposures in water, air, food; aspects of environment that are beneficial for health; environmental justice; emerging environmental health threats; how epidemiology and risk assessment inform public health policy and practice.

subject: SPPH
title: Canadian Health Care Policy
description: Features of the Canadian health care system, stages in the evolution of Medicare, and how institutions, interests, and ideas shape health care policies.

subject: SPPH
title: Basic Epidemiology for Infection Control
description: Epidemiology, study, design and analysis, and outbreak investigation as it applies to institutional infection control. Equivalency: PATH 477

subject: SPPH
title: Indigenous Health: Historical Impacts and Contemporary Approaches
description: This course covers an epistemological approach that considers the social determinants of health and Indigenous spiritual-environmental and cultural perspectives and approaches to health and wellness.

subject: SPPH
title: Aging from an Interdisciplinary Perspective
description: Population and Public Health issues associated with aging.

subject: SPPH
title: Topics in Aboriginal Health: Community-based Learning Experience
description: In-depth cultural and interprofessional learning experience that enables students to live and study in BC First Nations communities while learning about health, wellness, and community strengths from a local perspective.

subject: SPPH
title: International Indigenous Experiences of Colonization
description: Interprofessional, comparative inquiry of Indigenous experiences of global colonization and the manifestations of that experience in the contemporary socio-cultural environment. Informed and guided by Indigenous knowledge and drawing upon a range of disciplines.

subject: SPPH
title: Improving Public Health: An Interprofessional Approach to Designing and Implementing Effective Interventions
description: Improving public health by developing the skills to design and deliver pragmatic, effective health behavior change interventions.

subject: SPPH
title: Violence Across the Lifespan
description: Overview of violence across the lifespan. Epidemiology, dynamics, health effects, intervention and prevention.

subject: SPPH
title: Analytical Methods in Epidemiological Research
description: Basic epidemiological designs as a framework for commonly used biostatistical techniques such as the Mantel-Haenszel, chi-squared, linear and logistic regression, and survival analysis. Computer packages will be available for computation of assignments. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502 or (b) all of SPPH 521, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 567, SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502 or (b) all of SPPH 521, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 567, SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Analysis of Longitudinal Data from Epidemiological Studies
description: To explore and compare methods of analyzing continuous and categorical longitudinal data. The issues of missing data and errors in measurement/misclassification will be covered in depth. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 or (b) all of SPPH 521, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502, SPPH 567. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 or (b) all of SPPH 521, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502, SPPH 567. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Epidemiological Methods 1
description: Sources and uses of epidemiologic data for health services planning and administration including methods of data collection and study design. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Epidemiological Methods 2
description: Critical thinking in epidemiology; principles and methods of study design; context for epidemiological investigations of human health. Prerequisite: SPPH 502 and one of SPPH 400 or SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SPPH 502 and one of SPPH 400 or SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Application of Epidemiological Methods
description: This second level course will teach research trainees to apply methods taught in prior courses towards the development of a fundable research protocol and the analysis and interpretation of real epidemiologic data. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502, SPPH 503. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502, SPPH 503. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Scientific Basis for Epidemiological Thinking
description: The course will provide a framework for students to use epidemiological and other scientific evidence to make decisions about causation and to recommend policy actions. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Quantitative Research Methods
description: Major quantitative research designs, measurement reliability and validity, common data sources used, internal and external validity, research proposals, and peer review. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: M.P.H. Practicum
description: Applied epidemiology and biostatistics in a field setting. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Genetic Epidemiology
description: Human genetics and genomics, behavioural, social, and environmental factors in modifying or influencing genetics in the manifestation of disease. Prerequisite: SPPH 502 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SPPH 502 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Survey Methods in Health Measurement
description: Concepts and techniques of measurement in epidemiological research. Topics covered include validity, reliability and misclassification, scale design and the construction of questionnaires and indices for both health outcomes and exposures. Prerequisite: One of SPPH 400, SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of SPPH 400, SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Cancer Control and Epidemiology
description: Collection and analysis of epidemiological data on cancer; genetic, occupational, and other risk factors; analytic techniques; cancer control, prevention, screening, early detection, and policy issues. Prerequisite: SPPH 502. or equivalent. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SPPH 502. or equivalent. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: The Design and Analysis of Clinical Trials
description: Ethical considerations, intention-to-treat versus efficacy trials, principles of sampling and exclusion, methods of allocation and techniques of randomization, parallel versus cross over design, monitoring treatment outcomes, adverse effects, stopping rules, analytic techniques and data interpretation, and logistical issues in the management of clinical trials. Prerequisite: One of SPPH 502, SPPH 513. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of SPPH 502, SPPH 513. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Clinical Epidemiology
description: Principles and methods of epidemiology are applied to clinical problems. Evaluation and design of laboratory and clinical tests and of therapeutic interventions. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Decision Analysis in Health Care
description: Methods and application of decision analysis to improve health from the perspective of the policy maker, health professional, and patient. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Surveillance and Monitoring in Public Health
description: Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Methods for Systematic Reviews in Health Research
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Clinical Research methods for Surgical Procedures
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Mathematical Modelling of Communicable Diseases
description: Application of mathematical models in understanding communicable disease dynamics and control; interpretation of model outcomes; modelling methods and their applications. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Qualitative Methods in Health Research Design
description: Purposes, context, procedures, and relationships within qualitative health research and methodologies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Control of Communicable Disease
description: Epidemiology of viral, bacterial and parasitic infections with emphasis on the control of these infections in human populations. Immunization programs will be stressed. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Statistics for Health Research
description: Planned collection, numeric and graphic summarization, elementary statistical analysis of data. Examples from health sciences illustrate standard techniques for parametric and nonparametric hypothesis testing; regression and correlation; contingency tables. Also randomization, "blindfolding" and other specifically biomedical topics in statistics. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 400 or SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Planned collection, numeric and graphic summarization, elementary statistical analysis of data. Examples from health sciences illustrate standard techniques for parametric and nonparametric hypothesis testing; regression and correlation; contingency tables. Also randomization, "blindfolding" and other specifically biomedical topics in statistics. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 400 or SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Topics in Environmental Health
description: Role of air, water, food and solid waste as sources of human health risks; global environmental health issues; sustainability. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Global Health and Human Security
description: Global threats to human health stemming from conflict, poverty, and environmental degradation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Core Biological Concepts of Public Health Practice
description: Cell biology, microbiology, molecular science, genetics, physiology, and evolution. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Issues and Concepts in Public Health
description: History of public health research and practice; occupational and environmental health; health services and systems; social and lifecourse determinants of health; and population health and emerging trends. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Leadership in Public Health
description: Organizational structure; engaging others in an organization; inter-organizational networking; building coalitions; identification of opportunities to bring change to organizations through knowledge development, management, synthesis, and implementation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Social Determinants of Health
description: Foundational thinking giving rise to the concept of population health. Overview of the current state of research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Rural and Remote Health
description: Issues and solutions to delivery of health services to underserved rural populations. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH_V 400 or (b) SPPH_V 521; and SPPH_V 502. Corequisite: SPPH_V 500 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SPPH_V 400 or (b) SPPH_V 521; and SPPH_V 502. Corequisite: SPPH_V 500 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: SPPH_V 500 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Major Essay
description: Required for all M.H.Sc. students. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Epidemiology of Occupational and Environmental Health
description: Design and analysis of etiologic research in occupational health. Prerequisite: SPPH 502. or permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SPPH 502. or permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Health Care Systems Analysis
description: Theory, concepts, measurement, and practical skills using administrative data for analysis of health care systems. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Environmental Health Risk Assessment and Communication
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Toxicology and Public Health
description: Mechanism of action of commonly encountered occupational toxic agents; relevance of laboratory and epidemiological evidence. Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Permission of instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Occupational Health and Illness Processes
description: Occupational diseases; research, historical perspectives, and surveillance. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Principles of Occupational and Environmental Hygiene
description: Scientific basis for the recognition, evaluation, and control of chemical, physical, and biological, exposures; standard setting; exposure monitoring methods. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Aboriginal People and Public Health: Ethics, Policy, and Practice
description: Experience of colonization; Indian Act; the histories and intergenerational impact of the residential school; child-welfare systems; communicable disease prevention; the challenge of ethical public health practice; and traditional healing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Perinatal Epidemiology
description: Indicators of maternal/newborn well-being across population subgroups, changing trends in obstetrical intervention, perinatal morbidity, and the analysis of perinatal data. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. Corequisite: SPPH 500 Equivalency: OBST 507 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. Corequisite: SPPH 500 Equivalency: OBST 507 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: SPPH 500 Equivalency: OBST 507 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Application of Ethical Theories in the Practice of Public Health
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Epidemiology of Aging and Chronic Diseases
description: Biology of aging, epidemiology of cardiovascular disease, neoplasms, osteoporosis and fractures, psychosocial factors and health in old age, dementias, functional status, and prevention of disease. Prerequisite: SPPH 502, SPPH 524 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SPPH 502, SPPH 524 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Program Planning and Evaluation
description: Examines the concept of evaluation in health services and how various methodological approaches can be used in evaluative studies. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Economic Evaluation
description: Economic evaluation of health service interventions and programs, with emphasis on methods and components of program costing. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Canadian Health Policy
description: Analysis of the evolution and structure of the Canadian health care system. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Health Technology Assessment for Health Policy
description: This course is an advanced program evaluation course. Prerequisite: SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Social Determinants of Health Across the Life Course
description: The social determinants of health have profound impacts on inequities across the life course, as do population-level interventions. Builds on SPPH 527, with an emphasis on life course perspectives and vulnerable populations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Community Health Promotion
description: Practice and community-based (participatory) research related to health promotion, including its historical and philosophical roots. Application of social and behavioural theories to participatory research and the planning, implementation, and evaluation of community health promotion initiatives. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Introduction to Health Economics
description: Broad understanding of the health system and health system change from an economics perspective, with a focus on delivery, organization, and financing of healthcare. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Health Care Priority Setting
description: Resource allocation, economics and ethics based approaches for decision making, uptake of evidence to inform resource use in health care. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Knowledge to Action in Population Health
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Advanced Economic Evaluation in Health Care
description: Economic evaluation of health technologies, considering, in detail, the policy context for the use of economic evaluation. Prerequisite: SPPH 541. Or equivalent training. Equivalency: PHAR 560. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SPPH 541. Or equivalent training. Equivalency: PHAR 560. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Public Health Approaches to Substance Use and Addictions
description: Critical examination of strategies regarding addictive behaviours, substance use and related problems, in the context of a multi-disciplinary approach. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Pharmacoepidemiology
description: Principles and applications of pharmacoepidemiology. Practical skills in designing, conducting, and appraising studies of medications in large populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 551 or PHAR 561. Prerequisite: Previous coursework in statistics or biostatistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Previous coursework in statistics or biostatistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Principles and applications of pharmacoepidemiology. Practical skills in designing, conducting, and appraising studies of medications in large populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 551 or PHAR 561. Prerequisite: Previous coursework in statistics or biostatistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Science and Risk Communication for Public Health
description: Theory and practice of risk communication in public health, basic principles underlying effective science communication with peers, the media, and the public. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Foundations of Public Health Computing
description: Data gathering, cleaning, analysis, and visualization to produce key results using statistical software. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Addiction and Mental Health
description: Severe addiction and mental illness and the systemic context in which they occur. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Principles and Practices of Injury Prevention
description: Injury epidemiology; surveillance; development, implementation, and evaluation techniques of preventive strategies; determinants of health; social marketing; injury policy; evidence-based prevention strategies; utilization of injury datasets. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Major Essay
description: Required for Master of Health Administration (M.H.A.) non-thesis program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Chemical and Biological Hazard Measurement
description: Industrial hygiene and environmental exposure monitoring, methods, and instrumentation, and theory. Laboratories demonstrate workplace sampling and analysis techniques. [2-3] Prerequisite: SPPH 535. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SPPH 535. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Technical Aspects of Occupational Hygiene Hazard Controls
description: Industrial ventilation, heating and air conditioning systems, respiratory protection, chemical protective clothing. Prerequisite: SPPH 535. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SPPH 535. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Advanced Topics in Occupational and Environmental Health
description: Recommended: SPPH 567 or an equivalent statistics or quantitative course is recommended. Prerequisite: All of SPPH 502, SPPH 535. Corequisite: SPPH 522. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of SPPH 502, SPPH 535. Corequisite: SPPH 522. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: SPPH 522. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Ergonomics
description: Human factors in workplace design, anthropometry, work physiology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Occupational Hygiene Practice
description: Application of occupational hygiene principles using field investigations, critical appraisal of results, and communication with labour and management. [2-3] Prerequisite: SPPH 562. Corequisite: SPPH 563. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SPPH 562. Corequisite: SPPH 563. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: SPPH 563. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Quantitative Methods for the Assessment and Analysis of Exposure Data
description: Determinants of exposure, sampling strategies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Occupational Safety Programs and Systems
description: Safety management; systems analysis; accident investigation; collection of accident data; fault trees; total loss control. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Industrial and Environmental Acoustics and Vibration
description: Fundamentals of acoustics and vibrations, physiologic effects, measurement, instrumentation, interpretation of data, industrial standards, and control. For students in Occupational and Environmental Hygiene; other graduate students may enrol with permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Current Issues in Public Health Practice
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Public Health, Transportation, and the Built Environment
description: Health issues associated with transportation and the built environment; design of urban form for non-motorized transportation for the improvement of personal and environmental health; factors that impact transportation choices; applying findings from research to specific transportation planning processes and projects. Credit will be granted for only one of PLAN 579 or SPPH 571. Equivalency: PLAN579 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Health issues associated with transportation and the built environment; design of urban form for non-motorized transportation for the improvement of personal and environmental health; factors that impact transportation choices; applying findings from research to specific transportation planning processes and projects. Credit will be granted for only one of PLAN 579 or SPPH 571. Equivalency: PLAN579 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: M.P.H. Capstone
description: Restricted to students in the Master of Public Health. Prerequisites: All of SPPH_V 521, SPPH_V 500, SPPH_V 502, SPPH_V 503. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Occupational and Environmental Hygiene Project
description: Applied project on approved topic based on practicum: requires a written and oral report. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: M.Sc. Thesis
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Application of Advanced Epidemiological Methods
description: Statistical approaches for confounding, missingness, and complex surveys, the development of analysis plans, the analysis and interpretation of real-world epidemiologic data, and the communication of findings. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502; and one of SPPH 503, SPPH 506, SPPH 519, SPPH 530. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502; and one of SPPH 503, SPPH 506, SPPH 519, SPPH 530. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Approaches to Enquiry in Population and Public Health
description: Research approaches in the area of population and public health; focus on developing research questions and the centrality of research questions in conducting research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Current Issues in Public Health Practice
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Field Experience
description: A series of visits to facilities and organizations related to Community Medicine Practice. Directed by Faculty. At least four hours per month. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Supervised Work
description: A weekly review by Faculty of the work carried out by the resident with discussion on the objectives, planning, method of operation and outcome. Two hours per week. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Community Health Tutorials
description: Topics of Public Health interest presented throughout the year by Faculty and guest lecturers. Two hours per month. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Community Medicine Seminars
description: Selected topics of current interest in Community Medicine Practice or in its basic sciences. Presented by residents and discussed with Faculty and invited guests. Three hours per month. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Journal Seminars
description: A monthly two-hour seminar on selected journal articles of Community Medicine interest are presented by the residents and discussed with Faculty and invited guests. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Research in Community Medicine or its Basic Sciences by a Resident
description: Up to two days per week. Supervised by Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Introduction to Occupational Medicine Practice
description: An introductory survey to Occupational Medicine practice. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SPPH
title: Fundamentals of Clinical Epidemiology
description: Seminar series covering critical appraisal of the medical literature and basic research methods for residents in any post-graduate training program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Elementary Statistics for Applications
description: Classical, nonparametric, and robust inferences about means, variances, and analysis of variance, using computers. Emphasis on problem formulation, assumptions, and interpretation. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-1-0] Prerequisite: One of any course on the MATH 100 credit exclusion list [ https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… ], MATH 190, SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: One of any course on the MATH 100 credit exclusion list [ https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… ], MATH 190, SCIE 001.

subject: STAT
title: Statistical Inference for Data Science
description: Classical and simulation-based techniques for estimation and hypothesis testing, including inference for means and proportions. Emphasis on case studies and real data sets, as well as reproducible and transparent workflows when writing computer scripts for analysis and reports. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: DSCI 100.
prerequisite_raw: DSCI 100.

subject: STAT
title: Statistical Methods
description: Organizing, displaying and summarizing data. Inference estimation and testing for elementary probability models. Not for credit towards a B.Sc. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.) [3-1-0] Prerequisite: MATH 11. Or Pre-calculus 11.
prerequisite_raw: MATH 11. Or Pre-calculus 11.

subject: STAT
title: Elementary Statistics
description: Probability, discrete and continuous random variables, joint probability distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, analysis of variance, goodness of fit. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar). [3-1-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

subject: STAT
title: Intermediate Statistics for Applications
description: Further topics in statistical inference, including parametric and non-parametric methods, goodness-of-fit methods, analysis of variance and covariance, regression analysis, categorical data analysis, experimental designs, time series, model fitting, and statistical computing. [3-1-0] Prerequisite: One of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, BUSI 291, COMM 191, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, KIN 206, LFS 252, POLI 380, PSYC 218, PSYC 278. Equivalency: COMM411
prerequisite_raw: One of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, BUSI 291, COMM 191, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, KIN 206, LFS 252, POLI 380, PSYC 218, PSYC 278. Equivalency: COMM411

subject: STAT
title: Statistical Modelling for Data Science
description: Data analysis using statistical models and algorithms (e.g., linear and logistic regression, peeking, bandit, and variable selection algorithms) in case studies from different disciplines. Generative versus out-of-sample predictive models. Reproducible and transparent workflows for computer scripts and reports. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: STAT 201 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184, SCIE 001.
prerequisite_raw: STAT 201 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184, SCIE 001.

subject: STAT
title: Introduction to Probability
description: Basic notions of probability, random variables, expectation and conditional expectation, limit theorems. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.) [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 217, MATH 253, MATH 254. Equivalency: MATH302
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 217, MATH 253, MATH 254. Equivalency: MATH302

subject: STAT
title: Introduction to Statistical Inference
description: Review of probability theory. Sampling distribution theory, large sample theory and methods of estimation and hypothesis testing, including maximum likelihood estimation, likelihood ratio testing and confidence interval construction. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of STAT_V 200, STAT_V 203, BIOL_V 300, STAT_V 251, COMM_V 291, ECON_V 325, FRST_V 231, PSYC_V 218, PSYC_V 366 and one of MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302; or (b) DSCI_V 200 and STAT_V 201 and one of MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302; or (c) a score of 65% or higher in one of MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302. The Department recommends that students meet the prerequisite through option (a) or (b).
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) one of STAT_V 200, STAT_V 203, BIOL_V 300, STAT_V 251, COMM_V 291, ECON_V 325, FRST_V 231, PSYC_V 218, PSYC_V 366 and one of MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302; or (b) DSCI_V 200 and STAT_V 201 and one of MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302; or (c) a score of 65% or higher in one of MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302. The Department recommends that students meet the prerequisite through option (a) or (b).

subject: STAT
title: Finding Relationships in Data
description: Modelling a response (output) variable as a function of several explanatory (input) variables: multiple regression for a continuous response, logistic regression for a binary response, and log-linear models for count data. Finding low-dimensional structure: principal components analysis. Cluster analysis. (Consult the Credit Exclusion List within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar). [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 300, BIOL 300, BUSI 291, COMM 191, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 278 and one of MATH 302, STAT 302.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 300, BIOL 300, BUSI 291, COMM 191, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 278 and one of MATH 302, STAT 302.

subject: STAT
title: Statistics Laboratory I
description: Implementing theory in applications. Problem based learning. Generation and analysis of case data. Modelling, computation and reporting. [0-4-0] Corequisite: STAT306
corequisite_raw: STAT306

subject: STAT
title: Statistics Laboratory II
description: Continuation of STAT 307. [0-2-0]

subject: STAT
title: Stochastic Signals and Systems
description: Stochastic behaviour of signals and systems (e.g., communication systems); discrete and continuous probability; random processes; modelling and identification of linear time-invariant systems; binary hypothesis testing and decision making. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: One of ELEC 221, STAT 305. STAT 305 may be taken concurrently, with registration assistance from the Student Programs Coordinator in the Department of Statistics. Equivalency: ELEC321
prerequisite_raw: One of ELEC 221, STAT 305. STAT 305 may be taken concurrently, with registration assistance from the Student Programs Coordinator in the Department of Statistics. Equivalency: ELEC321

subject: STAT
title: Statistics in Quality Assurance
description: Philosophy of quality improvement and total quality control. Definitions of quality. Deming's principles, Ishikawa's tools, control charts, acceptance sampling, continuous improvement, quality design. Credit cannot be obtained for both STAT 335 and WOOD 335. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300.
prerequisite_raw: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300.

subject: STAT
title: Sample Surveys
description: Planning and practice of sample surveys. Random sampling, bias and variance, unequal probability sampling, systematic, multistage and stratified sampling, ratio and regression estimators, post-stratification, establishing a frame, pretesting, pilot studies, nonresponse and additional topics. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 278, PSYC 366. Corequisite: One of MATH 302, STAT 302.
prerequisite_raw: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 278, PSYC 366. Corequisite: One of MATH 302, STAT 302.
corequisite_raw: One of MATH 302, STAT 302.

subject: STAT
title: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Winter Session of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics. Prerequisite: Registration in Statistics Honours or Major Program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Registration in Statistics Honours or Major Program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Summer Session following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics. Prerequisite: [STAT398] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: [STAT398] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Design and Analysis of Experiments
description: Theory and application of analysis of variance for standard experimental designs, including blocked, nested, factorial and split plot designs. Fixed and random effects, multiple comparisons, analysis of covariance. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar). [3-0-1] Prerequisite: STAT305, one of MATH 152, MATH 221, or MATH 223. Corequisite: ECON 326 or STAT 306.
prerequisite_raw: STAT305, one of MATH 152, MATH 221, or MATH 223. Corequisite: ECON 326 or STAT 306.
corequisite_raw: ECON 326 or STAT 306.

subject: STAT
title: Bayesian Statistics
description: Bayesian approaches to statistical inference: probabilistic modelling, Bayesian inference workflows, approximation of posterior distributions supported by modelling languages, analysis of Bayesian procedures and posterior approximation methods. [3-0-1] Prerequisites: One of MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302, or MATH_V 418, and either STAT_V 305 or STAT_V 460.

subject: STAT
title: Methods for Statistical Learning
description: Flexible, data-adaptive methods for regression and classification models; regression smoothers; penalty methods; assessing accuracy of prediction; model selection; robustness; classification and regression trees; nearest-neighbour methods; neural networks; model averaging and ensembles; computational time and visualization for large data sets. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: a) One of STAT_V 306, CPSC_V 340, or b) STAT_V 301 and one of MATH_V 152, MATH_V 221, MATH_V 223 and one of MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302.
prerequisite_raw: a) One of STAT_V 306, CPSC_V 340, or b) STAT_V 301 and one of MATH_V 152, MATH_V 221, MATH_V 223 and one of MATH_V 302, STAT_V 302.

subject: STAT
title: Time Series and Forecasting
description: Trend and seasonality, autocorrelation, stationarity, stochastic models, exponential smoothing, Holt-Winters methods, Box-Jenkins approach, frequency domain analysis. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 302 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 300, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, POLI 380, PSYC 218, PSYC 278, PSYC 366. Corequisite: STAT 305.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 302 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 300, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, POLI 380, PSYC 218, PSYC 278, PSYC 366. Corequisite: STAT 305.
corequisite_raw: STAT 305.

subject: STAT
title: Introduction to Exploratory Data Analysis
description: Methods for exploring and presenting the structure of data: one group of numbers, several groups, bivariate data, time series data and two-way tables. Data displays, outlier identification, transformations, resistant regression, several types of data smoothing, comparisons with standard statistical methods. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: [STAT306]
prerequisite_raw: [STAT306]

subject: STAT
title: Case Studies in Statistics
description: Readings and projects in areas of current statistical application including environmental science, industrial statistics, official statistics, actuarial statistics, and medical statistics. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: [STAT306]
prerequisite_raw: [STAT306]

subject: STAT
title: Statistical Inference I
description: Statistical models and their properties, estimation methods, properties of point and interval estimation, likelihood, Bayesian inference. Intended for Honours students. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: All of MATH 320, STAT 305 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
prerequisite_raw: All of MATH 320, STAT 305 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

subject: STAT
title: Statistical Inference II
description: Hypothesis testing and model selection in modern statistics, confidence regions, multiple testing, model comparison criteria. Intended for Honours students. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: [STAT460]
prerequisite_raw: [STAT460]

subject: STAT
title: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Summer Session following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Term 1 of Winter Session of fifth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Theoretical Statistics
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Techniques of Statistical Consulting
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Statistical Consulting Practicum
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Statistical Theory I
description: Credit will not be given for both STAT 460 and STAT 560. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Statistical Theory II
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: M.Sc. Project
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative M.Sc. Education Program in Statistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative M.Sc. Education Program in Statistics. Prerequisite: STAT 598. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: STAT 598. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STAT
title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STS
title: Proseminar in Science and Technology Studies
description: Classic work in the history, philosophy, rhetoric, and sociology of science, and the development of a unified science and technology studies. Required for all students in the STS Program. This course is co-taught. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STS
title: Core Seminar in Science and Technology Studies
description: Thematizes the relations of historical, philosophical, literary, rhetorical, sociological, and anthropological approaches to science and technology. Recommended pre-requisite: STS 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STS
title: Master's Colloquium in Science and Technology Studies
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: STS
title: Master's Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SURG
title: Experimental Surgery
description: Lectures and seminars dealing with the selected application of surgical techniques in biological investigation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SURG
title: Surgical Care in International Health
description: Foundation to international surgery. The discussion of the global burden of unmet surgical needs and a professional response in low and middle income regions of the world. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SURG
title: Global Disability: A Surgical Care Mandate
description: Relationship of surgery to preventing and treating disabling impairments in lower income countries. Focus will be on sensory impairments (blindness and deafness) and physical impairment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SURG
title: Surgical Care in Humanitarian Disaster Response
description: Examines response to humanitarian disasters. Includes case models of surgical care responses and strategies to move from relief to recovery. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SURG
title: Program Planning and Evaluation in Surgical Care Low Resource Settings
description: Program Planning and Evaluation in Surgical Care contexts. Theory, approaches and methods for conducting surgical care programs among populations in various low resource contexts. Key concepts, ethical approaches and practices, and practical skills development. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH_V 540 or SURG_V 516. Prerequisite: SURG_V 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SURG_V 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Program Planning and Evaluation in Surgical Care contexts. Theory, approaches and methods for conducting surgical care programs among populations in various low resource contexts. Key concepts, ethical approaches and practices, and practical skills development. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH_V 540 or SURG_V 516. Prerequisite: SURG_V 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SURG
title: Clinical Research Methods for Surgical Procedures with Global Surgical Comparisons
description: Clinical research methods, research process, systematic reviews, quality improvement and assurance, and technology evaluation with an emphasis on research in global surgical care. Credit will be granted for only one of SURG_V 517 or SPPH_V 517. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Clinical research methods, research process, systematic reviews, quality improvement and assurance, and technology evaluation with an emphasis on research in global surgical care. Credit will be granted for only one of SURG_V 517 or SPPH_V 517. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SURG
title: Surgical Care in Canada's Rural and Remote Indigenous Communities with Global Comparisons
description: Critiques the current and historical provision of surgical care services to indigenous communities in Canada and globally. Examines challenges and opportunities confronting both the clinician and the service delivery system, embracing lessons learned from these communities. Prerequisite: SURG_V 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: SURG_V 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SURG
title: Directed Study in Global Surgical Care
description: Literature review of a global surgical care topic chosen in consultation with an advisor. Includes analysis of existing literature and research, and identification of gaps in current knowledge. Prerequisite: All of SURG_V 510, SURG_V 512, SURG_V 514. Corequisite: SURG_V 517. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of SURG_V 510, SURG_V 512, SURG_V 514. Corequisite: SURG_V 517. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: SURG_V 517. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SURG
title: Global Surgical Care Field Practicum
description: Course with a four to eight week on-site field placement. Proposal development, implementation and high-level written report of a surgical care field practicum in an underserved location globally, producing practical on-the-ground skills. Prerequisite: All of SURG_V 510, SURG 512_V, SURG_V 514, SURG_V 516. Corequisite: SURG_V 517. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of SURG_V 510, SURG 512_V, SURG_V 514, SURG_V 516. Corequisite: SURG_V 517. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: SURG_V 517. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: SWAH
title: Beginners' Swahili I
description: Skills in listening to and speaking Swahili, a major language of Africa and one of the most widely spoken languages in the world. Emphasizes everyday vocabulary, core grammar, use in context, and connections between the language and African cultures.

subject: SWAH
title: Beginners' Swahili II
description: Skills in using Swahili in a range of social contexts. Training in grammar and vocabulary that builds fluency, and in using the language appropriately for meaningful interactions with native speakers. Prerequisite: SWAH 101. or equivalent.
prerequisite_raw: SWAH 101. or equivalent.

subject: SWED
title: Elementary Swedish I
description: Students with native or near-native proficiency in a Scandinavian language (e.g. Danish, Norwegian, Swedish) cannot participate in the elementary Swedish courses (SWED 100 and SWED 110), but are welcome to join the intermediate courses (SWED 200 and SWED 210).

subject: SWED
title: Elementary Swedish II
description: Students with native or near-native proficiency in a Scandinavian language (e.g. Danish, Norwegian, Swedish) cannot participate in the elementary Swedish courses (SWED 100 and SWED 110), but are welcome to join the intermediate courses (SWED 200 and SWED 210).

subject: THFL
title: The Art of Storytelling for Stage and Screen
description: Fundamental elements of the art of storytelling as approached within each of the core areas taught in the Department of Theatre and Film: Acting/Directing, Design and Production, and Film Production. Restricted to students in one of the following BFA programs: Major in Acting; Major in Film Production; Major in Theatre Design and Production

subject: THFL
title: Visual Narrative: Exploring Design and Creative Process
description: Visual storytelling, combining practical design techniques with creative methodologies. Uses design principles to shape visual narratives by emphasizing innovative visual communication and a thorough understanding of the creative process.

subject: THFL
title: Celebrity Studies
description: Critical analysis of global celebrity in the performing arts.

subject: THFL
title: Production Design
description: The tools and processes used by set designers, art directors, and production designers in North America. Prerequisite: One of THTR 205, THTR 305, FIPR 233.
prerequisite_raw: One of THTR 205, THTR 305, FIPR 233.

subject: THFL
title: Expanded Visual Media
description: Pre- and/or post-production strategies, techniques, and processes for time-based media effects. Credit will only be granted for one of THFL 312 or VISA 312. Prerequisite: One of VISA 241, VISA 210, FIPR 133, FIPR 233. Or B.M.S. students with 3rd year standing. Equivalency: VISA 312.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 241, VISA 210, FIPR 133, FIPR 233. Or B.M.S. students with 3rd year standing. Equivalency: VISA 312.
exclusion_raw: Pre- and/or post-production strategies, techniques, and processes for time-based media effects. Credit will only be granted for one of THFL 312 or VISA 312. Prerequisite: One of VISA 241, VISA 210, FIPR 133, FIPR 233. Or B.M.S. students with 3rd year standing. Equivalency: VISA 312.

subject: THFL
title: Professional Portfolio Preparation for Live and Digital Performance
description: Preparation to transition into the theatre and film industry. Portfolio development, visual identity, and skills to support professional performance practices aligned with theatre and film professional associations. Restricted to students in third or fourth-year in one of the following programs: Major in Film Production; Major in Theatre Design and Production. Prerequisite: One of THTR 305, THTR 306, THTR 307, THTR 308, FIPR 333.
prerequisite_raw: One of THTR 305, THTR 306, THTR 307, THTR 308, FIPR 333.

subject: THTR
title: Introduction to Theatre
description: Theory and practice of the theatrical arts. Attendance at plays is required.

subject: THTR
title: Drama: Forms and Ideas I
description: The Anatomy of Drama: Its history, aesthetic principles, performative potential.

subject: THTR
title: Drama: Forms and Ideas II
description: Topics in comparative drama; drama and the other performing arts; dramaturgy.

subject: THTR
title: Performance Study I
description: Study of the actor's process.

subject: THTR
title: Play-Interpretation and Production-Analysis
description: Basic methods of interpreting dramatic texts and analyzing plays in performance. The plays presented on the Frederic Wood Stage will be studied in this course.

subject: THTR
title: Technical Production

exclusion_raw: The construction and execution of scenery, costumes, properties, lighting, and sound for the stage. Credit will be granted for only one of THTR_V 250 or THTR_V 254. Equivalency: THTR_V 254

title: Scenery Design I

subject: THTR
title: Costume Design I

subject: THTR
title: Lighting Design I

subject: THTR
title: Sound Design

subject: THTR
title: Theory of Drama Performance
description: The basic principles of dramaturgy and theory of performance. Historical and contemporary writing on dramatic theory and criticism and their relation to theatrical practice.

subject: THTR
title: Studies in Drama
description: Topics will vary from year to year.

title: Introduction to Directing

prerequisite_raw: One of THTR 130, THTR 230 and THTR 299. Corequisite: One of THTR 299, THTR 399.
corequisite_raw: One of THTR 299, THTR 399.

title: Voice and Movement Study

title: Scenery Production I

title: Scene Painting I

title: Costume Construction

title: Costume Design II

title: Dramaturgy

title: Directing Lab

title: History of Theatre II

title: History of Theatre from 1900 to the present

subject: THTR
title: Theory of Drama and Performance

title: Costume Construction II

title: Advanced Speech and Movement II

title: Bibliography and Research Methods

title: Studies in Historic Design
