subject: TIBT
title: Introduction to Tibetan I
description: Concepts, grammar, syntax of spoken and written Tibetan for beginners. Also covers aspects of Tibetan worldview.

subject: TIBT
title: Introduction to Tibetan II
description: Focus on grammar, syntax, and structures to improve comprehension and communication skills. Also covers aspects of Tibetan worldview. Recommended pre-requisite: TIBT 100.

subject: TIBT
title: Classical Tibetan I
description: The basics of classical Tibetan grammar and vocabulary, with readings from a selection of daily prayer verses. Recommended pre-requisite: completion of TIBT 100 or TIBT 390 with a minimum grade of 60%.

subject: TIBT
title: Classical Tibetan II
description: Continuation of introductory classical Tibetan grammar and vocabulary, with selected readings to strengthen one's foundation in classical Tibetan. Recommended pre-requisite: completion of TIBT 300 with a minimum grade of 60%.

subject: TIBT
title: Tibetan Language in a Community Context
description: Beginner to conversational level Tibetan combined with experiential learning and cultural activities at local Tibetan community sites. Interactive practice with everyday phrases, grammar structure, and vocabulary with Tibetan community members.

subject: UDES
title: Urban Design Studio I
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UDES
title: Urban Design Studio II
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UDES
title: Urban Design Studio III
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UDES
title: History and Theory of Urban Design
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UDES
title: Urban Design as Public Policy: Policymaking for a Sustainable Region
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UDES
title: Real Estate Economics: Development Feasibility and Financing
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UFOR
title: Greening the City
description: Roles played by urban forestry and greenspace systems in a rapidly changing world; topics include urban ecology, urban forest conservation, urban forest management, climate change, society and human well-being, design and planning, urban/rural interface issues, and urban forest policy. [2-0-2]

subject: UFOR
title: Introduction to Urban Forest Design
description: Basic concepts of landscape design as it relates to urban forestry.

subject: UFOR
title: Urban Forests and Well-Being
description: Basic relationships between urban residents' mental and physical well-being and their urban forest environment. [2-0-2]

subject: UFOR
title: Urban Forest Inventory and Assessment
description: Overview of urban forest resources: structure and composition, extent, and ecosystem services and benefits provided; introduces methods and tools for urban forest inventory, monitoring, and assessment, and how they are integrated into the planning and management of urban forests. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UFOR
title: Introductory Statistical Methods for Urban Forestry
description: Basic theories and practice of statistical methods in an urban forestry context. Intended only for students in the Bachelor of Urban Forestry program. Students in the Bachelor of Science, Natural Resources should take NRES 231.

subject: UFOR
title: Arboriculture Principles and Practice
description: Principles and practices of individual urban tree management with emphasis on underlying biological and ecological concepts, plant-environment interactions above and below ground and implications for establishment, evaluation, and conservation of individual trees in a variety of urban situations. [3-1-0] Prerequisite: Pre-req or co-req: UFOR 316 and Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Pre-req or co-req: UFOR 316 and Third-year standing.

subject: UFOR
title: Trees and Shrubs in Landscape
description: Identification and suitability of woody plants used in the urban environment, with a focus on biological characteristics for plant identification, criteria for species selection, and other considerations for urban woody plant cultivation. Prerequisite: One of FRST 200, NRES 200. Corequisite: All of UFOR 316, UFOR 300.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 200, NRES 200. Corequisite: All of UFOR 316, UFOR 300.
corequisite_raw: All of UFOR 316, UFOR 300.

subject: UFOR
title: Urban Ecology
description: The nature and dynamics of urban ecosystems with emphasis on urban forests and greenspaces. The role of green infrastructure in urban sustainability with particular focus on the ecological impact of urban forest management, design, and policy decisions. [3-0-1].

subject: UFOR
title: Environmental Justice and Urban Green Equity
description: Theory, concepts and applications of urban green equity and urban environmental justice with particular focus on implications for urban forest policy, planning, management, and design. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Third-year standing.

subject: UFOR
title: Urban Forestry Field School
description: Development of field skills, professional judgment, critical reflection, and integration of theory, practice, and policy. Offered at Malcolm Knapp Research Forest over a 7-day period in April. Prerequisite: All of UFOR 300, UFOR 316. And third year standing in the B.U.F. program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of UFOR 300, UFOR 316. And third year standing in the B.U.F. program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UFOR
title: Integrated Urban Forestry Capstone Studio
description: Integration of biophysical and socio-economic components of urban greenspace management and planning through within a collaborative holistic group project linked to a real-world urban forestry situation. [3-6-0] Prerequisite: All of UFOR 300, UFOR 400. And fourth year standing in the B.U.F. program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of UFOR 300, UFOR 400. And fourth year standing in the B.U.F. program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UFOR
title: Urban Forestry Administration, Policy and Law
description: The administrative, legal, policy, and business environments for urban forestry governance, management, and planning. [3-1-0] Prerequisite: UFOR 300. And third year standing.
prerequisite_raw: UFOR 300. And third year standing.

subject: UFOR
title: Ecological Restoration
description: Perspectives and practices of ecological restoration in diverse ecosystems worldwide. Prerequisite: One of FRST 201, NRES 201, BIOL 230. And third-year standing. Equivalency: APBI423 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 201, NRES 201, BIOL 230. And third-year standing. Equivalency: APBI423 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UFOR
title: Planting Design
description: An introduction to the design of enhanced environments through the use of plants. Prerequisites: Third-year standing

subject: UFOR
title: Green Network Planning
description: Theory and methods of long-range green space planning for urban areas.

subject: UFOR
title: Biodiversity in Urban Areas
description: Urban centres can be designed and managed to contribute to biodiversity conservation commitments. Topics include designing human-dominated landscapes to promote biodiversity, the tools required, assessing outcomes, and the benefits and negatives of nature in the city. Prerequisite: One of FRST 201, NRES 201, BIOL 230. or permission of the instructor.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 201, NRES 201, BIOL 230. or permission of the instructor.

subject: UFOR
title: Developing Green and Resilient Cities - The Urban Forestry Approach
description: Online course on the importance of urban green space and urban trees for cities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UFOR
title: Urban Forest Governance
description: Governance theory and ways of applying a governance perspective to strategic decision-making in urban forestry. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UFOR
title: Ecology of Urban Green Infrastructure
description: The nature and dynamics of urban ecosystems with emphasis on urban forests and greenspaces. The role of green infrastructure in urban sustainability with particular focus on the ecological impact of urban forest management, design, and policy decisions. Credit may be granted for only one of UFOR 420 or UFOR 520. [3-0-1] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UFOR
title: Advances in Arboriculture and Urban Ecology
description: Overview of the field and current state-of-art of arboriculture, with emphasis on current research and good practices. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UFOR
title: Urban Forest Resources and Benefits Assessment
description: Overview of the state of the art assessment of urban forest resources and their benefits Prerequisite: UFOR 511. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: UFOR 511. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UFOR
title: Master of Urban Forestry Leadership Capstone Course
description: Application of urban forestry concepts and skills in a project-based learning experience. Prerequisite: FCOR 599. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: FCOR 599. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UKRN
title: Learning Ukrainian 1
description: Introduction to the language for beginners. Ability to identify unique features and communicate in everyday situations. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of UKRN_V 101 or UKRN_V 125.
exclusion_raw: Introduction to the language for beginners. Ability to identify unique features and communicate in everyday situations. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of UKRN_V 101 or UKRN_V 125.

subject: UKRN
title: Learning Ukrainian 2
description: Continuation of UKRN_V 101. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses Credit will be granted for only one of UKRN_V 102 or UKRN_V 125.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of UKRN_V 101. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses Credit will be granted for only one of UKRN_V 102 or UKRN_V 125.

subject: UKRN
title: Learning Ukrainian 3 and 4
description: Continuation of UKRN_V 102. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of UKRN_V 200 or UKRN_V 225. Equivalency: UKRN_V 225.
exclusion_raw: Continuation of UKRN_V 102. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of UKRN_V 200 or UKRN_V 225. Equivalency: UKRN_V 225.

title: Advanced Urology I
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: UROL

subject: URST
title: Cities
description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization. Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies. Credit will be granted for only one of URST_V 200 or GEOG_V 250. Equivalency: GEOG_V 250.
exclusion_raw: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization. Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies. Credit will be granted for only one of URST_V 200 or GEOG_V 250. Equivalency: GEOG_V 250.

subject: URST
title: Urbanization in the Global South
description: The role of cities in development and global capital circulation, and urban politics with emphasis on regions in Latin America, Africa, and Asia. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 352 or URST 352. Equivalency: GEOG 352
exclusion_raw: The role of cities in development and global capital circulation, and urban politics with emphasis on regions in Latin America, Africa, and Asia. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 352 or URST 352. Equivalency: GEOG 352

subject: URST
title: Seminar in Urban Studies
description: A seminar for senior students who wish to explore some common topics of importance to urban studies from the viewpoints of several disciplines. Restricted to students with fourth-year standing or higher.

subject: URST
title: Urban Research
description: Historical, legal, and quantitative analysis of urban research. Emphasis on spatial, racial, and political dynamics of urban inequality. Credit will be granted for only one of URST 450 or GEOG 450. Restricted to students with fourth-year standing or higher. Equivalency: GEOG 450
exclusion_raw: Historical, legal, and quantitative analysis of urban research. Emphasis on spatial, racial, and political dynamics of urban inequality. Credit will be granted for only one of URST 450 or GEOG 450. Restricted to students with fourth-year standing or higher. Equivalency: GEOG 450

subject: URST
title: Urban Studies Capstone I
description: Formulation of key elements of urban studies theory, concepts, and methods to a community-engaged urban challenge. Credit will be granted for only one of URST_V 451 or GEOG_V 451. Prerequisite: One of GEOG_V 250, URST_V 200 and all of PLAN_V 211, PLAN_V 231, GEOG_V 371. Equivalency: GEOG_V 451.
prerequisite_raw: One of GEOG_V 250, URST_V 200 and all of PLAN_V 211, PLAN_V 231, GEOG_V 371. Equivalency: GEOG_V 451.
exclusion_raw: Formulation of key elements of urban studies theory, concepts, and methods to a community-engaged urban challenge. Credit will be granted for only one of URST_V 451 or GEOG_V 451. Prerequisite: One of GEOG_V 250, URST_V 200 and all of PLAN_V 211, PLAN_V 231, GEOG_V 371. Equivalency: GEOG_V 451.

subject: URST
title: Urban Studies Capstone II
description: Application of key elements of urban studies theory, concepts, and methods to a community-engaged urban challenge. Restricted to students with fourth-year standing or higher. Credit will be granted for only one of URST_V 452 or PLAN_V 452. Prerequisite: GEOG_V 451. Equivalency: PLAN_V 452.
prerequisite_raw: GEOG_V 451. Equivalency: PLAN_V 452.
exclusion_raw: Application of key elements of urban studies theory, concepts, and methods to a community-engaged urban challenge. Restricted to students with fourth-year standing or higher. Credit will be granted for only one of URST_V 452 or PLAN_V 452. Prerequisite: GEOG_V 451. Equivalency: PLAN_V 452.

subject: URSY
title: Urban Systems and Society
description: Urban systems in society and economy; spatial issues; equity and social justice. Governance, policy, regulation. Globalization and international development; implications for urban systems. Urban and regional economics; infrastructure financing. Urban systems and technology; tradeoffs; socio-economic-technical systems; emerging and green technologies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: URSY
title: Urban Systems Analysis and Planning
description: Planning for engineers. Demand-side planning: population and demand modelling; demand management. Supply-side planning: long term planning, strategic planning. Data, metrics, indicators and assessment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: URSY
title: Urban Systems Engineering
description: Technical infrastructure systems that support communities: water; waste and storm water; solid waste; transportation; energy and data. Systems services and demands; technical alternatives; distribution systems; modelling, design, construction, operations and maintenance issues. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: URSY
title: Urban Systems Project Delivery and Economics
description: Stakeholder practices: stakeholder engagement, public consultation, partnerships, stakeholder management, buy-in. Project delivery: project delivery options, public-private partnerships (P3), integrated project delivery (IPD), partnering. Modelling, analytical methods, and decision support: economic and risk modelling. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: URSY
title: Infrastructure Asset Management
description: General frameworks for infrastructure management, system-specific asset management (road conditions, pipe inspection), maintenance and renewal. Data, metrics, indicators and assessment: data sources, performance indicators, assessment, assessing condition and sustainability, multi-objective, multi-criteria decision making, performance prediction, lifecycle cost analysis (LCA), sustainability. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VANT
title: UBC Vantage College Projects
description: Projects linked to topics explored in the UBC Vantage College International Program curricula. [1-0-1; 1-0-1]

subject: VANT
title: Multi-disciplinary Research Project
description: Research project that culminates in student-led conference and research presentation. [1-0-1] Prerequisite: VANT 148.
prerequisite_raw: VANT 148.

subject: VANT
title: Sustainability and Engineering Design
description: Topics in sustainability, including the impact of technology on the environment and society, and fundamentals of engineering design. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream. [1-0-2; 1-0-2]

subject: VANT
title: Multi-disciplinary Engineering Design Project
description: Design project that culminates in student-led project fair. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: VANT 150.
prerequisite_raw: VANT 150.

subject: VISA
title: BFA Studio Practice
description: Introduction to a broad range of contemporary studio practice. Intended for first year Bachelor of Fine Arts VISA students.

subject: VISA
title: Foundation Studio: Digital Media
description: Foundation instruction in techniques and approaches to digital practice. The nature of digital technologies and their role in contemporary culture will be examined. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

subject: VISA
title: Foundation Studio: Approaches to Media
description: Drawing, painting, and related media in an introduction to studio practice. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

subject: VISA
title: Foundation Studio: Ideas as Practice I
description: Contemporary art practices, emphasizing the relationship between meanings and materials, art historical contexts and concepts, and non-traditional materials. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

subject: VISA
title: Digital Arts
description: Examination of current art practices and issues related to digital technologies and contemporary culture, with an emphasis on the theoretical conceptualization of digital artistic media. Prerequisite: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183; or BMS student and VISA 110.
prerequisite_raw: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183; or BMS student and VISA 110.

subject: VISA
title: Drawing
description: Development of skills in drawing including life drawing. Introduction to the development of personal style and concepts. Prerequisite: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.
prerequisite_raw: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

subject: VISA
title: Painting
description: Development of a variety of techniques and approaches to painting. Emphasis on developing a strong paint vocabulary as well as acquiring knowledge of historical and contemporary issues in painting. Prerequisite: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.
prerequisite_raw: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

subject: VISA
title: Photography
description: Introduction to photography techniques and image-making. Emphasis on camera techniques and film and darkroom production. Only one of VISA 240 or VISA 241 may be used toward requirements for Major, Minor, or Honours programs in Visual Arts. Prerequisite: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.
prerequisite_raw: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

subject: VISA
title: Digital Photography
description: Introduction to digital photography image creation in relation to contemporary art. Emphasis on digital camera use, file management, and digital print production. Only one of VISA 240 or VISA 241 may be used toward requirements for Major, Minor, or Honours programs in Visual Arts. Prerequisite: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183; or BMS student and VISA 110.
prerequisite_raw: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183; or BMS student and VISA 110.

subject: VISA
title: Print Media
description: Visual print culture, and contemporary and historical technical print practices. Emphasis on hand-drawn intaglio, relief, screen and/or stencil printing, and graphic digital applications. Prerequisite: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.
prerequisite_raw: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

subject: VISA
title: Sculpture
description: Contemporary sculpture practice and theory. Various sculpture materials and technologies including machinery use. Prerequisite: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.
prerequisite_raw: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

subject: VISA
title: Special Studies
description: Introduction to various aspects of contemporary studio practice. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.
prerequisite_raw: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

subject: VISA
title: Contemporary Art: Ideas as Practice II
description: Development and history of contemporary art practice, with a focus on how artists realize and exchange ideas. Intended for second year BFA VISA students. Prerequisite: A score of 72% or higher in VISA 183.
prerequisite_raw: A score of 72% or higher in VISA 183.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Digital Arts I
description: Exploring issues and topics in interactive digital media and culture through the creation of critical contemporary art. Includes technical instruction with a focus on the development of individual and group projects. Prerequisite: One of VISA 210, VISA 287, FINA 287.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 210, VISA 287, FINA 287.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Digital Arts II
description: Investigation of issues and topics in digital media and visual culture through the production of contemporary video art. Technical instruction in video manipulation software. Individual and/or group projects. Prerequisite: One of VISA 240, VISA 241.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 240, VISA 241.

subject: VISA
title: Expanded Visual Media
description: Pre- and/or post-production strategies, techniques, and processes for time-based media effects. Credit will only be granted for one of THFL 312 or VISA 312. Prerequisite: One of VISA 241, VISA 210, FIPR 133, FIPR 233. Or B.M.S. students with 3rd year standing. Equivalency: THFL 312.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 241, VISA 210, FIPR 133, FIPR 233. Or B.M.S. students with 3rd year standing. Equivalency: THFL 312.
exclusion_raw: Pre- and/or post-production strategies, techniques, and processes for time-based media effects. Credit will only be granted for one of THFL 312 or VISA 312. Prerequisite: One of VISA 241, VISA 210, FIPR 133, FIPR 233. Or B.M.S. students with 3rd year standing. Equivalency: THFL 312.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Drawing I
description: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art. Emphasis on expanding definitions of the drawing practice while focusing on technical and conceptual development. Prerequisite: One of VISA 220, VISA 281, FINA 281.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 220, VISA 281, FINA 281.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Drawing II
description: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art and theory. Emphasis on self-directed projects in consultation with the instructor. Prerequisite: One of VISA 220, VISA 281, FINA 281.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 220, VISA 281, FINA 281.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Painting I
description: Development of techniques and personal style in relation to ideas. History and contemporary issues in painting will be introduced to assist students in conceptualizing their painting practice. Prerequisite: One of VISA 230, VISA 282, FINA 282.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 230, VISA 282, FINA 282.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Painting II
description: Further investigation of painting in the context of contemporary art. Emphasis on self directed projects in consultation with the instructor. Prerequisite: One of VISA 230, VISA 282, FINA 282.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 230, VISA 282, FINA 282.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Photography I
description: An investigation of approaches to photography and its meaning in the context of contemporary art. The term theme will be determined by the instructor. B & W, colour and digital production. Prerequisite: One of VISA 240, VISA 241.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 240, VISA 241.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Photography II
description: An investigation of contemporary photography production and approaches to the constructed image with emphasis on medium and large format camera use and studio lighting techniques. Prerequisite: One of VISA 240, VISA 241.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 240, VISA 241.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Print Media I: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
description: Intaglio and relief print applications (i.e., etching, wood and/or lino cut, and collagraph) in combination with digital and photographic technologies, and drawing; discussion of contemporary and historical visual print culture. Prerequisite: Either (a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 290, VISA 283, VISA 284, FINA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 290, VISA 283, VISA 284, FINA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Print Media II: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
description: Screen printing and other print applications in combination with digital and photographic technologies, and drawing, explored within the context of contemporary art. Prerequisite: Either(a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.
prerequisite_raw: Either(a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Print Media III: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
description: Lithographic printing; suitable for students interested in drawing and print media interface in context of contemporary art; related digital and photographic technologies employed. Prerequisite: Either (a) one of VISA 220, VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 281, FINA 281, VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.
prerequisite_raw: Either (a) one of VISA 220, VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 281, FINA 281, VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Sculpture I
description: Investigation of contemporary practices in sculpture and the use of scale. Emphasis on public sculpture. Prerequisite: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.

subject: VISA
title: Intermediate Sculpture II
description: Development of personal concerns in three-dimensional work. Emphasis on the integration of diverse materials and techniques. Prerequisite: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.

subject: VISA
title: Artists in Society
description: Exploring artistic practice through community-engaged partnerships and critical study. Prerequisite: Restricted to students with at least third-year standing, majoring in Visual Art or Art History. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Restricted to students with at least third-year standing, majoring in Visual Art or Art History. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Artist Books as Form and Idea
description: Approaches to book creation from the perspective of contemporary art and exploration of the artist book as an expansion of both art and books. Prerequisite: 3 credits of any 200-level VISA course.
prerequisite_raw: 3 credits of any 200-level VISA course.

subject: VISA
title: Studio Theory
description: A seminar in problems in contemporary art practice and related theory. Preference given to Visual Art students. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Studio Seminar
description: A seminar in problems in contemporary art practice and related theory. Preference given to Visual Art students. Prerequisite: VISA 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: VISA 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Performance Art
description: Seminar-based studio focusing on performance and actions in the field of contemporary art. Prerequisite: 6 credits of 200-level VISA with an average of at least 72%.
prerequisite_raw: 6 credits of 200-level VISA with an average of at least 72%.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Digital Arts I
description: Development of contemporary art works utilizing digital technologies including 3-dimensional applications, spatial, interactive and time-based installations. Focus on student-generated projects, either individual or group. Prerequisite: One of VISA 310, VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 310, VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Digital Arts II: Video
description: Contemporary practices in video media examined through individual projects and directed study. Prerequisite: One of VISA 310, VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 310, VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Drawing and Painting I
description: Interdisciplinary studio practice with emphasis on drawing, painting, and related media. Prerequisite: Two of VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Two of VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Drawing and Painting II
description: Interdisciplinary studio practice with emphasis on drawing, painting, and related media. Prerequisite: Two of VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Two of VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Photography I
description: Photography practice in the context of contemporary art. Interdisciplinary connections to other media will be encouraged. Prerequisite: Two of VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Two of VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Photography II
description: The production of self-directed projects investigating photography as art. Focus on integrative approaches including conventional, digital and multi-media. Prerequisite: Two of VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 440. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Two of VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 440. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Print Media and Sculpture I
description: Studies in contemporary trends in studio practice and theory. Emphasis on advanced two and three-dimensional work developed out of experimental approaches to sculpture, installation art and print-based media. Prerequisite: One of VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Print Media and Sculpture II
description: Further studies in advanced two and three-dimensional work developed out of experimental approaches to sculpture, installation art and print-based media. Prerequisite: One of VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Exhibition Theory and Practice
description: Exhibition course focusing on current curatorial practices and theories with an emphasis on contemporary visual art with the aim of preparing students to engage in the active organization of a large exhibition. Restricted to 4th year Majors in either VISA or ARTH, or permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Performance Actions and Approaches
description: Advanced performance art practices and research methodologies. Credit will be granted for only one of VISA 479 or ARTH 479. Equivalency: ARTH479 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Advanced performance art practices and research methodologies. Credit will be granted for only one of VISA 479 or ARTH 479. Equivalency: ARTH479 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Seminar I
description: Readings in art theory and criticism. Prerequisite: VISA 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: VISA 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Seminar II
description: Readings in art theory and criticism. Prerequisite: VISA 480. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: VISA 480. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Tutorial in Studio I
description: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Permission of instructor required. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: 6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: 6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Advanced Tutorial in Studio II
description: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Permission of instructor required. Prerequisite: 6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: 6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: Major Essay
description: M.F.A. only. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: MFA Studio V
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VISA
title: MFA Studio VI
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VRHC
title: Issues in Vocational Rehabilitation Counselling
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VRHC
title: Medical Aspects of Disability
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VRHC
title: Vocational Implications of Disability
description: Corequisite: [VRHC502] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
corequisite_raw: [VRHC502] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VRHC
title: Job Development and Placement
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VRHC
title: Rehabilitation Literature and Applications to Practice
description: Recommended pre-requisite: EPSE 481. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VRHC
title: Internship
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VRHC
title: Vocational Evaluation Internship
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VRHC
title: Case and Disability Management
description: Prerequisite: All of VRHC 501, VRHC 502. At least 3 credits of VRHC 502 is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of VRHC 501, VRHC 502. At least 3 credits of VRHC 502 is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VRHC
title: Psychosocial and Vocational Aspects of Disability
description: Prerequisite: All of VRHC 501, VRHC 502, VRHC 511. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of VRHC 501, VRHC 502, VRHC 511. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VRHC
title: Case Management and Job Development Counselling
description: Integration of theoretical constructs and research evidence to develop the competencies required for the case management/coordination of a continuum of vocational/rehabilitation counselling services, including job development, placement strategies and interventions. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: VRHC
title: Major Paper
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Women+ and Children's Health
description: Biomedical, clinical, translational, and population research; research approaches and opportunities across the four health research pillars (biomedical, clinical, health services, population health). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Seminars in Women+ and Children's Health
description: Biological and social determinants of health, health equity and inclusion. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Perinatal Epidemiology
description: Indicators of maternal/newborn well-being across population subgroups, changing trends in obstetrical intervention, perinatal morbidity, and the analysis of perinatal data. Equivalency: SPPH537, OBST507 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Critical Appraisal of Research in Reproductive and Children's Health Sciences
description: Principles of critical thinking and appraisal of medical literature with respect to study design and causal inference. Credit will be granted for only one of OBST 509 or WACH 504. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Principles of critical thinking and appraisal of medical literature with respect to study design and causal inference. Credit will be granted for only one of OBST 509 or WACH 504. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Fundamentals of Magnetic Resonance Imaging
description: Physics behind MRI and basic principles. Image weighting/contrast, special encoding and image formation, pulse sequences, and hardware. Advanced techniques (functional, diffusion, quantitative, phase- based, spectroscopy) and their applications in women+ and children's health. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Knowledge Translation and Implementation Sciences
description: Strategies to promote uptake of innovations and evidence in healthcare from bench to bedside to populations. Credit will be granted for only one of OBST 581 or WACH 506. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Strategies to promote uptake of innovations and evidence in healthcare from bench to bedside to populations. Credit will be granted for only one of OBST 581 or WACH 506. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Women+ Health Research
description: Sexual development, transgender medicine, reproduction and pregnancy, chronic and acute diseases, and social determinants of health. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Women's Mental Health Across Their Lifecycle
description: Multidisciplinary approach; interactions with reproductive health and concepts in women's mental health research. Credit will be granted for only one of OBST 511 or WACH 512. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Multidisciplinary approach; interactions with reproductive health and concepts in women's mental health research. Credit will be granted for only one of OBST 511 or WACH 512. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Gynecologic Pathologies: Benign and Malignant
description: Focus on genomics and pathophysiology. Credit will be granted for only one of OBST 510 or WACH 513. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Focus on genomics and pathophysiology. Credit will be granted for only one of OBST 510 or WACH 513. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Overview of Gynecologic Oncology
description: Molecular biology, epidemiology, prevention, and treatment of gynecologic cancers, including uterine cancer, vulvar/vaginal cancer, cervical cancer, ovarian cancer, and how to incorporate the patient experience into research. Credit will be granted for only one of OBST 512 or WACH 514. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
exclusion_raw: Molecular biology, epidemiology, prevention, and treatment of gynecologic cancers, including uterine cancer, vulvar/vaginal cancer, cervical cancer, ovarian cancer, and how to incorporate the patient experience into research. Credit will be granted for only one of OBST 512 or WACH 514. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Child Health Research
description: Biology of human development, child growth and puberty, adolescent health, childhood chronic and acute diseases, gender diversity in pediatrics, social environment and child health, and pediatric research in partnership with Indigenous communities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Pediatric Nutrition
description: Dietary assessment and nutrient requirements in children and youth, assessment of growth and adiposity, application of nutritional biochemistry and animal models, energy balance, macronutrient and micronutrient metabolism and research, restricted diets in children, nutritional interventions in children. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Reproductive Endocrinology
description: Neuroendocrine regulation of reproduction, regulation of the ovarian and testicular function. Equivalency: OBST501 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Physiology of the Mother, Fetus and Newborn
description: Functional development of the placenta and major organ systems in the fetal and newborn period in man and animals. Equivalency: OBST502 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Fetal and Perinatal Metabolism
description: Nutrient metabolism and requirements during fetal and perinatal development and research methods used to assess requirements; developmental origins of health and disease; gestational obesity and diabetes; nutritional supplements during pregnancy. Equivalency: OBST503 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: M.Sc. Thesis
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WACH
title: Ph.D. Thesis
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Introduction to Wood Products and Global Trade
description: Introduction to forestry, wood products industry, processes, products, markets and global trade policy issues affecting the wood industry. Students may only receive credit for one of: WOOD 120, WOOD 220. Not available for credit to students in the Forest Science Major of the B.Sc. Natural Resources degree.

subject: WOOD
title: Communications Strategies
description: Strategies for thinking critically and writing effectively about topics that engage practitioners in Forestry, particularly in Wood Products Processing. Planning, drafting and editing of professional-quality documents for specialists and other stakeholders. Developing oral presentation skills. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 150, NRES 150, LFS 150, WRDS 150. or ENGL 1st or WRCM 1st. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 150, NRES 150, LFS 150, WRDS 150. or ENGL 1st or WRCM 1st. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Quantitative Methods in the Wood Industry
description: Solving practical problems in the wood industry using computer-based mathematical tools including spreadsheets, visual basic programming and relational database systems. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 121.
prerequisite_raw: One of MATH 101, MATH 121.

subject: WOOD
title: Programming for Wood Products Manufacturing Applications
description: Practical computer and problem solving cases taken from wood products manufacturing industrial applications. [2-4-0] Prerequisite: WOOD 244.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 244.

subject: WOOD
title: Contemporary Topics in Forestry and Wood Products
description: Seminars on current forestry and wood products topics. [1-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Products Chemistry I
description: Chemistry relating to wood and wood products: chemistry of lignin, cellulose, hemicelluloses, extractives, and biological degradation of lignocellulosics; wood pressure impregnation procedures. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: WOOD_V 280 and one of CHEM_V 113, CHEM_V 123.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD_V 280 and one of CHEM_V 113, CHEM_V 123.

subject: WOOD
title: Mechanics of Wood Products
description: Introduction to the strength of materials with emphasis on the elastic properties and ultimate strength of wood and wood products. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 101, MATH 121.
prerequisite_raw: One of PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 101, MATH 121.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Anatomy and Identification
description: Introduction to tree growth; macroscopic and microscopic anatomy and identification of softwoods and hardwoods; descriptions of cell wall ultra-structure, wood variability and wood quality. [3-2-0]

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Physics and Mechanics
description: Wood-moisture relationships, transport phenomena, acoustical and electrical properties of wood. Effects of wood attributes at macro- and micro-levels on the strength properties of solid wood. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: [WOOD280]
prerequisite_raw: [WOOD280]

subject: WOOD
title: Secondary Wood Products Manufacturing
description: Basic secondary wood products manufacturing. Focus on producing and joining lumber, edging, drilling, veneers and CNC equipment. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: [WOOD120]
prerequisite_raw: [WOOD120]

subject: WOOD
title: Two-Dimensional and Solid Computer-Aided Graphics
description: Computer-aided graphics software used in the wood products sector. Visualization of product designs and specifications in two and three dimensions. [0-4] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing who have completed the co-op orientation workshops. Prerequisite: WOOD 305. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 305. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Machining Skills
description: Safe working procedures for wood processing machinery, explanation of various manufacturing equipment, product documentation, product development and manufacturing processes. Prerequisite: WOOD290
prerequisite_raw: WOOD290

subject: WOOD
title: Co-operative Work Placement
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing. Prerequisite: Permission of the Co-op Coordinator. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Permission of the Co-op Coordinator. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing. Prerequisite: WOOD 300. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 300. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing. Prerequisite: WOOD 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Industrial Engineering
description: Use of industrial engineering concepts and methods to analyze and improve organizations, including operations strategy and competitiveness, quality control, work measurement, inventory management, linear programming, sensitivity analysis, transportation problems, and capacity planning. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: One of ECON 101, FRST 101 and one of FRST 231, NRES 231.
prerequisite_raw: One of ECON 101, FRST 101 and one of FRST 231, NRES 231.

subject: WOOD
title: Quality Improvement
description: Modern techniques for improving quality in the workplace with particular emphasis on the forest products industry. Topics include quality control management, control charting, continuous improvement and analysis of variance techniques. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 231, NRES 231.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 231, NRES 231.

subject: WOOD
title: Mill Site Visits
description: One week of on-site study of forest products manufacturing plants immediately following Spring examinations of second or third year. Representative sawmills, plywood mills, remanufacturing plants, particleboard manufacturers, pulp mills, laminated timber plants and wood preservation facilities in the Interior are studied. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Machine Components
description: Machines used for wood products manufacturing, design, maintenance, purchasing. Selection of components including drives, bearings, brakes, clutches, fasteners, springs. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: WOOD 276. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 276. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Industry Business Management
description: Business management concepts common in the forest products industry including marketing, customer research, product development and design. [3-0-2]

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Adhesives and Coatings
description: Introduction to structure and properties of polymers and wood finishes; chemistry of adhesives and preservatives. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123.
prerequisite_raw: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Sawmilling and Drying
description: Introduction to primary log breakdown systems and lumber material flow in modern sawmills and planermills. Lumber drying equipment and methods. [3-2] Prerequisite: WOOD 282.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 282.

subject: WOOD
title: Applied Mechanics of Materials
description: Beam analysis, shaft analysis, columns, stress/strain transformations, thin-walled pressure vessels, material strength failure, criteria, fatigue, design and sizing, ISO standards. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: WOOD 276.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 276.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Products Performance and Building Applications
description: Introduction of mechanical properties of solid sawn lumber/timber and engineered wood products, common connection technologies using mechanical fasteners and adhesives, and typical applications to wood buildings. Prerequisites: WOOD_V 386

subject: WOOD
title: Fire Safety for Timber Buildings
description: Fire safety context, origin and application for wood in the built environment. Fire science principles from ignition to compartment fires. Application of fire resistance and fire protection. Implicit and explicit fire safety solutions. Prerequisites: Third-year standing

subject: WOOD
title: Sustainable Timber-Built Technologies
description: Critical technologies and standards used to construct sustainable and contemporary timber products and buildings, including: Sustainable timber products and systems, Low-carbon timber products and buildings and building LCA, 3D design for timber products and buildings, and digital technologies for timber-built sustainability. Prerequisites: Third-year standing

subject: WOOD
title: Co-operative Work Placement
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks fulltime. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing. Prerequisite: Permission of the Co-op Coordinator. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Permission of the Co-op Coordinator. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Cooperative Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing. Prerequisite: WOOD 312. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 312. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Co-operative Work Placement V
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing. Prerequisite: WOOD 411. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 411. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Plant Layout and Design
description: Techniques for developing a plan, setting goals, and evaluating the impact of changes in the design, layout and operation of the factory with an emphasis on computer simulation. Prerequisite: All of WOOD_V 290, WOOD_V 330, WOOD_V 485.
prerequisite_raw: All of WOOD_V 290, WOOD_V 330, WOOD_V 485.

subject: WOOD
title: Engineering Economics
description: Use of engineering economics to evaluate investment proposals of an engineering nature, including decision making processes, time value of money, cash flow analysis, comparison methods, depreciation, replacement analysis, taxes, inflation and sensitivity analysis. [3-1] Prerequisite: [WOOD330]
prerequisite_raw: [WOOD330]

subject: WOOD
title: Globalization and Sustainability
description: Examination of globalization and its impact on sustainability, including social, economic, and environmental aspects. [3-1] Prerequisite: At least third-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: At least third-year standing.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Finishing and Protection
description: Introduction to polymeric coatings and finishes used in the wood products industry; surface preparation, application equipment and properties of various coatings; wood deterioration and its protection for external applications. [1-3-2] Prerequisite: All of WOOD 282, WOOD 373.
prerequisite_raw: All of WOOD 282, WOOD 373.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Properties, Identification and Uses
description: Elementary chemical, physical and mechanical properties of wood and their variations in relation to structure; identification by hand lens features; manufacture of lumber, pulp and composite wood products. Not available for credit to Wood Products Processing students. [3-2]

subject: WOOD
title: Design of Timber Structures
description: Design of timber structural elements using limit states design principles; joints and fasteners, sawn lumber and engineered wood products, light frame systems and shear walls. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of WOOD 276, CIVL 230. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: One of WOOD 276, CIVL 230. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Building Science
description: Building enclosure design considering heat and moisture transmission, air flow and ventilation, condensation, acoustics; roofing systems; diagnostic evaluations; fire protection. [3-0-0] Equivalency: CIVL478

subject: WOOD
title: CAD/CAM
description: Introduction to computer assisted design and manufacturing with a focus on the fundamental issues of geometry and machine tools including an understanding of standard computer tools. Applications to secondary wood products manufacturing. [3-4-0] Prerequisite: All of WOOD 290, WOOD 292. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of WOOD 290, WOOD 292. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Furniture Construction
description: The theory and practice of modern construction techniques used in the manufacture of furniture and cabinets. [3-1] Prerequisite: All of WOOD 292, WOOD 305.
prerequisite_raw: All of WOOD 292, WOOD 305.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Composites
description: Physical, chemical and mechanical variables involved in adhesive bonding of composite wood products; characteristics of adhesives; plywood, composite wood panels, hardboard, medium density fibreboard, laminated wood and engineered lumber composites manufacturing processes; important physical and chemical properties of products. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: WOOD 373.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 373.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Products Design and Development I
description: Introduction to wood products design, from the product idea to the production-ready design. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: All of WOOD 305, WOOD 482, WOOD 485. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of WOOD 305, WOOD 482, WOOD 485. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Products Design and Development II
description: Design and fabrication of wood products. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: WOOD 488. and a portfolio demonstrating competence in the operation of woodworking machinery. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 488. and a portfolio demonstrating competence in the operation of woodworking machinery. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Environmental Facilities Design
description: Introduction to pneumatic and hydraulic power, design and selection of waste recycling systems, boilers, energy generation and environmental legislation. [3-2] Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing.
prerequisite_raw: Fourth-year standing.

subject: WOOD
title: Modelling for Decision Support
description: Applications of mathematical modelling, optimization, and simulation in forest planning and manufacturing; formulating models and interpreting results for decision support. [3-3] Prerequisite: One of FRST 232, NRES 232, WOOD 245.
prerequisite_raw: One of FRST 232, NRES 232, WOOD 245.

subject: WOOD
title: Project in Program Major
description: A report (approved by a faculty supervisor and the Program Director) based on either a technical description of a study, an extension of the senior co-op report, a detailed literature review, a research-based project, or a guided independent study developed by the student. Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing
prerequisite_raw: Fourth-year standing

subject: WOOD
title: Principles of Wood Cutting and Tooling
description: Wood cutting fundamentals, chip formation, cutting conditions, cutting edge maintenance, sawing, planing and molding, veneer cutting, chipping, turning. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: WOOD 356.
prerequisite_raw: WOOD 356.

subject: WOOD
title: Net-Zero Carbon Solutions for Timber Products
description: Cutting-edge knowledge to develop emerging sustainable timber products and systems towards net-zero carbon. Strategies and solutions adapted to promote net-zero carbon emissions throughout timber product life cycle from harvesting, manufacturing, design, use and disposal. Prerequisites: Fourth-year standing.

subject: WOOD
title: Wood Products Capstone
description: Development of a wood products manufacturing start-up company. Development of comprehensive business plan, marketing strategy, product design, equipment selection and justification, manufacturing plant layout, and economic analyses. [4-2-3] Prerequisite: All of WOOD 365, WOOD 440. and fourth-year standing in Wood Products Processing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: All of WOOD 365, WOOD 440. and fourth-year standing in Wood Products Processing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Globalization and the Marketing of Wood Products
description: Globalization's impact on developing and developed countries and what this means to world trade in forest products. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Advanced Wood Physics
description: Thermo-physical and mechano-sorptive properties of wood and their effect on service performance. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WOOD
title: Advanced Wood Mechanics
description: Analysis and design of structural wood products. Effect of material structure and variability on performance of wood products. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WRDS
title: Writing and Research in the Disciplines
description: Writing and reading in disciplines across the academy, focusing on practices that research disciplines share and those that differentiate them. Restricted to students not in the Faculty of Arts. Credit can be granted for only one of WRDS_V 150 or WRDS_V 151. Equivalency: WRDS_V 151. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WRDS
title: Writing and Research in the Disciplines
description: Writing and reading in disciplines across the academy, focusing on practices that research disciplines share and those that differentiate them. Restricted to students in the Faculty of Arts. Credit can be granted for only one of WRDS_V 150 or WRDS_V 151. Equivalency: WRDS_V 150. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WRDS
title: Writing and Communication Foundations
description: Key principles of writing and communication and issues currently debated in the field of Writing Studies. The role of writing and communication in making knowledge, constructing identity, and exercising power. Restricted to students with second year standing or above.

subject: WRDS
title: Evaluating Knowledge Production and Mobilization
description: Critical and practical questions about how discourse communities construct and mobilize knowledge. The evaluation of knowledge as information/misinformation. How the evaluation of information is shaped by discursive contexts, rhetorical goals, and communication forms. Prerequisite: One of ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100, WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350.
prerequisite_raw: One of ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100, WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350.

subject: WRDS
title: Multimodal Writing
description: Creation of multimodal texts, including audio, visual, and alphabetical modes, for different audiences, purposes, and contexts. Examines the impact of digital technologies on writers’ considerations of purpose, audience, design, accessibility and ethics. Restricted to students with at least third year standing. Prerequisite: 3 credits from one of WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350, ENGL_V 100, SCIE_V 113, SCIE_V 300, CHEM_V 300, APSC_V 176, LFS_V 150, FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150, COMM_V 196, Arts One, ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100.
prerequisite_raw: 3 credits from one of WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350, ENGL_V 100, SCIE_V 113, SCIE_V 300, CHEM_V 300, APSC_V 176, LFS_V 150, FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150, COMM_V 196, Arts One, ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100.

subject: WRDS
title: Knowledge-Making in the Disciplines
description: An advanced scholarly research and writing course that allows students to build on their existing knowledge of academic research and writing practices by studying specific features of scholarly writing relevant to their own interests and disciplines. Prerequisite: Restricted to students with at least 3rd-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
prerequisite_raw: Restricted to students with at least 3rd-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WRDS
title: Knowledge Popularization: Research Writing in New Media
description: Rhetorical purposes, moves and features of new media genres that use or transform research for public audiences. Provides opportunities for students to analyze, critically assess, and produce these genres themselves. Restricted to students with third year standing or above. Prerequisites: 3 credits from one of Arts One, ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100, WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350, ENGL_V 100, SCIE_V 113, SCIE_V 300, CHEM_V 300, APSC_V 176, LFS_V 150, FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150, COMM_V 196.

subject: WRDS
title: Research Writing and Marginalization
description: Examines how marginalized groups are positioned in research writing. Focuses on the role of power, knowledge, and ethics in shaping language features and textual structures of research writing. Prerequisite: Third year standing and 3 credits from one of WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350, ENGL_V 100, SCIE_V 113, SCIE_V 300, CHEM_V 300, APSC_V 176, LFS_V 150, FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150, COMM_V 196, Arts One, ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100.
prerequisite_raw: Third year standing and 3 credits from one of WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350, ENGL_V 100, SCIE_V 113, SCIE_V 300, CHEM_V 300, APSC_V 176, LFS_V 150, FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150, COMM_V 196, Arts One, ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100.

subject: WRDS
title: Research Writing and Community Engagement
description: Examines models of communication, engagement, and knowledge sharing between university researchers and other communities. Applies scholarly research to community-engaged work that incorporates ethical communication and reflection. Restricted to students with third year standing or above. Prerequisite: 3 credits from one of WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350, ENGL_V 100, SCIE_V 113, SCIE_V 300, CHEM_V 300, APSC_V 176, LFS_V 150, FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150, COMM_V 196, Arts One, ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100.
prerequisite_raw: 3 credits from one of WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350, ENGL_V 100, SCIE_V 113, SCIE_V 300, CHEM_V 300, APSC_V 176, LFS_V 150, FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150, COMM_V 196, Arts One, ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100.

subject: WRDS
title: Writing Disability
description: Explores Disability theories, to understand their connections to writing and discourse studies. Prerequisite: Third year standing and 3 credits from one of WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350, ENGL_V 100, SCIE_V 113, SCIE_V 300, CHEM_V 300, APSC_V 176, LFS_V 150, FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150, COMM_V 196, Arts One, ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100 .
prerequisite_raw: Third year standing and 3 credits from one of WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350, ENGL_V 100, SCIE_V 113, SCIE_V 300, CHEM_V 300, APSC_V 176, LFS_V 150, FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150, COMM_V 196, Arts One, ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100 .

subject: WRDS
title: Writing and Communication Capstone
description: Critical assessment of approaches to writing and communication. Key principles of the field applied to public and professional domains relevant to students' future work, studies, service, or work. Restricted to students enrolled in the Minor in Writing and Communication. Prerequisite: WRDS_V 200. and 6 credits of WRDS_V courses at the 300-or 400-level
prerequisite_raw: WRDS_V 200. and 6 credits of WRDS_V courses at the 300-or 400-level

subject: WRDS
title: Writing Practices for Publics & Publications
description: Writing processes and strategies conducive to developing larger, long-term research projects into genres of writing intended to publicly engage with scholars, activists, and intellectuals. Restricted to students with third year standing or above. Prerequisite: 3 credits from one of WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350, ENGL_V 100, SCIE_V 113, SCIE_V 300, CHEM_V 300, APSC_V 176, LFS_V 150, FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150, COMM_V 196, Arts One, ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100.
prerequisite_raw: 3 credits from one of WRDS_V 150, WRDS_V 151, WRDS_V 350, ENGL_V 100, SCIE_V 113, SCIE_V 300, CHEM_V 300, APSC_V 176, LFS_V 150, FRST_V 150, NRES_V 150, COMM_V 196, Arts One, ASTU_V 100, ASTU_V 101, CAP_V 100.

subject: WRIT
title: Preparation for University Writing and the LPI
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: WRIT
title: Advanced Composition
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

subject: YDSH
title: Learning Yiddish: Foundations I
description: Introduction to Yiddish language and culture. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/

subject: YDSH
title: Learning Yiddish: Foundations II
description: Continuation of YDSH 101. Yiddish language and culture. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/

prerequisite_raw: [ZOOL502] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
